HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW;
Bombing Ends as Serbs Begin Pullout

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, June 10

 BODY:
NATO suspended its bombing of Yugoslavia today after Serbian troops began withdrawing from Kosovo, halting an assault that rained 23,000 bombs and missiles on Serbia without losing the life of a single NATO fighter.
The halt in the bombing after 78 days set the stage for the United Nations Security Council's swift approval of a resolution that permits 50,000 international peacekeepers to move in to help more than a million Albanian refugees driven out of Kosovo to try to return. 
 NATO's Secretary General, Javier Solana, announced the suspension of the bombing in midafternoon European time, morning in the United States.
"I would urge all parties to the conflict to seize this opportunity for peace," he said, adding that the moment was a result of allied determination and intense diplomacy by many countries, including Russia.
Allied leaders on both sides of the Atlantic were restrained in claiming victory in NATO's first war, a fight that took a toll not only on the Serbs and Kosovars, but also at times on the allies themselves. The war challenged the alliance, leaving it transformed and helping to determine its course in the coming century.
"We have to finish the job and build the peace," President Clinton said today, while Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said, "I feel no sense of triumph now, only the knowledge that our cause was just and rightly upheld."
President Jacques Chirac of France said, "A page has been turned in the conflict."
With their approval and that of other allied leaders, Mr. Solana halted the bombing after Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, confirmed that the withdrawal of 40,000 Serbian soldiers, police officers and paramilitary units had begun at midday.
Several hundred Yugoslav Army military trucks bearing soldiers clogged the road north from Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, today, more than 12 hours after Yugoslav military commanders agreed to allied terms with the commander of the peacekeeping force in Macedonia on Wednesday night. Allied commanders swore vigilance to make sure the Serbian forces lived up to the agreement.
President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, in his first address to his people regarding the conflict with NATO, did not claim victory for the Government today, but instead thanked ordinary citizens for their contributions and sacrifices. In the televised address, he said, "The aggression is over, happy peace to us all."
The first deployment of NATO peacekeeping troops had been scheduled for Friday. But it will probably be delayed until Saturday because Serbian forces have encountered difficulties in carrying out their withdrawal, Western officials said.
"The Serbs are having trouble getting their equipment out," a senior Western official said. "Their equipment is broken and out of fuel" and they need more time to clear the road of mines. The official said the Serbs were wary of moving at night because they fear the Kosovo Liberation Army.
Once bombs were no longer falling -- a condition Russia, China and France had set for a Security Council vote -- the Council reconvened in New York City today and quickly approved a resolution that had been worked out earlier this week in Cologne by the European allies, the United States, Russia, Canada and Japan.
The vote this morning, 14 to 0 with one abstention, China's, put Kosovo under international civilian control and placed the peacekeeping force under United Nations authority.
Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael Jackson of Britain, the force commander, was set to start leading the 18,500 European and American soldiers in Macedonia into Kosovo. NATO ambassadors met again tonight and approved an operation order clearing the way for the move, which is expected eventually to involve a total of around 50,000 troops, mostly Europeans from allied and other countries, with about 7,000 Americans.
Russian troops, expected to number about 2,500, could also join if Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and American military negotiators who met Russian officers in Moscow today can work out command arrangements for them. Russia was vehemently opposed to the NATO bombing and says it will not put its troops under the alliance's orders.
Allied warplanes flew their last 82 strike missions Wednesday, the allied command said, but will continue flying reconnaissance missions to monitor the Serbian withdrawal, which is to be completed within 11 days.
"Violence or noncompliance by any party will not be tolerated," Mr. Solana warned. But he said that the alliance and other international organizations would now try to help all the ethnic groups of Kosovo, including the Serbs, to build a society free of the repression that had spawned the conflict in the first place.
The bombing campaign sorely tested and profoundly changed the 50-year-old alliance, which never fired a shot in anger during the cold war.
It surmounted objections to the use of force to make peace in Kosovo, but at the price of a strategy that retired generals from San Diego to Vladivostok said would never succeed, using air power alone to try to prevent and then reverse the expulsion of the ethnic Albanian majority living in hallowed Serbian territory in Kosovo.
In the end it was diplomacy, by Western powers and by Russia, that tipped the balance, convincing President Milosevic that he had no choice but to accede to international demands and make peace in Kosovo. Now the alliance has taken on the challenge of keeping the peace, a challenge that may prove even more difficult than waging the air war.
Preserving unity among 19 allies during more than two months of a bombing campaign was a formidable task, one that allied diplomats from several countries today said Mr. Solana had handled with diplomatic skill.
From Britain, which alone among the allies argued for preparations for an invasion of Kosovo with troops on the ground to force Mr. Milosevic to accept their will, to Greece, where opposition was strong against using force against a fellow Orthodox Christian nation, the allies constantly questioned the air war strategy, but never could agree on anything better.
In the end, Mr. Solana always insisted, NATO's air war was about human values, about 21st-century Europe not tolerating the throwback to 20th-century totalitarian brutality that the allies said Mr. Milosevic's "ethnic cleansing" in Kosovo represented. In this, NATO had public opinion behind it on most of the Continent.
"What Milosevic didn't reckon with," said a European diplomat at NATO, "was the effect on public opinion of seeing all those hundreds of thousands of refugees streaming out of Kosovo. It reminded all Europeans of the scenes they had seen during World War II and caused immediate and long-lasting revulsion."
NATO's bombing took the highest toll on Serbia, where President Milosevic, in his address today, called for unity to rebuild the country.
Led by Germany's Chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, foreign ministers of the world's seven largest industrial democracies plus Russia met with Balkans leaders in Cologne today and agreed to commit money and effort to a stability pact.
The "Schroder Plan," which European leaders say could cost $5 billion to $6 billion a year for many years, aims at raising all the Balkans to the economic and social level of the rest of Europe, in an effort to make another war there after a decade of ethnic conflict as unthinkable as it is now in France, Britain or Germany.
"Europe cannot be fully secure unless its southeast corner is free from strife," Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said in Cologne today, warning Mr. Milosevic against putting political or military pressure on Montenegro, another constituent republic of Yugoslavia whose leaders did not support his attacks in Kosovo.
Now NATO hopes its relationship with Russia can slowly begin to recover from the damage it suffered from the bombing campaign. Russian officials have refused to attend regular meetings at the alliance headquarters since the bombing began on March 24.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Show Time for Reluctant Soccer Superstar

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN

 BODY:
Every time Mia Hamm steps onto or off a soccer field, the young girls are waiting. They are wearing her No. 9 jersey. Their hair is pulled back into a replica of her ponytail. The cumulative effect is of nesting dolls, each one opening to reveal another inside that is smaller but identical.
Hamm is considered the world's best female soccer player, a woman born in 1972, the year of Title IX, the Federal law aimed in part at prohibiting discrimination against athletes on the basis of gender. And now, at 27, Hamm represents for many the full realization of sports opportunities for women. At 15, she became the youngest player ever to join the national soccer team, and in winning a world championship and an Olympic gold medal in recent years, she has scored 109 career goals, more than any other man or woman to play the game. 
 She has also reached an uncommon level of celebrity and corporate appeal. People magazine voted her one of its 50 most beautiful people. Nike named a building in her honor at its headquarters. She appears in a commercial with Michael Jordan, challenging him in basketball, soccer, track and fencing, and flipping him over her hip in a judo maneuver while the music asserts, "Anything you can do, I can do better."
And starting next week, Hamm will headline the largest sporting event ever held for women, the Women's World Cup, a 16-team tournament that begins at Giants Stadium on June 19 and will be played in stadiums across the country.
The games will provide the biggest stage yet for the woman who is a sports role model for 7.5 million girls who play soccer in the United States. Girls wait for her after practices and games in adoring flocks, shrieking her name in a way familiar to anyone who saw the Beatles on Ed Sullivan.
The scrutiny promises to be intense, for athletes are rarely asked to carry the enormous burden of opportunity that Hamm is being asked to shoulder this summer. And she is not completely comfortable with it. She is being counted on not only to lead the favored American team, but also to help fill stadiums, to lend a name and a face to an emerging game, to be the spark that could ignite a professional soccer league for women in 2001.
If Hamm fails, or her team fails early, the Women's World Cup -- games are being broadcast on ESPN and ABC, and the World Cup organizers expect to sell 500,000 tickets -- could become a diminished athletic and commercial affair. And a women's pro league, now a long-shot proposition looking for a star to hook onto, may have trouble becoming more than a proposal in a boardroom.
"I feel it is important for soccer that Mia plays well," said Leonardo Cuellar, coach of the Mexican women's team and a former star of its men's national team. "I don't want to add pressure, but it's always important, when fans have expectations about seeing a player excel in a world-class event, for that to happen. She's charismatic, very humble. Those are the attributes of Pele and some of the best stars."
 
PRESSURE
A Hesitant Hero Overcomes Doubts
 Sometimes the pressure to dominate on the soccer field can feel to Hamm like a knotted muscle. She did not finish among the top scorers in previous major tournaments -- the 1991 World Cup, the 1995 World Cup, the 1996 Summer Olympics. The burden was particularly evident earlier this year when Hamm did not score a goal for eight consecutive games. Twice during that drought the Americans lost to China, the United States' chief rival and the team it defeated for the 1996 Olympic gold medal.
Hamm seemed reluctant to challenge defenders one on one, according to the American coach Tony DiCicco. No one is better at this aspect of the women's game that is part croquet, part ballet, part bullfight. At her best, Hamm seems to release and retrieve the ball as if it were a yo-yo. But now she was hesitant. For the first time in her career, she made as much news when she did not score as when she did. Doubt seeped into her game like sweat.
"There's a fine line between setting standards that keep you getting better and being hypercritical to the point that it undermines your confidence," DiCicco said. "She's always flirted with that line. She's not only a soccer icon, but she's an icon for women's athletics. That's a huge responsibility. It's a very vulnerable place to be."
The girls who wait for her hold out their hands for her to slap, or ask her to sign their jerseys, or thrust soccer balls toward her. In return, Hamm offers high-fives, an autograph, a smile, a nod, an affirming gesture that they can aspire to be everything she has become.
"It's very important for young girls to have female athletes they can identify with," Hamm said.
While she accepts that she is a pioneer, she is a reluctant celebrity. She wears the role awkwardly, like wearing a fur coat in the dead of summer. Having grown up in a military family with three sisters and two brothers, there is a reserve about her, almost a sense of rank, as if she should succeed at a high level but should not stand out from the others.
She is a scorer who is a selfless passer, a forward who is as economical with her words as she is explosive with her feet, an athlete as effortless and guarded as Joe DiMaggio. Even her handshake is noncommittal, as if it might reveal too much.
"Men grow up knowing that if they are the best they are going to be famous," said Hamm's agent, David Bober. "Mia didn't sign up for soccer to be a famous sports icon. It's an adjustment."
Hamm is actually more forthcoming discussing her failures than her successes. The mantle of "best player in the world" is subjective, she said. Failure is objective. It can be taken apart, examined, repaired. She said that confidence, like fitness, must be cultivated daily.
"Someone tried to tell me that Michael Jordan doesn't have confidence problems, but he is probably very selective who he shares it with," Hamm said. "I don't think a lot of athletes walk around thinking they're the best. If they do, it's probably to hide some weaknesses they have."
During the scoring drought, Hamm heard and read that she was not playing her best, and by repetition, the supposition of a slump became fact.
"You try not to listen, but it does get to you," Hamm said. "I was putting too much pressure on myself. I wasn't enjoying what I was doing. I was so worried about, 'All right team, jump on my back, I'm going to carry you through all this.' "
She consulted friends, like Nomar Garciaparra, the shortstop for the Boston Red Sox, who told her, "Go out and enjoy the game and don't worry about all that other stuff." Eventually, she scored again, and with five goals in her last five matches leading to the World Cup, her personal fog cleared.
"Mia takes the burden really seriously on herself," said Tiffeny Milbrett, who plays forward alongside Hamm. "She needs to realize she's not alone. The team will be fine. She will pull off the spectacular play just by being on the field. All she needs to do is play."
 
PRODIGY
Soccer Triumph; Personal Sadness
 Hamm was born in Selma, Ala., and lived a road-map childhood in Texas, California, Virginia and Italy, where her father, an Air Force colonel, was passionately drawn to soccer. When Mia was 5, her family adopted an 8-year-old boy named Garrett, whose legs and arms seemed wondrously suited to propelling a ball off a bat, through a hoop, into a net.
"Garrett was an influence on me on any form of athletics," Hamm said. "When he'd go play pickup football or baseball, I was always right behind him. He always picked me for his teams."
By the time she was 14, the national soccer team wanted her, too. Anson Dorrance, who coached the team then, got an excited call about her from a coaching friend in Texas. Skeptical, Dorrance went to watch her play.
"The team kicks off, a girl passes the ball to the right about 30 yards and I see this skinny brunette take off like she had been shot out of a cannon," he said.
He walked around the field and approached his coaching friend.
"Is that Mia Hamm?" Dorrance asked.
"Yes."
"We've got something here."
But Hamm was only 14.
"When you have a potential genius, you don't want to crush their spirit and shatter their confidence if they don't succeed," Dorrance said. "I decided we couldn't wait. The rest is history."
At 15, Hamm became the youngest player, male or female, ever to join the national team. She then followed Dorrance to the University of North Carolina, where he coached, and she won four national championships and met her husband, Christian Corry, a Marine pilot. With Hamm, the Americans won the initial Women's World Cup in 1991, a bronze medal in the 1995 World Cup, then later won the gold medal at the 1996 Olympics. But her success has been tempered by sadness.
Garrett Hamm contracted a rare blood disorder. Mia raised $50,000 for his care through a benefit soccer game. But in April 1997, at the age of 28, her brother died.
Hamm absorbed the hurt, and she has played on, scoring more goals, raising expectations. But some close to her believe she has been pulled too thin, playing and promoting the game.
"All of us might be asking her to do too much," Dorrance said. "I have a great fear it will burn her out, on the field, off the field."
 
PASSION
A Dancer's Feet, A Felon's Heart
 Although Hamm is reticent off the field, her style of play is dynamically suited to spreading the sport to a wider audience. A fiercer countenance emerges, cheeks hollow and jaw clenched in exertion, her ponytail fanning out behind as she sprints 40 yards to finish a fast break or carves a defender with a deft two-step and makes an inexorable charge toward the goal.
The passion of her game is most evident in the celebrative convulsion when she scores, the tendons in her neck flared, her mouth an open scream, her arms cocked at the elbow and fists closed as if she has just lifted some enormous weight.
She has a dancer's feet, a felon's heart.
"Her acceleration is so visceral," Dorrance said. "When she gets the ball, you hold your breath."
Her athleticism is such that during a desperate moment of the 1995 Women's World Cup, the Americans made her a goalkeeper. Someone brought a football to a recent practice, and Hamm expertly knocked in field goals from 35 yards.
With her teammates, Hamm can be funny, outgoing, a master of accents, someone who gives as good as she gets. When midfielder Julie Foudy, in a moment of introspection, said that she wanted to retire from soccer to do something that "makes a difference," Hamm dabbed at fake tears and burst into a mock Bette Midler number, singing, "Did you ever know that you're my hero?"
Nor does she mind pinpricking her own public image. On the box of Soccer Barbie, which she endorses, Hamm is pictured with a doll's freeze-dried smile and eternity-proof makeup. "You can't tell which one is the Barbie," she said.
In filming the Gatorade commercial with Jordan, cameras began rolling in the unscripted judo sequence, and Hamm moved confidently toward Jordan and flung him to the mat. He played along, said Bober, Hamm's agent, "but he waved his finger and said, 'That better not make the final cut.' "
It did.
The cameras will be rolling for real in the coming weeks, and there will be no playacting. Everyone will be watching.
"All sports lacking a profile really have to push one or two of the best athletes who have a number of qualities in and out of the game," said Julie Murray, captain of the Australian women's team. "Sometimes it can be daunting, standing up and making speeches when all you want to do is play. But I know it is better for the sport and for the people who will follow in Mia's shoes. Girls who are 13, 14, 15 are looking at her. The sport is better off doing that."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Grows 1.9%, to Economists' Disbelief

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, June 11

 BODY:
After nearly two years of recession, Japan's dormant economy leaped to life in the first three months of the year, according to official figures so strong that they were played down by some of the Government's own economists.
The gross domestic product rose for the first time since the end of 1997, gaining 1.9 percent from the last quarter of 1998, compared with a drop of eight-tenths of a percent in the previous quarter, according to the figures released on Thursday. If this pace were maintained for a full year -- something virtually no one expects -- the economy would grow 7.9 percent in 1999. 
 Japanese Government officials, long criticized for failing to acknowledge the depths of the nation's economic crisis, hastened to stamp out any sense of euphoria.
"It's too early to say the economy has recovered or bottomed out," said Taiichi Sakaiya, the head of the Economic Planning Agency, which compiles the figures.
Indeed, few are betting that the improvement in output will have much momentum, and many worried that it would force the Government to postpone drafting a supplemental budget devoted to further stimulating the economy.
"We still have a risk of a slowdown in the economy in the second half of this year because public expenditures are likely to decrease," said Hiroyuki Inoue, chief economist at the Japan Center for Research, adding that the new report "doesn't mean the crisis is over."
The latest output figures appeared to indicate, though, that the Government's yearlong, $800-billion-plus spending program had begun to have stimulative effects. The Government estimates annual growth of one-half of 1 percent for the year, a figure that until now was considered unrealistically rosy by many economists.
"The Government's projections will not be so difficult to achieve," given the new figures, said Masaru Takagi, an economist at Meiji University. "The key point is whether private demand continues to improve, especially in the second half of this year."
Apparently, stock buyers were impressed by the data. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues shot up 480.12 points, or 2.89 percent, on Thursday, and added a further 237.74 points this morning, to 17,340.36 at midday. The yen spiked up against the dollar after the new figures were announced, then fell back on the belief among currency traders that the Japanese central bank had intervened in the markets and was selling yen -- something Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa confirmed this morning. A strong yen could crush hopes of an economic turnaround because so many big Japanese manufacturers rely on exports. In late currency trading in New York, though, the yen stood at 118.84 to the dollar, slightly stronger than Wednesday's rate of 118.93, then gained strength early today, trading at midday at 118.72 to the dollar.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said in Washington on Thursday that the United States was not selling yen. Mr. Rubin would not draw broad conclusions from the Japanese output data. "My instinct is that individual quarterly numbers don't give you much sense about what's happening in an economy," he said. "Clearly, they have enormous challenges ahead."
Here, the magnitude of the improvement caught economists off guard. The consensus forecast on Thursday morning of 28 economists polled by Bloomberg News had been for growth of only one-tenth of 1 percent -- and many forecasters grumbled that the Government's statistics were based on data that did not accurately reflect economic reality. Just a day earlier, Bloomberg's economists were predicting that the economy would contract by eight-tenths of a percent -- until comments late that afternoon by the Prime Minister's spokesman, who suggested the figures would be positive, sent them back to rework their models.
"I'm cautious about the accuracy of the numbers in reflecting what's really happening in the economy," said Chris Calderwood, chief economist at Jardine Fleming Securities here. "Even if the numbers are vaguely right, it's possible we're getting all the good news in one blow, and it's all downhill from here."
In particular, Mr. Calderwood and others looked askance at the figures for private consumption and corporate investment, which rose 1.2 percent and 2.5 percent, respectively.
Consumer spending, which was down two-tenths of a percent the previous quarter, has always been the wild card in a Japanese recovery. While there are signs that the Japanese are shopping more freely, companies are forcing workers to retire early and are cutting bonuses and perquisites. Consumers face tax increases for the public pension system and for medical insurance, which should also restrain spending.
Much of the increase in corporate spending was due to a one-time outlay for technology related to a new digital telephone system. In the previous quarter, corporate expenditures dropped 5.5 percent, and almost every major company has plans to cut capital spending anywhere from 15 to 30 percent.
Some economists have been skeptical about the corporate profit survey compiled by the Finance Ministry, which contains the figures on company spending that are used to calculate output. The same survey showed employment up 6.2 percent compared with the period last year, according to one economist. Such a figure seems so clearly out of sync with reality -- unemployment is at a record high 4.8 percent -- that it raises questions about the entire survey. "The data on corporate spending doesn't really jibe with other data we have," said Brian H. Rose, senior economist at Warburg Dillon Read. "I'd conclude that the survey just isn't that accurate."
The new output figures would appear to support the Government's strategy of setting aside fiscal caution in order to goad the economy into action. More than $800 billion has been invested in public works over the last year, and tax cuts, credit guarantees and shopping vouchers have been handed out to encourage spending.
Economists worry that once spending stops, Japan will again fall into a prolonged decline, and they say that spending is almost certain to stop. Public-sector debt has ballooned, with the Finance Ministry predicting it will stand at 108.5 percent of the gross domestic product this year. Tax revenue is falling.
"We're approaching the peak of Government spending," Mr. Rose said. "I think a lot of people, including us, are really more worried about what will happen in 2000 rather than this year, when it looks like they've propped things up pretty well."
Public investment rose 10.3 percent in the first quarter, on the back of a 10.6 percent increase the previous quarter.
Bankruptcies are down, largely because the Government has spent 15 trillion yen in the last six months -- $126 billion at current exchange rates -- on a loan guarantee program for small and midsized businesses.
Tax breaks have produced a surge in new housing, pushing housing investment up 1.2 percent in the first quarter, compared with a 7 percent decline in the fourth quarter of 1998. Interest rates are about as low as they can go without being negative.
Today, the Government is taking the wraps off a plan to halt the rise in unemployment, with billions more in new spending aimed at creating 700,000 jobs and preserving existing ones.
These sorts of pump-priming activities are applauded by officials in the United States and other foreign governments; in Japan, they draw criticism as an expensive effort to stave off wrenching structural changes needed to put the economy on a globally competitive footing.
Some economists said that a danger inherent in Thursday's figures was complacency -- that hints of Asian economic recovery would squelch the drive for market-driven changes that was so strong in worse times a few months ago.
"We now have a new set of risks," Mr. Inoue of the Japan Center for Research maintained. "If private corporations react to the current numbers the wrong way, if they think the crisis is over, they might not press ahead with restructuring and reform. And that will postpone necessary structural readjustments to the economy."

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
Show Time for Reluctant Soccer Superstar

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
Every time Mia Hamm steps onto or off a soccer field, the young girls are waiting. They are wearing her No. 9 jersey. Their hair is pulled back into a replica of her ponytail. The cumulative effect is of nesting dolls, each one opening to reveal another inside that is smaller but identical.
Hamm is considered the world's best female soccer player, a woman born in 1972, the year of Title IX, the Federal law aimed in part at prohibiting discrimination against athletes on the basis of gender. And now, at 27, Hamm represents for many the full realization of sports opportunities for women. At 15, she became the youngest player ever to join the national soccer team, and in winning a world championship and an Olympic gold medal in recent years, she has scored 109 career goals, more than any other man or woman to play the game. 
 She has also reached an uncommon level of celebrity and corporate appeal. People magazine voted her one of its 50 most beautiful people. Nike named a building in her honor at its headquarters. She appears in a commercial with Michael Jordan, challenging him in basketball, soccer, track and fencing, and flipping him over her hip in a judo maneuver while the music asserts, "Anything you can do, I can do better."
And starting next week, Hamm will headline the largest sporting event ever held for women, the Women's World Cup, a 16-team tournament that begins at Giants Stadium on June 19 and will be played in stadiums across the country.
The games will provide the biggest stage yet for the woman who is a sports role model for 7.5 million girls who play soccer in the United States. Girls wait for her after practices and games in adoring flocks, shrieking her name in a way familiar to anyone who saw the Beatles on Ed Sullivan.
The scrutiny promises to be intense, for athletes are rarely asked to carry the enormous burden of opportunity that Hamm is being asked to shoulder this summer. And she is not completely comfortable with it. She is being counted on not only to lead the favored American team, but also to help fill stadiums, to lend a name and a face to an emerging game, to be the spark that could ignite a professional soccer league for women in 2001.
If Hamm fails, or her team fails early, the Women's World Cup -- games are being broadcast on ESPN and ABC, and the World Cup organizers expect to sell 500,000 tickets -- could become a diminished athletic and commercial affair. And a women's pro league, now a long-shot proposition looking for a star to hook onto, may have trouble becoming more than a proposal in a boardroom.
"I feel it is important for soccer that Mia plays well," said Leonardo Cuellar, coach of the Mexican women's team and a former star of its men's national team. "I don't want to add pressure, but it's always important, when fans have expectations about seeing a player excel in a world-class event, for that to happen. She's charismatic, very humble. Those are the attributes of Pele and some of the best stars."
 
PRESSURE
A Hesitant Hero Overcomes Doubts
 Sometimes the pressure to dominate on the soccer field can feel to Hamm like a knotted muscle. She did not finish among the top scorers in previous major tournaments -- the 1991 World Cup, the 1995 World Cup, the 1996 Summer Olympics. The burden was particularly evident earlier this year when Hamm did not score a goal for eight consecutive games. Twice during that drought the Americans lost to China, the United States' chief rival and the team it defeated for the 1996 Olympic gold medal.
Hamm seemed reluctant to challenge defenders one on one, according to the American coach Tony DiCicco. No one is better at this aspect of the women's game that is part croquet, part ballet, part bullfight. At her best, Hamm seems to release and retrieve the ball as if it were a yo-yo. But now she was hesitant. For the first time in her career, she made as much news when she did not score as when she did. Doubt seeped into her game like sweat.
"There's a fine line between setting standards that keep you getting better and being hypercritical to the point that it undermines your confidence," DiCicco said. "She's always flirted with that line. She's not only a soccer icon, but she's an icon for women's athletics. That's a huge responsibility. It's a very vulnerable place to be."
The girls who wait for her hold out their hands for her to slap, or ask her to sign their jerseys, or thrust soccer balls toward her. In return, Hamm offers high-fives, an autograph, a smile, a nod, an affirming gesture that they can aspire to be everything she has become.
"It's very important for young girls to have female athletes they can identify with," Hamm said.
While she accepts that she is a pioneer, she is a reluctant celebrity. She wears the role awkwardly, like wearing a fur coat in the dead of summer. Having grown up in a military family with three sisters and two brothers, there is a reserve about her, almost a sense of rank, as if she should succeed at a high level but should not stand out from the others.
She is a scorer who is a selfless passer, a forward who is as economical with her words as she is explosive with her feet, an athlete as effortless and guarded as Joe DiMaggio. Even her handshake is noncommittal, as if it might reveal too much.
"Men grow up knowing that if they are the best they are going to be famous," said Hamm's agent, David Bober. "Mia didn't sign up for soccer to be a famous sports icon. It's an adjustment."
Hamm is actually more forthcoming discussing her failures than her successes. The mantle of "best player in the world" is subjective, she said. Failure is objective. It can be taken apart, examined, repaired. She said that confidence, like fitness, must be cultivated daily.
"Someone tried to tell me that Michael Jordan doesn't have confidence problems, but he is probably very selective who he shares it with," Hamm said. "I don't think a lot of athletes walk around thinking they're the best. If they do, it's probably to hide some weaknesses they have."
During the scoring drought, Hamm heard and read that she was not playing her best, and by repetition, the supposition of a slump became fact.
"You try not to listen, but it does get to you," Hamm said. "I was putting too much pressure on myself. I wasn't enjoying what I was doing. I was so worried about, 'All right team, jump on my back, I'm going to carry you through all this.' "
She consulted friends, like Nomar Garciaparra, the shortstop for the Boston Red Sox, who told her, "Go out and enjoy the game and don't worry about all that other stuff." Eventually, she scored again, and with five goals in her last five matches leading to the World Cup, her personal fog cleared.
"Mia takes the burden really seriously on herself," said Tiffeny Milbrett, who plays forward alongside Hamm. "She needs to realize she's not alone. The team will be fine. She will pull off the spectacular play just by being on the field. All she needs to do is play."
 
PRODIGY
Soccer Triumph; Personal Sadness
 Hamm was born in Selma, Ala., and lived a road-map childhood in Texas, California, Virginia and Italy, where her father, an Air Force colonel, was passionately drawn to soccer. When Mia was 5, her family adopted an 8-year-old boy named Garrett, whose legs and arms seemed wondrously suited to propelling a ball off a bat, through a hoop, into a net.
"Garrett was an influence on me on any form of athletics," Hamm said. "When he'd go play pickup football or baseball, I was always right behind him. He always picked me for his teams."
By the time she was 14, the national soccer team wanted her, too. Anson Dorrance, who coached the team then, got an excited call about her from a coaching friend in Texas. Skeptical, Dorrance went to watch her play.
"The team kicks off, a girl passes the ball to the right about 30 yards and I see this skinny brunette take off like she had been shot out of a cannon," he said.
He walked around the field and approached his coaching friend.
"Is that Mia Hamm?" Dorrance asked.
"Yes."
"We've got something here."
But Hamm was only 14.
"When you have a potential genius, you don't want to crush their spirit and shatter their confidence if they don't succeed," Dorrance said. "I decided we couldn't wait. The rest is history."
At 15, Hamm became the youngest player, male or female, ever to join the national team. She then followed Dorrance to the University of North Carolina, where he coached, and she won four national championships and met her husband, Christian Corry, a Marine pilot. With Hamm, the Americans won the initial Women's World Cup in 1991, a bronze medal in the 1995 World Cup, then later won the gold medal at the 1996 Olympics. But her success has been tempered by sadness.
Garrett Hamm contracted a rare blood disorder. Mia raised $50,000 for his care through a benefit soccer game. But in April 1997, at the age of 28, her brother died.
Hamm absorbed the hurt, and she has played on, scoring more goals, raising expectations. But some close to her believe she has been pulled too thin, playing and promoting the game.
"All of us might be asking her to do too much," Dorrance said. "I have a great fear it will burn her out, on the field, off the field."
 
PASSION
A Dancer's Feet, A Felon's Heart
 Although Hamm is reticent off the field, her style of play is dynamically suited to spreading the sport to a wider audience. A fiercer countenance emerges, cheeks hollow and jaw clenched in exertion, her ponytail fanning out behind as she sprints 40 yards to finish a fast break or carves a defender with a deft two-step and makes an inexorable charge toward the goal.
The passion of her game is most evident in the celebrative convulsion when she scores, the tendons in her neck flared, her mouth an open scream, her arms cocked at the elbow and fists closed as if she has just lifted some enormous weight.
She has a dancer's feet, a felon's heart.
"Her acceleration is so visceral," Dorrance said. "When she gets the ball, you hold your breath."
Her athleticism is such that during a desperate moment of the 1995 Women's World Cup, the Americans made her a goalkeeper. Someone brought a football to a recent practice, and Hamm expertly knocked in field goals from 35 yards.
With her teammates, Hamm can be funny, outgoing, a master of accents, someone who gives as good as she gets. When midfielder Julie Foudy, in a moment of introspection, said that she wanted to retire from soccer to do something that "makes a difference," Hamm dabbed at fake tears and burst into a mock Bette Midler number, singing, "Did you ever know that you're my hero?"
Nor does she mind pinpricking her own public image. On the box of Soccer Barbie, which she endorses, Hamm is pictured with a doll's freeze-dried smile and eternity-proof makeup. "You can't tell which one is the Barbie," she said.
In filming the Gatorade commercial with Jordan, cameras began rolling in the unscripted judo sequence, and Hamm moved confidently toward Jordan and flung him to the mat. He played along, said Bober, Hamm's agent, "but he waved his finger and said, 'That better not make the final cut.' "
It did.
The cameras will be rolling for real in the coming weeks, and there will be no playacting. Everyone will be watching.
"All sports lacking a profile really have to push one or two of the best athletes who have a number of qualities in and out of the game," said Julie Murray, captain of the Australian women's team. "Sometimes it can be daunting, standing up and making speeches when all you want to do is play. But I know it is better for the sport and for the people who will follow in Mia's shoes. Girls who are 13, 14, 15 are looking at her. The sport is better off doing that."

HEADLINE: Bush's Tort Tale

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In saying that "the most important thing you and I can do to improve our economy and create jobs in Texas is to reform our civil justice system," Gov. George W. Bush argues a position that makes little real economic sense (front page, June 7). States have been adopting significant reductions in tort liability since the mid-1980's. To date, no well-accepted empirical evidence shows that these reforms either increased employment or reduced insurance rates. 
 Tort law is not primarily an economic-development policy tool. Tort law is intended to encourage business to take cost-justified precautions. While eliminating frivolous lawsuits is a valuable goal, measures like caps on damages do not distinguish between justified and frivolous suits. They only encourage companies to act irresponsibly.
 
LISA KIMMEL
Oakland, Calif., June 7, 1999
 
The writer, a lawyer, is a Ph.D candidate in economics at the University of California at Berkeley.

HEADLINE: Punitive Tariffs Are Approved On Imports of Japanese Steel

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 11

 BODY:
United States steel producers won an important ruling today when the International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, approved punitive tariffs to combat low-priced Japanese shipments.
Tariffs ranging from 18 percent to 67 percent will be ordered by the Clinton Administration within weeks. Those tariffs will effectively make Japanese steel more expensive to sell in the United States, a move intended to offer domestic producers some relief. 
 The trade commission ruled 6 to 0 that Japanese pricing practices on hot-rolled carbon steel, the industry's main product, had harmed or could harm domestic producers. The Commerce Department had previously declared the pricing illegal.
Curtis H. Barnette, chairman and chief executive of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said he considered the ruling a vindication for the industry, which blames low-priced imports for the loss of thousands of jobs.
But he said tariffs were not a cure-all. The American industry has been pushing for stronger sanctions, such as quotas covering all steel products from all countries.
"This is just a further step in a lengthy process needed to end our crisis in the industry," Mr. Barnette said. "The vote clearly demonstrates the serious injury we have been sustaining, but our problems continue."
The import surge last year came in the aftermath of the Asian economic crisis, which lowered demand for steel abroad. As a result, foreign producers became more reliant on sales in the healthier economy in the United States.
The tariffs, which will be made retroactive to February, will probably be in place at least five years.
Japanese steel producers blamed politics for the ruling.
"We are disappointed that a majority of the commissioners, facing overwhelming political pressure, ignored the facts and imposed long-term restrictions on hot-rolled steel imports," said Hidenori Tazawa, executive vice president for NKK America Inc.
He said the tariffs "will raise prices and limit supply availability and choice for U.S. steel users."
Another executive, Masaki Sato of Nippon Steel U.S.A. Inc., said that his company was likely to appeal to the United States Court of International Trade in New York. The court handles disputed cases from the trade commission, a fact-finding agency independent from the Administration.
Hot-rolled steel can be used as is in such applications as construction or turned into higher-grade products for use in appliances or automobiles.
The ruling today would not apply to other steel products or to other countries. Hot-rolled shipments from Japan have already fallen to almost insignificant levels partly because of the threat of tariffs, so the vote was mostly about sustaining those reductions.
Supporters of global quotas are hoping for a Senate vote on the issue later this month. The House passed a quota bill in March by a vote of 289 to 141, despite the threat of a Presidential veto.
The American industry accused Japanese, Russian and Brazilian producers of illegally selling hot-rolled steel in the United States at prices below production costs or home-market prices, a practice known as dumping.
The Clinton Administration has tentatively struck deals with Russia and Brazil that will enable those countries to avoid tariffs by voluntarily reducing steel shipments.
The foreign producers contend that the pricing trends are a result of normal market forces. They also say that the American industry's claims of harm are exaggerated because last year's declines in profits and production followed one of the industry's best years ever. 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1584 words

HEADLINE: An American in Warsaw;
U.S. Businesswoman Challenges Old Phone Monopoly

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WARSAW, June 11

 BODY:
The lobby of the Sheraton Hotel here was packed with dark-suited bankers last Wednesday, when Barbara J. Lundberg blazed in.
Her strawberry-red hair, bright enough to spot across the huge room, had once again begun to rebel against her efforts to tame it. But her freckled face scrunched up in easy laughter. 
 "I have never seen a picture of me that I liked," she remarked as she begged to avoid being photographed.
Yet like it or not, Mrs. Lundberg is the center of a lot of attention here.
A former Wall Street executive who set up a venture capital fund in Warsaw nine years ago, Mrs. Lundberg is suddenly in charge of one of Poland's biggest and messiest conglomerates. Her goal? Engineering a billion-dollar bet on telecommunications to compete against Poland's former state telephone monopoly in both wireless and traditional telephone service.
The opportunities and the risks are enormous. Poland, with its population of 42 million and its remarkably strong growth, has become Central Europe's hottest target for foreign investors.
Foreign investors, mostly banks, own 50 percent of the shares in Poland's banks. Foreign phone companies, including SBC Communications of the United States and Deutsche Telekom A.G. of Germany, are circling with interest around the plan to sell off a big chunk of the national phone company.
But it is hard to match the audacity of Mrs. Lundberg's ambition. If she succeeds, analysts predict Elektrim's debt will double to about $1 billion next year. The potential profit gains could be equally staggering.
Four months ago, Mrs. Lundberg became the chief executive of Elektrim S.A., a sprawling post-Communist behemoth that had alienated shareholders by buying up businesses from cable manufacturing to chicken farms.
Recruited by rebellious shareholders, many of them American investment firms, she dismissed Elektrim's top management and moved to sell off stakes in more than 80 companies.
But far more important, she has plunged into the telecommunications business with a string of acquisitions totaling more than $1 billion.
On Tuesday, she cemented a key part of her plan by teaming up with Vivendi S.A., the French media and telecommunications conglomerate. Vivendi will invest about $750 million to acquire 30 percent of Elektrim's telecommunications ventures, which will be pooled into a new joint-venture company.
Next week, Mrs. Lundberg plans to up the ante once again. In need of big money to build high-speed networks around Poland, she will try to raise about $500 million through a global convertible bond offering.
Not only are the financial risks a huge challenge; so are the political ones. Elektrim's strategy assumes in large part that the Polish Government will allow only one rival in each city to Telekomunikacja Ploska S.A., the former Polish telephone monopoly. But political leaders have vacillated under strong lobbying pressure from a Swedish-backed rival, Netia Holdings.
Worried about violating Securities and Exchange Commission restrictions against promoting stocks before a public securities offering, Mrs. Lundgren refused to talk about her plans with American publications this week.
Nevertheless, she has long been one of Warsaw's most visible foreigners, and the broad elements of her plan are clear.
 Unlike many expatriate American entrepreneurs here, Mrs. Lundberg did not come to Warsaw because of a Polish ancestry. Now 46, she had worked as a venture capitalist in California and later as vice president for corporate finance at Kidder, Peabody & Company.
In 1990, less than a year after the collapse of Poland's last Communist regime, she organized the Polish American Enterprise Fund, a venture capital fund financed initially by the American Government to encourage the development of Poland's private sector.
The fund was successful enough that she subsequently began several other investment outfits, which together managed about $500 million at the end of last year.
Elektrim, by contrast, was a direct holdover from the Communist era. Formed around several of Poland's formerly state-owned industrial companies, it was privatized as the country's biggest producer of power-generation equipment, electrical cable and engineering services.
Like many other privatized companies in Eastern Europe, it remained largely under control of the same managers as it had during the old regime. The key player was Andrzej Skowronski, its chairman, who took the company public on the Warsaw Stock Exchange and then used its cash flow to buy up a treasure trove of smaller companies.
But despite Poland's steady economic ascent under governments that consistently pushed the country toward private enterprise, many soured investors came to view Elektrim as a bad example of Russian-style crony capitalism.
Elektrim's strategy was opaque, and its financial disclosure was even worse. Dozens of companies and stakes in other companies were hived off into separate entities, with the result that few people had any idea what its true assets really were.
By the end of last year, Elektrim reported sales of $182 million and a loss of $94 million. But those numbers did not include many of the company's biggest properties, like its big cable-producing business or its 34 percent stake in one of Poland's two nationwide cellular telephone carriers, Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa.
In a recent letter to shareholders, Mrs. Lundberg estimated that revenues from Elektrim's core equipment and engineering businesses were about $886 million.
But the real revolt came after revelations last year that Elektrim had secretly agreed to sell part of its stake in the wireless company -- the one business that enjoyed rocketing sales and profits.
Backed by dissident shareholders, believed to include investment funds run by Merrill Lynch among others, Mrs. Lundberg took over as chief executive in early February.
With an uncanny knack to charm almost anybody, people who know her say Mrs. Lundberg, a twice-divorced mother with a 10-year-old son, is tough and shrewd as well. She knows the key players in Warsaw's elite, and she has mapped the political minefields.
And she has not been shy about imposing her ideas. Besides insuring the departure of Mr. Skowronski, Mrs. Lundberg got rid of Elektrim's vice chairman and chief accountant. Then she recruited two top executives from ABB Asea Brown Boveri's Poland subsidiary to draft a cleanup effort.
Under their blueprint, Elektrim will jettison stakes in more than 80 noncore businesses and refocus on power generation equipment, power engineering and telecommunications.
Of the three, telecommunications is to be the main event. Mrs. Lundberg quickly scrapped the deal to sell off the stake in the wireless company, agreeing to pay the aspiring buyer $25 million to go away.
Instead, she negotiated to acquire a 51 percent stake in the wireless venture, up from 34 percent, for which Elektrim will pay about $700 million. On top of that, she reached a deal to buy up Bresnan International Partners, a cable television operator, for $325 million. Bresnan operates cable systems in northwest Poland as well as a fiber optic network in Warsaw.
Mrs. Lundberg is also negotiating to buy a consortium of local telephone operators in other cities around Poland, a deal that is expected to cost several hundred million dollars.
To top it off, Elektrim will need to invest hundreds of millions of dollars in new networks and to start new businesses.
Knowing she needed strategic partners, Mrs. Lundberg began talks with Deutsche Telekom. But those talks bogged down because of disputes over control.
Mrs. Lundberg had much better luck with Vivendi, a former water company that owns stakes in media companies and competes against France Telecom in both wireless- and wired-phone service.
Analysts and investors have generally applauded the new strategy, but the political risks are enormous.
"The biggest risk is regulatory risk," said Pajak Sobek, an analyst at Wood & Company in Warsaw. "No one knows, including Elektrim, what is going on."
Poland is taking a relatively slow path toward allowing competition in the telephone market. It has begun issuing licenses allowing a single rival to the state system in each of Poland's major cities. Long-distance and international service, which are far more lucrative, will be off-limits for another few years.
But even that modest plan has been wobbly and politically messy. Elektrim waged a long and bitter battle against Netia Holdings, whose biggest shareholder is the Swedish telephone company Telia A.B., just to acquire a local license in Warsaw.
After months of lobbying and acrimony, Elektrim announced this week that the Government had guaranteed it the exclusive license for Warsaw. But then today, just three days later, Polish newspapers quoted Government officials saying they might indeed allow another rival into the Warsaw market.
"That would be very bad for Elektrim because of their assumption that they would be the sole rival for the next five years," Mr. Sobek said. It would also raise deeper fears about future decisions that might change the rules of the game.
Mrs. Lundberg seems determined to stay. Poland, she said, "is my home."
Though she still speaks Polish only haltingly, she quickly won over many Elektrim workers.
"You may speak Polish, and I may speak English," she told workers shortly after arriving. "But in business we are all speaking the same language."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Prospect of Rise in Interest Rates Takes Toll on Equities

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average fell yesterday for a fourth consecutive day after economic reports deepened investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month. Internet shares like America Online and CMGI slumped.
Any question of the Fed's raising rates is "gone because of the extreme strength in the U.S. economy," said David Mead, chief investment officer at Harris Bank in Chicago, which oversees $25 billion. 
 "It's a given the Fed will tighten," Mr. Mead said, adding that the only remaining issue was whether the increase would be a half-point rather than a quarter.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 130.76 points, or 1.23 percent, to 10,490.51, extending its loss for the last four days to 456 points. The Nasdaq composite index declined 36.74 points, or 1.48 percent, to 2,447.88, pulled lower by Microsoft and CMGI. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 9.18 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,293.64.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1 7/32, to 87 22/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.16 percent, from 6.06 percent on Thursday.
For the week, the Dow average lost 2.9 percent, its biggest weekly loss since a 3.1 percent drop for the week ended Jan. 15. The S.& P. 500 fell 2.6 percent, and the Nasdaq dropped 1.2 percent.
The Commerce Department said yesterday that retail sales rose 1 percent in May. Sales excluding automobiles rose half a percent.
The report on producer prices matched expectations. Traders said they were more concerned about retail sales, because the Fed cited consumer demand when it warned last month that it was leaning toward increasing interest rates.
The University of Michigan's preliminary index of June consumer sentiment rose to 109 from 106.8, above economists' expectations of 106.2. Gains and losses indicate Americans' degree of comfort with their finances and the state of the economy.
"The market is pulling apart trying to sort out" whether the Fed will focus on "the stability of prices or the strengthening of the economy," Tracy Herrick, chief investment strategist at Jefferies & Company in Los Angeles, said.
The New York Stock Exchange imposed its "downtick" rule 20 minutes before the close as the Dow briefly fell 190 points. The rule is meant to slow market declines by forcing traders to wait until shares rise before executing orders involving groups of stocks and equity index futures. It was the 15th time the rule was imposed since Feb. 16, when the trigger was raised from a 50-point move in the Dow industrials.
The decline in stocks and bonds came amid speculation about the health of Tiger Management L.L.C., a hedge fund. A spokesman for Tiger said the fund was able to handle redemptions by its investors and was not meeting with the Federal Reserve.
"Tiger is in a highly liquid position," the spokesman said. "It has enough cash on hand to pay out its redemptions fourfold." He called talk that the Fed was holding a special meeting about the fund "absurd."
A Fed spokesman declined to comment.
About 698 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, below the three-month daily average of 802 million.
"It's Friday afternoon and there's light volume, so any move in the market is exaggerated," Bob Basel, chief listed trader at Salomon Smith Barney, said. "Stocks are falling because people didn't like the fact that retail sales were higher."
CMGI fell 11 3/4, to 89 3/4, after the Internet venture fund said it lost 30 cents in its fiscal third quarter, which ended April 30, compared with a profit a year earlier, as its operating expenses almost doubled. The loss was wider than the 13-cent average estimate of seven analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation, which tracks corporate earnings.
Ebay, the Internet's leading auctioneer, fell 16 13/16 , to 165 7/8, after a computer problem forced it to suspend its auction business.

HEADLINE: Beliefs;
The leader of Kosovo's Muslims, himself a chief victim of the terror, sees reason to hope for a lasting reconciliation in the Balkans.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
Dr. Rexhep Boja, the Grand Mufti of Kosovo, left New York last Sunday for Istanbul. Yesterday he was heading for the refugee camps in Albania and Macedonia so that he could be with people as they faced the joys and terrors of returning home.
Home for Dr. Boja himself is what it is for many other Kosovars: a burned-out dwelling, in Pristina in his case, from which he and his family were driven at gunpoint shortly after the NATO bombing began. 
 But home for Dr. Boja (pronounced BOY-ah) also seems to be a remarkable zone of faith in God, in the future and in human nature -- a zone where sorrow nests, but no discernible trace of animosity.
The Mufti was, of course, a marked man. As the elected religious leader of Kosovo's Muslims, he had long been harassed, arrested and interrogated by Yugoslav officials. Then he led the funeral prayers for Bajram Kelmendi, a neighbor and prominent human rights advocate. Mr. Kelmendi and two sons were seized on the first night of the bombing; their corpses were found two days later.
It was lunchtime not long afterward when armed men arrived at Dr. Boja's home. Forced entrance, orders to lie on the floor, demands for money, seizure of documents, house set aflame, the march to the train, people shoved into the cars through open windows -- the sequence is by now all too familiar.
The 50 miles to the Macedonian border took eight hours. At each prolonged halt, the passengers feared they were about to be shot, or used as shields against NATO bombers.
"Yes, I was praying and depending on God," Dr. Boja said, "and many people were saying, 'Pray for us.' Everyone was scared." Sitting in a Manhattan hotel restaurant next to a translator, he raised his eyes to Heaven and threw up his hands in a manner expressing a state of both helplessness and supplication.
It was an expansive gesture for this grave, neatly bearded man in a dark suit who most often bent forward as he spoke and made small, graceful circles with his cupped hands, like a potter rounding, shaping and smoothing his words into reality. It was typical that he concluded his story of flight with a plea: Please don't sensationalize it so as merely to stir up more passion.
Dr. Boja was in the United States under the auspices of the World Conference on Religion and Peace, a global coalition of religious leaders addressing issues of conflict resolution, human rights and economic development. The organization is convinced that cooperation among Balkan religious leaders will be a crucial component of any reconstruction and reconciliation in the region.
Dr. Boja expressed disappointment that Kosovo's Serbian Orthodox leaders had not condemned the anti-Albanian terror. Then he quickly qualified his remarks. "Maybe myself I would try to find some excuse for the Orthodox leadership," he said, "because we know the mentality of the Communist regime: if any priests said a single word, they could pay with their lives."
For Dr. Boja, there was clear continuity between the anti-religious attitudes of the earlier "Communist regime" and the current Belgrade Government's efforts to inflame and manipulate religious feelings. As a youth, he was spurned by Communist organizations and condemned by Communist publications for his devotion to Islam.
He challenges the widespread impression that Balkan history is nothing but a chronicle of religious warfare. In Kosovo, it is quite the contrary, he said: three religious communities -- Muslim, Orthodox and Roman Catholic -- long coexisted peacefully. There are sacred sites of the Serbian Orthodox in Kosovo, he said, that for many years have been in the safekeeping of Albanian Muslim Kosovars, who consider them part of a national heritage and spared them damage even as ethnic conflict grew acute. In earlier years, imams and priests were often jailed by Communist officials in the same cells, and emerged friends.
Dr. Boja's hopes for the future brightened even while he was in New York. The conversation in the restaurant took place before the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, accepted NATO's terms; it continued, four days later, after that initial acceptance, over tea at the home of William F. Vendley, secretary general of the World Conference on Religion and Peace.
What appeared to remain constant, however, was his conviction that with the aid of "civilized nations" -- first among them the United States, in his eyes a model of religious pluralism -- reconstruction and tolerance could overcome bitterness and revenge.
At moments during the talk at Dr. Vendley's home, it was hard not to think the Mufti naive. Yet only that morning he had been visiting refugees at Fort Dix, N.J., and he knew he would soon be counseling families learning not only of homes and livelihoods destroyed but also of sons murdered and daughters raped.
"We need to visit, advise, encourage and guide the families, psychologically and spiritually," he said, "and help them look to the future, not be caught in the past."
Nor was Dr. Boja discouraged by the fact that the Islamic center in Pristina, which had also functioned as a civic and educational center with newly installed computer technology, was now gutted: "Even the spoons were taken and everything shot up with machine guns."
Dr. Vendley recalled having been welcomed there in the last year.
"You will come again," the Mufti said softly.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Strong Consumer Spending Worsens the Interest-Rate Jitters;
Data Convince Many That Fed Will Move; Yield Climbs to 6.16%

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
American consumers, the backbone of the second-longest economic expansion ever, are not showing any signs of pinching pennies. And their spending spree is putting continued upward pressure on market interest rates, with long-term yields jumping to a 19-month high yesterday.
Automobile and furniture buying helped push retail sales up 1 percent in May, the Government reported yesterday. 
 A separate economic report showed that prices paid to producers of finished goods rose two-tenths of 1 percent last month, suggesting that inflation was still in check. But price increases outside the oil sector in crude goods, like wheat, and intermediate goods, like flour, could signal a turnaround in the global economy. Such a turnaround would mean more demand for credit and would put even more upward pressure on interest rates.
The prospect of an economic rebound in Asia gained credibility this week after Japan reported that its economy grew a surprisingly strong 1.9 percent in the first three months of the year. Economists found reason for optimism even after the Japanese Government rushed to play down the size of the increase, suggesting the growth rate would not be sustained.
"We agree with everyone that first-quarter G.D.P. overstates the rate of revival in Japan," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company. "But we buy the notion that Japan is now rebounding."
The data from this country and Japan strengthened the view of many analysts that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates to slow economic growth and prevent any surge in prices. Economists expect a rise of a quarter of a percentage point when the Fed's policy makers meet at the end of the month.
Like many of his colleagues, Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, expects the central bank to push rates up yet another quarter-point later in the year. "The question now," he said, "is what will the Fed do after that" second rate increase.
The new data and growing concern about how far the Fed might go to slow the economy helped send interest rates higher again yesterday in a very jittery market.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond jumped to 6.16 percent, its highest since November 1997, as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 1 7/32, to 87 22/32. This selloff capped the worst week for bonds in three and a half months; the yield on the 30-year-bond was 5.96 percent last Friday. The yield has now risen nearly 1.5 percentage points from the 30-year low that was set last October.
And as interest rates moved higher yesterday, the stock market tumbled. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 130.76 points, or 1.2 percent, to finish at 10,490.51.
Talk of bond sales by big investors, which was not confirmed, and other rumors about hedge fund troubles pushed the bond market sharply lower in the afternoon. Some traders said the Japanese were selling, while others said that big money managers who had waited too long to sell were jumping in to stop their losses.
The market should continue to be volatile as investors await next week's report on May consumer prices, scheduled for release on Wednesday, and the appearance of Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, before Congress the next day. "There is a lot of nervousness about that," said Thomas Connor, head government trader at J. P. Morgan Securities.
The Consumer Price Index jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, and many analysts say that even if the May increase is more moderate, the Fed will still raise interest rates.
Based on various market monitors, investors seem to be expecting an increase of at least half a percentage point in the Fed's short-term target for Federal funds, which is what banks charge each other for overnight loans. But one barometer is leaning toward a bigger move. The yield on the two-year Treasury note jumped yesterday to 5.69 percent, which leaves it almost a full percentage point above the central bank's current Federal funds target of 4.75 percent.
If that yield moves just a little higher, it will indicate that some investors are expecting a total move of three-quarters of a percentage point in a series of steps. Such a move by the central bank would erase all three of the quarter-point rate cuts made last fall in a successful effort to calm global financial markets after the devaluation of the Russian currency and the near-collapse of a major hedge fund.
Mr. Barbera of Hoenig & Company contends that long-term rates could edge toward 6.50 percent, rather then the 6.25 percent peak many analysts are discussing. He contends that much of the rise in market rates this year reflects increasing demand for credit as the economy grows, not just concerns about inflation. If this is the case, he said, a revival of the global economy will put much more pressure on interest rates than expected.
The 1 percent increase in retail sales in May came after what had appeared to be two anemic months. But yesterday's report from the Commerce Department also included an upward revision in April sales, to an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent from the initial report of one-tenth of 1 percent. Retail sales rose one-tenth of 1 percent in March.
The May increase was led by a 2.7 percent jump in automobile sales, a 1.1 percent climb in sales of furniture and other home furnishings, and a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in department store sales, adjusted for differences related to the seasons, holidays and number of business days. Over the last 12 months, retail sales have risen 7.8 percent.
On producer prices, the increase of two-tenths of 1 percent that was registered in finished goods in May followed gains of half a percent in April and two-tenths in March. The big difference between May and April was the price of energy. In April, when the price of oil climbed above $18 a barrel, prices for finished energy goods, like gasoline, jumped 5.1 percent. But last month, when crude oil prices dropped back to $17 a barrel, finished-goods energy prices were unchanged. The gasoline index dropped 2.7 percent, after a record 29.1 percent increase, on a seasonally adjusted basis, in April.
The core producer index for finished goods, which excludes energy and food, depicted a more restrained situation. It has risen one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the last two months and through the first five months of the year is unchanged at an annual rate. In the same period the overall finished-goods index is up at a 2 percent annual rate after being unchanged in 1998.
"This lift in commodity prices and the revival in the early stages of processing does reflect that the global economy is on the mend," Mr. Berner of Morgan Stanley said, "and that is consistent with inflation moving higher."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Strong Consumer Spending Worsens the Interest-Rate Jitters;
Once Again, Wall St. Worries About Hedge Funds

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Investors stung by falling bond prices and a strengthening Japanese yen fled the Treasury market yesterday, driving the 30-year bond yield up to 6.16 percent, its highest level since November 1997.
The violent move, from 6.06 percent the previous day, was fed in part by Wall Street fears that some large investment portfolios known as hedge funds had encountered a fresh set of problems. 
 The day began rather calmly, with bond investors taking in stride the increase of 1 percent in retail sales in May and the rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in producer prices reported by the Government. Then, around midday, talk swirled about liquidations by hedge funds, which are open to wealthy individuals and institutions. This brought even more sellers to the market.
Many of the sellers appeared to be unwinding a type of trade that has been extremely popular among speculative investors in recent months, known as the yen-carry trade. An investor making such a bet borrows funds in Japan at prevailing interest rates there, which are far lower than those in the United States, and then uses the money to buy bonds in the United States. The difference between what investors pay in borrowing costs and what they receive on their investments has been alluringly high.
Or it was until Wednesday, when the yen began rallying strongly against the dollar. Then came the news on Thursday that the Japanese economy grew 1.9 percent in the first quarter of 1999, the nation's first growth reading in six quarters. The dollar fell 2.5 percent against the yen in four days of trading.
At the same time, United States bond prices were falling, and yields rising, on fears that the Federal Reserve Board would raise interest rates at its June 30 meeting. So any investor in a yen-carry trade was losing on both sides of the transaction: the stronger yen meant less for investors repatriating their funds into dollars and falling bond prices created losses as well.
Because the yen-carry trade has been so popular among speculative investors, such as those managing hedge funds for wealthy clients, the rising yen and declining bonds raised the specter of a financial market dislocation like that caused last fall by the near-demise of Long-Term Capital Management, a fund run by John Meriwether, a former Salomon trader.
Contributing to hedge-fund fears is the fact that some of the best-known portfolios have had a poor year, with some investors abandoning ship. Through June 3, Tiger Management, a hedge fund with $13 billion run by Julian Robertson, had lost 7.36 percent. Quantum Fund, the flagship fund overseen by George Soros, was down 14.8 percent as of June 4.
A spokesman for Tiger Management said yesterday that the fund had plenty of ready cash and could cover its investor redemptions four times over. The fund allows investors to exit only twice a year, and redemption requests for the latest period were due by May 31. People on Wall Street said that Tiger had experienced redemptions of about $1 billion.
In addition to performance problems of its own, the Quantum Fund of Mr. Soros has recently experienced management turmoil. Three high-level managers left last month, and Mr. Soros said at a news conference Thursday that he expected to hire new managers shortly to improve the fund's returns.
A person close to the firm said that it was also interviewing candidates to fill the new post of chief executive. The chief would run the operation and report to Mr. Soros.
People in the hedge fund community may also have been unnerved by the news that one of the biggest and oldest investors in the Soros fund was liquidating some holdings. Reuters reported that Haussman Holdings N.V., which manages $3.5 billion for investors, had reduced its Quantum Fund investment to 8 percent of Haussman assets, from 12 percent at the end of 1998. Hedge fund watchers say that the Haussman action is significant because the firm was one of Mr. Soros' earliest investors.
With memories of the rescue of Long-Term Capital still fresh, skittishness about hedge funds is to be expected, particularly among the banks and brokerage firms that lend to them. A senior bank executive with knowledge of Quantum Fund's portfolio said yesterday that lenders had very recently looked at the fund's positions. The lenders came away untroubled, this person said. Calls to the Soros Fund spokesman for comment were not returned.

Dow Jones Average Drops On Interest Rate Concerns
The Dow Jones industrial average declined for a fourth consecutive day after economic reports deepened investors' concerns that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later this month. The Dow average fell 130.76 points, or 1.23 percent, to 10,490.51. 
 Other market gauges also dropped. The Nasdaq composite index, which includes many computer issues, declined 36.74 points, or 1.48 percent, to 2,447.88, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 9.18 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,293.64. Page C3.
 
Companies Fight Computer Attacks
Boeing and other big companies worldwide scrambled to halt the spread of a malicious computer program that began infecting computers in Israel on Monday and spread rapidly into Europe and the United States, carried by E-mail. It destroys files created by Microsoft programs, including Word and Excel, and infects entire networks. C4.
 
Service Resumes on Ebay Web Site
The popular on-line auction service Ebay experienced one of the worst service disruptions in recent Internet memory, but resumed service late Friday. C14.
 
Hechinger Set to Close 89 Stores
The home improvement chain Hechinger filed for bankruptcy protection and plans to close 89 stores to focus on its healthier 117 outlets. Separately, Kmart said it would reduce its earnings by about $230 million because it had guaranteed the leases on the Builders Square chain, which it sold to a venture that was combined with Hechinger two years ago. C4.
 
Japan to Create 700,000 Jobs
With unemployment at a postwar high of 4.8 percent, the Japanese Government announced a plan to create more than 700,000 jobs. The measures would include offering subsidies to emerging industries like biotechnology and telecommunications. But the Government did not say how much it intended to spend, making it difficult to assess the plan's potential for stimulating the economy. C2.
 
Delta Delays Aircraft Order
Delta Air Lines said that it would defer an order for 11 Boeing 777 aircraft and that it would put two 777's that it already owns on the market because it could not reach an agreement with its pilots on pay scales for flying the airplanes. The pilots, calling the 777's moneymakers, have asked for $319 an hour to fly the 777, while Delta has offered them $239 an hour. C4.
 
New Nissan Chief Plans Changes
Carlos Ghosn, the former Renault executive who will soon be helping manage Nissan Motor, gave reporters a peek at where he hopes to help steer the Japanese car maker. C2.
 
Trade Victory for American Steel
The International Trade Commission, a Federal agency, handed United States steel producers an important victory, approving punitive tariffs to combat low-priced Japanese shipments. Tariffs ranging from 18 percent to 67 percent will be ordered by the Clinton Administration within weeks. C3.
 
G.M. Is Buying Arriva Fleet Unit
Arriva has agreed to sell its automotive fleet-management business to the finance subsidiary of General Motors for 235 million ($376 million). C3.
 
Tracking Pets by Microchips
Microchips are reuniting lost pets with their owners. At least 1.6 million American dogs and cats now have identifying chips the size of a grain of rice implanted in their shoulders, and three manufacturers -- Home Again, Infopet and Avid -- are working to develop an industry standard. Now, some people suggest, the same technology could be used at hospitals to be sure babies are not switched and later to help find children who are lost or kidnapped. A9.
