SECTION: Section 15; Page 18; Column 1; Women's Health 

LENGTH: 1279 words

HEADLINE: For Employed Moms, the Pinnacle Of Stress Comes After Work Ends

BYLINE: By ALICE LESCH KELLY; Alice Lesch Kelly, a Massachusetts writer, contributes to Health and Shape magazines.

 BODY:
SUSAN REICHE, a public policy manager at AT&T in Basking Ridge, N.J., can handle what work throws at her from 9 to 5. It's what life throws at her between 5 and 9 that pushes her to the limit.
After she flips off her office computer, she hurries to a day care center to pick up her 4-year-old son and then rushes across town to fetch her 7-year-old daughter from an after-school program. She makes a quick trip to the store to buy food for dinner, then zips home, where she lets the dog out, makes dinner, referees a fight or two between the children, feeds the dog, says hello to her husband, gives her son a bath, helps her daughter with her spelling words, tosses a load of laundry into the washing machine, plays with her children, reads with them and puts them to bed. 
 Finally, about 9 P.M., she has a minute to sit down. Whew.
"Before that, the feeling is that if I can sit down, then I'm not doing everything I need to do," said Ms. Reiche, 37. "Most of the time, I don't even have a chance to change out of my work clothes."
For working mothers like Ms. Reiche, the evening is when all the roles they juggle -- employee, mother, wife -- come crashing together as they try to separate from work, spend time with their children and reconnect with their spouses. It's also a short window of time for a long list of chores, from homework to housework.
"For most working mothers, this is the most stressful part of the day," said Alice D. Domar, the director of the Mind/Body Center for Women's Health at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, a Harvard University teaching hospital in Boston.
As Dr. Domar's research has shown, unrelenting stress is more than just an irritation. It can take a physical toll on a woman's body, weakening her immune system, threatening her cardiovascular system and contributing to headaches, backaches, gastrointestinal distress and insomnia.
Some of the factors that make up the evening rush could be described as the duel of the deadlines, the missing co-pilot and the unpredictable audience.
Just getting out of the office on time can jangle the nerves of the calmest of women, especially as the American economy has moved away from shift work. And day care centers and baby sitters can be just as unyielding, as any mother who's been scolded by a baby sitter or charged $1 a minute in late fees at a day care center that closes at 5:30 on the dot knows.
For Victoria Parker, 30, of Ipswich, Mass., the intense pressure of having to leave work precisely at 4:30 P.M., sometimes in the middle of a meeting, to get to her baby sitter's doorstep by 5:30 contributed to her decision to quit her job as a magazine editor.
"It was a frantic rush to get out of the office," Mrs. Parker said. "It was so stressful."
Even with a smooth departure, a woman can still feel stress when she gets home if her husband is unwilling or unavailable to help with child care, cooking and housework. And women whose husbands pitch in can still find themselves flying solo in the evenings.
The good news is that men in dual-income families are starting to catch up with women on household chores, said Rosalind C. Barnett, a senior scientist in the Women's Studies Program at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. Her research shows that women in dual-income couples do about 55 percent of the household chores, and men do about 45 percent.
But men who work full time put in an average of six to eight hours more a week at the office than women who work full time. Because those hours are usually tacked to the beginning or end of a man's workday, women must often take responsibility for feeding the children breakfast and dinner. "Men miss out on meal chores, and those tend to be very stressful," Dr. Barnett said.
There may be another reason husbands don't do more: their wives don't let them. In a recent study published in the Journal of Marriage and Family, researchers at Brigham Young University in Provo, Utah, concluded that about 21 percent of working mothers are "gatekeepers" who limit their husband's participation in household tasks and child care.
ACCORDING to Alan Hawkins, the director of the Family Studies Center at Brigham Young University and a co-author of the study, these mothers discourage their husbands from taking on household tasks and child care for several reasons: running the household reinforces their identity as mothers; they can't or won't let go of traditional conceptions of family roles, or their standards are so high that nobody else can satisfy them.
"Sometimes what it takes is being willing to turn a job over to your husband and letting him do it his way," Dr. Hawkins said.
Even if fathers help, working mothers say that planning and organization are crucial to removing stress from evening routines. But the unpredictability of children's behavior can throw kinks into even the most carefully engineered schedules. No amount of planning can prevent a poorly timed tantrum or bitter bickering between siblings.
"Children hold together until their parents pick them up from day care, and then they fall apart," said Carol A. Seefeldt, a professor of human development at the Institute for Child Study at the University of Maryland at College Park.
They fall apart for several reasons: hunger, excitement at seeing their parents, difficulty making transitions and fatigue, Dr. Seefeldt said. Fatigue may be the biggest problem.
"Many working parents keep their children up late at night so they can spend extra time with them," she said. "The child is often just physically exhausted."
Given the choice of dealing with all these stresses or making a job change, many couples opt for change. After her second child was born, Mrs. Parker, the former magazine editor, gave up her three-day-a-week job in Boston because the numbers didn't add up. After she subtracted day care costs of $4.50 an hour for each child from her part-time salary and added the stress of commuting two hours a day, she decided to stay home and squeeze in occasional writing and editing jobs during nap times and at night.
"I don't regret my decision for a minute," Mrs. Parker said.
Other parents -- particularly those whose high salaries give them financial flexibility -- reduce their hours and take a pay cut.
Dr. Barnett said the average highly educated professional works well over 50 hours a week, not including commuting time, but would like to reduce that commitment by at least 20 hours.
But what of women who can neither cut back on work nor quit their jobs? Psychologists and others who have studied work-life issues offered these suggestions for smoothing the evening rush hours:
* Learn to "compartmentalize." When you are home, try your best to put work behind you and to focus on being a mother rather than an employee. If that is tough, keep a notebook or recorder at hand so that you can capture work-related thoughts, then move back to the home task at hand.
* Take time to get reacquainted. Many women go home and immediately start on dinner preparations. But dinner is not the most important thing on the evening's agenda; reconnecting with your family is. Offer the children a nutritious, high-protein snack, like cheese and orange juice, to stave off crankiness, then focus on them for a few minutes. Then, start dinner.
* Cut corners wherever you can. Catherine Chambliss, a psychology professor at Ursinus College, near Philadelphia, recommends looking at your typical evening and asking this: What in our routine is the most onerous task? Can it be renegotiated in some way? "As the adult, you have the freedom to define the standard," Dr. Chambliss said.

9:00 P.M. -- Daughter goes to bed.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 51; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2906 words

HEADLINE: The Trailblazer

BYLINE: By Daniel Lewis; Daniel Lewis, a former cultural news editor at The Times, is writing a book on the California wilderness.

 BODY:
The day came when Mike Dombeck was asked if he could straighten out the United States Forest Service, and although he had no history of rash behavior, he said yes. Now he's in charge of 191 million acres of national forest -- about 8 percent of the United States. It's a nice job, in theory, for someone who grew up roaming the north woods of Wisconsin. In practice, though, just about the only trail Mike Dombeck ever gets to wander anymore is the Heartburn Loop, from his office near the Washington Monument to the halls of Congress.
On this damp February day, Mike Dombeck is bivouacked at a hearing before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, run by timber-state Republicans who are eager to give the Forest Service chief a few whacks. Nothing personal: "We like Mike," an aide to Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho explains. "We feel sorry for him." 
 The thing is, Western politicians have not quite given up hope of raising logging quotas in the national forests, where timber output has dropped about 70 percent over the last decade under the pressure of environmental lawsuits and Clinton Administration policies. They have received small comfort from Dombeck, by reputation an easygoing guy, who has turned out to be the most aggressive conservationist to head the Forest Service in at least half a century. Not, by a long shot, so aggressive as to suit all environmental groups. But enough to justify the hope that the long, mean-spirited battle for control of the national forests might finally be inching toward an environmentally sensible end.
The ostensible topic before the committee is the new Forest Service budget request, $3.48 billion for the fiscal year 2000. But there's another subject on the senators' minds, and that's the flurry of timber and mining reforms Dombeck put in place earlier in the month, when the Republicans were preoccupied with the wreck of the Clinton impeachment.
One week Dombeck petitioned Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt to ban new mining claims for 20 years all along the Rocky Mountain Front, an especially scenic and fragile belt where the Montana plains stop dead against the first rank of cliffs. The following week came enactment of the boldest stroke of forest policy in years: a moratorium on the construction of new logging roads in remote reaches of most national forests. That decision effectively blocked timber-cutting in a combined area larger than Pennsylvania.
Now Senator Craig is peering down at Mike Dombeck from the dais and gesturing with some papers he's holding in his hand, as if he might have somehow gotten an indictment. Actually it's a sheaf of editorials about the road moratorium, which has been criticized by Western newspapers and praised by Eastern ones, including The New York Times. "It would appear that you have been quite busy since we last talked, Chief Dombeck," Craig begins. "I am not sure whether you have been busier managing the national forests or creating a religious cult among East Coast editorial writers."
This is already sounding like good, nasty fun, and when in the next breath Craig sardonically refers to a "cult of Mike," some of the Forest Service staff members in the room simply break up. Dombeck, on the other hand, does a pretty good impression of someone who didn't get the joke. In fact, he is known around the office as something of a square: a fish biologist whose one-note speaking style and wire-rimmed glasses seem to have followed him into middle age all the way from high school.
Still, political theatrics aside, Larry Craig is on to something. It really is a little weird that Mike Dombeck has emerged from the middle distance of Government bureaucracy to become the environmental man of the hour. As he himself said after this particular three-hour grilling, "I'm not one that's naturally attracted to controversy." And, with his flat, Lake Wobegon voice, you believe him.
When Mike Dombeck took over the Forest Service in 1997, he inherited just about the biggest mess Government had to offer. The once-proud agency's bloated staff was famous for inefficiency, except when it came to doing exactly the wrong thing -- kowtowing to timber interests, abusing the land and punishing dissenters in the ranks. The results of poor stewardship were plain to see. The Forest Service's finances were such a swamp of sloppiness and fantastic accounting that it was one of only two agencies -- the other being the Defense Department -- that prevented the Federal Government from getting a clean audit.
The real estate was no better off. At least a quarter of all national forest land was in such poor shape from logging and neglect that conditions were ripe for cataclysmic fires -- by the Forest Service's own reckoning. Further damage was done by the construction of nearly 400,000 miles of logging roads, the deterioration of which has caused soil erosion and watershed damage on a grand scale.
To its credit, the Clinton Administration set about reforming the Forest Service early on, curbing logging and confronting racial and sexual prejudice among the agency's 35,000 workers. The Clintonites, however, managed to betray their efforts by going along with Congress in the short-lived salvage-timber rider of 1995. That deal, which allowed loggers to harvest diseased and damaged trees under a suspension of environmental regulations, quickly touched off a feeding frenzy on healthy trees as well, until public outrage reached a pitch that even Congress couldn't ignore.
Among other things, the salvage fiasco figured importantly in the undoing of Jack Ward Thomas, Mike Dombeck's predecessor. A biologist noted for his work on the spotted owl, Thomas was an outsider, known more as a hands-on forester than as a Washington bureaucrat. His three years in office were marked by attacks from environmentalists and by hopeless efforts to win the confidence of the agency's old guard, which had openly protested his appointment and sabotaged his initiatives.
So when Mike Dombeck, the acting director of the Bureau of Land Management, was appointed to head the Forest Service, many were quick to dismiss the chance of further reforms. When Dan Beard heard about Dombeck's move, he got depressed. Beard, a senior vice president of the National Audubon Society and the head of the Bureau of Reclamation for part of Bill Clinton's first term, had a clear impression of Dombeck as "a quiet, demure guy -- a Caspar Milquetoast." And he said to himself, "There goes any chance of reform at that agency."
The fact that Beard now thinks Dombeck is the best Forest Service chief since Gifford Pinchot, the agency's founding father a century ago, is evidence that Mike Dombeck learned something important from the ugly demise of Jack Ward Thomas: the chief of the Forest Service will be in trouble regardless of what he does, so he may as well be in trouble for things of his own choosing.
When I first met Mike Dombeck in June 1998, a year and half after he'd taken the job, he had already challenged the Republican Congress and his own bureaucracy on so many fronts that the momentum seemed to be shifting to his side. Besides pushing his road-moratorium plan, Dombeck had restructured practically the entire top layer of the agency, replacing all six deputy chiefs and replacing or transferring seven of the nine regional foresters, the top field officers in the far-flung system of 155 national forests and grasslands. He had also reversed the criteria for judging the performance of Forest Service officers in the field, putting things like watershed improvement and wildlife protection ahead of the traditional emphasis on meeting timber-cut quotas.
In response to the Forest Service's legacy of misleading bookkeeping, he had published figures that officially acknowledged for the first time what outside analysts had known for years: that the Forest Service lost tens of millions of dollars annually on logging operations.
Perhaps more important, he had survived with wry good humor the distinction of being, he says, "the first chief in history to appear before three House committees at one time," and in the process put to rest any doubts about his courage under fire. This was a joint hearing on March 26, 1998, prompted, officially, by a scathing Government audit of Forest Service fiscal and management problems and, unofficially, by cumulative anger over Mike Dombeck's reformist notions. There was no shortage of House members in the room, but characteristically, Representative Helen Chenoweth of Idaho, the Republican chairman of a subcommittee on forest health, was the one who cut the fastest swath through the underbrush.
At one point, she asked if Forest Service personnel were violating Federal lobbying laws by explaining the details of pending legislation in public forums. She demanded a list of organizations that had been contacted about such presentations. And then Congressman Chenoweth, as she prefers to be called, offered Dombeck a little friendly advice about the job he was doing: "I guess I want to say, this is awful dangerous for a man as young as you are, and has a long way to continue with your successful career. I am just speaking as an individual, but I feel very badly about this, and I hope that you will ask your people to re-evaluate this kind of activity."
"I particularly appreciate the compliment about my age," the 50-year-old Mike Dombeck answered.
Mike Dombeck has the patience of a fisherman, which is not surprising given the fact he was reared in the Chequamegon National Forest of northern Wisconsin. His parents ran a backwoods emporium there, the Moose Lake Store, where people from miles around came to get phone messages and buy everything from kerosene to bib overalls and milk and bread.
As a teen-ager, Dombeck worked two summers as a logger, cutting pulpwood and being eaten alive by mosquitoes before it dawned on him that the other local line of work, fishing guide, meant being on the big lakes where breezes kept the bugs away. Dombeck fished for 11 summers, earning money for college and going on to the University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point to study biology. It was there that he read "A Sand County Almanac," the classic of environmentalism by Aldo Leopold. The book turned the aspiring scientist into a conservationist, helping him to see science from "a philosophical angle" and to understand that the natural world is "all tied together."
While getting a Ph.D. in fisheries biology from Iowa State University, Dombeck also worked for the Forest Service as a field biologist. In 1989 he came to Washington as the agency's national fisheries manager. By the time of his appointment as Forest Service chief, he had a head full of ideas not just about the forests but also about clean water, open land and livability.
He also knew how to play well with others -- an important skill in an age of exploding Forest Service chiefs and spotted-owl skirmishes. According to Kathleen McGinty, a former head of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, the Administration chose Dombeck to lead the service because of his ability at the Bureau of Land Management "to not have train wrecks and lawsuits and everybody across the spectrum shouting." He was also picked, she adds, because he is "a person of great patience."
Francis Pandolfi, who until recently worked as a top aide to Dombeck, saw that patience applied to practical politics. "I've seen Mike with Larry Craig, with Helen Chenoweth, with a lot of people who are very confrontational," he says. "They fire these barbs at you, and they try to get you mad. Well, Mike doesn't get mad. I don't know what he does when he goes home at night -- takes the dog for long walks. But he will not return fire. He will recognize their point of view and respect it, and if he says he will look into something, he will look into it."
Like Gifford Pinchot at the turn of the century, Dombeck may be uniquely situated to repair several decades' worth of damage to the forests, rehabilitate streams silted by erosion and encourage the preservation of open space. To do all that, however, he must first change the economics of the Forest Service. The agency's budget is still organized like a perpetual-motion machine whose primary purpose is to sell trees for harvest, under the direction of the very forces in Congress that are demanding reform now that the harvest isn't paying sufficient dividends to their contributors and constituents.
Until the White House and Congress can agree to do things differently, regional forest managers will be forced to cut down trees to make money for other things they may want to do, including repairing environmental damage caused by cutting down trees. The imperative to keep logging is further reinforced by provisions that pay rural towns and counties 25 percent of the value of trees harvested in their area -- money used for schools and county roads. Although some of these places are coming around to Dombeck's argument that it makes no sense for the richest country in the world to make the quality of children's education dependent on cutting down trees, there's no immediate prospect of a change in that formula, either.
It's still not clear that the new way of doing business has worked its way through the ranks, despite Dombeck's frequent exhortations for people to get timber off their brains. This past winter, the inspector general of the Forest Service's own parent agency, the Agriculture Deparment, issued a finding of "numerous serious deficiencies" in all 12 of the timber projects inspected from 1994 through 1996. Though Dombeck took over in 1997, even diehard optimists don't expect the next report card to be all that much better. Bureaucracies simply don't turn on a dime.
Come summer, when most of the rougher congressional hearings have been held, even the chief of the United States Forest Service can spend time in the great outdoors. And thus it was last July that Dombeck and I hooked up in Great Falls, Mont., and drove across the Continental Divide into the Swan Valley. His idea, besides making a little time for fly-fishing with his daughter, was to drop in at district ranger stations for give-and-take sessions on the front lines -- in the places where the trees grow and the directives from Washington swamp the in-boxes and the townspeople are wondering what to do now that there are no more logs to feed the sawmills.
Lincoln, Mont., is such a town, though it will probably be known forever as the place where Theodore Kaczynski, the Unabomber, was found and arrested in April 1996. At the Lincoln ranger station, people greeted Dombeck like a comrade who had inexplicably returned from a suicide mission. They said "Mike" and "Chief" and "way to go" and punched him lightly on the biceps. And when the meeting got down to business, they didn't sound much like a bunch of foot-draggers standing in the way of reform.
One of those present was Tom Clifford, the supervisor of the Helena National Forest. A professional forester with 30 years of service, he was fed up with paperwork and the lawsuits from the left and the right over everything he planned to do. His budget had been subdivided into so many specialized categories to meet the demands of Congress and Washington program managers, he said, that the salaries of some of his staff were being patched together from six different accounts.
He was even more frustrated by his inability to do anything about cleaning up abandoned mines on forest property, which the State of Montana stood ready to help finance. More than 2,000 old mines are scattered on national forest land in Montana alone, and many of them are leaching toxic heavy metals into the trout streams that run through Norman Maclean's "River Runs Through It."
"Mike!" Clifford said at one point. "Somebody has to get passionate about this!"
A little later, up the road at Seeley Lake, Dombeck took questions from townspeople distressed by the local impact of logging restrictions. One woman put it in the plainest possible terms: "What is to become of us?"
This was no time to answer that everyone was feeling the pain, that trees from the national forests were now accounting for only 55,000 jobs nationwide and supplying only 4 percent of the country's wood-product needs and that the business of timber had changed fundamentally and forever.
"You have to think ahead," Mike Dombeck said. "You have to think about what you want this place to look like 20 years from now."
Dombeck himself is naturally at ease with the long view and willing to plug away until he outlasts the opposition, says Pandolfi, his former aide. Whether it is the old timber barons or environmental groups alarmed over the booming recreation business in national forests, it takes a long time to change things in Washington. "So over time," Pandolfi says, "he makes the changes that he thinks are right, follows the policy that he thinks is right, and by then these people have nothing left to say. They have gone on to other things."
Still, Dombeck's time could run out with the next Presidential election. And Michael Francis of the Wilderness Society speaks for many environmentalists when he wishes that Dombeck would be even "more daring and lock in more changes."
"He may have only two more years before Darth Vader comes in," Francis says. "Whoever Darth Vader may be."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 28; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Word & Image;
The Information Tyranny

BYLINE: By Max Frankel 

 BODY:
The Web nuts of America career around the Internet celebrating a new freedom to shout and spout anything into the ether: no more restraints on speech, they insist; no more hierarchy of thought. I hope they were watching old-time public television for just an hour last week, as Bill Moyers documented our society's slide into a new information tyranny, how corporate wealth is monopolizing debate, corrupting politicians and dictating policy. (The program will be rebroadcast tonight on WNET in the New York area.)
Moyers's thesis, oxymoronically titled "Free Speech for Sale," began with a modest morality tale about how special interests can easily mislead the public. It featured Cindy Watson, the first Republican in a century to represent her rural district in the North Carolina Legislature. Responding to her constituency, she helped pass a moratorium to limit the growth of hog farming until something was done to control the hog waste that spewed nauseating ammonia fumes across the landscape. 
 What the hog corporations did instead was lay waste to Cindy Watson, using their wealth to, essentially, buy the franchise. They spent $2.6 million on TV ads to smear her reputation and to conduct fake polls designed not to sample public sentiment but to ask suggestive questions about her "flip-flops" and "loss of the voters' trust." Unable to afford rebuttal ads, Watson drowned in the muck and lost her seat in 1996.
When corporate interests are unable to mislead the public, Moyers showed, they concentrate their wealth to intimidate Congress. The obvious example: last year's $40 million television ad campaign to redefine an anti-smoking bill as a "tax and spend" public burden. Even after victory, the triumphant industry kept buying commercials to assist the campaigns of loyal senators. No one bankrolled an opposing interest.
Finally, as if monopolizing media time were not enough, some corporate behemoths have bought favor and protection simply by buying the media. Vast conglomerates like Disney, Fox and General Electric have acquired control over entertainment hardware and software -- both the wires into every home and the images they carry. Not incidentally, that also gives them control over all the television news concerning their own conduct. That is why the giveaway of perhaps $70 billion worth of spectrum space -- reserved channels in which broadcasters will greatly improve and multiply their transmissions -- was passed last year with hardly any public discussion. The television networks allowed no serious on-air debate of the possibility of auctioning off such a valuable public resource.
In this distortion of democratic values, the obvious culprit is a legal mythology that grants every corporation -- already enjoying immortality and limited economic liability -- the same First Amendment rights of free speech as those guaranteed to individual citizens. That relatively recent reading of the Constitution produces a false equality between a corporate shout and every ordinary citizen's whisper.
As Bert Neuborne, the legal director of the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University's Law School, told Moyers: "The First Amendment is aspirational. It's romantic. It says that the purpose is to create a world in which people can speak freely and equally to one another. And therefore there's an obligation to step in at some point and even the playing field so that individuals can actually have real discussions and real debates. . . . What we've now got is not a real democracy with real debate but . . . a plutocracy in which money talks."
And on television, money talks out of proportion to all other speech. So it is the field of political talk on television that needs leveling. The great effect and high cost of television commercials corrupt all politics and most politicians. If the commercials cannot be banned altogether, they should at least be offset with free and fair time for opposing views. As Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, has said to the broadcast industry: "If you're getting that kind of income out of this advertising process, don't you have some obligation to provide some alternative access to the alternative points of view?"
The disingenuous opponents of such reform contend that "full disclosure" of who is paying for a propaganda blitz should suffice to keep politics honest. But the discovery that the "Farmers for Fairness" who knocked off Cindy Watson are really corporate hogs who stood to profit enormously did not come nearly in time to do her much good. After the 1996 election, even a paper with the resources of The Wall Street Journal needed more than a year to track the contributions -- including 165,000 individual checks for $5,000 -- that the hedge-fund industry made to Republicans to induce them to pass an amendment yielding huge profits to their industry.
As for legislated "limits" on corporate giving, they have been rendered farcical. Even corporations that bother to observe the limits now give to a wild variety of committees, party units, "issue" campaigns and far-flung state and local do-good organizations, all of whom invariably mock the law by directing the money to the campaign chests of specific candidates.
As has become painfully obvious, the winners of elections by these means are in no mood to change the rules. Can reform be accomplished without them? Can a victimized public somehow circumvent the cynical maneuvers by which both major parties protect their corrupting quest of funds and the influence of wealth? Under pressure from Congress, the Federal Communications Commission has refused to revive the fairness doctrine that once required broadcasters to give equal time to opposing views. But Dennis Morrisseau, now of Oak Island, N.C., once had an idea whose time may have come.
When I last addressed the issue, Morrisseau recalled that as a hugely "underfunded" candidate for Congress in Vermont 25 years ago, he sued the local TV station and the F.C.C. in Federal Court, demanding that they halt the overpowering commercials of his opponents. He said the great effect of television commercials and their high cost meant, in combination, that broadcasters were using the public air to establish an unconstitutional "means test" for achieving Federal office.
His case was thrown out, but "I still like the point," Morrisseau writes.
So do I, and so would most folks if they were told enough about how our information democracy has been hijacked by a corporate tyranny.

LENGTH: 1517 words

HEADLINE: ART / ARHITECTURE;
A Bridge Between a City and Its Self-Image

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
JEAN NOUVEL'S new design for a hotel and cineplex on the Brooklyn waterfront strikes me as one of the most imaginatively conceived pieces of architecture New York has seen in a long time. I've been groping for ideas to explain why. What makes a building contemporary? An impossible question to answer, but perhaps not a fruitless one to ask.
These days, architecture is not governed by a fixed set of guidelines, as it was, for instance, during the years of the modern movement. Buildings by Frank Gehry, Rem Koolhaas, Peter Eisenman, Steven Holl, Tod Williams and Billie Tsien, Daniel Libeskind, Philippe Starck, Rafael Vinoly, Zaha Hadid, Eric Moss and Thom Mayne are each highly distinctive in appearance and atmosphere, yet in common they can quicken your awareness of the present and its untapped possibilities. Where does that power come from? 
 Four thoughts. Walter Pater said that critics should ask: "In whom did the stir, the genius, the sentiment of the period find itself?" That's a start. Iris Murdoch, in "Metaphysics as a Guide to Morals," offered a more rigorous definition. "Serious art," she wrote, "is a continuous working of meaning in the light of the discovery of some truth."
John Summerson, writing in 1947, also emphasized the idea that contemporary art depends on a process of continuous working and on the value of discovery: "The most a critic can do is to sort out those aging ideas that get encrusted around past creative achievements and clog the proper working of the imagination in changing times." And if you can accept that architecture is a public art, indeed the most conspicuously public art of all, then I think that a statement by Arthur Danto also helps illuminate the meaning and and value of Mr. Nouvel's new design: "Public art is the public transfigured. It is us, in the medium of artistic transformation."
Actually, I can't improve on Mr. Danto's idea as a depiction of Mr. Nouvel's design. It's a bridgelike building for a city poised between being and becoming. It shows a city in transition from manufacturing to information as an economic base. It is playful, disciplined, sociable and pushy. It refracts into crystalline form New York's exquisite and infuriating narcissism, a town enthralled by its cinematic panoramas and animated by the yearning of its citizens to star in them. And the project has aroused local opposition that is a form of narcissism in itself. The opponents seem to be fighting their own reflection in a mirror.
The River Hotel is part of a plan to redevelop a 72-acre, former industrial area on the East River called Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass). The plan, which is seriously flawed, includes masses of retail shops, a redesign of the small, disheveled Fulton Landing Park, a small marina and parking garages. It also proposes housing a museum in the upper floors of Empire Stores, a handsome set of landmark brick warehouses that border the eastern edge of the park.
The Brooklyn Bridge Park Coalition, which opposes the plan, is right to demand that it be reconceived. The hotel itself is another matter. It deserves support.
Designed to resemble a pier, the hotel complex is in two main sections. A slim, four-story bar building is cantilevered from atop a square, five-story box. The bar projects 134 feet out over the East River and rises to a height of 100 feet, stopping just short of the Manhattan Bridge roadway. A glass bridge connects the hotel to a health club and spa across the street.
Mr. Nouvel has chosen a spare, industrial vocabulary. The facades are a simple grid pattern of gray metal fitted with floor-to-ceiling windows of white glass, so called because of its high degree of transparency. Because the hotel roof and its underside would be visible to bridge and water traffic, Mr. Nouvel has treated these surfaces as if they, too, were facades.
On the roof, instead of mechanical equipment, there are rectangular skylights and landscaped patios for the top floor. Three levels of public rooms, enclosed by seamless glass walls, are suspended beneath the building in a reverse ziggurat formation. On the lower of these floors a dance floor-size square of glass allows views of the river beneath.
The private rooms are minimally furnished and stylish. The east wall of each room is lined with mirror, doubling the skyline views. (Pray for soft lighting.) For the roof of the building, Mr. Nouvel has designed a tilted louver of reflective glass mirror that would cast reflections through skylights into the top floor rooms.
No museum has yet been named to occupy the old brick warehouses, and perhaps the proposal to put one there is redundant. The fact is that Mr. Nouvel has designed his cineplex as if it were a museum of contemporary art. And why shouldn't it be, if films are our leading popular art form?
The 16-screen cineplex is housed in a low, rectangular structure from which the projecting pier form is cantilevered. Mr. Nouvel has a thing about technological gimmicks (like the photosensitive irises installed in the facade of the Arab World Institute in Paris; alas, they occasionally break down). For the cineplex, he has installed windows behind the screens. These would be raised and lowered between performances, allowing stunning views of that other great collective art form: the Manhattan skyline. He has also proposed mounting screens on the exterior of the building, which could be used for artists' projects.
Dumbo's developer, David Walentas, the client, calls the design Main Street Pier. The architect himself calls it a bridge between two bridges. To my eye, the imagery looks nautical, as if the defunct Brooklyn Navy Yard nearby had gone into the business of floating hotels. There are open and enclosed promenades, reminiscent of those on the great trans-Atlantic liners. In the public corridors, surfboard-shape light wells are enclosed by shiplike railings.
In fact, the project should be seen as a step toward the time when New York is once again a great water city, with water taxis, ferries, piers, parks and other public amenities as well as new industrial uses enlarging the maritime dimension of New York.
Murdoch's idea helps illuminate this design. Mr. Nouvel has rethought the character of the city's waterfront at a time of change. If you look down on that site now (and it happens that I see part of Fulton Landing Park from my kitchen window), it is hard to believe that this is the ideal location for a luxury hotel. But you don't have to think ahead too far to glimpse a very different picture, of a time when water traffic will help to reshape the city's urban contours, just as the Brooklyn Bridge did years ago.
Will this project be built? Snowball's chance in hell, they say. But the ideas this particular snowball represents are not going to melt away. Mr. Nouvel has considered both the city's psychological and physical context. With its mirrors, its views, its white glass reflections, the building is a portrait of New York's narcissism at architectural scale. It brings to mind the famous Saul Steinberg drawing of New York's self-absorbed view of the world. Like that drawing, it counters self-absorption with self-awareness. It is a reflection on the city's narcissism, not a mindless indulgence in it. "The stir, the genius, the sentiment of the period" don't come more persuasively than this.
In this, it differs from the vanity that has trickled into architectural preservation circles in recent years. That threatens to turn an otherwise estimable movement into one of those aging ideas that get encrusted around past creative achievement and clog the proper workings of the imagination in changing times. The preservation movement has been a dominant influence on New York architecture for two decades, and its achievements are overwhelmingly constructive. But it has also come to include a sanctimonious Sacred Cow mentality. Perhaps the time has come to measure its environmental impact on the quality of New York's architecture.
Who doesn't love the kind of vanitythat we experience when we check out our reflections in fancy shop windows and see images of ourselves and the city overlaid atop pouty mannequins?This is one of the great urban pleasures. Mr. Nouvel's building will offer many similar moments throughout.
There's another kind of narcissistic outlook that is not so benign. According to this view, the public realm exists only to reflect popular prejudices, not to challenge or expose them. This strain has played a major role in New York's resistance to change. It has led to a confusion between architecture and architectural history, and in recent years this confusion has covered the city's architectural aspirations like a blanket of dust.
Mr. Nouvel's design and the opposition raised against it are both immensely narcissistic. The difference is that Mr. Nouvel knows what he is about. He has reworked meaning in light of the discovery of an important truth about the city today. That's what makes him a serious artist and his design an important work of art.

LENGTH: 1542 words

HEADLINE: In the Region /Connecticut;
An Amusement Park on a Roller-Coaster Upswing

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, after a decade of more ups and downs at the Lake Compounce amusement park than its 72-year-old wooden Wildcat roller coaster, the Pennsylvania-based Kennywood Corporation took over with a promise to return it to its former glory.
"We weren't smart enough to know that we couldn't make it work," said Harry Henninger, president and chief executive of Kennywood. "We really thought it was a wonderful opportunity, and fortunately we were right." 
 On Memorial Day weekend the park, which straddles the border of Bristol and Southington in central Connecticut, reopened for its third season under the new owners. Over the last couple of years, Kennywood has invested $35 million in the park. Orange stakes designate where the newest development will go -- a $6 million roller coaster almost a mile long built right into the side of the mountain that forms the park's western border.
The park's year-round workforce of 35 will swell to 1,000 by the Fourth of July weekend. While the privately held Kennywood does not release attendance figures, Richard L. Bisi, the park's marketing director, called the estimate of 500,000 visitors last year by the state's Department of Economic and Community Development "pretty close."
John Weichsel, Town Manager of Southington, said Kennywood has had a big impact on the town's economic base and, more important, has evolved into a good, stable neighbor.
"Before this group came in it was sitting there dormant," said Mr. Weichsel. "They've come in, paid the back taxes and kept up with their current taxes, and they've put in many improvements, so it's been very good in terms of tax revenues. They're now one of our top 10 taxpayers once again.
"And since they've come in, we have not had any complaints. The prior owner had rock concerts there, and every time they had a concert we got complaints about noise, and the traffic was devastating. With a family-oriented park like they're operating, we don't have those same kinds of peaks."
Mayor Frank N. Nicastro of Bristol said that since Kennywood took over Lake Compounce, two new factories have opened in town, and three more are under construction, ranging in size from 8,000 to 120,000 square feet.
"I think it's difficult to point to one thing that is improving the economy of Bristol," Mr. Nicastro said. "But let's say this -- Lake Compounce is providing a lot of people with jobs, especially young people in the summer, and that's going to keep them in town, and that's going to give them money to spend. I would say, in general, Lake Compounce has improved the quality of life all around."
Edward D. Dombroskas, executive director of the Connecticut Office of Tourism, said he expected the economic impact of the amusement park will spread over the next several years.
"When Lake Compounce first opened under the new management they were looking out 50 miles for their market area," Mr. Dombroskas said. "Now we're seeing signs that they're reaching out much farther. That means they're reaching into markets that tend to translate into overnight stays, and that's what spawns the development of new industries -- hotels, restaurants, gasoline stations, and that sort of thing."
Some of that development could be done by Kennywood. The amusement park uses only about 100 of the 325 acres Kennywood purchased in 1996, including the 28-acre lake that is the centerpiece of the park. Thomas A. Wages, the park's general manager, noted that some of the land was not developable, so it's hard to say how much room might be available for expansion. And he deflected questions about what Kennywood might be planning for the rest. "At this point, we're really concentrating on the park -- that has to be our primary focus for a number of years," Mr. Wages said.
What is now the Lake Compounce amusement park opened as a "picnic park" in 1846, a date that a succession of owners has said gives it bragging rights as the oldest amusement complex in the country. Even during the early 1990's when the park was failing financially, the owners opened it at least one day each year to retain that title.
THE first permanent building was constructed overlooking the lake in 1895, with a restaurant on the ground floor and a ballroom on the second floor. The park's famous carousel, constructed by Timothy Murphy of Savin Rock, a village of West Haven, was opened to the public on Memorial Day in 1911, and three years later the Green Dragon, an electric-powered roller coaster, was added.
When Kennywood took it over, a lot of the locals wondered whether Lake Compounce could be revived. There was speculation that an amusement park didn't make much sense in New England, where weather limited the operating season to about a third of the year.
But Mr. Henninger, Kennywood's chief executive, said the Connecticut market had been underserved by amusement parks for some time, so the market potential is significant. In many areas, the penetration rate -- the number of households in a market area that visit a park each year -- can be as high as 65 percent. He estimated it is less than half that in Connecticut.
"We've got to get people back into the habit of going to the amusement park for a day, and not thinking their only option is to go to one of the big destination parks for a week," Mr. Henninger said.
Kennywood was founded in 1898 by the Monongahela Street Railway Company, which opened an amusement park in Pittsburgh on leased land that was formerly a picnic grove operated by Anthony Kenny. The company purchased the Idlewild Park in Ligonier, Pa., 1983, and developed Sandcastle Park in Pittsburgh, a water park that opened in 1990.
 The Lake Compounce park reopened for nearly a full season in 1997, with more than a dozen new rides, including a giant Ferris wheel, the Zoomerang, a lakeside trolley, a ski-lift ride to the top of Compounce Mountain, and the Thunder Rapids Raft Ride that earned it five minutes in a one-hour Discovery Channel special on "Extreme Rides."
In 1998, additions included the Splash Harbor water park, the Tornado, and the Skycoaster, with a 180-foot free fall that is not for the faint of heart. In all, the first two years saw 25 new rides.
This year, the new attractions include Ghost Hunt, which combines a haunted-house ride with the interactivity of a video game, and the Mark Twain, a 70-foot paddle-wheeler boat that plies the waters of the lake.
But park officials are most excited about the new $6 million Mountain Coaster designed by Custom Coasters International, which will stretch from the log-flume ride at the north end of the park, nearly to the pavilions at the south end. It will be built right into the side of the mountain with a 140-foot vertical drop giving it speeds of more than 60 miles an hour.
Construction will start during the season with fences to hide the work from parkgoers. The plan is to leave in place most of the hardwood forest and the house-sized boulders that now cover the slope.
"We really think it's going to become the park's signature ride, and because of the way it will be laid out it will tie the whole park together," Mr. Bisi said. "They've told us they've never built one like it before."
Mr. Henninger said big destination parks can develop big rides, or lots of rides, to attract visitors.
"That's great if you have really deep pockets, but when you're operating a regional park on a tight budget, and trying to get the most from your investment, you have to make the most of your assets," he said. "In the case of Lake Compounce, the mountain is one of its assets."
The park is also starting to market more of its off-season time. The weekend before it opened, Pfizer, which has its chief research site in nearby Groton, brought 8,000 employees and family members to the park for a company picnic. Next Thursday and Friday will be the last days of its educational program, which ran two days a week since May 20 bringing in 2,500 to 3,000 school children each day from all over Massachusetts, Connecticut and New York.
"Students don't often get a chance to see math and science applied in the real world, but this gives them a chance not only to see it but have fun while they're doing it," said Marianne Dudac, the park's education specialist, and a longtime teacher in Bristol schools. For younger children it might be something as simple as figuring out change at the concession stands; for older students, roller coasters and Ferris wheels are a great way to teach about centrifugal force.
"Our mountain here is where two continents collided and there was an upheaval, so they get to see examine the striations in the rocks and see what geology is all about," Ms. Dudac said.
Mr. Wages, the park's general manager, said the hope was that the employees who came to Pfizer's picnic, and the children who visited in school groups would be back with their families.
"It's very difficult to say you have a trend when you only have two seasons under your belt, but the trend that seems to be emerging so far is a steady growth in visitation, and a reasonable level of repeat business within the season," Mr. Wages said. "We still have the capacity for quite a bit of growth, and we're on the right trajectory."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1739 words

HEADLINE: Trying to Halt the Push of the Bulldozers

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

 BODY:
FOR decades, Westchester County watched its farms disappear one by one as milking cows and apple orchards gave way to Cape Cods and Colonials in the march of suburbanization. But in the final year of the century, county officials are finally taking action to preserve what little remains of Westchester's agricultural heritage.
Late last month County Executive Andrew J. Spano sent a proposal to the Board of Legislators to establish an agriculture and farmland protection board. Such a board, authorized under state law, would be the first step in the county's battle to save farms. The board would then draft a farmland protection plan and could ultimately designate agricultural districts where farmers would have special benefits. 
 Mr. Spano said farmland protection serves several purposes. "It preserves open space, which is a priority for our administration," he said. "It preserves agriculture as a Westchester County industry, and it preserves tourism because people come up here to pick apples and strawberries."
The county initiative comes as Gov. George E. Pataki's administration has made millions of dollars available to local governments to save open space and support commercial farming.
Since 1996, New York State has awarded $18 million to municipalities to buy development rights on farms to keep the land forever in agriculture. More than half of that money went to protect farms on Long Island and in the Hudson Valley where development pressures are greatest. By establishing a farmland protection board, Westchester would be able to share those funds.
"Farms are under siege from developers who are throwing hundreds of thousands of dollars an acre at them to sell," said Pete Gregg, a spokesman for the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. "We're looking to prevent farms and open space from becoming strip malls. We're in a race here."
Westchester is one of only 10 counties that do not have an agricultural district. But farmers here are still able to take advantage of a state law that gives tax exemptions to farm operations with at least 10 acres and $10,000 in yearly revenue. Indeed, 84 farms in the county now qualify for the so-called agricultural assessment, receiving a substantial break on property taxes.
By the county's estimate, nearly 4,000 acres of farmland were lost between 1983 and 1994. There are 8,738 acres left, representing 236 agricultural business, ranging from horse farms and livestock operations to orchards and nurseries.
Establishing agricultural districts would extend some additional, modest tax relief to farmers. But mostly, officials say, it would free farmers from onerous local ordinances that hamper their ability to make money off the land, and it would also put new home buyers on notice that they are in farm country -- and that noise, dust and odors come with the territory.
"It's good that the county is beginning to recognize that there are some farms left and that they should remain," said Bob Stuart, who owns the 200-acre Stuart's Fruit Farm in Somers. The 171-year-old farm is one of the last in Westchester dating from the early 1800's, and Mr. Stuart's is the fifth generation to coax fruits, vegetables and flowers from the soil.
"A lot of people move here, and they don't know about orchards because they are coming from down-county," the 47-year-old Mr. Stuart said as he dismounted a tractor recently, a spring tan already well established on his lined face. "They don't have a clue about what it takes to run a farm."
While some counties have had culture clashes between farmers and suburbanites, with newcomers resenting the smell of manure or the torpor of a tractor on a county road, that has been less of an issue in Westchester because there are only a handful of livestock farms left, and many of the horse operations are pristine showplaces owned by gentlemen farmers and hobbyists. The nurseries are often little more than verdant markets where residents can buy petunias and arbor vitae.
Cabbage Hill Farm is an example of a spacious, well-maintained farm belonging to a retired couple, Jerome and Nancy Kohlberg, who developed it for their own pleasure and for public education. (Mr. Kohlberg was a founding partner of the investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.)
Nestled on 225 acres in Mount Kisco, the farm is home to rare breeds of cattle, sheep, pigs and geese -- mostly from Britain. The Kohlbergs enlisted Annie M. Farrell, an expert in sustainable agriculture and ecologically friendly farm practices, to oversee the farm's day-to-day operations. Although a neighbor recently complained about a couple of peacocks that had wandered off the farm onto her roof, for the most part Cabbage Hill's neighbors never see the livestock because the property is so large.
But one culture clash, in the town of New Castle, was the impetus for the county's efforts to establish a farm board.
The dispute between the farmer, Thomas Cogger, and the town, which acted after a neighbor complained about Mr. Cogger's animals, eventually went to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court. Last year the court upheld the town's enforcement of ordinances prohibiting horses from grazing within 100 feet of a wetlands and livestock from grazing within 250 feet of a property line.
Mr. Cogger said the town's actions forced him to move the cattle, horses, sheep and goats off his 11-acre farm in Chappaqua, a hamlet in the town of New Castle. Today, the only animals left are some ducks. "The town said the horse's hoofs would disturb the turf after heavy rains," Mr. Cogger said. "It's not real science. It's voodoo science, and it's a way to control your operation."
Had he been in an agricultural district, Mr. Cogger contended, the state's Department of Agriculture and Markets could have intervened on his behalf. And so began a crusade by Mr. Cogger and Ms. Farrell of Cabbage Hill Farm, who read about his situation in a local newspaper, to establish a farm board. The state law authorizing agricultural districts says local governments may not "unreasonably restrict or regulate farm operations" unless it can be demonstrated that "public health or safety is threatened." The state agency has the power to overturn a local ordinance after reviewing a case, but it is not at all clear that Mr. Cogger would have prevailed.
Mr. Gregg, the spokesman for the Department of Agriculture and Markets, called the state law establishing agricultural districts very powerful and said it had "protected farmers across the state from unreasonable restrictions." But he also said that farmers were still subject to state and Federal clean-water regulations and wetlands laws.
The impact of an agricultural district on long-established municipal ordinances is still a concern for some local officials. Michael B. Kaplowitz, a County Legislator who is chairman of the committee on the environment, said he strongly supported farmland preservation in theory, saying, "Open spaces are very soothing to the mind and spirit."
But Mr. Kaplowitz, a Democrat representing Somers, Yorktown and Croton-on-Hudson, said he needed answers on environmental impact before signing off on a farm board. "Are we in some perverse way watering down local protections?" he asked.
County and state officials argue, however, that a well-managed farm is less harmful to the environment than a subdivision of houses where septic tanks and lawn chemicals can cause problems. New York State and New York City both have programs to help farmers create natural buffer strips along wetlands and manure storage tanks to protect watershed areas. By establishing a farm board, Westchester will "have a framework for implementing 'best practices' on farms," Mr. Spano said, referring to environmentally sound agricultural techniques.
Establishing a farm board and possibly an agricultural district in Westchester, where zoning laws are both plentiful and painstakingly developed, could be a challenge, state officials say.
"We bring in two or three agricultural districts a year but in rural areas -- not urban areas where towns have code books the size of telephone books," Mr. Gregg said. "In Westchester there are a lot of layers of municipal government that all of a sudden would be subject to review. But a farmer in an urban county has as much of a right to be protected as a farmer in a rural county."
Town supervisors do not seem overly concerned about the possible curtailment of their precious home rule, however. Sy Globerman, Supervisor of North Salem, which has nurseries and horse farms, said that except for an ordinance about the disposal of manure, the town does not have laws affecting farms. "The town's happy to have them," he said. "They keep the land open, they hold down your school taxes and keep traffic down."
Clinton B. Smith, Supervisor of New Castle, where Mr. Cogger challenged the town ordinance, said the whole notion of home rule was vacuous in light of real estate development fueled by a thriving economy and rising land prices. "Home rule and local autonomy are things that everyone shouts from the rooftops about," he said, "but frequently we might not have as much autonomy as we think we do."
One of the biggest benefits of a farmland protection board would be the county's ability to take advantage of state money to buy development rights.
The state's Farmland Protection Program awards municipalities 75 percent of the cost to buy the rights, with the rest contributed either by the town where the farm is situated or by a farmland protection trust. In general, the state looks for commercially viable farms with clear lines of succession. The state funds come from the 1996 Clean Air-Clean Water Bond Act and the state's Environmental Protection Fund.
The county's decision to embrace farming is part of Mr. Spano's larger objective to preserve open space, and he has set aside $25 million to buy parcels of undeveloped land over five years.
Advocates of open space favor the county's efforts, saying it is important to have a mix of land uses, from parks to working farms. "Parks are wonderful and we all need them," said Caroline Niemczyk, a member of the board of the Westchester Land Trust, a nonprofit group. "But to have people who understand the care of animals and the cycle of seasons and the distinctions between types of soils is a remarkable thing in Westchester."

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Insurance for Redevelopers of Polluted Sites

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LAST year the state enacted the Brownfields and Contaminated Site Redemption Act, providing developers reimbursement of up to 75 percent of the cost of the completed cleanup if, among other things, the redevelopment project would generate new tax revenue exceeding the cleanup cost.
The measure also provides purchasers protection from private lawsuits related to past contamination problems and carries an assurance that the state will not sue once the site is cleaned according to the the state's now more flexible standards. 
 Still, industry professionals and developers said, redeveloping polluted sites could be like opening Pandora's box since the state's changes address neither the actual cost of doing the required cleanup nor protection from lawsuits if unknown contaminants are found.
One answer to both of these problems, say brokers and developers, is the use of private environmental insurance. The developers of two projects, one in Linden, the other in Edison, have taken out environmental insurance policies as they prepare to transform contaminated sites into mixed-used centers.
"The insurance allows all parties to distill what is a large unknown to a fixed cost and eliminate the potential of a huge loss due to liability," said Richard S. Greenberg. He is the president of Environmental Waste Management Associates, an environmental cleanup firm in Parsippany, who is involved in the cleanups of the Linden and Edison sites.
Insurance covering unexpected costs is based on an initial estimate of what it will cost to remediate known contaminants on the site. Any costs incurred over that estimate, less a deductible of 10 to 20 percent, depending on the insurer, are covered by the policy, which runs for the length of the cleanup. The policy can be tailored to protect buyers and sellers as well as lenders and tenants.
The policy can also be extended, or a separate policy can be written, to cover third-party liability issues, including property damage and the discovery of unknown pollutants. This coverage usually runs from one to five years, but can be extended to up to 10 or 15 years and can be put in place before during or after the cleanup.
Most insurers will issue policies only after the state approves a cleanup plan. But some will do so even without state approval if the consultant who did the estimate has a proven track record and will do the cleanup in accordance with state standards.
While insurers began offering such policies three years ago, they only started to be actively used in the last 18 months. Among the reasons, analysts say, is the scarcity of developable land. The state's efforts to return contaminated sites to productive use has increased developers' interest in such sites.
Moreover, they say, technological advances in assessing the cost of cleanups have made insurance companies more willing to underwrite such policies. As more policies are written, increasing competition among insurers has resulted in lower prices.
Major insurers offering the coverage include American International Group, or AIG, of Manhattan, Kemper Environmental of Princeton, a division of the Kemper Insurance Companies, and the Reliance National Insurance Company of Exton, Pa.
Environmental insurance is not inexpensive. Premiums for policies covering cost overruns generally range from 4 to 10 percent of the estimated cost of the cleanup, said Robin G. Kelliher, a vice president at the Morris Plains office of Willis Corron Corporation, an international insurance brokerage.
Among the factors influencing the premium amount are the amount of contamination and whether there is off-site migration of the contaminants through soil or groundwater. The minimum premium is $15,000, Ms. Kelliher said.
What buyers are paying for, said Joseph L. Boren, president of AIG Environmental, an affiliate of the giant insurer, is that the insurance "can help control the cleanup cost" and enable them to decide whether moving forward makes economic sense. Otherwise, he added, "if something is missed they could be left with tapioca."
NO one sees insurance as a panacea and even supporters say policies must be carefully read by buyers to make sure they are getting the coverage they need. Insurance also cannot be obtained for every deal, nor is it always necessary, Ms. Kelliher said, adding that for small cleanups of $25,000 or less insurance doesn't make sense.
State environmental officials consider the use of insurance complementary to their efforts to facilitate the reuse of the 10,000 contaminated sites in the state, down from about 20,000 in 1985. Of the remaining sites, 1,130 are brownfields, which the state defines as tainted, underutilized industrial or commercial sites.
"All of a sudden there's a ton of insurance products to deal with cost overruns," said Richard J. Gimello, assistant commissioner at the Site Remediation Program, part of the state's Department of Environmental Protection. "For projects with $1 million cleanups it sounds like a good idea because it gives developers a level of comfort that there is finality to their costs."
Such insurance played a role in the purchase earlier this month by Starwood Ceruzzi L.L.C. of 62 acres of the 188-acre city-owned Linden Airport along Route 1-9 in Linden. Part of the airport is used for small cargo and private planes.
Starwood Ceruzzi -- a joint venture of Ceruzzi Holdings of Fairfield, Conn. and Starwood Opportunity Fund V, an affiliate of Starwood Capital Group of Greenwich, Conn. -- intends to turn the 62 acres into a 650,000-square-foot mixed-use center, comprising a hotel, movie theater and retail shops. Financing for the $60-million project, the latest in a three decade effort to redevelop the airport, is coming from banks and investors.
Starwood Ceruzzi had 60 days to decide to redevelop the site and take on the cleanup associated with it. Mr. Greenberg of Environmental Waste Management Associates estimated the cost of cleaning the contaminants on the site and in the groundwater, which included chlorinated solvents left behind from the airport operation, at $1.2 million. To meet the partners' time frame the cleanup plan was designed without state approval, which saved time and will allow them to "hit the ground running," Mr. Greenberg said.
Louis Ceruzzi, president of Starwood Ceruzzi, added: "Whenever there is a significant cleanup we wring the risk out of it and protect our investors by buying insurance."
The partners paid a $100,000 premium for an insurance policy from Reliance that covers $1 million in unexpected costs. "The price of the policy was worthwhile when weighed against our ability to move ahead today with a $60 million project," Mr. Ceruzzi said. And since Mr. Greenberg told the developers that the cleanup would meet state standards, he said, "we will be able to avail ourselves of the state's reimbursement program and its assurance not to sue once the cleanup is complete."
The cleanup will be tied to the construction of the project, which is to start in 30 days. Completion is expected in 18 months, said Mr. Ceruzzi.
In Edison, Starwood Heller L.L.C. purchased environmental insurance to redevelop a 63-acre former Revlon complex, including the cosmetic giant's worldwide research and development center, near the intersection of Route 27 and Interstate 287.
Plans call for demolishing most of the vacant 750,000-square-foot former manufacturing plant and replacing it with 390,000 square feet of new and renovated industrial space, as well as building 150,000 square feet of retail space on 18 undeveloped acres.
Starwood Heller -- a joint venture between G. Heller Enterprises of Edgewater and the Starwood Capital Group -- also agreed to lease back to Revlon the 100,000-square-foot research component, as well as 75,000 square feet in an existing 250,000-square-foot office building. That four-story building will be renovated.
But for the $49 million purchase and redevelopment plan to proceed Revlon wanted to limit its exposure to cost overruns and legal liability involved in the $1 million cleanup of the site, said Scott D. Heller, executive vice president at G. Heller Enterprises. So, he said, the partners agreed to pay a premium of $100,000 to $200,000 to buy an $8 million insurance policy from AIG. The cleanup involves treating contaminants in the groundwater, including a variety of chemical solvents, Mr. Heller said.
"The insurance made cautious people more comfortable," Mr. Heller said, noting that without the policy Revlon would not have sold the property.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 3; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1228 words

HEADLINE: State's Economy Under a Microscope

BYLINE: By PEGGY McCARTHY 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT is still No. 1 in the nation in per capita wealth, but its population and jobs growth has been virtually stagnant over the past decade. Despite a strong economy and low unemployment, the state still has not recovered all of the jobs it lost during the recession earlier this decade.
At the same time, some Connecticut business leaders said that other regions of the country, such as northern New Jersey, have experienced rapid and dramatic growth spurts, giving Connecticut strong competition in per capita wealth and allowing those regions to compete better in the global and national economy. 
 With this as a backdrop, a group of business, political and government leaders, who don't always share the same positions, have joined together to help develop a competitive strategy for the state. Called the Connecticut Regional Institute for the 21st Century, the group has hired a strategic planning consultant to complete a $200,000, six-month study. It will be designed to assess the state in a broad context, as an economic entity in New England, the Northeast, and the global economy.
Institute members said the study will help assess whether improvements need to be made in the state's infrastructure and institutions, including transportation, higher education, and culture. The members predicted that the results of the study will show the need for economic cooperation among towns and regions of the state, and across state borders, something they admitted will be a hard sell in a state where home rule and local boundaries are so valued.
Nelson Griebel, chairman of the institute, pointed to a partnership among counties in North Carolina and South Carolina that has had some success. He said, for example, they avoided a damaging competition among area airports by assigning different aviation responsibilities to each.
Bruce A. Wilson, Bank Boston's president for Connecticut and western Massachusetts and a founder of the institute, said that there is no interest in dissolving political entities, just in getting cooperation among them.
"In order to compete in what is a rapidly emerging global economy, we need to think in more global terms," Mr. Wilson said. Otherwise, he added, the result would be stagnation and an absence of policies needed to "give us the ability to draw the kind of capital into development projects we need when competing with other regions of our own country and on a worldwide basis."
He said Connecticut's cities are key to any strategic plan. "Without our cities surviving, we don't survive economically," he said.
Mr. Wilson said the institute also wants to insure that "the region is competitive for those who are here already. Obviously, we want to encourage continuing investment, continuous growth, creating a climate that makes it conducive for businesses to be created, develop, and grow here."
Matthew Nemerson, president of the Greater New Haven Chamber of Commerce and a member of the institute, said while the economic growth of other regions, such as the Midwest, can be compared to rapid elevator rides, Connecticut's economy has been on a roller coaster that has landed virtually where it was at the beginning of the decade.
Mr. Nemerson said that while many Connecticut residents are comfortable, the future won't be as bright without planning and aggressive action.
"Clearly, Connecticut is very attractive to a more mature audience of talent," he said, referring to established workers who can afford to live in the state. But, he added, expensive land and housing are barriers for recent graduates of colleges and graduate schools. "We know we're not moving in young people from other parts of the country and we know we've got a drain of our own college kids."
Michael Gallis, the Charlotte-based strategic planning consultant hired by the institute, said Connecticut's situation is part of a phenomenon prevalent in much of the Northeast.
He said that 30 years ago, sociologists declared that the Northeast was the economic leader of the country. The result, he said, was that many in the Northeast took that fact for granted, while those in other regions of the country were motivated to aggressively work to grow.
And, with the fall of the Soviet Union and the onset of the global economy, he said, results elsewhere in the country have included a bustling port in Baltimore, massive office space expansion in Washington, and a booming Midwest capitalizing on the North American Free Trade Agreement and serving as a conduit for goods traveling between Canada and Mexico.
Other areas of the country have also taken steps to meet demands of a global economy, such as making their ports deeper, improving their rail capability to accommodate double-decker rail cars for freight, and expanding airports, Mr. Gallis said.
Mr. Gallis said his study will try to answer the following question: "Is there such a thing in economic terms as Connecticut?" Among other things, he will look at why businesses chose to locate in New Jersey instead of Connecticut and the role of colleges, universities and major hospitals, which he called "an increasingly important part of the region and are seldom brought to the table."
He said the study he is doing in Connecticut and a similar one he's doing for Rhode Island can help provide "a huge opportunity to create a New England-is-back movement."
He said "at this moment of change, there are enormous new opportunities at the same time the region is facing enormous new threats."
Members of the Institute visited Charlotte, N.C., last September to see results of the Charlotte Partnership, a regional initiative involving counties in both North Carolina and South Carolina, said Mr. Griebel, president of MacDermid Inc., a specialty chemicals company in Waterbury. He noted that "one example they use, which is good or bad depending on how you feel about professional sports, is they are convinced that the only reason they ended up with a National Football League franchise down there is they approached the N.F.L. as a region, not just the city of Charlotte." The region is one of Mr. Gallis's clients.
Mr. Nemerson said even organizations like his chamber of commerce are "dinosaurs" because they are geographically bounded institutions at a time that regionalization is seen as the key to economic survival. He said, for instance, instead of Bridgeport and New Haven competing and worrying about such issues as which city's baseball team, the New Haven Ravens or the Bridgeport Blue Fish, gets larger attendance, they should consider themselves part of one economic region.
He said members of the institute "realized when looking at the next 100 years we're all in this together. We're all little dots in the global map. We have to band together to be any kind of a destination that would be noticed."
The institute was started by executives of Bank Boston. Its members and funding sources include the state and city governments, Chambers of Commerce in Bridgeport, Hartford, New Haven, Norwalk, Stamford, and Waterbury, the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, Connecticut Business and Industry Association, regional planning agencies and councils of government, economic development organizations, the New Haven Foundation, and several businesses. Mr. Gallis is expected to have a report completed by October.
