HEADLINE: The Local Club Of Back When (Loud 'n' Dark) Is Right Now

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FRIED 

 BODY:
IN every version of the basic rock star myth, there is the Local Club Where They Got Their Start. The Beatles had the Cavern Club. Bruce Springsteen had the Stone Pony. Those are the early days, and in most versions of the story, it is not just an innocent time, but the rough-edged moment of first inspiration -- the moment that gives rise to another rock cliche: Sure, they're good now, but you should've seen them Back When.
The Pony is closed, but through the efforts of a few true believers who refuse to accept the economic realities of running a small rock club, Back When can be found right now at several other spots in New Jersey. 
 A young couple walks in to a darkened room and the temporary blindness is more than made up for by the overload of sound, which they can feel in their ribs as readily as they can hear it. The volume overpowers everything, including the otherwise bracing smell of beer and cigarettes. The couple turns the corner in the small, L-shaped room and just as they lay eyes on the band playing on the low, dimly lit stage, the sound and the musicians come to a dead stop.
For a moment, the room is completely, almost implausibly, silent. Then the crowd, standing, staring, filling half the room, begins to make some noise. They either clap, or if their hands are busy with a drink, shout out. The four sweaty musicians crank it up again, the crowd remains rapt, and the two newcomers glance at each other and nod. They've stumbled on to something. And for less than the price of a movie.
This is a scene often repeated at the venerable rock (and blues) dives of New Jersey: The Court Tavern in New Brunswick, the Brighton Bar in Long Branch, Maxwell's in Hoboken and the Stanhope House in downtown Stanhope.
There are many other bars featuring live music, but these are the ones that are in it for the long haul, presenting the best talent they can find -- whether on the way up, the way down, or just cruising.
Tony Pallagrosi, whose company Concerts East books many of the national touring acts in the area, calls them "irreplaceable."
"They're held together by blood, sweat, love and a few tears," Mr. Pallagrosi says. "It's people hanging in there for next to no money. It's absolutely a labor of love."
It doesn't always start out that way. Bob Albert was about to join the Jesuit Volunteer Corps (like the Peace Corps but harder to get into), when his father asked him to come home to New Brunswick to help with the bar, which has been in the family since 1961. Though reluctant to give up the plans he had made at Marquette University in Milwaukee, he came back in August 1981. Four months later, the Court Tavern was booking live bands.
The pleasure-and-pain principle of rock and roll -- tinnitus, unsteady income, sleep deprivation, and other forms of self-abuse -- comes to mind as Mr. Albert recounts the highs and lows of rock club life with equal enthusiasm.
The worst night: mid-80's a band that shall go nameless for the sake of family values totally destroyed the bathroom.
"The bass player blew up a urinal with an M-80," Mr. Albert recalled. "The cops were there 20 times. There were 80 kids on skateboards outside, there were fistfights."
A member of the opening band, the Serial Killers from Philadelphia, worked in sausage factory, he said, and brought condoms filled with sausage meat to throw into the audience. "The floor was slick as ice."
Mr. Albert remembers ruefully: "Dad knew most of the New Brunswick cops. He wasn't too happy."
He speaks with equal awe of the best night, which also comes immediately to mind. Local favorites, Crossfire Choir, were headed for the big time in the mid-80's. One Thursday night, they opened for Culture Club at an arena in Atlanta. By Saturday the band was home at the Court. "They blew the roof off the place," Mr. Albert said.
It takes only about 25 people in the back room of the Court Tavern basement to make something happen, though the room will hold several times that. Nirvana played the club. It was -- and occasionally still is, though unannounced -- the Back When place for New Jersey's own The Smithereens.
When asked about the economics of it, no one complains. "It's a flux business," says Jack Monahan, who was laid up in a hospital with a broken leg in Portland, Ore., when he decided his wandering days were over and he wanted to return to the Brighton Bar, where he had hung out as a high school rock musician.
"Making the rent is tough,' Mr. Monahan allows, referring to the financial obligations of his bosses, Greg Macolino and James Connelly, fellow musicians and friends of his.
But a return on the investment is not the main motivating factor. Mr, Macolino admitted that he had dreams, not daydreams, but night dreams, of owning the bar, which has been a launching pad for area bands since 1984. "I grew up in that place," he said.
After 11 years of booking three to four bands a night, five to seven nights a week, Mr. Monahan has no trouble picking his magical moment: the night he booked three funk legends -- T.M. Stevens, Bernie Worrell and Will Calhoun.
His worst night: "Two nights ago. I had a local band and an out-of-town band. The local band brought in one paid person. The out-of-town band brought in three they'd met at another bar across town."
On a recent Saturday night, Rare Form from Portland, Maine, spewed out a furious roar of spleen and post-modern metal to a crowd of about 20, not all of whom appeared to be aware of the slim but viable chance they might be seeing some kind of history in the making.
Mr. Monahan performs his poetry now instead of his music, and he describes booking as another creative outlet. "Once a month," he admitted, "I have a total crisis and want to quit."
Why doesn't he? "I don't know how to do anything else," he says.
From Mr. Pallagrosi's view, Mr. Monahan is also performing a service. "He's mining the street," he says
Doug Vizmuth, the Court Tavern booker for the past three years, spoke of the pressures of needing to bring in bands that bring in customers. The soundman, doormen, bartender all get paid, even if the band's cut of the door doesn't buy them a tank of gas.
"It's a battle," said Mr. Vizmuth. "It's never been easy."
A moment later, though, he says, "We've been lucky."
As a musician who first started playing the room in 1981, Mr. Vizmuth has seen the business rise and fall. These days, it's on the rise again.
He credits the club's longevity to having the best sound system in the state. Bryan Bruden, a former booker and disc jockey at WRSU, the Rutgers University station at 88.7 FM, explains why he loves the place -- even though they fired him.
"Any freak is welcome," said Mr. Bruden, "a dude in a three-piece suit on down."
The club that has done the best at making a reputation for itself has not been spared the economic roller coaster ride. Maxwell's of Hoboken has shut is doors twice since it began offering live music in 1978: once in the early 80's and again last year after a brief and disastrous incarnation as a microbrew pub. Now the club is back in the hands of two musicians, Steve Shelley (Sonic Youth), Dave Post (Amazing Incredibles) and Todd Abramson.
It's Mr. Abramson, the booker for more than a decade, who is credited by music people throughout the state with maintaining the international cachet for a room that is essentially, like the others, a black box.
Initially, the bands came because they were offered not only a meal at the restaurant, but a place to sleep in one of the railroad apartments upstairs. Bands don't stay there anymore, but every band in the club circuit wants to play the room anyway. And it is up to Mr. Abramson to decide who will get the honor, and, if need be, go after the acts he thinks belong there. How does he know what bands to book?
He speaks self-effacingly in his habitual just-woke-up-from a nap voice. "It's various things," Mr. Abramson says. "Including luck. I pay a little attention to a lot of things. The big thing is to have the bands' experience such that they want to come back."
Mr. Abramson traces the Glory Days of the business to a Bruce Springsteen song of the same name. The video for the song was filmed at Maxwell's in the mid-80's, and for a year, he says, the crowds; "were unreal. It didn't matter who was playing."
These days, with singles bars pulling crowds at the other end of town, the frequency with which Mr. Abramson asks himself why he keeps doing it is "a few times a night." But, he adds, "on a good night, I can still feel the rush I did when I was 13 or 14 and just discovering the pure adrenaline rush of great rock 'n roll."
The bands today, he insists, are often as good as their famous predecessors: R.E.M., Oasis, the Offspring, Korn, Lucinda Williams, Sonic Youth, Nirvana, Smashing Pumpkins, Shawn Colvin, the Wallflowers. Is it hard to choose his favorite nights? No: Jimmie Dale Gilmore, and the Cowsills.
"I was not a huge fan of the Cowsills and was not expecting anything, but it turned into one of those magical nights," Mr. Abramson says.
A bit of magic arrived at the Stanhope House on a recent Friday, when Little Sammy Davis, the upstate New York bluesman, surprised Big Mike and the Perpetrators in the middle of their second set. Playing harmonica through his nose, doing a solo rendition of the Air Force anthem, and gently coaxing Mike's band through some blues standards, Mr. Davis raised the crowd noise level in the room significantly.
Earlier in the night, a lone dancer, eyes shut, swayed in her floor-length neo-hippie skirt, while small groups stood with their drinks chattering by the bar opposite the stage. In between, guys with long hair and biker tattoos, and others who looked like they got home from work and quickly changed into their Friday-night jeans, leaned back at their tables and kept an eye on the band. With a little help from Sammy Davis, several couples eased onto the dance floor, some keeping apart, rock and roll style, some holding tight for a bit of the old time bump and grind.
"It's a juke joint without the rowdiness," says Ev Myers, the owner, quoting Robert Lockwood Jr., one of the blues giants who has graced the Stanhope stage. The list of blues alumni, from Pinetop Perkins and John Lee Hooker to Muddy Waters and Stevie Ray Vaughn, is easily as impressive as the list of rockers who have been through Maxwell's, and Mr. Myers appreciates the comparison.
"We think like Maxwell's does," he says.
In most ways, however, the Stanhope stands in contrast to the rock dives. The blues draws a steady crowd, and that takes away much of the pressure of keeping up with what's hip and viable among the new acts. And unlike his counterparts, Mr. Myers came to the bar band business relatively late, and with fewer of the financial worries that come with the trade, thanks to his retirement from a successful career in banking. Then there is the place itself.
Where most clubs seem almost to make a point of creating atmosphere out of nothing but beer and noise -- and perhaps some dimly lit paintings, or a crude rock and roll surrealist mural on the wall -- the Stanhope House is itself a landmark. Dating from 1790, it has been a stagecoach stop, general store, tavern, possibly a brothel, and has numbered Babe Ruth among its regular customers. The low, wood ceilings offer reasonable acoustics, wonderful atmosphere and a bit of a challenge for someone as tall as Big Mike. The stage is in the front, and the original front porch can be seen through the more recent but equally roadhouse-worthy stained glass windows.
Mr. Myers is a big man with a big, bright grin, and a loud, deep, Brooklyn voice. He and his wife Maureen sit at a table in the middle of a side room of the house that functions as their box office, stamping hands as people come in, chatting with regulars and new faces alike. The walls are covered with publicity photos.
He bought the club five years ago, in his mid-40's, because he wanted out of the high-pressure life and he loved the blues. "My proudest moments are when I have what I call the originators," Mr. Meyers says. "Homesick James was 91 years old when he played here. Pinetop Perkins, 88. Homeboy Edwards was young when he played here; he was 81."
His worst night? "No bad nights," he says with a laugh. He is confident enough in his performers to offer a guarantee. If you don't like the band after three songs, you can leave and have your money back. "Very few exercise that option," he says.
The bottom line for every nightspot is, of course, selling alcohol. Each of the rooms has seen a past life as an old man bar or a shot-and-beer joint. Maxwell's was named for the Maxwell House factory, now closed, across the street, which provided its share of the clientele. But the people running these businesses today have committed themselves to accomplishing something more than selling drinks. "I love live music," says Mr. Monahan of the Brighton Bar.
There are a few others who seem to have the long haul in mind. Scott Stamper of the Saint in Asbury Park has been at it five years, and sounds as dreamy as the rest when he recalls Joey Ramone's sold-out solo show in the summer of 1997. Andy Gesner books an average of one night a week at the Budapest Cocktail Lounge in New Brunswick, makes no money, and says, "Why would I want to stop?"
 
Don't Know the Lyrics? Don't Worry. Who Does?
ARE you staring at a gold-spangled green lame jersey you bought at a yard sale earlier this spring and wishing you had just the right place to show it off?
Are you dying to go out for a drink but too hot and sticky to think about changing out of your tank top and shorts?
Are you alone and thinking about people watching?
Are you and your gang looking for a place to get loud?
If you are over 21, or maybe 18 and ready for some soda, the rock clubs of New Jersey beckon. But first, some notes and suggestions for those venturing out for the first time, or the first time in a long while, based on observations over recent months:
Anyone concerned about not understanding the music should not give it too much thought. The lyrics are indecipherable to everyone, and 90's bands, by and large, recycle, in various combinations, pop-rock styles of the last 40 to 50 years. Or as Todd Abramson of Maxwell's put it, "We basically still have people on stage wailing away on guitars."
Familiarity with the bands is helpful but not necessary. Any original music group playing in the better clubs has at least something going for it -- amplification, for one -- and all the musicians in every band are up there because at one point or another, however long or short, they felt the tremor of rock inspiration move through their fingers or vocal chords. In the small clubs, they are certainly not doing it for the money.
Sets are generally short, from 30 to 45 minutes, and there are several bands each night. Bookers try to create harmonious intersections of bands and styles, which provides a useful framework of theme and variation.
The material varies wildly between and within sets, but careful listening is almost always rewarded with a few gems: a cool riff, a brilliant hook, a moment of pure undiluted attitude.
Careful listening is not required, of course, although it is suggested that everyone avail himself or herself of the opportunity to make noise -- from growling woofs to sharp squeals, with voices, beer bottles or hand claps -- not so much as to express appreciation for the musicians as simply because it is one of the few places where such behavior is perfectly acceptable, almost required.
Going to even the most expensive rock club is much cheaper than a sporting event and you don't have to wait for your team to score before you let loose. You don't even have to wait at all.
Enormously casual as a rule, clubs are still perfect places to wear an outlandish outfit of any kind. Or not. From the impossibly sexy to the utterly bland, everything works. Any hairstyle will pass. Any age will pass too. Youth culture victims of every era from the past 50 years are common.
Volume is a constant complaint, but is easily handled by ear plugs, either the commercial foam variety, or a bar napkin ripped in quarters, rolled into balls and stuffed gently into the ear canal. This goes a long way toward preventing ringing ear syndrome, and anyone worried about appearing wimpy will notice many of the sound men, bartenders and musicians doing the same. On the other hand, a night of people watching in most clubs will turn up someone standing calmly by the stage with his ear directly in front of an amplifier.
I N the past, the recorded music played between sets was as loud as the bands, but now there is generally a respite. One reason is that rock clubs are not places for dancing anymore. Dancing happens in the dance clubs, trendier places where many of the democratic principles mentioned above do not apply.
The physical movement in rock clubs is mostly heading bobbing, swaying and foot tapping. Certain styles of rock are still accompanied by certain physical responses -- punk music and moshing, ska and skanking -- but the crowds must be in sufficient numbers, and even then, the energy of a riled up crowd these days seems to implode more than explode.
There are not always many places to sit, though sitting on the floor, off the beaten track, is certainly acceptable.
For the seeker of summer entertainment, the quality of air-conditioning is often a consideration. The wall-mounted units in most clubs do a good job early in the night and a passable job as the crowd fills in. If the place is mobbed, everyone will sweat no matter what time of year, but this is, after all, something of the point.
Second-hand smoke is an issue, but what is a nightclub without wisps of gray curling across a beam of light?
Finally, there is no burst of energy in the world like a live band wailing in a small room. JONATHAN FRIED

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Bumper Crop of Homes in Dutchess County

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

 BODY:
LIVING in Dutchess County is a long way from Bensonhurst, says Michael Boccia, but he's successfully making the transition.
"I can't get the same Italian bread and pastries we used to in Bensonhurst," said Mr. Boccia, a lawyer, "but they have Arthur Avenue bread here, which is pretty good. It's second best to Bensonhurst." 
 Mr. Boccia is now semiretired and working part time as a lawyer in Poughkeepsie. He and his wife, Jennie, moved to Poughkeepsie to be nearer their three children and seven grandchildren. Two of the couple's sons live in Dutchess, and one is across the Hudson River in Orange County.
"It was actually the kids who found the house for us," Mr. Boccia said, referring to the three-bedroom ranch the couple purchased at Vassar Oaks, a 150-home subdivision in Poughkeepsie.
Vassar Oaks is one of close to 40 new developments now under construction in the county, 18 of which have 20 or more units, according to Steven Domber, president of Prudential Serls Prime Properties, in La Grange.
"I've been involved in Dutchess since 1981," said Lenard Thylan, president of the Manhattan-based Thylan Associates, which is developing Vassar Oaks, "and the past three years is the strongest market I've ever seen."
There were 820 residential construction permits issued in 1998, compared to 584 in 1996, an increase of more than 40 percent, according to the Marist College Bureau of Economic Research, based in Poughkeepsie.
As a result of its relative proximity to New York City (Poughkeepsie is about an an hour and a half away on Metro-North's Hudson Line), coupled with the availability of land at more affordable prices, developers have hopscotched over Westchester and Putnam Counties to land in Dutchess.
"There's no more land in Westchester, " said Mr. Thylan. "And even if you found some, it would be so expensive, you could only afford to do a luxury development. And not everyone can afford a $750,000 house."
"Dutchess," said Ann Conroy, economic development zone coordinator for the county's Office of Economic Development, "is now in the process of a resurgence since the downsizing of I.B.M. The local economy has been recovering, and with it the residential market as well."
At one time, I.B.M. provided 60 percent of the county's manufacturing jobs and 20 percent of the overall jobs. Then, starting in the early 1990's, the company singlehandedly caused a regional recession when it laid off more than 20,000 employees in its Fishkill, Poughkeepsie and Kingston plants.
In the last few years, however, the county has seen a resurgence in its economic base. In 1998 it had 18,600 manufacturing jobs, compared to 17,500 in 1996, according to Marist College.
"We've been gaining new businesses," Ms. Conroy said. "and businesses in the county have been expanding. And even though I.B.M. laid people off, it continues to maintain a major presence in the county, with two plants, one in East Fishkill and one in Poughkeepsie, employing over 11,000 people."
I.B.M. has also announced plans to build a $700 million microchip facility in East Fishkill. Originally scheduled to open later this year, it has been delayed, Ms. Conroy said, and "should happen, we've been told, within the next 12 to 18 months." It is expected to employ 400 people.
Mr. Domber of Prudential Serls said his office is now marketing 26 new construction projects, ranging in price from just under $100,000 for a one-bedroom condominium to $600,000 for a four-bedroom colonial.
In addition to Vassar Oaks, Mr. Thylan's company also has a 150-unit town-house development called Cedar Valley nearing completion in Pawling, at the eastern side of the county and an hour and 40 minute commute to Grand Central, or an hour and seven minutes to White Plains, on the Upper Hudson Valley line. "People are coming here because there's no place where a family can afford to live in Manhattan, New Jersey, Long Island and Westchester," Mr. Thylan said.
Since opening sales in 1997, Mr. Thylan has sold 100 houses at Vassar Oaks and is now building its fifth phase, which consists of 26 houses. Of that, 13 have already been sold. The two- to three-bedroom homes are selling for $159,900 to $231,900.
Site clearing has begun on phase six, which will have 19 homes. "We're about one year ahead of where we thought we'd be," Mr. Thylan said.
His company is now completing Sparrow Ridge, a 116 town-house development in Kent in Putnam County. "Putnam is mostly wetland," Mr. Thylan said, "and while there's open land, it's not buildable."
That leaves Dutchess, which used to be considered too far for commuters. "Now people are willing to travel a little longer in order to have a house they can afford," Mr. Thylan said. "They don't want to be house poor."
Mr. Thylan said that the buyers at his two Dutchess projects run the gamut from young families to empty-nesters and retirees. "The Boccias are very typical of the empty-nester buyer," Mr. Thylan said. "They bought a ranch, which many of the older buyers prefer. We also have houses with the master bedroom on the ground floor, which is preferred by many people without children living at home They can close off the top floor when no one is using it. Young families prefer to have all the bedrooms on the second floor."
Out of the 100 buyers at Vassar Oaks so far, 20 percent are over 50 years old and half are between 35 and 50, Mr. Thylan said. The balance are between 20 and 34. "Some," according to Laurie Webber, sales manager for the development. "work locally at I.B.M. or they're attorneys with offices nearby." But 35 percent of them commute to Manhattan, she added.
It takes Carla Ribaudo-Ballon one and a half hours to commute from Vassar Oaks to her job as a purchasing assistant at the United Nations. She moved from Ossining, in Westchester, and she would have preferred staying there, but "I couldn't afford it," she said. "The taxes alone for a house were $6,000."
She also considered New Jersey, but thought the commute was harder from there than from Dutchess. "From here I take the Hudson line" of Metro-North "and I'm right downtown," Ms. Ribaudo-Ballon said. "At least it's an easy commute."
She and her husband, Luis, bought a three-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath home that now sells for $197,900 without customizing. "I thought it made more sense to get new construction," Ms. Ribaudo-Ballon said, "so there will be no headaches, at least for a long time."
The growing number of commuters willing to live an hour plus out of Manhattan is definitely a major factor in the resurgence of the residential market, Ms. Conroy said. "But that alone would not account for the increases in residential construction that we've seen. It had to also be accompanied with real growth in the local economy."
An example of that is a 361-unit apartment complex, called the Jefferson at Merritt Park that just started construction on a site across from where Gap Inc. is building a 2.57-million-square-foot distribution center in Fishkill. The new facility is expected to add 1,475 new jobs.
"The Gap's plans definitely made the site extremely attractive to us," said Andrew Kaye, regional managing partner for JPI, a developer, based in Irving, Tex. "We were also looking at I.B.M.'s plans to build their microchip facility nearby."
THIS is JPI's first project in Dutchess, Mr. Kaye said. "There was already a demonstrated success for a project like this with Avalon View," Mr. Kaye said, referring to a 288-unit rental project in Wappingers Falls, completed in 1993 by Avalon Bay Communities, which is based in Alexandria, Va. "We thought the time was right simply because of supply and demand. The county has seen healthy rent growth and high occupancy."
At Jefferson Park, one- to three-bedroom apartments will rent for $895 to $1,320. Mr. Kaye said the project would be marketed to corporate relocations, "professionals on a one- to two-year contracts," he explained. "And also empty-nesters, who are downsizing and might have a second home in Florida."
Jefferson at Merritt Park is expected to be completed by next February.
One of Dutchess's largest residential projects is also a microcosm, in many ways, of its recent history. Dalton Farm, a 540-unit development now under construction in the Town of Beekman, in the south-central part of the county, had its beginnings in 1988.
The original plan called for a mix of town houses and detached houses, selling for $148,000 to $280,000. A total of 120 homes were sold before the project went into foreclosure in 1994.
"A lot of factors conspired to cause the project's demise," said Michael Meyers, president of Farm Development, one of three local builders hired to turn the project around. The others are Creekview Homes and O'Donnel Development. "There were certain problems with the original design. Then, of course, there was the downturn of the real estate market."
The project has been entirely redesigned and is now envisioned as a complex of four discrete neighborhoods, one with two-bedroom town houses, priced from $140,000 to $205,000, and two with detached homes, with three to four bedrooms, priced from $202,500 to $300,000.
The fourth neighborhood is called the Commons, and it is designed to offer a feeling of life in a small village. "There's a village green, sidewalks and streetlights" Mr. Meyers explained. "The homes will be oriented toward the front with set-back garages to keep them out of sight." Its 82 three-bedroom houses will be priced from $162,500 to $182,500.
"The Commons is a first for Dutchess," Mr. Meyers said. "The village-type design has never been tried before. We only got the models up three months ago, and already we sold 18 homes."
Mr. Meyers is also a partner on another project that's a first for Dutchess, one that caters to the trade-up market. The Legends at the Beekman Country Club, in East Fishkill, is a development of 250 single-family homes to be built around a golf course. The first phase of 31 homes has begun construction.
Four-bedroom colonials and Victorians will be offered for $389,900 to $575,000. "This type of project just doesn't exist in the county now, where there's really no new trade-up development," said Mr. Domber of Prudential Serls, whose firm is marketing the project. Of the present trade-up market in new houses, Mr. Domber said: "It's really topped out at around the $275,000 to $300,000 range now."
Mr. Domber said that the time is ripe for a project like this, "due to Dutchess's stable employment and the fact that there's more affluence due to the stock market." With the golf-course project, he said, "People will now have a place to trade up if they decide to sell their home."
He expects the first phase to attract primarily the local buying market, "where there's tremendous pent-up demand," Mr. Domber said. "This is a seven- to eight-year project; eventually we plan to also draw from Westchester. We think we'll attract the commuter who finds that they can get the same house here as in Westchester, but for $150,000 less. Right now we think there's a market for higher-end homes in Dutchess, It's the next new thing."

HEADLINE: Old Charleston Navy Base With New Controversies

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE 

DATELINE: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
SPRAWLING on a spit of land beside the Cooper River, the 1,600 acres of the now-closed Charleston Navy Base have come to represent both an enormously valuable development opportunity and a continuing focus of charges, countercharges and commercial and political maneuvering.
With three miles of riverfront, the former base represents hundreds of millions of dollars of real estate. It includes 21 first-rate piers and some 600 buildings, from large warehouses to a handsome colonial-style home that once housed admirals. 
 So far, 68 companies with a total of 4,200 workers have moved into two-thirds of the buildings. But very public controversies have surrounded the competing plans of a handful of companies and agencies for some of the prime facilities within the base.
Even selecting who would oversee the redevelopment of the former base was not easy. In most communities where a base is closed, the redevelopment agency is run by a city or county. But here, the Charleston Naval Complex Redevelopment Authority, which oversees the site, is run by the state.
The base is in this city, but just a few miles upriver from Charleston, which by size and tradition has been the most influential in the region. Three counties are close to the base, and all entities wanted a say in what would become of the land. So the counties, cities and state all have representatives on the redevelopment board.
"It is uniquely Charleston," said Jack A. Sprott, the director of the redevelopment agency. "There's a lot of jealousy between Charleston and North Charleston and the political folks said this was the best way to handle it, and it's worked pretty well. The only drawback is the city has zoning powers. We've had our lumps and bumps, but we're in lock step now."
Perhaps the sharpest controversy involved how the north end of the base would be used. The City of North Charleston wanted residential development. But the Charleston Naval Complex Redevelopment Authority wanted a cargo operation. The city eventually won. According to James C. Bryan, chairman of the authority, his agency expects to begin work on a waterfront park, commercial buildings and residences for North Charleston within a year.
The announcement in 1993 that the base would close was met with instant panic. "It was gloom and doom all over Charleston," said Mr. Sprott. But in the six years since, Mr. Sprott said, community leaders have managed to regain the 25,000 jobs lost when the base closed with the arrival of new businesses throughout the region, while the redevelopment agency continues to foster commercial operations at the former naval complex.
In a recent visit to the site, William J. Cassidy Jr., deputy assistant secretary of the Navy, called the redevelopment authority "a model for the country" in base reuse, according to Mr. Sprott.
The companies that set up shop at the former base perform a wide range of services, from repairing ships to preparing small boats for overseas shipment.
The Navy shipyard here was established in 1902. During World War II it grew to become the Navy's third largest home port, behind Norfolk and San Diego. When closing was announced in 1993, 80 ships and submarines were based at North Charleston. The Navy turned the base over to the redevelopment agency in April 1996, but the final land conveyance has not yet taken place.
MR. Sprott said his agency put off those negotiations, preferring to find tenants first. The first was Charleston Marine Manufacturing, a consortium of area businesses that leased the largest drydock to repair ships. Ten government operations occupy space at the base as well, including the Border Patrol, the Postal Service and the state's National Guard. Soon, the South Carolina State Ports Authority plans to operate a cargo facility here, a plan that has resulted in a fair share of controversy.
Initially, the state's Ports Authority, which operates four terminals in the Charleston area, wanted to set up a break-bulk facility on the northern tip of the base.
But the City of North Charleston had other plans for the site. Mayor Keith Summey said he wanted the area for residences, businesses and a waterfront park. The base includes the only waterfront in the city. Plus, he said, the site abuts a residential area.
"It had," said Mr. Sprott, "been a break-bulk facility for 100 years and we thought that was the best use. But the last thing we wanted was a controversy with the city."
He worked out a deal to lease land at the center of the base to the Ports Authority, leaving the north end for North Charleston. The north end is now the subject of a lawsuit by Braswell Shipyard, which contends that the redevelopment authority did not execute an agreed-upon sublease there. Mr. Sprott declined to comment on the matter.
In still another dispute, Carolina Marine Handling, one of the base's current tenants, has charged that the agency had improperly signed leases and has not been diligent in protecting assets left behind by the Navy. When the military closes a facility, more than just buildings are left behind. Pencils are even left in holders, said James A. Kenney, a former chief of staff at the base.
H. R. Stender, president of Carolina Marine Handling, said he had applied to lease the north end of the base with virtually the same plan originally espoused by the Ports Authority, but was turned down. Now, he said, the authority will soon move onto the pier in the central part of the base that he had been using for his break-bulk operation, whose lease was canceled.
"One billion dollars is being chipped and diced and given out to friends of the former Governor, David Beasley," said Mr. Stender, whose family has operated stevedoring companies in the Charleston area for three generations.
He also maintains that the redevelopment agency and the Ports Authority have conspired to drive him out of business, using his own business plan, which he sent to the agency when he applied for the land at the north end of the base. The regional state legislative delegation has looked into his claims but found them groundless. But four of its 20 members have asked for a review by the state's Legislative Audit Council, which is scheduled to begin its study later this year.
The State Law Enforcement Division has turned over its report on Mr. Stender's allegations to the State Attorney General but the results have not been released.
Mr. Sprott calls Mr. Stender's claims "garbage."
"We've done more for him than anybody," Mr. Sprott said. "We had a fair competition and we did not pick him. Now he's irate."
Mr. Stender operated a break-bulk facility, loading frozen chicken on ships destined for Russia, up until a few months ago on one of the base's prime piers, called Zulu. But his operation dwindled as word spread that the company he leased from -- Charleston Shipbuilders -- was out of business and that that company's lease would be canceled. Charleston Shipbuilders intended to overhaul Navy ships to supply electricity to rural areas in South America, but the one ship it completed was not able to supply power adequately.
Mr. Sprott said the Zulu Pier would be used by the Ports Authority, but Mr. Stender was offered the use of another pier.
Byron Miller, a spokesman for the Ports Authority, said that its terminals were public "and anybody and everybody can come and operate there."
He said that his agency had been interested in operating another break-bulk terminal for years. He also rejected Mr. Stender's charges of political favoritism.
Mr. Sprott said the next step in redevelopment would be to negotiate the cleanup of the property and get the land deeded to his agency. The agency wants not just to occupy existing buildings, but to build new ones.
Now considering leasing space on the base is a company that wants to convert the former Navy hospital and a number of smaller buildings into a film studio, at a cost of $30 million. The company would rent out space for the production of commercials, television shows and feature films.
The company, called Carolopolis, is making "a serious effort to develop a motion picture studio in the state," said Isabel Hill, director of the South Carolina Film Office.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
A Walk To the Past Demands Good Shoes

BYLINE: By FRED B. ADELSON 

 BODY:
"MOST people experience architecture at 30 m.p.h.," the architect Robert Venturi has often said. Reading a building at 3 m.p.h. on a walking tour offers an ideal opportunity for both social storytelling and esthetic appreciation. From the sidewalk, history is within arm's reach.
With an impressive variety of architectural styles, New Jersey can be a real show-off, offering guided tours, spring through early fall. From Warren County to Cape May County, these architectural experiences spotlight the man-made environment of daily life. 
 Some are single, one-day events. The New Jersey Historical Society will explore three centuries of building along Washington and Military Parks in Newark in a public tour on June 15, but it is willing to repeat the walk for groups of 10 or more. The Manhattan-based Adventure on a Shoestring has presented many programs in New Jersey over 36 years; in the coming weeks, it will examine the evolution of the Ironbound district of Newark on June 19 and Hoboken on July 10. Preservation New Jersey, a Trenton organization that promotes awareness of the state's historical sites, plans an intriguing tour of Ocean Grove and Asbury Park, neighboring communities that demonstrate profound differences in architectural history, city planning and preservation, on Sept. 25.
Architectural tours are often more than educational; at $5 to $13 a ticket, they can provide revenue for research and restoration. From July 8 to Sept. 2, the Long Beach Island Historic Preservation Committee offers weekly three-hour trolley tours of historic sites on the island that have raised $4,000 in the last four years. On the opposite side of the state, every Saturday (weather permitting) until Oct. 30, Help Our Preservation Effort conducts 90-minute guided walking tours of the limestone buildings constructed by Moravians who settled in Hope Township in 1769. More than two dozen extant structures reveal the legacy of a planned community built in the German vernacular mode, and "we need to do a lot of walking to pay for Long House," which the group bought last year, said Mio French, its vice president.
The Foundation for Architecture presents about 400 events a year in Philadelphia and its environs, including two tours in New Jersey, guided walks along Kings Highway in Haddonfield. One of them, "Historic Haddonfield," covers only a few suburban blocks but several centuries of architectural styles, from Georgian to Beaux-Arts (the Borough Hall).
On a Saturday afternoon in May, Deborah Troemner, a volunteer guide who was one of the tour's creators, began the "Historic Haddonfield" walk with a discussion of the Sarah Hopkins House, and one of the oldest residences in the town. Like many historic Haddonfield homes, it is not at its original site; moving was more economical than rebuilding.
In talking about the Revolutionary War, which the Quakers referred to as "the commotion," Ms. Troemner used modern real estate jargon to emphasize that Haddonfield had "location, location, location." The town was strategically positioned between Burlington and Salem, two major settlements in South Jersey. Indian King Tavern, the most significant historic property discussed on the tour, was Haddonfield's premier 18th-century establishment. It became the state's first official historic site in 1903.
Old buildings are merely a picturesque backdrop in Haddonfield, but in Cape May architecture is big business. The Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts has aggressively organized tours to promote the city's substantial concentration of Victorian-era frame buildings, as well as Federal, Craftsman and even post-modern buildings. (A house on Hughes Street proudly announces, "Built 1986.") The town's compact layout encourages walking along the veranda-rich residential streets.
Wearing a jaunty bow tie and a straw boater, Ray Maher, a guide for the arts center, led an informative tour around the eastern end of Cape May's Historic District on a weekday in May. The nearly two-hour walk began at the Stick Style guardhouse, which originally stood in Fairmount Park in Philadelphia but is now an information booth on the Washington Street Mall. Mr. Maher explained that Cape May, one of the nation's oldest seaside resorts and a 19th-century summer retreat for several Presidents, experienced numerous fires, including one that destroyed about 35 acres of prime real estate at the height of its popularity in 1878. Since "everybody who was anybody in the United States came to Cape May for the summer," the town was immediately rebuilt, he said.
Carpenters, not architects, were responsible for most of the houses in Cape May, and those craftsmen with access to pattern books were only too willing to demonstrate their virtuosity at using a saw. With the sun hitting the gingerbread trim, Mr. Maher pointed out how the shadows cast by the applied wooden decoration "give more bang for the buck." He also brought to the group's attention several houses that had the amenity of a small bathroom on stilts added on the side. Nineteenth-century advertisements urged people "to trade the path for the bath," Mr. Maher said.
The growing popularity of the automobile in the 1920's led to the decline of Cape May when people began driving to resorts up the shore, but in the 1950's the family car, with its tail fins, contributed to the development of the Wildwoods and their motels with eye-catching neon signs along Atlantic and Ocean Avenues. Just as Victoriana defines Cape May, doo-wop is Wildwood.
Fortunately, the Bobby Rydell-era buildings still retain much of their authenticity. From the sleek lines and chrome of Ernie's Diner, manufactured by Mountain View Diners of Singac, Passaic County, to the sharp angles of the Casa Bahama motel, with its fiberglass palm trees at poolside, the man-made landscape nostalgically evokes those "wild, wild Wildwood days." Some elements of New Jersey's rich heritage may not be monuments in the history of architecture, but as social documentation they provide a fascinating and tangible expression of culture from bygone days.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK/THEATER;
Feeling a Bit Snubbed? New Jersey at the Tonys

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
IT started with a smile and a wave to the cameras, for all those people, millions of them, out there in the dark. So what if it was really an act of disrespect to the greatest American actress of all?
And it ended with the sort of dread omission that mortifies producers and disappoints theatergoers. For almost three hours in between, last Sunday's Tony Awards telecasts, produced to show off Broadway at its best, was, as one television reviewer dubbed it, the "Death of an Awards Show." 
 The woman who smiled and waved was Uta Hagen, the first lady of the theater, whose performance in "Collected Stories" at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick this season, after an Off Broadway run, was an object lesson on how many more truths can be exposed in a single role, given time. But Ms. Hagen had already received her special Tony for lifetime achievement in the theater -- off camera. Giving thanks, she spoke (yes, off camera) of her "destiny to answer my calling to a noble art, the theater, the stage."
"It's sad to think our destinies are now ruled by economics," she said. "I want to throw out a battle cry to those who think as I do: that this transcendental art will become insignificant only as we allow it to do so."
And then the cameras rolled just in time to capture Ms. Hagen, smiling and waving from the audience, for perhaps 32 seconds, thus relegating to insignificance her battle cry from the soul. Talk about rude.
The fleeting glimpse of Ms. Hagen and Ricardo Khan's delirious acceptance of the award for outstanding regional theater on behalf of Crossroads in New Brunswick, where he is the artistic director, were both seen during the first hour, on PBS. New Jersey theater figured prominently in the Tony race in what television deems to be the more important categories. But choreographers, orchestrators, lighting, costume and scenic designers, directors of plays and musicals, book writers of musicals, and composers and lyricists were all consigned to PBS.
The important Tonys were handed out during the second and third hours, on CBS, which had an estimated audience of 6,860,000 on Sunday, down from the last two years. Productions emanating from New Jersey -- "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" and "Electra," both co-produced by Eric Krebs of Highland Park -- were up for seven Tonys. Best book was not won by "Blues," which came from Crossroads. Best revival was not "Electra," transferred to Broadway intact from the McCarter Theater in Princeton.
In the two prime hours, Mr. Krebs's productions lost all seven. But this is a year of few real winners, one that represented an impoverished Broadway season for new American plays and new musicals of any stripe. And the television show that is meant to celebrate the winners was the biggest loser of all, consisting of monumental gaffes and slurs -- to Off Broadway, in particular. The show was misconceived, miscalculated, underrehearsed and amateurishly executed. What a dubious accomplishment to make the self-possessed Kevin Kline, a presenter, appear helpless.
The last-minute omission of a number from "Blues" was the centerpiece of theater outrage all week. The television show was running overtime. Never mind that Isabelle Stevenson, chairwoman of the American Theater Wing, another lifetime achievement winner, went on interminably. Or that Barry and Fran Weissler, two of the six producers of "Annie Get Your Gun" (best revival of a musical) did a coy routine, unconvincingly and brashly displaying humility. Those indomitable theater zealots who lasted two CBS hours could add many more indignities; the list is very long.
So Mr. Krebs and all the other "Blues" producers may be consoled by the likelihood that, given the grim circumstances, few viewers would have been awake to see the number anyway.
Y ET every member of the "Blues" company could well have cause for singing the real lowdown blues of dashed hopes and broken hearts.
On Thursday, four days after Tony fallout and the investigation of legal action by the "Blues" producers, and the morning after the "Blues" cast appeared on David Letterman's "Late Show" to resounding cheers, Mr. Krebs said: "Letterman was terrific and useful; his audience is four million to five million. But if 1 out of 20 people watching the Tonys bought tickets, it would fill our show for over a year."
So goes the astounding numbers game of television versus live theater. Mr. Krebs is a gentleman and a businessman, and as a producer he must be a politician; therefore, he said he felt "just dandy." Ms. Hagen, with nothing to lose, no longer needs to play games. What she must be thinking would surely outroar the invective of Martha, the role she created in "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?"
"Blues" is holding on at the box office. Yet "You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown," a revival that won two Tonys and did have a number performed on the television show, and "Not About Nightingales," a play that won one Tony, are closing today. Perhaps the clout of a misguided awards system is on a downhill slide. And it's not just ratings.
Everything -- truly everything -- about the Tonys needs honest-to-theater re-evaluation. And the regional theater, which flourishes esthetically in New Jersey as well as nationwide, must not look to Broadway as a goal, as a lure or for any validation of any kind. Regional theater lives for and should be supported by its homegrown community. All the rest is vapidity.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Ties That Bind New Jersey Begin at the Hudson River

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: PRINCETON

 BODY:
For once, a tax even a Democrat can hate.
After squabbling over taxes and spending for years, New Jersey's Republicans and Democrats are as one when it comes to trying to force Gov. George Pataki of New York to give New Jersey commuters the same commuter tax relief he wants to give New York State residents who work in New York City. 
 Mr. Pataki's unequal treatment of people similarly situated, to quote the lawyers, is being committed by a New Yorker who once called himself "a Whitman Republican" when being like the New Jersey governor was a plus. Now Mr. Pataki is on one side of the fence and Governor Whitman, the Republican legislative majority, the Democratic minority and commuters down to the last straggler on the 8:24 out of Rahway are on the other side, fighting as one.
"Nothing unites New Jerseyans, Democrats and Republicans alike, more than being treated unfairly by New Yorkers," said Raul (Rudy) Garcia, the Democratic mayor of Union City who is also a member of the Assembly.
In Jersey City, Mayor Bret Schundler, a Republican, collected the signatures of 300 commuters, fodder for a class-action suit, in the days after Mr. Pataki announced his move, and none of the signers spoke of politics.
"The bottom line is that this is not partisan," Mr. Schundler said.
It is on the other side of the river, since Governor Pataki hopes giving tax relief to New Yorker commuters will win votes for Republicans next year, even if the statewide ballot in New York may end up being headed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, who is suing to stop his fellow Republican Pataki from ending the tax.
So the tax that has produced Republican disunity across the Hudson has produced unity among Republicans and Democrats on this side. But that has not meant there were not opportunities for headline grabbing by members of each party. When Governor Pataki signed the in-state tax repeal nearly three weeks ago, Mayor Schundler hastened down to the bulkhead at Exchange Place in Jersey City to cock a snoot at New York by dumping tea (Lipton) into the Hudson, and then announcing that only a lawsuit could protect his city's more than 25,000 commuters.
Democrats made similarly defiant noises, including, strangely, the cry of "no taxation without representation," as if paying a commuter tax ever purchased a New York ballot. Mr. Garcia even urged New Jerseyans to "stop rewarding rudeness" by boycotting New York. "Fuhgeddaboutit the Yankees and the Mets," he said in a news release, having a little fun. "Skip 'NYPD Blue' and tune into 'The Sopranos'."
In fact, as Mr. Garcia pointed out, the border war with New York has, like all wars, made profiteers of a kind out of the old waterfront cities that Mr. Garcia and Mr. Schundler lead. Each has received expensive new waterfront developments thanks to investment money fleeing the high rents and taxes of New York. And whatever the commuter tax bite, each benefits from the tens of thousands of resident commuters who get their pay from New York City employers.
"Quite honestly, the commuter tax is one of the things that has created jobs and economic development in our part of New Jersey," Mr. Garcia said. "We have a friendlier tax system than New York on several levels, so in that sense, New York has already helped us. But if they want to play politics with this tax and give New York residents a break, they are going to have to give it to New Jerseyans too."
The New Jersey Legislature has appropriated money and hired lawyers to sue Governor Pataki and New York State on behalf of the estimated 240,000 New Jersey commuters who pay about $110 million in taxes to New York City . Mayor Schundler, who is holding back on bringing his own suit while the state's lawyers make their case, maintains that the anti-Pataki position is such a constitutional lock that there is hardly any doubt about the outcome.
"This is such an open-and-shut case that if we don't seem excited about it it's because we're so confident we will win," Mr. Schundler said. All of the suits against Mr. Pataki's measure -- from New Jersey, Connecticut and Mayor Giuliani as well as a private suit -- have been combined before Judge Barry Crozier of the New York State Supreme Court.
Judge Crozier has said that he would rule by July 1, when the commuter tax is scheduled to cease for New York state residents. It is worth remembering that the matter is not about the legality of the commuter tax -- that was settled in favor of the tax, and against commuters, years ago. The New Jersey and Connecticut lawyers only want the court to force Mr. Pataki to give their commuters the same tax break he is trying to gain for his own residents.
And if Judge Crozier sides with his governor, and the appeals also go against the out-of-staters? Will the Democrats then wish they had not been quite so cozy with the Republicans on the commuter tax? After all, New Jersey has big United State Senate race coming up, and by making nice with the Republicans this year, the Democrats may be giving up a chance to make nasty next year about "who lost on the commuter tax."

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Not Ready To Press The Inflation Panic Button

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE bombs stopped falling on Kosovo last week. Japan's economy recorded its first growth in 18 months in the first quarter. Germany's industrial output is quickening, and its unemployment rate is falling. Yet the markets persist in brooding about the prospect of a modest hike in interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Recent price moves suggest that the bond market is convinced the Fed will raise rates. Partly in sympathy, stock measures like the Dow Jones industrial average have slipped 5 percent or more from their peaks. 
 It is not clear, however, that an increase in interest rates would be unremittingly bad for stocks. Robert Heisterberg, a senior vice president and chairman of the asset allocation committee of Alliance Capital Management, took some time last week to discuss that proposition. Here are some excerpts:
 
Q. Market interest rates have risen much more sharply from their troughs than they did in 1994 and 1997, the last two periods when the Fed tightened monetary policy. Has the increase been justified?
 
A. The bond market overshot by about 50 basis points on the downside last fall, because everything conspired to create a set of expectations that, in a medium-term sense, led people to believe we were about to enter a recession, if not a depression.
In terms of cyclical factors, I would trace the rise we have seen from a level of about 5 percent or 5.25 percent on the 30-year Treasury bond. That backup has been warranted. The American economy has continued to grow, and now we are seeing signs of growth elsewhere.
The news out of Japan is important. If they can sustain positive economic growth, it will do a lot for the Asian region and for the world economy. If others pitch in, it means America doesn't have to as much.
 
Q. In response to the crisis last year, the Fed cut short-term interest rates by three-quarters of a percentage point in a matter of weeks. Will it take back all of those cuts?
 
A. I would be surprised if they will be required to take back all of the 75 basis points they eased last year. However, I am quite confident they will take back one-quarter of a percentage point. At this point, it's a 50-50 proposition they will raise rates by another one-quarter of a point after that.
 
Q. Why do you think they will stop short of taking more dramatic action?
 
A. The fundamentals of inflation are still performing quite well. Inflation becomes a problem when it begins to influence decisions. When I start to see companies and consumers making decisions based on concern over rising prices, that is when I start to get concerned. I haven't seen that. Also, I think we will get some slowing in the economy during the second half of the year.
 
Q. Does the increase in interest rates we have seen, and may yet see, pose a significant threat to stocks?
 
A. Valuation levels right now are fairly lofty, and that makes stocks more vulnerable. But to say that interest rates are going to unglue this market is probably an overstatement. To make a strong negative case for stocks relative to interest rates, you would have to see rates go up considerably more than they have.
 
Q. Money is getting drained out of stocks that are viewed to be vulnerable to rising interest rates, like technology and financial services. But some of these companies performed quite nicely when rates were higher than they are now. What is your view?
 
A. A resumption of growth outside the United States has to be good news for multinationals and a number of technology companies, as well as some less exotic machinery manufacturers and capital goods makers. A good number of these companies were hurt by contraction in consumption spending in Latin America and Asia, and some were just shut off by the recession outside the United States, especially in the Far East.
The traditional view is that rising interest rates hurt banks and financial stocks. But most of these companies, if you study them closely, have been hell-bent on generating fee income, which is not sensitive to interest rates at all. Generally speaking, we think the valuations in this area reflect the old view about their vulnerability to interest rates, and not the new reality.
 
Q. Has the rise in interest rates caused you to alter your model portfolio?
 
A. In terms of allocation, we are closer to our long-term benchmarks now than we were a few months ago, but that is because, due to superior performance, we took some money out of the equity market.
Our allocation for growth-investor accounts is about 70 percent in equities, about 24 percent in bonds and the remainder in cash. We are modestly overweighted internationally, and our domestic equity positions are skewed toward a somewhat broader list of stocks than the large-cap growth stocks that have been driving the market. The market has broadened dramatically, and we have had to respond to that.

HEADLINE: Dick Morris, Say Hello To Mr. Wilde

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN

 BODY:
WHEN the eminent politician Sir Robert Chiltern worries, he bites his lip, and for most of "An Ideal Husband," the Oscar Wilde play that comes to the screen this week , he has plenty to worry about. He is threatened with exposure for having sold a government secret to a stock exchange speculator.
The deed, done years before the curtain rises, laid the foundation for Sir Robert's wealth and career as well as for a witty play. Exposure now, at the height of his prospects, would ruin his reputation and destroy his ambitions. 
 A century after the debut of "An Ideal Husband," Wilde's portrait of a successful politician trying to slip out of humiliation retains a certain currency, while the portrait of his wife seems like a daguerreotype that has faded from fashion.
Sir Robert's readiness to commit a new offense in an effort to cover up an old one bears comparison with current events. Though he doesn't resort to charges of a right-wing conspiracy, he denounces any who would criticize him as "men who, each one of them, have worse secrets in their own lives." Take that, Congress!
Like generations of lip-biters, Sir Robert tries to talk his way out of trouble by glossing over his act: "The affair to which you allude was no more than a speculation. The House of Commons had not yet passed the bill; it might have been rejected." But, alas, there is an incriminating letter afloat that even a glib politician would be hard put to explain. (Victorian playwrights had to make do without the evidence of a stained frock.)
Sir Robert, along with the play, is saved by some mechanics of 19th-century melodrama, but he is almost done in by his moralizing wife, for whom he represents the ideal husband. To his explanation that "Sooner or later in political life one has to compromise," she instructs him in female psychology straight out of romance fiction: "Robert, men can love what is beneath them, things unworthy, stained, dishonored. We women worship when we love and when we lose our worship, we lose everything."
Along with being a threat to her husband, Lady Chiltern's worshipful attitude is an offense to feminism, which was astir at the time. She is assuredly no model for today's achieving woman. If she had political ambitions of her own, say to run for senator from New York; if she had a career, perhaps as an Arkansas lawyer, that brought her into dubious company; if she had made surprising amounts of money in problematic ways, then she might well have collaborated sensibly in the cover-up, although at the expense of an enjoyable plot.
But what prudent spouse with the slightest acquaintance with politics would advance the dangerous proposition "that a person who has once been guilty of a dishonest and dishonorable action may be guilty of it a second time, and should be shunned"? An invitation to voters?
As Lady Chiltern, more bent on saving her husband's soul than his career, urges him into assured destruction, she preaches, "I don't think you realize sufficiently, Robert, that you have brought into the political life of our time a nobler atmosphere, an inner attitude towards life, a freer air of purer aims and higher ideals." Some consolation for a man whose career is going down the drain.
Today's more knowing spouse would surely be found off the pedestal and at rallies celebrating her husband's record of accomplishment: the economy is perking, the electorate is tranquil. And anyway, the offense was small. Sir Robert claims he did not make much money on the deal after all, that he has since given away far more in public charities. To which his friend Lord Goring, who utters Wilde's best lines, cracks: "In public charities? Dear me! What a lot of harm you must have done, Robert."
When Lord Goring asks, "How could you have sold yourself for money?" Sir Robert produces one of those parsings that have lately become famous: "I did not sell myself for money. I bought success at a great price. That is all." Oscar! Thou shouldst be living at this hour.
Wilde's own attitude, delivered via Lord Goring, combines what today's audience might dismiss as a dated and dreamy depiction of women's role in public life with an acute view of the politician's reason for being. "Failure to Robert would be the very mire of shame," he warns Lady Chiltern. "Power is his passion. He would lose everything, even his power to love." No contemporary woman requires such a reminder.
The discerning Lord Goring could not fail to note that these days the sexes are equally prone to the appeals of power and ambition, which can make for ideal bedfellows as the campaign grows hot.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;
Leader Leaves, to Mixed Reviews

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
Jerome H. Blue, the embattled leader of Roosevelt Island, resigned last week to become the State Human Rights Commissioner. Reactions from residents ranged from good job to good riddance.
Gov. George E. Pataki appointed Robert Ryan, the vice president of communications for the Empire State Development Corporation, to succeed Dr. Blue, who is a neuroscientist, as chief executive of the Roosevelt Island Operating Corporation, which runs the island. At a meeting Thursday, the corporation's board approved the appointment. 
 Dr. Blue's three-year tenure was marked by fierce battles with residents, who accused him of arrogance and nonresponsiveness. During the last year, as relations deteriorated, Joseph Lynch, Commissioner of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal, began traveling from Albany to the island's heated monthly meetings.
"There was a stormy relationship between the activists on the island and Dr. Blue," Mr. Lynch said after the Thursday meeting. "The new appointee has much more people skills and the experience to bring this island forward."
Mr. Ryan called himself "an easy guy to get along with" and promised he would meet with local groups.
Dr. Blue did not attend, but submitted a farewell letter, read by Mr. Lynch, who drew loud laughs when he read, "I have fought for human rights and social justice throughout my career."
Many residents greeted Mr. Ryan warmly and asked him to mend a divided community. "There is a lot of healing that needs to be done," said Joan Christianson, vice president of the island's residents association.
State officials said Dr. Blue stayed within his budget, unlike many predecessors, but some residents say he cut spending in irresponsible ways, such as neglecting seawall repair.
Dr. Blue's spokesman, David O. Bailey, said, "Dr. Blue's only comment is that he is proud of his accomplishments."
Edward Rademaker, who has owned Roosevelt Island Wines and Liquors for 20 years, praised Dr. Blue, who he said kept rents low for struggling business owners.
"He gave summer jobs to our young people and a loving hand to those of lesser means," he said. "He put this island back on a stable economic plane." Mr. Rademaker said most of Dr. Blue's opponents were white and only appeared to be a majority because "the same group of well-to-do activists come to every meeting."
But Byron Gaspard, who is black, as is Dr. Blue, said Dr. Blue used race to pit the island's 8,500 residents against one another. "Right now this community is greatly divided," he said, "and that was by design."
 COREY KILGANNON
