LENGTH: 2631 words

HEADLINE: The Revenge Of the Bean Counters;
Studios Yell 'Cut!' As Costs Spiral For Filmmaking

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB and GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
TEN years ago, the stars, and their agents, ruled Hollywood. Duds like "Legal Eagles" and "Family Business" were packaged by talent agents for clients like Robert Redford, Dustin Hoffman and Sean Connery, and the studios, without batting an eye, paid lavish sums to make them.
But now the studios are regaining the upper hand, and their main weapon is supply and demand. Under strict orders from their corporate owners to pay more heed to the bottom line, studios are making fewer films, forcing the people who work in the industry to carve up a smaller pie. 
 Midlevel actors and directors, hungry for jobs, are quietly willing to take pay cuts. And while top stars and directors can still usually write their own tickets -- Steven Spielberg and Tom Hanks earned $40 million each from the success of "Saving Private Ryan" -- sometimes even the most high-profile projects are dropped altogether if their costs seem unlikely to be recouped.
Those who control the big studios -- many of which have been reduced to midsized operating units of giant conglomerates -- devote much of their creative energies to conjuring up new ways to limit the financial risks of filmmaking.
The artists may not like it, but the corporate bosses know that is the only way to get predictable earnings in a low-margin business, one in which the flops far outnumber the hits. And that mind-set has stripped the movie business of some of the sex appeal that a decade ago -- in the pre-dot-com era -- made it a mecca for investors the world over.
"If you look at the return on capital in the film industry, it has to be in the mid-single digits, which is probably no better than a Treasury bill," said David J. Londoner, a media analyst for Schroder & Company. He estimated that overall profits from the major film studios would drop about 20 percent this year.
"The television divisions make money, the film library makes money, but current releases lose money," Mr. Londoner said. "It's worse than it has been for the past couple of years."
The Hollywood sky, of course, is hardly falling. Producers, executives and talent agents still earn huge sums. Christopher McGurk, a former top executive at Universal Pictures, was recently hired as vice chairman and chief operating officer by the floundering Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for a five-year compensation package worth at least $20 million. And though Tom Cruise deferred his customary $20 million-plus salary for a hefty percentage of Stanley Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut," he may easily earn double that if the film is successful.
But revenues have simply not kept up, as the average cost of a film doubled between 1993 and 1998, from $26.1 million to $52.7 million, and marketing costs climbed 79 percent, to $25.3 million. Something had to give. And it has.
"It's a time of creative deal-making -- and I mean that as a euphemism," said Tom Strickler, a partner at the Endeavor talent agency, which represents actors like Adam Sandler and Bette Midler. "Artists can't be as selective as they once were."
Moreover, some agents are being laid off. And a growing number of producers -- as well as actors, filmmakers and technicians -- can no longer count on being kept on a studio payroll as they scout for projects or seek jobs in television.
PART of the shift can be traced to changing film-industry economics. In the 1980's and early 1990's, the home-video, cable and pay-TV businesses exploded, creating new sources of revenue for the studios. Box-office receipts, which generated 35 percent of film revenue in 1990, dwindled to 24 percent last year. But in the last few years, the growth in the home-video business has slowed, and DVD's, which some studios are heralding as the next big revenue source, are still in their infancy.
In this bottom-line atmosphere, studios negotiate with talent agents, but their dictum is simple: Take it or leave it. This is a striking turnabout from the 1980's and early 1990's, when Michael Ovitz, then chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, dominated Hollywood by packaging projects for actors and directors and virtually telling studios the same thing studios are telling agents now. Mr. Ovitz himself is seeking to return to Hollywood, this time as a manager.
"We were delivering product to very receptive buyers," said Ron Meyer, who once worked as a partner with Mr. Ovitz at Creative Artists but now sits on the other side of table as president of Universal Studios. "In today's climate, with the risks so great, it's just much easier for a studio to say no to anything they believe is not very commercial."
Talent agents are adjusting. "If a movie doesn't fit a studio's financial model, they can do without making it," said David O'Connor, a top agent at Creative Artists. Mr. Connor minimized the shift, saying that the movie business was facing a "correction." Studios are reasserting financial controls, he said, but the talent -- or at least top stars and a handful of directors -- is still the main engine.
But there are limits. Recently, Dreamworks refused to pay Brad Pitt, whose last few films have fallen short of their studios' expectations, his $15 million fee for a film about the world of rock music written and directed by Cameron Crowe, who made "Jerry McGuire." Instead, Billy Crudup, a relative unknown, will play the role -- for less than $1 million.
Nicolas Cage dropped his fee from $20 million to $8 million to work within the budget of Martin Scorsese's "Bringing Out the Dead," about paramedics in Hell's Kitchen, due in October from Paramount. And after extensive wrangling with 20th Century Fox, agents for Cuba Gooding Jr. have agreed to less than his customary $3 million for an action film, "Navy Diver."
Warner Brothers, once an extravagant spender on hits like "Lethal Weapon" and flops like "The Postman," surprised Hollywood last year by shelving two big-budget films: a new version of "Superman," which was to star Mr. Cage and Kevin Spacey, and "I Am Legend," an action-adventure film with Arnold Schwarzenegger.
"Everybody has been forced to see the cold realities of the very narrow profit margins of the movie business," said Brian Grazer, producer of films like "Ransom" and "Apollo 13."
Another factor is the influx of conglomerates, which have moved into the business on the theory that while film operations may not always be great moneymakers, they enhance the value of cable channels and TV networks, and build lucrative film libraries.
"What you are really trying to do is to build asset values that help your other businesses," said Mr. Londoner, the media analyst.
The News Corporation, run by Rupert Murdoch, started the trend in 1985 by buying 20th Century Fox. Then came Sony, which bought Columbia; Viacom, which bought Paramount, and Matsushita, which bought Universal and then sold it to Seagram.
In the halcyon days of growth in home video and cable, the number of films produced rose sharply. But the corporate owners have finally begun to apply pressure to their studios -- which, though glamorous, are much riskier enterprises than many of the other business lines competing with them for management attention and capital.
In 1988, films and television accounted for 68 percent of revenues at Paramount Communications; last year, they represented 39 percent of Viacom's sales. At Time Warner, they are around 30 percent of sales, down from 37 percent a decade earlier at Warner Communications, before the merger with Time Inc. In the case of Disney, it is almost impossible to figure out how the film and TV business is doing, because its results are lumped in with the ABC television network and other operations.
"These used to be stand-alone entities, and as such they were the total focus of the management," said Herbert Allen, who heads Allen & Company, an investment banking firm in New York that specializes in media deals. "Now they are divisions of larger companies, representing dramatically less of a percentage of sales and earnings."
ABOVE all, corporate chiefs are putting heavy pressure on division heads to control spending so that even a bad run of films will not crush earnings.
"The Eisners, Murdochs and Redstones have all woken up and said, 'This can't go on,' " said Joe Roth, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, referring to the chief executives of Disney, the News Corporation and Viacom, respectively.
So Brian Mulligan, executive vice president at Seagram's Universal, likes to talk about managing a "portfolio of films" assembled to reduce risk, while Time Warner's chairman, Gerald M. Levin, is quick to point out that Warner's film and television business is only 11 percent of cash flow. (That helps to explain why Time Warner stock climbed even while Warner Brothers studios endured several flops in recent years, like "The Avengers," "Quest for Camelot" and "Father's Day.")
At Fox Filmed Entertainment, the chairman, Bill Mechanic, and his associates recently spent more than a year scaling back the budget of "Entrapment," the Sean Connery romantic adventure. The film was initially budgeted at $140 million, but the price tag was slashed to $60 million, Mr. Mechanic said. The studio hired a new director willing to work within its budget, dropped numerous costly action sequences and revised the script to focus more on character. The film, which was released in late April, has grossed $75 million and, with foreign ticket sales, will probably turn a profit.
Similar re-evaluations across Hollywood are having a striking impact. For the most part, studios make either large-scale films like "The Mummy," "The Matrix" or "Armageddon," with appeal to a wide, international audience, or smaller films aimed at specific moviegoers, like teen-agers, women or African-Americans.
"Movies are either more global in their appeal, or they're more focused and targeted to specific audiences," said Casey Silver, a producer and a former chairman at Universal Studios, who gave the go-ahead to "The Mummy" and acquired "Notting Hill."
Grown-up films -- movies more serious or sophisticated than, say, the new hit "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me," released this weekend -- are increasingly left to independents. Of course, some of the leading "independents," like Disney's Miramax, Time Warner's Fine Line and Fox Searchlight, are not independent at all but are owned by the same companies that control studios. But the financial contrasts are startling nonetheless, as these production outfits operate with lower overhead, and actors expect lower fees when they make independent films.
One of the most profitable films of the 1990's is "The Full Monty," from Fox Searchlight. It cost $3.5 million and grossed $250 million around the world. By contrast, "The Horse Whisperer" and "Six Days, Seven Nights," from Disney, grossed $190 million and $175 million, respectively, but did not make a dime for the studio. The reasons were huge budgets and marketing costs, and hefty salaries for the likes of Robert Redford, Harrison Ford and the director Ivan Reitman.
Mr. Roth made it clear that, as a studio chief, he has limited options. Fewer and fewer studios are making serious films -- those designed for a relatively small audience "that's older, requires the most in terms of production value and wants to have movie stars," he said.
"So if we make a high-end drama intended for adults over 40," he added, "then you're dealing with an audience that shows up only sporadically and that requires great reviews.
"And if I have it executed one degree short of perfection, I may lose it all."
Conversely, he said, younger audiences do not require expensive stars, often return to the same film two or three -- or even more -- times and are unaffected by critics. For studios like Disney, the choice is clear.
THE mantra for many, but not all, studio executives in Hollywood is now "sharing the risk," or laying off part of a film's cost by seeking a financial partner or pre-selling the foreign rights to other distributors. The most notable example is "Titanic," which grossed $1.8 billion around the world but was notoriously over budget before its Christmas 1997 release.
Fox, which had the film rights, put up $135 million of the $200 million cost and distributed the film overseas. Paramount paid the rest and released the film in the United States.
After the costs were recouped, Fox has received 60 percent of the revenues while the remainder has gone to Paramount. However lucrative the film, though, the partnership was so tense that there was a near-fistfight between two top studio executives over the movie's release date.
A handful of top executives and producers are ambivalent, at best, about sharing costs. Those who make such deals, said John Calley, chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, are letting their anxiety about their own decisions stop them from capitalizing on their successes.
"Because you're betting the downside, you're not supporting your creative choices," Mr. Calley said. Sony, which buys rights but does not sell them, is now sharing the costs of two films with Universal and one with Disney.
A different corporate approach is typified by Jonathan Dolgen, chairman of the Viacom Entertainment Group, Paramount's parent.
Although Paramount owns most of its films outright, he said, the studio strongly believes in spreading risks by splitting costs, whether by taking on equity investors, acquiring limited rights to movies or making other arrangements.
"It substantially modifies the thing that people on the Street most hate about the movie business, which is the wild swings," Mr. Dolgen said. "If you have a movie that cost $100 million, you can wake up on the first Saturday morning after it opens and realize you've lost $50 million. There are a limited number of those Saturday mornings that you actually want to entertain that."
AT the moment, there are some possible new revenue sources that may ease the stinginess.
Studio chiefs say the advent of higher-quality digital video disks, known as DVD's, will prompt moviegoers to rebuild their film libraries. Robert A. Daly, co-chairman of Warner Brothers, is especially hopeful.
"DVD, pay per view, video on demand -- these are the critical areas of the movie business over the next few years," Mr. Daly said. "And the good part about DVD is it's going to bring in revenues in the area that doesn't push up costs: the library."
But optimism is in somewhat short supply in Hollywood. Studio executives have even noticed that the glitter of Internet riches is shining brighter among ambitious college graduates than the glitz of movieland.
"There has been an explosion of industries with a visual orientation, with the computer and the Internet, and for the moment, those are far more interesting," Mr. Allen said. "If you look at the total compensation of the people in those industries, and the wealth generated, the Internet businesses make everyone else look small, boring and pale in comparison."
But Mr. Calley, who helped run Warner Brothers studios from 1968 to 1981, takes the long view. He recalled that Warner Brothers and Stanley Kubrick were locked in a dispute in 1970 over the costs of "A Clockwork Orange." Mr. Kubrick insisted on spending $1.32 million on the film, while Mr. Calley wanted to spend $1.28 million. A compromise was reached.
"I hate to say it, but we were having budget interviews with Variety and The Hollywood Reporter in the mid-70's about how these out-of-control costs were going to destroy the industry," he said. "What occurs over and over again is that as costs seem to have reached the ultimate state of 'out of control,' along comes a new income stream, a la DVD, that takes up the slack and resuscitates you through yet another cycle."

Photos/Chart: "Belt-Tightening, Hollywood Style"
The economics of movie-making is changing as corporate overlords squeeze the Hollywood studios to produce a higher return on capital. The studios have responded by reducing the number of films they release -- thereby increasing their leverage with artists and producers -- and finding ways to lower costs. The change from a decade ago is striking.
 
THEN
 
TIED UP WITH A BOW
The late 1980's were the heyday of the "package deal" in Hollywood. Powerful agents like Michael Ovitz of the Creative Artists Agency put together movie projects with actors, directors and writers they represented. The studios, eager to keep the "creatives" happy, signed onto the deals at the prices the agents dictated. But the agents did not go down in cinematic history as brilliant filmmakers:
 
For "Legal Eagles," below, released in 1986 by Universal, Creative Artists teamed up Robert Redford, Debra Winger and the director Ivan Reitman. The film cost an estimated $60 million and grossed about $50 million in the United States. With overseas ticket sales, executives said, it turned a profit. But it is still remembered as an embarrassment for the studio.
 
Another flop was "Family Business," above, a 1989 release from Tristar, a division of Sony. Creative Artists put the film together as a package deal for Matthew Broderick, Sean Connery and Dustin Hoffman. It cost $35 million and grossed just $11 million in the United States; overseas sales were also disappointing.
 
NOW
 
INDEPENDENT HITS
While cutting back their own production levels, the major studios are releasing more films made by their "independent" divisions, which have much lower costs. The objective is a hit like "The Full Monty," right, a 1997 Fox Searchlight film that cost $3.5 million and grossed more than $250 million worldwide.
 
STAR-FREE BY DESIGN
Another way to improve the odds of a film's profitability is to keep the story simple -- to play better overseas -- and to cast lesser-known actors in leading roles. "There's Something About Mary," a 20th Century Fox film released last year starring Cameron Diaz, cost $23 million and grossed $176 million just in the United States, plus $186 million overseas.
 
STAR-FREE BY FIAT
A film about the rock music world by the director Cameron Crowe, still untitled, was set to star Brad Pitt, right, among others. But Dreamworks balked at his $15 million fee and instead cast Billy Crudup, far right. His fee: less than $1 million.
 
SHIFTING THE RISK
Tom Cruise won't receive his usual $20 million-plus fee for starring with his wife, Nicole Kidman, in "Eyes Wide Shut," right, from Warner Brothers. Instead, he agreed to accept a percentage of the film's receipts; the better it does, the more he'll earn.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Arden Armstrong;
MAS Mid-Cap Growth Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
ARDEN ARMSTRONG, lead manager of the $887.6 million MAS Mid-Cap Growth fund, cheerfully acknowledges the growth-oriented nature of her investing discipline. She asks only that her style not be confused with the methods of other growth-fund managers. "We like to find quality growth," she explained from her office in West Conshohocken, Pa. "We're not momentum or growth-at-a-reasonable-price investors."
Three elements characterize what she calls "quality growth" companies: projected annual earnings growth of more than 15 percent over the next one to three years, expanding profit margins over the same period and consistency in the profit growth -- which helps to determine whether growth can be sustained. 
 The fund seems to have benefited from the formula. MAS Mid-Cap returned 25.9 percent, annualized, for the three years ended June 4, compared with an average of 12.3 percent for its peer group of mid-cap growth funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher, and 27.6 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Individuals can buy the fund's institutional shares through financial advisers or directly through fund networks.
Ms. Armstrong, 38, begins the stock-selection process with a computer program that looks at the 2,500 or so companies traded on United States exchanges that have market capitalizations of $500 million to $5 billion. About 40 percent of them have the quality earnings characteristics she seeks and become candidates for further research, which she does with the help of two co-managers and eight analysts. They whittle down their list to the 90 or so stocks in the portfolio.
The research focuses on whether Wall Street earnings estimates are sustainable. On company balance sheets, she looks for lean inventories and low totals in accounts receivable and working capital -- signs of a company that operates efficiently, producing excess cash flow.
She also reviews companies' market position. "In small-cap and mid-cap investing," she said, "you can end up with little companies that compete with big companies." She avoids those small companies because they risk being overwhelmed, and looks instead for those that are leaders in fragmented industries or that dominate market niches.
Roughly one-third of the portfolio is always allocated to aggressive-growth stocks -- with rates of earnings growth above 25 percent -- and another third to more stable growth companies. The remainder shifts between those two categories.
"We've trimmed our holdings in the stable growers, because we're trying to get more economically sensitive stocks that are poised to benefit from a better global economy, like semiconductor or energy stocks," she said. "These are a little more cyclical, but I think we're in the right point in the cycle for them."
The price she will pay varies. If a company has a very stable growth rate, she's willing to pay a price-to- earnings multiple that is higher than the company's earnings growth rate, perhaps buying a stock with a P/E of 25 whose earnings growth is below 25 percent. For cyclical growth companies with low profit margins and no excess cash flow, she is likely to pay a multiple that is only 60 to 80 percent of the growth rate.
THE bought CNF Transportation, a Palo Alto, Calif., air carrier and trucking company, for $44 a share in January. "Merchandise bought over the Internet is generally shipped by the U.S. post office, and CNF has a contract with the post office for providing transportation for priority mail on the East Coast," she said.
CNF owns Emery Worldwide, a shipping company that has suffered over the last two years as many foreign economies stumbled. But CNF has cut costs and improved service at Emery, she said, and its earnings should improve as economic activity picks up abroad. Analysts expect earnings to grow 14.5 percent annually over the next three years. The stock now trades at $39.25, or 11.7 times the earnings of $3.36 a share that analysts estimate for 2000.
Ms. Armstrong began buying General Instrument, which makes cable set-top boxes, at $20 a share in April 1998, hoping to profit from the cable TV boom. The company has recently introduced digital cable versions of its boxes, she said, and is upgrading its equipment to provide modem and telephone services. General Instrument had a 1998 net profit margin of 10.9 percent. Wall Street expects earnings to grow 23.5 percent a year over the next three years.
The stock now trades at $38.25, or 32.7 times expected 2000 earnings of $1.17 a share.
The fund recently added to its position in Premier Parks, which it originally bought in 1997 at $16 a share. The company, based in Oklahoma City, acquired the Six Flags theme parks and name from Time Warner last year and has been rechristening its existing larger parks with the Six Flags name. Ms. Armstrong said the company is likely to see steady growth because its parks are used by day-trippers and are not as sensitive to the economy as parks requiring longer stays.
Because Premier Parks makes lots of acquisitions, which can distort profits, Ms. Armstrong looks at its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. She expects that figure to grow 22 percent a year over the next three years. The stock now trades at $37.50.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2660 words

HEADLINE: The Space Race;
Why Is It So Hard to Find a Parking Spot in Manhattan?

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
HE concedes that others might call him a gadfly or consider him a tad obsessed. But to Thomas J. Hillgardner, a lawyer from Flushing, Queens, and the founder of a group called the Parking Justice League, it all comes down to civic responsibility and civil rights.
So last October, when Mr. Hillgardner saw a police officer ticketing a stranger's car at Bleecker and Lafayette Streets in Manhattan, he spoke up.Complained. Argued. "I told the cop that he could not give a ticket if there was no 'No Parking' sign on the block," said Mr. Hillgardner, who no longer has a car of his own. The officer was unconvinced, he said, and told him to move along. Twice. 
 Mr. Hillgardner did not comply and was arrested for harassment. He was held in a station house jail for six hours, he said, before he was released and told to appear in court in December. Mr. Hillgardner said he went to court as scheduled, eager to defend himself. But the case was put off, he said. Within a few weeks, the Manhattan District Attorney's office dropped it.
That did not satisfy Mr. Hillgardner. This month, he sued the city and the Police Department in Federal District Court for violation of his civil rights, seeking $417 million in punitive damages. "That's how much the city earned last year from parking revenues," he said.
Actually, it was $378 million, according to the Department of Finance, the parent agency of the Parking Violations Bureau. But whatever the figure, to Mr. Hillgardner and many other New Yorkers, the money is a testament to the distress residents and visitors suffer when they try to find a place to park, especially in Manhattan. Where else do people pay $20, sometimes more, to park for half an hour in a garage? Or worry about moving their cars from one side of the street to the other, sometimes every day? On the street, the slightest misstep can lead to a ticket in the blink of an eye, or to having one's car towed. And forget about pleading for mercy with a traffic agent.
To many Americans, parking is an inalienable right, right up there with free speech and unlimited iced-tea refills. But New York is a crowded place, with two million vehicles registered in the five boroughs, and many millions more coming in daily from the suburbs and beyond. There just isn't room for all of them on the streets. Demand for parking exceeds supply. Simple as that.
The squeeze on parking in Manhattan began in 1982, when concerns about air pollution from traffic led to a tightening of the rules on construction of parking garages, city planning officials said. New commercial garages, which until then could be built as of right, were banned except with special permits. And the number of new residential garage spaces was reduced. Builders, who had been obliged to provide 40 spaces for every 100 apartments, no longer were required to provide any, and if they did, they could create only 25 or 35 per 100 apartments, depending on the neighborhood.
Like the 8 percent surcharge levied on Manhattan parking in 1980 -- the total tax is now 18.25 percent -- the restrictions were meant to reduce traffic into the borough. They didn't. But decreased construction of new parking spaces, and the loss of open-air lots to new buildings, reduced the number of commercial and residential parking spots in the borough by about 10 percent over all and by about 17 percent from midtown to lower Manhattan, said the chairman of the city's Planning Commission, Joseph B. Rose.
Today, there are 127,000 parking spaces in garages in Manhattan, with 35,000 or so spots in outdoor lots, said Joel Stahl, the executive director of the Metropolitan Parking Association, an industry trade group to which most of the city's parking lot and garage operators belong. Commercial parking remains a big business in New York, with annual revenues of at least $1 billion, Mr. Stahl said. With the local economy booming, he said, demand has increased.
Parking lot professionals have taken notice. Within the last year, the Central Parking Corporation of Nashville, which already owned Meyers Parking, a major garage operator in the city, went on a shopping spree, acquiring Kinney Parking, Square Parking and part of Edison Parking.
Monroe Carell Jr., the chairman of Central Parking, the country's largest commercial parking operator, now controls 135,000 parking spots in New York City, including those at Yankee and Shea Stadiums. "New York has the best ratio of demand to number of spaces in the country," he said.
Most of Central Parking's garages are leased from the owners of the buildings. Anne DeMarzo, co-president of DeMarzo Realty Company in Manhattan, which specializes in parking lots and garages, said the market for them was strong. Most leases, she said, run for 10 years or more, and these days Manhattan property owners are demanding $1,000 to $6,000 per space per year, depending on location.
That's a lot of money, especially since companies that lease garages from landlords usually look for a return of eight to nine times on their investment, said Howard Greenberg, the other co-president of DeMarzo Realty.
The more garage operators pay, the more customers pay. A day's parking in midtown can now cost as much as $50, although Mr. Stahl said that several garages in midtown charge $20 or less. The Department of Consumer Affairs has rules requiring garage and lot operators to post signs about rate increases and to warn consumers about them, but the city does not regulate how much they can charge. So parking companies are free to charge whatever the traffic will bear.
And they do. "We have artificially created a parking shortage in New York City," Mr. Rose said. "The $450-a-month parking space is as much a product of foolish regulation as anything else."
Mr. Rose has proposed allowing builders to create more parking spots in residential buildings. "We're the only major city that prohibits residents from parking," he said. "We want to change that." But no change is planned for the rules on commercial garage construction. The city still does not want to encourage nonresidents to drive in.
City Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, whose lower Manhattan district includes SoHo, where the streets are clogged on weekends with visitors' cars, said she was "conflicted" about Mr. Rose's plans.
"I know people who live in the city need places to park," she said. "But we are so congested that the idea of allowing more parking in the center of the city is insane."
Whether or not more residential garage spaces are on the horizon, for many people who live in the city, parking the car means a daily hunt for a spot.
Just how many legal parking spaces are there on the streets? A spokesman for the Department of Transportation, Mark Patterson, would only provide written answers to written questions about general procedures concerning parking. "D.O.T. has no use for this information and therefore has no reason to maintain such records," the department said about the number of street spots, adding that there are roughly 66,000 parking meters citywide.
Whatever the number of spaces, in many neighborhoods, the opportunities for street parking are quite limited, and in some, they even seem to be shrinking.
In lower Manhattan, 2,400 old fire hydrants are supposed to be removed, but most remain on the streets. They have not been used since 1980, but motorists can still get a $55 ticket for parking next to one. Plans to get rid of them have been delayed for years. Though an 18-month project to do the job was announced in 1997, only 54 have been taken out so far, said a spokesman for the Department of Design and Construction, Matthew Monahan.
Meanwhile, in parts of lower Manhattan, including much of the area south of Canal Street, the Sanitation Department has imposed new rules that ban parking between 2 A.M. and 6 A.M. on various nights of the week, so that street cleaning, previously done during the day, can take place after dark. In effect, overnight parking becomes impossible on those nights.
The reason? Many streets are far too congested to clean during the day, said a Sanitation Department spokeswoman, Kathy Dawkins.
The result? "They are making it impossible," said Martin Shaw, a disgusted TriBeCa resident who parks on the street.
Then there are the holders of city-authorized parking permits, who seem to gobble up spaces, legal and illegal, all over the city. Most of the permits, laminated cards placed on dashboards, are issued by the Police Department and the Department of Transportation. There are parking permits for the handicapped, for clergy and for nonprofit groups, as well as film and press permits. And there are official business permits, which are given to city employees who are supposed to use them on city business only, for no more than three hours at a time.
But some permit holders seem to have unconventional beliefs about the meaning of official business, not to mention elastic notions of time. The problem is particularly acute in areas with numerous city offices, like Long Island City, and in downtown Brooklyn and lower Manhattan, where some streets are actually designated as "no permit zones," and where city permit holders park anyway, in flagrant disregard of the rules.
The area around 30th Place in Long Island City is home to several city agencies, and cars with city permits are often parked in no-parking zones there. "I have the Cadillac of parking permits," City Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, who represents the neighborhood, said last September, "and I can hardly park anywhere."
Paul Goldstein, the district manager for Community Board 1, which includes most of Manhattan south of Canal Street, said his district is especially hard hit because of all the government offices there. Government cars sit on the streets all day long, he said, and "nothing is ever done about it."
"We've complained about abuse of the permits to the police and to the Department of Transportation for years," Mr. Goldstein said.
Cars with police or Transportation Department permits can be found all over lower Manhattan. Near Police Plaza, they are even on the sidewalk. In addition to occupying no-parking and no-standing zones, cars with permits also occupy metered spots that are supposed to be available to the general public. Often they also fill those few streets where daytime parking is otherwise allowed, shutting out residents.
That's not supposed to happen. "We expect our people to abide by rules and regulations," said a police spokesman, Lieut. Dennis Cirillo. And when officers spot vehicles with city permits that are illegally parked, he said: "They should ticket there. If not, they should be subject to discipline."
All well and good, but who gets these permits? Inspector Michael Collins of the Police Department's public information office did not return several telephone calls requesting information about the number of permits issued by the department and the identity of the recipients.
The Transportation Department spokesman, Mr. Patterson, wrote that approximately 9,753 department permits are issued citywide, "with different criteria for each kind of permit."
Because the department would not voluntarily reveal the names and titles of those to whom it has issued parking permits, The New York Times made a formal request for the information last month under New York State's Freedom of Information law. Despite time limits under the law that required a response to the request before publication of this article, Diane Poland, the director of the agency's office of litigation support and records management, said it could not provide the information until the end of June "at the earliest" because its computer operators "could not be taken off the Y2K problem."
The ticketing of illegally parked cars is the responsibility of the Police Department, whose officers and traffic agents are supposed to enforce the law. But parking tickets also mean money for the city. According to the Finance Department, 9,143,000 tickets were issued during the 1997-98 fiscal year, bringing in $378 million in revenue. (That's a little more than 1 percent of the city's recently announced $35 billion budget. It's considerably more than the estimated $210 million the city expects to lose as a result of the recent repeal of the income tax on commuters.)
Though parking revenue for 1996-97 was slightly higher, $385 million, the revenue trend has been generally upward since 1993-94, when New York City took in $295 million from parking violations. And though the number of tickets issued has been declining since the early 90's, the amount of the average ticket, about $48 in fiscal 1998, has been rising.
The police deny that officers have ticket-writing quotas. But many New Yorkers believe they exist.
"Sure there are quotas," said James Savage, the departing president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, the police union, who was unseated this month in a union election. "Ask any police officer, and if he can cover his badge he'll tell you."
"Sometimes," he added, "it's called 'Book of the Month Club.' "
According to Mr. Savage, an average monthly requirement in midtown might be 25 parking tickets, 5 moving violations and at least 2 "quality of life" tickets. That's for regular beat patrol officers; a so-called summons man, assigned to parking ticket duty, is expected to write 30 to 50 tickets a day, he said.
Mr. Savage denied that officers issue tickets where they should not just to make their quotas, as Mr. Hillgardner alleges in his Federal suit. But he did acknowledge that there are consequences for not writing a sufficient number of summonses. "If you don't make your quota, you're subject to reassignment or a change of tour," he said. "They can also give you a hard time when you want to take a day off if you haven't given them lots of summonses."
And while cars with city-issued parking permits illegally line city streets every day, they often do not receive tickets, local officials say. "We get reports all the time about cars with three-hour permits staying in spots all day," said Mr. Goldstein of Community Board 1. "Without tickets."
Why not? "You've got to be kidding," said one traffic enforcement agent last week. "Last time I gave a ticket to a cop with a permit he came out and threatened me," she said. "I don't need that."
 
A Cavern for Cars With Art on the Walls
AMONG the concrete caverns where city dwellers shell out big bucks to park their cars, there are some garages that try to make the experience a little less painful. GGMC, a family-run company that operates 27 garages and parking lots in Manhattan and Brooklyn, puts museum posters in its garages, and some have creative paint jobs.
At the Ruppert Towers garage on East 92d Street, between Second and Third Avenues, GGMC has mounted an exhibition of historic photographs depicting the Yorkville area in the early years of the century. The garage, in a housing complex that was built in the 1970's on the site of the old Ruppert Knickerbocker brewery, also features taxicab-yellow walls with a checkerboard border.
The company's Cove Club garage at Battery Park City, meanwhile, has red walls and posters of artworks by Toulouse-Lautrec and Cezanne.
GGMC's rates are competitive with other commercial garages in the city. But do its efforts to create a hospitable atmosphere encourage more people to park in its garages?
"Sure, people mainly choose their garages based upon convenience," said Andrew Grossman, the vice president of the company, which his father, Semone Grossman, started in 1957. "But I think they enjoy the experience here."
Mr. Grossman said the artistic environments create goodwill among landlords and residents. "Many tenants have told me that they would rather bring their guest up through the garage than through the lobby," he said proudly.
Imagine that.
 BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
A Marshall Plan, on the Cheap?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHEN George Marshall died in 1959, he left strict instructions: No eulogies. But getting politicians to follow commands, even those issued by former generals, is tricky business. And these days nearly everyone is paying homage to the Marshall Plan, which rebuilt Europe and Japan after World War II and became the gold standard for reconstructing some very deconstructed corners of the Earth.
Last week, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and the foreign ministers of Europe were talking about a "Marshall Plan for the Balkans." It will be a main topic at the annual summit meeting of industrialized nations this week in Cologne, Germany. 
 At the same meeting, an agreement is expected on whether and how to forgive the debts of some of the world's poorest nations, which owe upward of $130 billion in loans that they can probably never repay. Lifting that burden, advocates say, amounts to a Marshall Plan for the poor.
The use of the term is no surprise: Congress despises foreign aid almost as much as it loves phantom tax cuts. But call it a Marshall Plan, and suddenly it's not a handout, but a noble effort to turn beaten, bombed-out or broke nations into models of democratic capitalism.
There's only one real difference: Politicians who invoke the term today are not really interested in paying Marshall-sized money. By most estimates, the Marshall Plan cost about 2 percent of America's gross national product annually from 1947 to 1951. If the same ratio were used today, after the biggest run-up in national wealth in a century, the United States would spend $160 billion a year on modern Marshall Plans.
In fact, the talk is of spending only a tiny fraction of that figure, perhaps forgiving a bit more than $600 million for the poorest nations, assuming they meet a number of reform conditions that many have resisted.
The reality is that true Marshall Plans are not big sellers these days. During the cold war they carried a strategic logic of their own, shoring up economies so that nations would not be tempted to spread Communism. They also helped American industry by creating export markets. But in the post-cold war era, there is far less enthusiasm for spending money to encourage countries to adopt Western-style capitalism, much less to become customers.
So the same countries that are enthusiastic about new Marshall Plans talk even more enthusiastically about how to make others pay for them.
The bombs barely stopped dropping on Belgrade last week before the NATO allies began jockeying about who would pick up the bill.
"Everyone knows it's going to be expensive, but it has to be done," Ms. Albright said. Then, in background briefings, American officials said the United States had borne most of the cost of prosecuting the war, so Europe ought to pay to rebuild Kosovo and aid Albania and Macedonia. The price tag gyrates from $5 billion to $100 billion, depending on whether people are talking just about rebuilding roads and power lines and the like or about a wholesale economic upgrade for the region.
BUT the real arm-wrestling is over debt forgiveness for the poorest nations, chiefly in Africa. It's one of those ideas that everyone agrees on in general but almost no one can agree on in specific.
No one thinks debt service should be allowed to keep gobbling 60 percent or more of destitute countries' budgets. But neither is there much support for 100 percent debt forgiveness, no strings attached. The International Monetary Fund and others fear that simply writing off debts creates a serious "moral hazard" -- the expectation that future borrowing need not be repaid.
The outgoing Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, describing the American position last week, talked about step-by-step debt relief in return for real economic reforms -- more openness, enforceable property rights, revamped banking systems -- akin to those asked of South Korea, Indonesia, Russia and others in return for I.M.F. bailouts.
The problem is figuring out who pays. The French and the Japanese, who have done the most country-to-country lending, like the idea that Western nations would contribute in proportion to the size of their economies -- meaning the United States would pay the most. Washington, not surprisingly, has a different formula in mind.
Aid groups fear that debt forgiveness will cannibalize other aid. "We want to see as much debt relief as possible," said Lydia Williams, a policy adviser at Oxfam America, who has been lobbying Congress for a bigger package, but "it has to be additional, new resources to do much good."
As Jeffrey D. Sachs of Harvard points out, the West can now afford to solve the problem "without resorting to the kinds of huge numbers" involved in the Marshall Plan. "It's just a matter of political will," he said -- which General Marshall had less trouble gathering.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
For Physical Therapists, a Sudden Drought

BYLINE: By ERIC QUINONES 

 BODY:
IN his first year in the physical therapy program at Thomas Jefferson University in Philadelphia, Tony Woods saw advanced students receiving multiple job offers -- sometimes months before graduation. Mr. Woods, who had been a carpenter, was feeling good about trying a career change.
Three years later, he is close to earning his master's degree, but recruiters have not come calling. "No responses on anything so far," he said, "and I've probably put a couple of dozen feelers out there." 
 Mr. Woods's plight exemplifies a sudden shift in physical therapy. Beginning about a decade ago, it was a booming field desperate for skilled practitioners to treat an aging, fitness-minded population. But now it faces a slowdown caused by its own growing pains, the growth of managed care and, especially, Medicare cutbacks that took effect in January. Years of undersupply have given way to a tighter job market and to reduced work hours and salaries.
"The shortfall has literally evaporated," said William Quillen, director of the physical therapy program at Indiana University in Indianapolis. "There's just not the hot, hot job market there was two or three years ago."
In the past decade, with graduates in demand at hospitals, rehabilitation centers, nursing homes and home health care agencies, the number of physical therapy programs at colleges and universities nationwide soared 75 percent, to 208. And, in a trend that has since abated, thousands of foreign therapists arrived.
Full-time therapists typically earn $55,000 a year, according to the American Physical Therapy Association, and some make more than $100,000. But the ranks of full-timers are thinning even as more graduates enter the field each year.
Therapists assign some of the blame to the cost controls of managed-care companies, but more of it to a Medicare cutback. Before this year, the program's only limit on spending for physical therapy was a $900 cap for private outpatient care. Now Medicare will pay no more than a total of $1,500 a year for physical and speech therapy, though the head of a Federal advisory panel recently recommended eliminating that cap.
THE changes have meant that patients often get less care than they would have under the old rules and that new graduates must look harder for jobs.
"When I actually got accepted to Jefferson, everybody was telling me what a great field it was," said Mr. Woods, who is 46. But now he is facing $50,000 in loans, on which he must start payments later this year, and the job prospects appear dim in the area around Philadelphia, where he lives. As he finishes his clinical training, Mr. Woods and his wife, Cynthia, a management training consultant, have begun to consider leaving the Northeast, a saturated market for physical therapists.
"We have two children, so that's a big issue," Mr. Woods said.
In contrast, Jennifer Sonn, who graduated from Thomas Jefferson in 1996, had three offers before she finished school and chose Presbyterian Medical Center in Philadelphia, which offered her a signing bonus 10 months before she graduated. She left the hospital last summer and now works for the Visiting Nurses Association, a nonprofit home health care agency, in Runnemede, N.J.
Though she is doing well, other experienced therapists have been hurt by the tightened job market. Of a dozen of her friends from Thomas Jefferson, Mrs. Sonn said, three have been laid off and two have taken pay cuts of up to $5,000 in the past year.
Martin Weinstein, a veteran therapist who practices in Flushing, Queens, said managed-care restrictions had cut his revenues by 35 percent in two years.
The physical therapy association, in Alexandria, Va., which represents about 49,000 of the nation's 116,000 or so licensed therapists, reported that 20 percent of 6,000 therapists surveyed in April said their hours had been reduced in the past six months, compared with 13 percent who said yes to the same question in October 1998. It also said that while unemployment among therapists who prefer working in nursing homes and home health care remained low, at 3 percent in April, the rate was still more than double the 1.2 percent last October. There was virtually no unemployment in those areas just three years ago, said the group's spokeswoman, Alexis Waters.
The association has not compiled industrywide unemployment figures this year. But even before the new law, a 1997 study commissioned by the group predicted a 20 percent to 30 percent surplus of therapists as early as 2005, citing the rising numbers of students and the managed-care companies' cost controls.
"Managed-care reimbursement has caused an impact on every aspect of health care," said Sandra Howell, interim chairwoman of the physical therapy department at the University of Southern California. "Patients are being discharged from the hospital a lot sooner, and there's less time for physical therapy, occupational therapy and a number of ancillary health professions."
Dr. Thomas Simmer, medical director of Health Alliance Plan, a health maintenance organization based in Detroit, said managed care companies are emphasizing cutting drug and hospital costs. "I do not believe that nationally or locally, physical therapy is undergoing that same type of energetic cost-reduction strategy," he said.
But Dr. Quillen of Indiana University said older patients already receiving therapy might not be able to afford further care if, say, they broke a bone. In many cases, he said, people "can very quickly exhaust their Medicare benefits."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Attacking Military Excess, From the Executive Office

BYLINE: By ERIC QUINONES 

 BODY:
WHY must Bell Industries, a computer services company in El Segundo, Calif., go all the way to India to hire programmers? The company's co-chairman, Theodore Williams, thinks it is because America doesn't have its priorities straight.
Mr. Williams says his frustration at being unable to find enough qualified Americans for the jobs is why he believes the goals of Business Leaders for Sensible Priorities are so important. The organization is a group of business people campaigning for fundamental changes in the way the Government uses its resources, and Mr. Williams is one of the founders. 
 To Mr. Williams and others in the group, the shortage of programmers is symptomatic of an education system that is starved of money and hurting America's competitiveness, all while billions of dollars are lavished on unproductive military spending. The group wants a higher budget priority for schools, health care for children and other programs to insure America's future economic vitality.
Led by an unabashed liberal activist, Ben Cohen, co-founder of Ben & Jerry's Homemade, the group has attracted members like Paul Newman and Ted Turner -- names that are decidedly not part of the business mainstream. But most of the group's members are lesser-known executives and business owners who hope their practical business background will give them credibility with lawmakers and voters.
The group steers away from the usual ideological and partisan camps. It does not ask its members about their party affiliations, and several members said in interviews that encouraging wiser spending was a goal that fit a conservative agenda as well as a liberal one.
" 'Conservative' means prudence, and 'conservative' means not spending money indiscriminately without a return," said Arnold Hiatt, chairman of the Stride Rite Foundation and another of the group's founders. "I think an awful lot of money is being spent, particularly in the Defense Department, not for the right reasons."
But pacifism isn't on the group's agenda, either.
"We are in favor of a strong military," said Bruce Klatsky, the chairman and chief executive of the Philips-Van Heusen Corporation, a clothing and shoe manufacturer, and also a founder of the group. "What we are against is the waste in the military."
The group's profile rose considerably late last year when it began an advertising campaign arguing that, with the cold war over, billions of dollars could safely be cut from nuclear weapons programs and from new generations of fighter aircraft and attack submarines meant to replace models that are already the world's best.
In expressing these views, the business group relies on several military advisers, including Lawrence Korb, assistant Defense Secretary in the Reagan Administration, and Paul C. Warnke, chief arms negotiator in the Carter Administration.
NOT surprisingly, the group's message is anathema to the military industry.
The Pentagon spent $44 billion on weapons last year, the least in more than a decade, said John W. Douglass, president and chief executive of the Aerospace Industries Association of America. Over all, he said, arms spending has fallen by 70 percent since the end of the cold war.
"Just to try to say that Americans have two choices, education or Pentagon waste, is just an outrageous oversimplification and unfair statement," Mr. Douglass said.
The business group counters that military spending is already rebounding. Even before NATO began bombing Yugoslavia in late March, the Clinton Administration was asking Congress for the biggest increase in military spending since the 1980's, an additional $112 billion over the next five years, raising the Pentagon budget to $319 billion by 2005.
"The fact that we're in a warlike state creates a climate for larger budget increases and less examination of the wastefulness that already exists," Mr. Newman said in an interview conducted before the Kosovo peace agreement was concluded late last week.
The business leaders' group has grown from 5 members in 1996 -- Messrs. Cohen, Williams, Hiatt and Klatsky, as well as Alan Hassenfeld, chairman and chief executive of Hasbro -- to 450 today.
Beyond the advertising campaign, the group is also paying for a bus tour called "U Slice the Pie." It began in April in Washington and is to run through November, spending a lot of time in Iowa, an early stop in the 2000 Presidential campaign.
At events like county fairs and church picnics, three young actors present the group's message using huge inflatable displays with statistics on budget allocations, military industry lobbying and job creation. The bus is painted to look like piles of cash; some of the executives have spoken at the stops.
"This issue of Federal budget priorities is kind of dry," Mr. Cohen said. "It's kind of off-putting to people. The object of the 'U Slice the Pie' performance is to make it fun and exciting."

HEADLINE: Trickle-Down Prosperity;
How Low the Boom Can Go

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
FOR the last eight years, the nation's economic boom, which has made so many Americans rich and self-confident, has been noteworthy for those it has left out: the people at the bottom of the ladder. Suddenly, that's changed. Unemployment rates among blacks and Hispanic people, though still high compared with that for whites, are at or near record lows. Joblessness among high school dropouts has fallen to about half the rate in 1992. And wages for the lowest paid are rising faster than inflation for the first time in decades.
That's important because the last generation produced an underclass of people so poor, discouraged and alienated that they were thought to exist almost outside the general economy. The conventional wisdom has been that the country could get richer or poorer, and the number of jobs could rise or fall, but a large swath of the poor would be left out. 
 Until recently that wisdom held true, but now prosperity is trickling down to the underclass. Imagine that the economy continues to flourish. The question then becomes how far down the ladder economic benefits will reach. Economists aren't sure, but they are gathering statistical tidbits, tossing in some educated hunches and producing some interesting predictions, however tentative.
Start with the nation's stunning 4.2 percent unemployment rate, which is lower than at any time since the late 1960's, when the economy was artificially buoyed by Government spending on the Vietnam War.
Perhaps overall unemployment cannot fall much more, no matter how tight the labor market becomes. The number of workers who are temporarily unemployed appears to have been squeezed to a minimum. And many of the long-term unemployed -- those who persistently look for work but can't find it -- will remain unattractive to employers no matter how big the boom.
But there is another category of people, including single mothers and young black men with few skills and little education, who appear willing to seize the new opportunities that a robust economy is creating.
Even under the best economic conditions, there are people who are temporarily out of work. At any moment, some workers quit their jobs. Others get fired. Students and spouses leave school and home to find their first jobs. All these people need time to find attractive jobs. Economists call this frictional unemployment and say it is a necessary feature of labor markets and nothing to fret about.
IN the super-charged economy of the 1960's, about 2 percent of the labor force was unemployed for fewer than five weeks. Today the percentage is about the same. So perhaps the time between jobs for qualified workers has contracted as much as it can, suggesting that further economic growth will produce little additional employment.
Prof. Robert Hall of Stanford University, after studying business cycles and current unemployment data, has concluded that, "Anyone who wants a job and is plausibly attractive to employers can find a job within a half-dozen weeks of searching." This may sound cavalier, given the fact that about five million people say they can't find suitable work. But economists across the political spectrum share Professor Hall's view.
THEN there are the long-term unemployed -- those who can't get hired even in the tightest labor markets. These people may be poorly educated, or have spotty work records or a history of crime. They may live in urban areas too far from suburban jobs for which they might qualify.
It is unclear how many of the long-term unemployed would find work if the economy continues to prosper. In the late 1960's, about 0.2 percent of the work force was unemployed for six months or more. Today the figure is three times higher. This suggests that a healthy economy alone may be incapable of reducing long-term unemployment to the levels achieved in the 1960's. This group might need other kinds of help like Government-provided training or subsidized jobs, though the record of such programs is hardly inspiring.
But if statistics for the temporary and long-term unemployed suggest that joblessness may have been driven as low as it can go, another jobless category appears to hold promise: the non-employed. This group includes all the unemployed plus those who don't bother looking for work and thus aren't counted among the jobless. These people may choose not to work, or may be physically or mentally incapable of holding jobs. Or they may be discouraged from seeking work because employers constantly reject their applications or because they are offered inadequate wages.
Among men aged 25 to 55, the non-employment rate is about 11 percent, compared with about 6 percent during the 1960's. Since there is no strong evidence that the rate of physical and mental disability has risen, it's worth asking whether the extra 5 percentage points -- several million people -- can be helped by a growing economy.
Robert H. Topel and Kevin Murphy of the University of Chicago think so. They say that most of those who dropped out of the labor force since the 1960's were low-skilled workers who gave up looking for jobs because of plummeting wages. Among men without a college education, wages have fallen about 25 percent over the past 25 years after accounting for inflation. But for the last two years wages for these workers have risen by 2 percent or 3 percent after inflation. Further economic expansion could bring a continued rise in pay and an attractive alternative for millions who have left the work force.
Other economists are more skeptical. A recent study by Richard B. Freeman of Harvard University and William M. Rodgers 3d of the College of William and Mary found that even in areas of the country with very tight labor markets, overall non-employment rates barely budged throughout the 1990's. That might suggest that relatively few non-working Americans would be drawn to work by an expanding economy.
And Gary Burtless of the Brookings Institution notes that income and other types of support for non-working people, like disability insurance payments, are much higher now than in the 1960's.
But the Freeman-Rodgers study cites one group that has made significant gains in tight labor markets: young black men without a college education, whose non-employment rate fell from 48 percent to 36 percent between 1992 and 1998. Though adult men barely registered gains in employment or earnings in the regions with tight labor markets, the earnings of young men -- including blacks without a college education -- rose by about 10 percent.
"The implication is that a long extended boom can go a long way to resolving the African-American youth employment problem," the report said.
Mr. Burtless points to another disadvantaged group that has been helped by the robust economy: single mothers, whose non-employment rate fell from 43 percent to 31 percent from 1992 to 1998. Mr. Burtless says that sharp improvement is due in part to welfare reform but also to a healthy economy.
HERE'S one encouraging reading of the tea leaves, even if it's unlikely that overall unemployment will dip much further: Those groups in the worst economic shape -- unskilled young black men and single mothers -- respond well to tight labor markets and would benefit from future economic prosperity.
And economists note that as more young black men and single mothers are absorbed into the labor force, they will gain work experience that will prove attractive to future employers and help them weather the next recession.
The strong economy has started to do for these groups what Government training programs have not accomplished: provide substantially higher earnings and employment. And if the economic boom continues for a few years, there is a chance it will do wonders for the disadvantaged workers who need help the most.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1571 words

HEADLINE: The World: Double Vision;
Two Views Of Inhumanity Split the World, Even in Victory

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
IT was a signal week for the West, no doubt about it. Fifty-four years after the Holocaust revelations, America and Europe had finally said "enough," and struck a blow against a revival of genocide.
Serbian ethnic cleansers were now routed; ethnic Albanians would be spared further murders and rapes. Germany was exorcising a few of its Nazi ghosts. Human rights had been elevated to a military priority and a pre-eminent Western value.
There was so much to applaud -- European unity, American technology, British spine, the stiff upper lips of the Greeks and Italians -- that it was easy to overlook the fact that much of the world was sitting on its hands. 
 Americans, flush with victory over Communism and inhumanity, think ever more reflexively that their values are the world's. In economics, that often is true. But to many other nations, the Kosovo atrocities that Germany equated with its own past and President Clinton labeled "vicious" and "terrifying" were just the broken eggs of yet another national omelet, and the West was a self-righteous, ever-more-meddlesome cook.
Chief among the nations that see Kosovo this way is Russia, and that is hardly a harbinger of smooth sailing in future efforts to right moral wrongs around the world.
True, Russia joined the diplomacy that forced Serbia's retreat from Kosovo and allowed 78 days of bombing to end. And its leaders promised to cooperate in peacekeeping -- even though a Russian unit rushed into Kosovo before NATO wanted it there.
But that is not the same thing as saying Russia shares the West's view that Kosovo is a turning point away from ethnic blood baths and toward harmony, even if at Western gunpoint. Quite the opposite: The war only underscored the deep ideological divide between an idealistic New World bent on ending inhumanity and an Old World equally fatalistic about unending conflict.
Woodrow Wilson tried to bridge that gap 81 years ago at Versailles, and failed. These days, his faith in internationalist ideals seems to be shared -- at least in their own backyard -- by the same British, French and Germans who were that day's nationalist cynics.
GO beyond Central Europe, however, and the world still seems rooted at Versailles, dismissing the notion of universal rights as wonderful in concept, and a foolish vanity in practice.
So the anti-West club is a big one -- not just perennial bad actors like Syria, Libya and Iraq, but rivals like China and even democracies like Russia and India. They are not motivated by love for Slobodan Milosevic -- by and large, they also find him and his tactics repulsive -- but by a conviction that bloodlettings like the one in Kosovo are internal matters; that it's arrogant and foolish to thrust yourself into someone else's war; that the safe and even humane course for the world usually is to let the two sides duke it out alone.
Put baldly, there is also a yawning gap between the West and much of the world on the value of a single life. Much of the world is still Hobbesian, looking to strongmen to impose order on lives that are nasty, brutish and short.
"It's the concept that the state as an entity is much more important than the life of one human being," said Yevgenia Albats, an author and independent journalist who writes about human rights issues here. "Pinochet is a hero in the press here. For a lot of writers, the fact that he killed 100,000 people before Chile had its economic miracle is just not a question."
THE West finds such views alien. But this war's epiphany may be that a lot of people around the world who drink Guinness, buy I.B.M. preferred and drive Audis just don't buy into Western notions of rights and responsibilities.
Consider the Russians, who by temperament, history and current attitudes are proving themselves the great case study for such attitudes.
"We're not only different countries; we're living in different dimensions," Leonid N. Dobrokhotov, an informal adviser to the Russian Communist Party leader, Gennady Zyuganov, said in a recent interview. "We have a completely different understanding of values. We're a very independent-minded people. Yes, maybe Saddam Hussein is the wrong guy. But let him live in his own country. If the Iraqis like it, it's their business. If they want to take him away and hang him, it's also their business."
The United States has absorbed this ideological slap in the face before, most recently from the Chinese. But America expects rebuffs from dictatorships like China. It is those new-found democrats, the Russians, who brought the message home in capital letters by turning overnight from ideological soulmates to embittered critics.
The first, most familiar explanation was that the Russians are the historic big Slavic brother to the Serbs. But that is only part of the story, and maybe not a big part. Moscow and Belgrade, after all, were estranged for most of the cold war.
No, more is at play here. In the words of the Russian Government -- and in the minds of many ordinary Russians -- it was NATO, not the Milosevic regime, that was a criminal organization, and NATO's air war, not ethnic cleansing, that was a humanitarian catastrophe.
No doubt the Russian backlash is rooted in part in Moscow's frustration at having to stand idly by at the drubbing of a country in its own backyard by its former enemies. But for Americans to view Moscow's anger as purely a political temper tantrum would be as mistaken as it is for Russians to view Kosovo as a Western land grab. For the truth is that Russians see Mr. Milosevic and Kosovo through an entirely different lens than do the United States and Western Europe.
Ethnic cleansing and forced migration are not exactly unknowns to Russians. Pogroms forced 1.5 million Russian Jews to flee at the turn of the century. And Nikita Khrushchev forcibly moved so many Russians to Kazakhstan that by 1959 native Kazakhs made up less than a third of the population. From Stalin on, Soviet policy was to dilute the Soviet Union's 80-odd ethnic groups by moving Russian citizens onto their territories, evicting them from homelands and drawing borders so as to split large ethnic groups in two.
Those carefully planned policies went south when the Soviet Union began to collapse, and nationalist strongmen began to take control. In 1988, United Nations officials say, a half-million Armenians and Azerbaijanis were driven back to homelands in each others' nations. In 1989, 60,000 Meskhetian Turks were forced out of Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan. In 1992 the Ossetians threw out tens of thousands of Inguish; hundreds of thousands of Tajiks fled Tajikistan. In 1995 scores of thousands died in a civil war in Chechnya.
Russians rapidly -- and correctly -- point out that these frenzies of ethnic retribution went virtually unnoticed by ordinary Westerners, and drew little more than hand-wringing from Western governments. And they wonder what is so different about Yugoslavia.
"Look at the leaders of almost all the newly independent states," said Sergei Rogov, the director of the Government's Institute of the U.S.A. and Canada. "Like Milosevic, they used to be leaders of the Communist Party before the collapse of Communism."
"And if you look at how they treat the ethnic minorities in the newly independent states, you'll see that Milosevic fits the pattern," he added. "He's not perceived as something outstanding."
But in Western Europe he is. Of course part of that is because Serbia is so close. Even as he declared victory Thursday, President Clinton added a caveat to the lessons of Kosovo for future ethnic cleansers: The world will act, he said, when "we can do something about it." But here, too, even more is at play.
Defeat, democratization and integration into Europe brought the Germans full circle. Unchecked slaughter in Bosnia and Rwanda shamed their neighbors into action. And now Western Europe has no stomach to watch Mr. Milosevic revive the bad memories, setting off ethnic expulsion and slaughters to consolidate the power of Serbs who don't like their neighbors.
Is that a step forward or a foolish vanity? Kosovo will be safe for Albanians, it seems, which is what 78 days of bombing were all about.
But nobody knows how many will return. Mr. Milosevic remains entrenched in Belgrade. Russia, burning at the popular notion that it has been a shill for NATO, is balking at Western efforts to oversee peacekeeping. And there is a new danger that radical Albanians will exact revenge on ordinary Serbs, starting the cycle anew.
It makes the Old World argument -- everyone does it; the world works this way; a few thousand Serbs or Albanians aren't important; it's none of our business -- seem almost attractive, even logical. It is not hard to envision the Russians nodding and saying, "Told you so."
Better to remember, however, that in attitude, if not behavior, Russia today is roughly whereBritain, Germany and France were 81 years ago. It took World War II to change the West's mind about inhumanity, and 50 years more to make that change of mind a commitment.
Ms. Albats, the journalist, says her nation needs time, too. "This is still imperial Russia," she said. "It's still the Soviet Union. The generation ruling this nation grew up in the Soviet Union, and you can't expect people to change their minds the way you change a rule on private property. But another generation is coming."

HEADLINE: WORKING;
The Cost Of Recharging

BYLINE: By MICHELLE COTTLE; Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer.

 BODY:

Q. After 15 years of working in sales and marketing for a Fortune 100 company, I need to make a change. I will most likely seek a position in a similar field, but first I need a break from the pressure. I have all but decided to quit my job and take a two-month respite. But if I do so, how much more difficult will it be to find another job? And how can I improve my chances? 

A. Even in a strong economy, getting a new job is easier when you already have one. Proving that a resignation was entirely voluntary can be tough; some old-school employers still view any gap in your employment record as a warning flag, said Edward D. Hendricks, a management consultant in Bridgeport, Conn.
Rather than dropping out of the rat race, consider moving into the slow lane. Many companies grant sabbaticals. You might try finding part-time consulting work, suggested Ruth J. Luban, a career counselor in Laguna Beach, Calif. In some cases, she added, you can even work as a consultant to the very company that you're leaving.
If consulting seems too daunting, think about going back to school, Mr. Hendricks said. Pick a topic or two that captures your interest and has practical applications in your field. Consider courses in Web design, for example, or in information technology advances. "Look for something that a new prospective employer would see as valuable," he said.
Still too much pressure? You could try developing your own informal (and low-key) learning regimen. Many of us have stacks of new computer software or industry-related reading that we'd like to go through, Ms. Luban said. Catching up on changes in your field -- and related fields -- can improve your prospects.
Despite the drawbacks of an extended break, it can put you in a much better frame of mind for job-hunting.
"Burnout so erodes your energy and self-concept that you're only 50 percent available to go out and sell yourself," Ms. Luban said. By recharging and rediscovering your passion for your work, you can make a much better impression than if you go to interviews when you're "fried and tired," as she put it.
"The biggest thing with burnout is that it does not go away by itself," she said. And it will only get worse if you jump directly into another high-impact job.
When you start looking for a new position, don't be defensive about taking a break. "De-emphasize the time out," Ms. Luban said. "Go in really pushing that you're the right person for the job."
If -- or, more likely, when -- an interviewer raises the issue, "lead with a positive, pro-active spin and explain the reasons why your time off was so productive," she said. Especially in today's tight labor market, many employers may be more interested in your abilities and experience.
"If you have the right skill set," she said, "you're going to land somewhere fairly soon."
 
Michelle Cottle is a Washington writer. Each week, she responds to readers' questions about career and workplace issues. Send them by E-mail to working@nytimes.com or by mail to Working, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: DATABANK: JUNE 7-11;
At Last, Japan Has Reason to Cheer

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
After two long years of pent-up emotions, Japanese traders and investors were able to let it all out on Friday. In the heaviest trading day in more than a decade, Japanese stocks rose as investors applauded the surprising 1.9 percent gain in Japan's first-quarter gross domestic product.
 Domestic traders were joined by overseas buyers sniffing out companies that would benefit most from a turnaround in Japan's economy. For the week, the benchmark Nikkei index rose 5.5 percent. 
 "Foreigners are taking the G.D.P. numbers at face value and are buying steelmakers and other cheap large-capital stocks," Takashi Miyazaki, strategist at Partners Asset Management, told Bloomberg News.
 For a change, the positive sentiment had a ripple effect. Shares rose in Hong Kong after a three-quarter point interest-rate cut in China on Wednesday and the release of Japan's growth figures. The Hang Seng index was up 4.6 percent for the week.
 In London, investors generally ignored an unexpected quarter-point interest rate cut on Thursday and rallied to close the week 2 percent higher.
 In the United States, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 3 percent for the week. MICKEY MEECE
