HEADLINE: Indonesia Changed, but Who Deserves the Credit?

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 12

 BODY:
"People say I look like a monkey," the President of Indonesia, B. J. Habibie, told an audience of schoolteachers not long ago. "But I don't care."
It was a strange moment of lese-majeste, described with a bemused shake of the head by Mr. Habibie's Minister of Education, Juwono Sudarsono. But this man, at once utterly un-self-conscious, effervescent, impulsive, scatterbrained, hyperactive and charming, is one of the most puzzling ever to rise to the forefront of public life in Indonesia, and one of the least understood. 
 This is the man who in the short space of one year overturned much of the repressive legacy of his predecessor and mentor, Suharto, and brought Indonesia galloping toward free elections and a new era of democracy.
Or is he?
Is Mr. Habibie responsible for freeing the press, bringing new respect for human rights and allowing dozens of political parties to compete on a newly open electoral playing field?
Or was he simply running scared, a weak leader helpless before a tidal wave of reform that swept all the country's politicians along with it?
Last Monday's parliamentary election was the capstone on a year of far-reaching transition that followed Mr. Suharto's forced resignation in May 1998. Already, people here seem to be taking their new freedoms for granted.
The outcome of Monday's vote is still unclear, with vote counting painfully slow. Whatever the result, Mr. Habibie may well be one of the leading candidates for President in an electoral assembly that will meet later this year, although few people, even in his own party, are touting him as a great reformer.
Most Indonesians seem rather to think that reform belongs to them, not to Mr. Habibie -- that it is a huge national movement born out of decades of frustration and that no one leader can lay claim to it.
If anyone can, perhaps, it may be Mr. Suharto himself, who fostered the economic development that allowed the nation to mature, to learn and then to reject his paternalistic form of leadership. In a way, the new post-Suharto era is also an extension of the old Suharto era, which ended in a blaze of violent protest that forced its maker from office.
Daniel S. Lev, an expert on Indonesia at the University of Washington, said, "It's hard to point to anything Habibie has come up with on his own."
"All he did, basically, was to recognize a whole bunch of faits accomplis," he said. "Free expression was hardly a gift; there was no way to stop it. He was under terrific pressure to come up with new laws, to get people out of jail and so on. These are concessions more than anything else. The guidance came from the streets."
The nation's post-colonial founder, Sukarno, was a father figure who gave Indonesia its identity. His successor, Mr. Suharto, developed the bureaucracy and brought economic growth. It will be the turn of the next President to begin the process of implanting democratic institutions and the rule of law, political analysts said.
In the interim, some analysts concede, Mr. Habibie may have been the right man for the moment -- pragmatic, optimistic and well versed in democratic values from his many years working as an aerospace engineer in West Germany.
Even his political weakness may have been an advantage, Mr. Juwono said. "In this period of openness, the last thing you want is a strong President. In a way, you could say his weakness is his strength."
But it is also true that Mr. Habibie's weakness is his weakness. By his nature, Mr. Habibie is a hard man to take seriously.
A shocking contrast to his studiously enigmatic predecessor and mentor, Mr. Habibie seems to be bubbling over with ideas that his aides say are sometimes brilliant, sometimes nutty.
"Habibie's problem as President is that people neither respect him nor fear him," a Western diplomat said.
This is a particular handicap in a nation that is accustomed to being governed by a powerful personality.
Mr. Juwono was also a Cabinet minister under Mr. Suharto and he seemed still to be under his spell, speaking of "the density of his silence."
"He would stare you in the face and create a sense of awe," Mr. Juwono recalled in a recent interview. "It was his presence and his stare. He looked right through you. Every five years, 1,000 people met in a congress and there was not one who was brave enough to stand up and say, 'Enough.' "
Mr. Habibie has another problem. Correctly or not, most people see him as a vestige of a despised old order who must be pushed aside before the country can truly move on.
His personal association with Mr. Suharto is strong. Mr. Suharto virtually adopted him as a boy and later brought him into public service as his Minister for Technology and Development. Three months before he resigned, Mr. Suharto named his friend to be Vice President.
There is an unanswered puzzle here. Though he was one of Mr. Suharto's oldest and closest friends and most obedient servants, it was Mr. Habibie who began almost from his first day in office uprooting the structure Mr. Suharto had built over three decades in power.
Although he remained studiously respectful of Mr. Suharto in his public comments, there may have been a personal rupture at the end. Aides say Mr. Habibie was badly hurt by a public display of disdain when Mr. Suharto presented his vice presidency as a sort of sick joke on the country.
Mr. Suharto warned critics explicitly, in so many words, "Watch out. If you drive me from power this is what you'll get."
The international financial markets responded in kind. It was on the day Mr. Habibie was named Vice President that the currency, the rupiah, fell to its lowest point, 17,000 to the dollar, less than one-sixth of its earlier value.
Mr. Habibie's claims to being a reformer have two weak points, both of them connected to Mr. Suharto's legacy. First, his Government has dodged and prevaricated in the face of public calls for an investigation of Mr. Suharto's stolen wealth. Second, he has allowed the military to evade calls for thorough investigations of past misconduct, putting only a few low-ranking officers on trial.
From one perspective, Mr. Habibie has virtually defined his presidency by overturning the Suharto legacy. But from another, he has shied away from directly challenging the abuses of the Government of which he was a key member.
As time passes and today's political battles fade, people here may begin to remember Mr. Habibie with affection as an eager and well-meaning man who met the needs of his day.
If nothing else, he gave Indonesians the freedom to laugh again, particularly at their President, and he laughed along with them.
Asked about criticisms that Mr. Habibie's possible successor as President, Megawati Sukarnoputri, may not be smart enough, a television commentator, Wimar Witoelar, offered a witticism that is now repeated everywhere.
"We already have a rocket scientist as President," he said, "and look where we are now."

HEADLINE: Latin America's Birth Surprise

 BODY:
Four months from now, the world's population is expected to hit six billion. Although it will continue to soar for decades to come, the population would be far higher if the last 30 years had not brought a significant drop in fertility in many regions. The drop is not surprising in rich countries and newly wealthy East Asian nations such as Taiwan and Singapore. More remarkable is the fertility drop in Latin America. A Times article last week detailed the change in Mexico, and similar gains have been made throughout the region. In the mid-1960's, Latin American women averaged more than 6 children. Today the average is 2.9. The benefits of smaller families are seen not only in a better life for children and their parents, but also in an increased savings rate and less cost to the state.
Latin America today is not markedly wealthier than in 1965. But its women have much higher levels of education, access to health care and employment. Latin American nations must do more to reduce their birth rates, but they are ahead of South Asia and especially Africa. Even as those regions struggle to get richer, they could reap the benefits of smaller families by making contraception available and emphasizing women's basic well-being. 
 Mexico's family-planning campaign is the major one initiated by a government. In 1974, Mexico established a network of clinics, and Government-sponsored billboards touting the benefits of small families are ubiquitous. In the rest of Latin America, governments reluctant to defy the Catholic Church have mainly left family planning to private groups, most of which got their start with financing from the United States Agency for International Development and the International Planned Parenthood Federation. Today, those groups are trying to become self-sufficient, as donors switch their focus to South Asia and Africa. They have also been hurt by hundreds of millions of dollars in cuts for overseas family planning engineered by Republicans in Congress.
The acknowledged leader is Colombia's Profamilia, founded in 1965. Profamilia has been a pioneer in many now-common techniques -- the use of radio to promote family planning, a network of trained volunteers offering contraceptives and information door to door, mobile sterilization vans and now special clinics for men. The most remote Colombian village has a bodega stocking Profamilia's pills and condoms. Now Profamilia, with grants from the Dutch Government and the United Nations, is training others.
Contraceptives became available because Latin American women demanded them as they began to get more education. Today, unlike any other region in the developing world, Latin American girls are just as likely as boys to be in school, except in the most rural areas.
Growing urbanization, which turns children from economic asset to burden, and increasing job opportunities for women have helped reduce the birth rate. In many nations, there has also been an expansion of social security, which lessens the need for children as old-age insurance. In addition, millions have had their first exposure to doctors and modern medicine.
Even television may have played a role. The evidence is strongest in Brazil, which, surprisingly, has a lower birth rate than its richer and better-educated neighbors. Vilmar Faria, a Brazilian sociologist, and Joseph Potter, a University of Texas sociologist, argue that the drop in fertility tracks the spread of television -- dominated by the universally popular nightly soap operas known as telenovelas. For many poor, the telenovelas provided their first glimpse of small, less authoritarian families and of consumer culture. Women realized they could choose fewer children, and that children had a cost.
For all the machismo in Latin America, women there have gained substantially more rights and better treatment than women in the rest of the developing world. The region's experience shows that this is the most important key to limiting the population explosion.

HEADLINE: Swiss Will Decide if Motherhood Warrants Salary Protection

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 12

 BODY:
The Swiss will decide on Sunday whether to provide new mothers with the kind of salary protections that every other Western European country affords women after they give birth.
While such benefits are tenuous in the United States, they are common in Europe. Only Switzerland fails to guarantee a woman's salary following childbirth -- even though it requires by law that women take eight weeks off after having a baby. 
 The Netherlands grants new mothers between 16 and 68 weeks off at 100 percent guaranteed salary. Britain allows 18 weeks at 90 percent of wages, Austria allows up to two years at reduced wages, with a guarantee of the same job back, and the Scandinavian countries all have generous benefits. Even tiny Liechtenstein guarantees new mothers 12 weeks off at 80 percent pay.
Opponents argue that money for the new benefits would come from state coffers, which are already strained by above-average unemployment.
The proposal would require employers to grant a 14-week leave at 80 percent salary and allow mothers in lower income families -- regardless of whether they work -- a certain sum for "maternity leave."
The proposal is part of a packet of options, including whether to toughen Swiss asylum laws and to continue to subsidize heroin treatment, being put before voters in Switzerland's direct democracy system.
The maternity benefits were approved in principle in 1945, but the Swiss have voted down three attempts -- in 1971, 1984 and 1987 -- to put the policy into practice.
"If there were a Nobel Prize for patience, it would be given to Swiss women," Switzerland's President, Ruth Dreifuss, said in launching a campaign for the benefits.
"There is no real maternity benefit for a young woman today, even though it was promised to her grandmother," she said. "Fifty-four years of waiting, that's enough."
She and the Justice Minister, Ruth Metzler -- neither of whom has children -- have campaigned energetically for the proposal.
Among its opponents is a conservative, Veronique Fontana, a mother and lawyer in Lausanne.
"It's a family choice," she said in an interview. "I worry when people tell me this will make the difference whether they have a child or not."
She said that most Swiss women are insured against income loss after pregnancy and that welfare benefits are already generous.
In fact, some Swiss women already benefit from ample maternity plans. For instance, the canton of Vaud, just east of Geneva, allows women 16 weeks of leave at full salary. According to Government statistics, employers in Switzerland provide maternity benefits totaling some $225 million a year.
But workplace conditions vary widely in Switzerland, where federal statistics say that women are often paid up to 30 percent less than men.
The benefits' backers say the annual cost, estimated at $333 million, could be met from surplus Government funds and a small sales tax increase. Employers are fighting against the benefits, arguing that they would add to labor costs.
Last month, on Mother's Day, Ms. Dreifuss told a rally that women should be able to become mothers without worrying about money. Her call came two days after a poll indicated that most voters favored increasing maternity support. Later polls have been less definitive.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: REFUGEES;
Aid Agencies Shift Focus To the Needs Inside Border

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: KUKES, Albania, June 12

 BODY:
The refugees stopped arriving only three days ago, but now, like trying to turn around a battleship, the aid agencies handling the 120,000 Kosovo Albanians in this border town are having to reverse focus to the refugees' safe return -- plus preparing to feed and help shelter an estimated 500,000 Albanians still inside Kosovo.
"This has not been the biggest refugee movement, and it's not been the worst emergency, but it's shaping up to be by far the most complex," said Rupert Colville, a spokesman for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. 
 Although aid organizations say there is no evidence so far of starvation, refugees crossing the border in recent days say they left family members behind who had run out of food.
One refugee who had been imprisoned by the Serbs and then released this week near the Albanian border, and who said he was too frightened to give his name, said he was worried about his wife and six children left behind in the village of Zhabar I Ulet in northern Kosovo.
"For three days they didn't have anything to eat," he said. "They didn't have enough flour to make bread."
Relief agencies say they have heard reports of Kosovo Albanian "displaced persons," as they call them, hiding in the mountains but moving from hamlet to hamlet looking for something to eat. "They've been scavenging in empty houses," said Anna DiLellio, a spokeswoman for the World Food Program.
Two weeks ago, a United Nations mission in Kosovo determined that on top of widespread destruction -- burned houses, destroyed roads and bridges -- one third of the arable land in Kosovo had not been cultivated this year. In addition, Serbian forces had taken over the main World Food Program warehouse in Kosovo, where they were said to be charging the equivalent of $2.50 for a pound of sugar -- an astronomical price in impoverished Kosovo. They also have reportedly shot cows, goats and sheep. "I think -- forget milk," Ms. DiLellio said.
Although only a few relief workers are to go into Kosovo from Albania on Sunday behind NATO troops, United Nations aid agencies are preparing to establish offices in seven cities in Kosovo within the next weeks. The World Food Program expects they will find that many people in Kosovo have no electricity and water and are unable to cook and so has readied 1.5 million ready-to-eat daily meals intended to last three months.
The ration comes in a yellow plastic bag, with "Food Gift from the People of the United States" printed prominently on the front, in three different varieties, or "menus" that contain a one-day supply of food.
Menu No. 3 contains a compressed rice loaf, shrink-wrapped in thick plastic, that tastes like a dry, cinnamon-flavored rice pudding. It also includes a shrink-wrapped rice with vegetables in sauce, a fruit pastry bar, vegetable crackers, shortbread cookies, blackberry jam, peanut butter and a book of matches (for smokers) with an American flag and "U.S.A." on the cover.
Today aid agencies continued to prepare returning refugees about the danger of land mines, many of which are thought to have been placed in the border area. Tehnaz J. Dastoor, Unicef's specialist in land mines, and Eric M. Filippino, a demining expert from Geneva, held a class this afternoon at the Unicef office here to educate a group of 16 Kosovo Albanian youths, elected "representatives" from five of the refugee camps here.
They also showed the representatives posters warning about land mines that are to go up in the refugee camps and asked for their opinions about them -- in essence, test-marketing.
"What is the first thing you thought when you saw it?" Mr. Filippino asked the group about a poster showing a land mine with a large hand covering its spike that simultaneously prevents a small child's foot from stepping on it.
"You must be careful when you walk," said Sanije Seferaj, 23, an economics student from Pristina, the Kosovo capital, who now lives in the Kukes I refugee camp.
Aid workers here are nervously hopeful that the refugees will heed the lessons and return slowly but are worried about the possibility of a chaotic rush to the border after NATO troops go in. Although NATO will be clearing the main paved road toward Pristina of mines, the troops will not get to the fields and smaller roads for some time.
"Most of the roads in Kosovo are dirt roads," said Ms. Dastoor. "It's going to be a huge process."

HEADLINE: A Feeding Frenzy For the Epicure;
A Question as Fancy Markets Multiply: Who's Eating All That Caviar?

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The astonishing explosion of New York City's specialty food markets began as a gustatory version of Genesis: in the beginning there was Balducci's, Dean & DeLuca and Zabar's. And they were good. And culinary darkness no longer blighted the face of Manhattan. And the merchants said: let there be more.
And so there was Vinegar Factory and Gourmet Garage and Eli's Manhattan and Healthy Pleasures and Grace's Marketplace and Agata & Valentina and Garden of Eden Farmers Markets and Amish Manhattan Farmers Markets and a grand mitosis of Greenmarkets. 
 And they were good. But just how much of a good thing can you have before it becomes, well, bad? Is the city now the world's capital of gourmet glut?
"There is just so much stuff for sale, it can be really confusing," said Chris Sadoff, a violinist who has lived on West 73d Street for two decades and has watched her neighborhood become a microcosm of the city's galloping gastronomy. "Who are these people living on caviar all the time? I'm not sure why all these stores are opening."
She was peering into the new addition at Fairway on Broadway and 74th Street, now the epicenter of a fiercely competitive seven-block food fight on the West Side of Manhattan. In coming weeks the market, which has expanded three times since 1975, will complete its incursion into the two-story space that was once the no man's land between no-frills Fairway and its primordial rival, Citarella, where fish, meats, poultry and produce are arrayed like jewelry on two floors at the corner of West 75th Street.
Only 60 paces to the south of Fairway, Food Emporium -- perhaps aspiring to capitalize on the hungry hordes from Donald Trump's Riverside South development -- established its 22d upscale beachhead in December. The store even has a green-and-white-uniformed doorman with a gold-braided cap who calls cabs for customers. He directs shoppers to the sleek escalator that takes them down to the anti-Fairway: a cheerful 21,000-square-foot basement space.
And to the north, plugging the Broadway gap between Citarella and the legendary Zabar's on West 80th Street, the unlegendary Westside Supermarket gives customers yet another shopping option at the corner of West 77th Street.
In the bull-market, fin-de-siecle rush to excess, the city's gourmet generals have been seizing strategic territory. A year after the perpetually expanding Fairway leapfrogged north to establish a bastion at 132d Street and 12th Avenue, Citarella opened a satellite across town from its main store, at 75th Street and Third Avenue; Citarella has leased another space in Grand Central Station.
And Gourmet Garage -- the warehouse-style purveyor that provides specialty foods to 180 restaurants, including Le Cirque 2000 and the Four Seasons -- has cloned itself in four Manhattan locations since 1992. "We are expanding aggressively, and our plan is to do two or three new stores a year," said John S. Gottfried, a partner, who said he has made offers on two new properties.
Eli Zabar's Vinegar Factory on East 91st Street, which was originally opened by Gourmet Garage and taken over by its landlord, Mr. Zabar, has siblings at Eli's Manhattan on Third Avenue at 80th Street, and E.A.T. on Madison Avenue at 80th.
Balducci's has planned to establish suburban satellites. Balducci family feuds led to a diaspora and the establishment of the high-end Agata & Valentina at 79th Street and First Avenue (which recently doubled its space) as well as the upscale Grace's Marketplace at 71st Street and Third Avenue, which also has expanded and added a butcher.
Whole Foods Market has leased 40,000 square feet of space on Seventh Avenue and 24th Street for a blockbuster organic food market. Healthy Pleasures on University Place in the Village, which claims to be the city's largest natural foods store, has opened a satellite in SoHo on Broome Street.
Amish Manhattan Farmers Market in Hell's Kitchen opened a sibling on East 45th Street near Third Avenue, and just this month unveiled another at Cedar Street. And the two Garden of Eden Farmers Markets, in Gramercy Park and Chelsea, are planning an outpost on West 14th Street.
The food retailing frenzy leaves some shoppers all epicured out. "I have five places now where I can buy cheese instead of two," said Nora Ephron, the director and writer, who lives in the Zabar's orbit and who shot scenes there for her most recent film, "You've Got Mail." "At first I thought, well, someone will go out of business, but apparently there is no telling how much food you can sell."
While many consumers are benefiting from runaway variety, new challenges are being posed by the New York's superabundance of brie. "It is very easy to go into one of these places and walk out with a small bag that costs you $100," said Tim Zagat, whose latest New York City Marketplace Survey has just been published, an overview of 1,360 food purveyors.
Hardy specialty food shoppers have refined their coping strategies. Especially scorned by the store owners are the bargain-hunting cherry pickers, who "go for sale items," said one store manager. "We don't make any money on them."
Then there's the uptown strategy. David Brody, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History, walks north along "the strip," as he calls it, heading from the Food Emporium to Zabar's. "I check the price, I see what's fresh, what looks good. It's entertainment."
Contrarily, Mildred Grant favors the downtown search, starting at 75th Street. "I just start at Citarella and work my way south," she said, winding up at Food Emporium, owned by the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, "for sales and staples." She smiled. "I was born to shop."
There are even those so victimized by gourmet glut that they totally opt out of high-end shopping. "It's too crazy here," said Nina Rhodes, a West Side resident for 20 years, as she glanced past the sidewalk flower stand to the frenzy within Fairway. "I just go to the A.& P on West End Avenue and 70th, where it's not so hectic."
These days, shoppers are not only sought after, but studied. "You need a population of about 14,000 upper-income people to support one of these stores," said Mr. Gottfried of Gourmet Garage. With their high-margin offerings and prepared foods, specialty markets can soar: their competitors estimate that Zabar's and Fairway, only six blocks apart, each take in $50 million in revenue each year.
Still, the current market proliferation is surprising, given the hard realities of the business. Yearly retail rents of $100 to $150 a square foot in Manhattan make opening new stores prohibitively expensive in the fickle, labor-intensive grocery business. Worse, experts say that for every 10 feet of selling space, a store needs about 3 feet of nonproductive storage and preparation space.
Furthermore, merchants cannot throw in a few tubs of Kumomoto oysters just anywhere and reap a windfall. Mr. Gottfried estimated that the market for Manhattan specialty food stores is "about 80 percent saturated, but there are still neighborhoods that haven't been penetrated."
Beyond this, the city's retail specialty food economy, which analysts estimate at close to $300 million, "is incredibly competitive," said Saul Zabar, president of Zabar's, the gastronomic landmark that has been around since 1936. "We are always running scared here, and we have to be on our toes more than ever. That said, all I know is that we are selling substantially more fish and prepared foods than we did last year."
Although the turf battles can get sort of ugly (Fairway and Citarella actually engaged in an awning war this year), even fierce competitors see an advantage in proximity. "We overlap with Fairway's customers," said Mindy A. Birnbaum, a spokeswoman for Citarella, when asked about the Fairway expansion. "So if more people come to the block, then we're bound to benefit."
Citarella's archrival was no less optimistic. "I think there is an infinite market for the good operators," said Howard Glickberg, an owner of Fairway. "The Red Apples, the Sloan's, they draw 90 percent of their customers from a four-block area. But we draw from all over."
Indeed, the specialty merchants are such a draw that bus companies are mounting day trips for food worshipers. "Our first stop is Zabar's," said Greg Abbott, a spokesman for Dattco in New Britain, Conn., which conducts a "Noshing Tour" of Manhattan 20 times a year. After about 50 foodies per bus load have descended on Zabar's, they head back into their red-and-white M.C.I. tour bus and proceed to Balducci's. That is followed by a visit to Guss's Lower East Side Pickles, a tour of Chinatown markets and finally a stroll through Little Italy.
But academics are traveling even greater distances. "My students ooh and aah in these markets," said Nancy Graham, an assistant professor in the hospitality department of Morehead State University in Morehead, Ky. She and her daughter stood near the $2.99-a-pound New Zealand pears at Fairway and explained that they had brought 13 of their hotel students to New York to research the exotic markets of the natives, starting at Balducci's and working their way up to Zabar's.
Given such interest, some insist that New York markets are poised to conquer the nation. "Whatever food you may want in Sioux City, Iowa, you can have it delivered in less than 24 hours, through mail order and the Internet," Mr. Zagat said. "Soon every major store in New York will be on line and available to the entire country."

HEADLINE: Competing Plans to Help Working Poor

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
Only weeks after they infuriated Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani by abolishing the city's commuter tax, Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature are now hinting that they may impede his plan to give a tax break to the working poor.
The proposal, an earned-income tax credit for families who make less than $30,000 a year, is one of three tax cuts to survive in the budget that Mr. Giuliani and the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, have proposed for the fiscal year that begins July 1. The Mayor, a Republican, and Mr. Vallone, a Democrat, had been seeking an array of tax cuts worth hundreds of millions of dollars, but abandoned nearly all of them because of the repeal of the commuter tax for New York State residents. The repeal, which is being challenged in court, would cost the city up to $360 million a year. 
 In the $35.3 billion budget they agreed on last week, they clung to three tax breaks totaling $348 million: the earned-income tax credit, which would save 600,000 families an average of $100 a year; an extension of a tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums, and a repeal of the sales tax on clothing that costs less than $110.
Mr. Pataki and the Legislature, whose approval is required for all tax cuts enacted in New York City, signed off on the sales tax initiative last year.
But the proposal for the $48 million earned-income tax credit, which would be the first in the nation offered by a city, comes at a time when legislative leaders in Albany want to spend at least $170 million to expand a similar tax credit offered by the state. City and state lawmakers both want to pay for their proposals with Federal welfare money that has piled up in the state treasury as the state's welfare rolls have declined.
State legislators have proposed using the surplus not only for the expanded tax credit, but also for a number of other state programs to keep the working poor off welfare. They also want to set aside a large portion of the surplus in case an economic downturn increases the welfare rolls.
The Giuliani administration says the city is entitled to a portion of the welfare surplus, which totals more than $1 billion, because it has generated most of the savings. But some state officials and advocates for the poor say the state's claim comes first. "The city is second in line behind the state for the money," said Russell Sykes, vice president of the State Communities Aid Association, which has been pushing for an increase in the state credit. "They have backed themselves into a corner by relying on a funding source that is very risky."
Aides to Sheldon Silver, the Assembly Speaker, and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, said that while they were not opposed to having earned-income tax credits at the city and state levels, they had reservations about sharing the welfare surplus with New York City. Michael McKeon, a spokesman for Mr. Pataki, said only that a number of programs were competing for the surplus funds.
"There are a number of well-intentioned competing interests, the earned-income tax credit among them," Mr. McKeon said. "But we will be looking at the allocation of that funding within the context of the overall state budget."
The other city tax cut that needs state approval -- an extension of a property tax relief program for owners of co-ops and condominiums -- is already moving through the Republican-controlled Senate, said John McArdle, a spokesman. But it may be held up in the Assembly, because the Mayor attached it to another property tax bill that Mr. Silver, a Democrat, opposes.
The other bill would change the rules for challenging property tax assessments in New York City. Under state law, city property owners can use recent sales prices of comparable buildings to challenge their assessment. But city officials say recent sales prices are not the most accurate measure of a property's worth, because the city's real estate market is so volatile.
Mr. Giuliani's bill would change the rules so that property owners could challenge their assessment only if it did not accurately reflect their building's income and operating expenses. Mr. Silver is holding up the bill -- and with it, the tax break for co-op and condominium owners -- because he thinks it limits property owners' chances of winning challenges to unfair assessments, his aides said.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani said they linked the two property tax bills in hopes of getting both passed at once. But Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Mr. Silver, said it was more likely that the Assembly would approve the co-op and condominium bill separately. The bill -- actually an extension of a tax abatement that has been in place for three years -- would save the owners of 285,000 dwellings an average of $600 a year.
But while city officials are worried about the fate of their property tax legislation, they appeared angrier last week about the resistance to their earned-income tax credit. Mr. Vallone questioned how state lawmakers could reject the city's request for a piece of the welfare surplus after stripping the city of commuter tax revenues. "They already put a deep hole in our budget," Mr. Vallone said. "I don't think they should be deepening that hole."
But Mr. Sykes of the State Communities Aid Association said it made more sense for the state to apply the surplus funds to its own earned-income tax credit, because the proposed increase would affect far more families than the city's plan. The expansion would increase the maximum credit per family to $1,127 from $751. About 1.1 million wage earners statewide qualify for the credit, and half of them live in New York City.
In comparison, about 600,000 households would qualify for the city's credit, with a maximum credit of $191 per family. Since the cost of the program -- $48 million -- is relatively small in the context of the city's $35 billion budget, the city should pay for it with its own money, Mr. Sykes said. "It's not a huge credit," he said. "Why can't the Giuliani administration absorb the cost?"
It could, said Douglas A. Criscitello, director of the city's Independent Budget Office. But city officials might prefer to let the tax cut die if Albany refuses to pay for it, he said, because state lawmakers -- already the target of New Yorkers' wrath because of the commuter tax repeal -- would probably get the blame.
"They've put the ball totally in Albany's court," Mr. Criscitello said. "So Albany gets the black eye."
City officials refused to say whether they would proceed with the tax cut if they were denied welfare surplus funds. But Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, said there was no question that the city deserved a piece of the surplus, because more of its residents have left the welfare rolls than those of any other city in the state. "Any distribution of that money that doesn't share it with the communities that helped create it would be unfortunate and unfair," Mr. Lhota said.

HEADLINE: The 2 Koreas Are Unrelenting in Standoff Over Sea Border

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sunday, June 13

 BODY:
North Korean vessels staged tactical intrusions into disputed waters today, as South Korea struggled to avoid armed clashes ahead of crucial peace talks.
A flotilla of North Korean military and fishing vessels moved in and out of a buffer zone in the Yellow sea, trying the patience of South Korea's navy, military officials said. 
 The change came after South Korean vessels rammed North Korean boats Friday to push them out of the zone, which has been used by North Korean spies for infiltration.
"Forebearance is required in such a war of nerves," a South Korean Defense Ministry official said. "We are trying to prevent the weeklong standoff from escalating into clashes."
Today, up to seven North Korean military vessels intruded twice into the area guarded heavily by South Korean patrol boats and frigates, he said.
"They were returning to their waters whenever our vessels scrambled with warning signals."
The two Koreas have agreed to open high-level official talks in Beijing next week, as part of Seoul's drive to ease tension through gradual and peaceful engagement.
The breakthrough followed a trip to North Korea by a United States envoy, William Perry, with offers to provide economic and political benefits in return for a halt to nuclear development and military threats.
The last round of talks in Beijing 14 months ago broke down after North Korea refused to come up with a timetable for the reunion of families separated since the division of the Korean peninsula in 1945.
The sea row since Monday has heightened tensions between the two Koreas, still technically at war following their 1950-53 conflict. But Seoul stressed it should not disrupt the Beijing meeting.
The United Nations Command has urged North Korea to recognize a border line declared in 1953, describing the repeated intrusions as "a provocative act."
But the North's military turned down the United Nation Command's proposal, saying it was prepared to launch "self-defensive strikes."
South Korea has put the army, navy and air force on alert, dispatched dozens of ships, frigates and destroyers to the area and tightened air security checks.
Shore guns, guided missiles and submarines were also put on standby along with a special combat team.
The buffer zone is close to Seoul and has been tightly guarded by South Korea since the Korean conflict ended with no peace treaty signed. Seoul has warned Pyongyang the standoff could lead to an armed conflict.
Analysts and Western diplomats said the North looked ever more desperate to harvest crabs, which can be sold for hard cash.
But Pyongyang also appeared to be sabre-rattling ahead of the inter-governmental talks later this month, in a move aimed at winning concessions, they said.
The buffer zone was set up below the maritime border at the end of the 1950-53 war. There have been armed clashes in the same area. The northerners frequently enters the area in the lucrative crab season but usually leave when ordered by the South Korean military.

HEADLINE: Auctioning Off the Treasures of Ralph Kramden and Scarlett

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
What price memory? How much of today's cash does it take to own a vestige of yesterday's passion?
For someone else's Oscar, Michael Jackson paid $1,542,500 at Sotheby's yesterday. The singer's winning bid, for the gold-plated Best Picture statuette awarded in 1939 to the producer David O. Selznick for "Gone With the Wind," dwarfed the previous Oscar auction record of $607,500 paid in 1996. 
 But Mr. Jackson, whose own doodads have occasionally gone on the auction block and who has been known to bid on esoteric items like an obscure Sinclair Lewis novel, was not alone in taking nostalgia to inflationary heights.
For a slate-blue wool jacket and matching pants worn about 45 years ago by the overweight (49 1/2-inch waist, 49 3/4-inch chest) Brooklyn bus driver Ralph Kramden, a k a Jackie Gleason, an unidentified but obviously devoted fan of the "The Honeymooners" television shows paid $64,100.
Understandably, as he banged his gavel, the Sotheby's auctioneer murmured, "How sweet it is."
For a pink percale dress with ruffled sleeves and lace collar worn by Vivien Leigh as Atlanta burned in "Gone With the Wind," a darkly beautiful Brazilian woman in a black fishnet veil and prim black gloves paid $90,500.
She would identify herself only as Elizabeth, the proud owner of trunkloads of Ms. Leigh's hats and clothing and a Sao Paolo restaurant named, not surprisingly, Scarlett's.
Deepening the mystery with hyperbole, her 11-year-old son, Rodrigo, said his mother was famous back home not only for greeting her customers in full Southern belle gloved-and-petticoated regalia, but also for having seen "Gone With the Wind" upward of 8,000 times since her first fateful encounter with the movie 31 years ago, when she was an impressionable 8-year-old girl.
And finally, although perhaps on a slightly different scale, a Manhattan psychologist recaptured a bit of his childhood for $1,035, buying a wooden mural of a clown and a dashing bejeweled couple riding a carpet through the clouds that once adorned the Magic Carpet ride at Coney Island.
"It was more thrilling than any roller coaster," said Barry S. Lubetkin, recalling how the whole chair of the ride collapsed and left its screeching occupant involuntarily recumbent. "It's one of my strongest memories."
Dr. Lubetkin, now 55, said he intended to hang his newly acquired amusement park memorabilia above the couch in his office. "I'm a shrink," he joked. "I use magic carpets in therapy."
Other pieces of Coney Island rides and attractions also were sold at prices up to $10,350, for the garish seven-foot-tall bubble-blowing clown face that used to delight children at the Brooklyn park.
But perhaps Coney Island's most famous lady, the mechanical Fat Lady called Minnie Ha Ha, did not draw a bid high enough to be sold.
Its owner, Leonard Goodstein, said he would put it on display at the Brooklyn Historical Society museum. "It's time," he said, "to let my childhood go."
The price paid for Mr. Selznick's Oscar was vastly higher than the $200,000 to $300,000 estimate made by Sotheby's in advance of the auction, which also sold the final shooting script belonging to the producer's script assistant on "Gone With the Wind" for $33,350.
Cinema flotsam, especially from the classics, has fetched increasingly high prices over the past decade, but the interests and passion of film buffs and collectors can be wildly unpredictable.
Clark Gable's leather-bound script from "Gone With the Wind" brought $77,000 in 1994. But in 1996, the director Steven Spielberg bought Mr. Gable's Oscar for his role as a reporter in "It Happened One Night" for $607,500 and then presented it as a gift to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.
Television and rock aficionados, at least those at Sotheby's yesterday, do not appear to have the same deep pockets.
A pair of John Lennon's wire-rimmed prescription glasses sold for $25,875 and an album cover of "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" signed by all four Beatles brought $57,500.
The kitchen suite -- a battered table and chairs, a dresser and icebox -- from "The Honeymooners" show during the 1960's, when Gleason and friends filmed it in Miami, was bought for $63,000 by the TV Land cable network.
Larry W. Jones, the network's general manager, said he planned to take the furniture from Ralph Kramden's fictional cold-water flat on the road to promote his company's airing of reruns from the show, starting in January.
Sotheby's officials said they could not identify the buyer of the oversized blue bus driver's outfit worn, around the mid-1950's, by Gleason. The bid was received by telephone.
But Peter Crescenti, one of the two remaining members of Ralph, the Royal Association for the Longevity and Preservation of the Honeymooners, said the outfit was one of very, very many produced over the years.
"Gleason was notorious for having his weight go up and down," said Mr. Crescenti, who put the Gleason memorabilia up for sale. "So there were a lot on hand."
The jacket and pants sold were from one of the star's heavier periods.

HEADLINE: A Discredited President Returns to Mexico

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 12

 BODY:
Interrupting a four-year exile, former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari visited Mexico today for the first time since his tumultuous departure in 1995, when he left behind a brother accused of murder, a country in economic crisis, and a presidential legacy under siege.
Mr. Salinas's return provoked scattered demonstrations, hundreds of angry calls to radio talk shows, and accusations by political opponents that the visit had been timed to influence Mexico's presidential campaign for next spring's elections. 
 Mr. Salinas told reporters he had returned for a two-day visit to attend to his ailing father and to other family matters. But the visit appeared to follow a carefully written political script.
In television interviews and other encounters with the news media that were choreographed hour by hour, Mr. Salinas defended his presidency, which ran from 1988 to 1994, and especially his efforts to modernize the Mexican economy. He also acknowledged mistakes.
"We were pioneers," the former President said. "And pioneers often make errors."
He especially lamented what he said was his failure to more closely oversee his older brother, Raul, who amassed an illicit fortune during his presidency and who was convicted last year of killing a political rival.
Mr. Salinas has spent his exile in Ireland, with frequent visits to other European countries, Cuba and occasionally the United States. He arrived in Mexico City this morning on a private jet after a flight from London via the Bahamas, he said, and said he intends to leave on Sunday.
His visit roiled political currents in Mexico that have already been whipped up by an unprecedented public struggle for the presidential nomination of the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party; a growing controversy over the finances of the 1994 campaign of his successor, President Ernesto Zedillo, and a continuing investigation into a $65 billion banking bailout.
Mr. Zedillo, an economist and a technocrat, retained many senior officials from the Salinas administration and continued many policies of his predecessor, who, in office, was regarded as a modernizer. Yet Mr. Zedillo enjoys considerable popularity while Mr. Salinas these days is one of Mexico's most reviled figures.
"He ruined my lunch!" shouted an enraged caller to TV Azteca minutes after an interview with Mr. Salinas was broadcast. "That man is not a true Mexican. How can he be allowed to move around freely here?"
Even in a political system where Presidents are exalted with king-like powers and then sometimes blamed for all the country's ills when they leave office, Mr. Salinas's fall from grace was one of the bitterest.
This is so largely because he brought broad and painful changes to the Mexican economy, including the sale of state industries that resulted in millions of workers becoming unemployed.
Weeks after he left office on December 1, 1994, speculators began to attack the peso, which had become overvalued as foreign investment capital left the country and a severe imbalance of trade developed. Mr. Zedillo, only recently in office, was forced to devalue. The peso, cut free to trade at market value, plunged in value -- setting off a financial crisis that would soon undermine the broad economy as interest rates soared and credit became virtually unavailable for many borrowers.
At least 500,000 Mexicans were thrown out of work and banks as well as borrowers were plunged into an economic crisis that continues, to a degree, to this day.
Two months later, the police arrested Raul Salinas on murder charges. The former President tried to defend his brother by announcing a hunger strike, then abandoned it days later, and after a secret meeting with President Zedillo flew to the United States.
At the time, aides to Mr. Zedillo who spoke anonymously to reporters said that Mr. Salinas had been forced into exile. Publicly, Mr. Zedillo and Mr. Salinas have always denied that Mr. Salinas's departure was forced.
Aides to Mr. Zedillo repeated those denials today in portraying Mr. Salinas's return as a strictly personal decision. "There was absolutely nothing to prevent him from returning," a presidential aide said. "He's not been charged with any crime; there's no lawsuit, no investigation. His absence until now has been his own free choice."
Mr. Salinas's visit seemed carefully planned. A secretary called scores of foreign and Mexican reporters this morning, inviting them to what was portrayed as an encounter with the former President, but turned out to be a news conference.
"Carlos Salinas de Gortari would like to have coffee with you this afternoon," she said, giving the address of Mr. Salinas's colonial-style boyhood home along a cobbled street in the Coyoacan neighborhood.
As reporters gathered outside the home, Mr. Salinas was already being interviewed live on TV Azteca, the first of several television appearances today.
In that interview, conducted by Sergio Sarmiento, Mr. Salinas said that during his presidency he had no knowledge that his brother was moving millions into foreign bank accounts.
"I see it is difficult for people to understand how a President who was as well-informed as they thought I was could not have known," Mr. Salinas said. "But I was focused on aspects of Mexican life that I considered important for the country's development."
Minutes into the interview, TV Azteca's switchboard lit up with calls.
"He's such a controversial figure that when I was interviewing him on television, irate telephone calls started coming in," Mr. Sarmiento said later. "His visit is going to arouse a political scandal."
Some callers assailed Mr. Sarmiento, an admired broadcast journalist and newspaper columnist, for his respectful treatment of Mr. Salinas, and the interviewer felt obliged to defend the interview.
Outside Mr. Salinas's Coyoacan home, several protesters appeared. "Salinas Get Out! Criminal!" a placard read.
During the news conference, Mr. Salinas complained that he and his family had suffered a four-year "campaign of leaks and distortion of the facts" by unnamed Mexican officials, aiming to discredit the successes of his presidency.
He denied any political motivations for his visit, promised to remain utterly aloof from the election campaign, and said he would never return to politics. "I've taken the decision not to have any involvement at all," Mr. Salinas said.
Jose Antonio Crespo, a political scientist at a research institute here, said he thought Mr. Salinas had misjudged the political climate.
"The public is definitely rejecting this man, and I don't think he expected that," Mr. Crespo said. "Salinas was probably betting that the Mexican public's hate and contempt of him had fallen off. But it hasn't. Not in any way."
Denise Dresser, a professor at another Mexico City college, said Mr. Salinas would not be able to return to live here until he negotiated with the nation's governing elite.
"Can you imagine him walking around in the street? Impossible," she said. "He'd be condemned to sitting in his house and ordering dial-a-pizza. "He can't come back to live without a political agreement."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
CLOSE RANGE: Wyoming Stories, by Annie Proulx. (Scribner, $25.) A collection that depicts the New West within the framework of the Wild West, and discovers life hasn't changed all that much for the cowboys and cowgirls who inhabit it.
 
1185 Park Avenue: A Memoir, by Anne Roiphe. (Free Press, $25.) Shunning modish confessionalism in favor of a sharp critical detachment, Roiphe recalls her postwar Upper East Side girlhood, where Scotch flowed daily on the stroke of 5 and children wanted for nothing but parental affection.
 
FREEDOM FROM FEAR: The American People in Depression and War, 1929-1945, by David M. Kennedy. (Oxford University, $39.95.) A history of the Roosevelt era, from the New Deal to V-E Day, and the America he taught to believe that "the only thing we have to fear is fear itself."
 
HAVANA BAY, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) Arkady Renko, taciturn Russian police detective and star of "Gorky Park," fetches up in Cuba bent on suicide; he is revitalized when his plan is rudely thwarted by a would-be assassin.
 
LOVE IN A DEAD LANGUAGE: A Romance, by Lee Siegel. (University of Chicago, $25.) An ambitious and imaginative novel masquerading as a commentary on the Kama Sutra that becomes a literary puzzle in which Nabokov, Joyce and Philip Roth provide the clues.
 
MARY PICKFORD REDISCOVERED: Rare Pictures of a Hollywood Legend, by Kevin Brownlow. (Abrams/Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, $39.95.) America's first film star, this celebratory reappraisal argues, was far more than the sum of her golden ringlets: urchin and princess, tomboy and coquette, she was an adroit shapeshifter worthy of serious critical attention.
 
MUSIC FOR TORCHING, by A. M. Homes. (Rob Weisbach/Morrow, $26.) Another provocative novel from the author who was almost banned in Britain, this time about a very odd couple in a middle-class suburbia that even Cheever never imagined.
 
THE NIGHT INSPECTOR, by Frederick Busch. (Harmony, $23.) A Union sniper in the Civil War, encased in a mask to hide his disfigurement from a wound, makes unlikely friends with a famous author who sounds a lot like Melville.
 
TURN OF THE CENTURY, by Kurt Andersen. (Random House, $24.95.) A novel about a "yoga-practicing Jew" and a "lapsed Unitarian" who are married and competing in the silicon rat race of the new millennium, where life is only slightly more crazy than the old one.
 
WOMAN: An Intimate Geography, by Natalie Angier. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) A personal celebration of the female of the species, written from the point of view of a member of that sex but which may prove instructive for the other one.

LENGTH: 1120 words

HEADLINE: Local Justice

BYLINE: By Sara Mosle; Sara Mosle is an editor at The Times Magazine.

 BODY:

Hadrian's Walls
 By Robert Draper.
 321 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $23. 
 NOW, here's a premise for a novel. In the early 1970's, a boy named Hadrian Coleman fatally shoots a powerful judge in East Texas and then scratches the dead man's eyes out with a broken whisky bottle. The crime is so heinous that the boy, although just 15 years old, is tried as an adult, convicted and sentenced to 50 years in the state penitentiary. A decade and a half later, he wins parole, but a few weeks before his release, he commits another murder, this time of a fellow inmate. Afraid of spending the rest of his life behind bars, he escapes from the most secure prison in Texas, embarrasses the state's correctional system by eluding a manhunt and is on the lam for eight years.
So far so good. Then, however, Hadrian is suddenly pardoned, while still at large, by the governor of Texas -- this in a state with perhaps the harshest criminal justice system in the country -- at the apparent behest of Sonny Hope, the head of the Hope Farm state penitentiary, who it just so happens, in a secret to no one, was the escaped convict's best childhood friend. In other words, in a deal that stinks to high heaven. It would never happen.
No governor -- certainly no governor of Texas -- would ever risk looking so ridiculously soft on crime by pardoning, out of the blue, an escaped two-time murderer, and certainly not to appease some two-bit state official with no campaign money to donate and no constituency to speak of. Yet the novel opens with Hadrian picking up his pardon papers at Sonny Hope's mansion, where he's welcomed with open arms and asked to recount his escape by gleeful prison officials. Hasn't anyone in these parts ever heard of the appearance of impropriety?
But if you can get past this gargantuan leap of logic, Robert Draper's first book, "Hadrian's Walls," is actually a deft, occasionally ingenious novel, doing for sadistic prison officials what Donna Tartt's "Secret History" did for murderous college cliques: making them seem, if only momentarily, far more appealing than you ever thought they could be.
Before long, a reporter gets nosy about the goings-on in Shepherdsville, a fictional stand-in for Huntsville, a prison community of 35,000 north of Houston, on the edge of East Texas' Pine Curtain. The pardon, at first glance, appears to correct an earlier injustice: Hadrian killed the judge to defend Sonny, whom the judge had tried to seduce and then murder when his advance was spurned. But Sonny inexplicably let his friend take the rap for the murder without providing exculpatory testimony. (There's a homophobic assumption underlying the plot: Sonny couldn't afford even an unwanted association with homosexuality or his life would be ruined.)
Sonny's father, who is the prison warden before Sonny succeeds him, tries to make it up to Hadrian, as he serves his time, by giving him a work detail in his mansion. The two boys -- one free, one not -- grow up together and, stretching all credulity, remain friends. Sonny courts and marries a gorgeous local girl, whom Hadrian also loves. Pained by his proximity to freedom, Hadrian finally forgoes his mansion privileges to live like any other convict.
In the meantime, Sonny, revealing his true character, becomes warden after betraying his father. Later, he wants Hadrian to repay the favor of the pardon by killing for him again -- this time, Ricky Tempesta, a sleazy former con who is threatening to run Sonny out of business by opening a private prison next door in Trust, Tex. (Some of the novel's most hilarious bits involve Tempesta's marketing of his prison: "Why We Need Trust.") More than half the novel is devoted to Hadrian's tedious agonizing over whether he owes it to Sonny to commit the murder. It's hard figuring out why Hadrian has ever felt any loyalty to Sonny -- particularly after serving 15 years' hard time. Indeed, everyone's devotion to Sonny -- his father's, the girl's, other prison officials' -- is pretty inexplicable. Even in Draper's sympathetic portrait, he comes across as completely odious.
Draper has found a modern Texas subject that is fresh and fertile: the exponential growth of the state's prison system and the rise of towns whose entire economies depend, with creepy exploitation, on incarceration. Draper covered the Texas prison system for Texas Monthly, and the novel borrows heavily from a long piece that he wrote for the magazine on Andy Collins, the former director of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, who was ousted for corruption and is an obvious model for Sonny Hope.
The novel, however, goes wrong precisely where it departs from the real story. In the Texas Monthly article, Collins comes across as something of a buffoon: a glad-handing, frat-boy bureaucrat with all the charm of a used car salesman. In the novel, however, Draper is gunning for more significance, for literature with a capital L. He wants Sonny to be a kind of Governor Stanton, a tragic, flawed figure who still inspires epic loyalty. But such men usually don't end up as lifers in the Texas Department of Corrections. Hadrian, in turn, is less a Texan than the Southern innocent, displaying a wide-eyed navete that is completely incongruous with his circumstances. The guy, after all, rather gratuitously gouged a man's eyes out and then was raised by the state pen. Hasn't Draper ever read "The Executioner's Song"?
Draper is guilty of a kind of Texas Uncle Tomism: playing up to the literary establishment's stereotypes of what Texas regional color should be. But he never gets past the cliches to conjure up a real place and time. His descriptions are mostly stock images from Southern literature. There's the wild, untamed nature: "The river exists in no postcard. Even on the calmest of evenings, it froths and flails like the devil's own handmaiden." There's the emphasis on patriarchy and the hammy folk wisdom: "But your daddy, 'course you know, if pure stubbornness is strength why then he's stronger'n Nellie's breath." There's even the obligatory lesson about race. At one point, Hadrian's father invites his young son onto the family porch to shame some Ku Klux Klan members with his innocence. The scene is straight out of "To Kill a Mockingbird."
There's tragedy in the Texas prison system, but Draper doesn't find it here. The novel's best bits are his sharp satire of Tempesta and Trust, and the whole prison industry. Indeed, there's a great comic novel struggling to get out of "Hadrian's Wall," but instead Draper gives us an implausible thriller. He wants us to believe that prison officials have the grandeur of "The Godfather." But these guys are the Sopranos.

HEADLINE: Oh Mom, Poor Mom

BYLINE: By Nancy Willard; Nancy Willard's books include "Telling Time: Angels, Ancestors, and Stories" and an anthology, "Step Lightly: Poems for the Journey." She teaches literature at Vassar College.

 BODY:

LAST THINGS
 By Jenny Offill.
 264 pp. New York:
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23. 
 Jean Piaget observed that scarcely any question seems absurd to a child, but he was silent on the question of absurd answers from adults. In Jenny Offill's remarkable first novel, "Last Things," 7-year-old Grace Davitt watches her mother, Anna, descend into madness and tries to make sense of the claustrophobic world that Anna has created for her. The child has been plucked out of school for behavior problems and is being educated at home, in a small town in Vermont on Lake Champlain. Her father, Jonathan, is a chemistry teacher; her mother is an ornithologist who decides to teach Grace the history of the world in a room she has painted black and decorated with glow-in-the-dark stars: "In one corner was a desk and a small blackboard. On the wall behind them, my mother had painted some words in white. 'It's the cosmic calendar,' she said. 'Everything that's happened since the beginning of time compressed into just one year.' "
Grace's unsentimental education is anything but rational, and this is no ordinary coming-of-age novel. Her mother's downward spiral takes center stage. Demonstrating a lively knowledge of both science and magic, Offill shows Anna stuffing her daughter with answers that veer from the scientific to the fantastic. Yet the child accepts every absurdity because it comes from a higher authority:
" 'Once,' my mother said, 'there was no true darkness. Even at night, the moon was as bright as the sun. The only difference was that the light was blue. You could see clearly for miles and miles and it was never cold. And this was called twilight.' 'Why twi?' I asked. 'Because it rhymes with sky,' my mother said. 'It's a code word for blue.' Code blue was what they said when someone died, I remembered, and this, too, had to do with the sky."
Important cosmic events, dated and noted like entries from the earth's diary, are interspersed throughout the narrative. But applying the rigorous methodology of science to the imagination is like putting a dream on dialysis, and the cosmic calendar, with its succession of vanishing species, casts a terrible shadow over Anna's faith in her own survival. "My mother said that stones were last things and would be around long after people were gone. Other last things were oceans, metal and crows." The child translates her mother's pronouncements into practical magic: "I thought that if I filled a birdbath with seawater and dropped a coin in it, I might glimpse the end of the world."
Grace ponders the mysteries revealed in the Encyclopedia of the Unexplained (a gift from her mother) and sees herself as a detective, keeping lists of words and facts in her notebook. "I had an idea that someday someone would come to me with a mystery and I would open up the notebook and all the clues would already be there." Ordinary communications are fringed with codes, signs, questions and disguises. Grace's eccentric baby sitter, a 16-year-old genius named Edgar, suggests that "everyone around you might be an ingenious robot and you're the only one that's not." Uncle Pete, her father's twin brother, plays Mr. Science on a television show for children. When he runs off with one of the show's writers, Grace's father easily steps into the role, playing his brother playing Mr. Science. Anna is fluent in Annic, her own secret language, invented by her father.
Appearances are not only deceiving, they are baffling. Who can one trust in such a world except a cryptozoologist? "Cryptozoologists were detectives who specialized in finding hidden animals. . . . This was the sort of detective my mother wanted me to be." For "hidden," read "endangered," "legendary," "vanished," "extinct." Make no mistake. Hide-and-seek is not child's play. Offill gives us journeys within journeys: the earth keeping time, the light sent eons ago from a dead star, Anna's harrowing cross-country drive with Grace, which ends in a California desert.
Offill does not succumb to the familiar tug-of-war between science and religion; her characters, not their ideas, are her major concern. The child's nonjudgmental point of view and deadpan accounts of people caught in the thrall of their convictions make "Last Things" an unexpectedly funny book. Grace's father wants to protect her from religion. Her mother wants to do no harm to the natural world. When Anna receives a collapsible iron from her husband for Christmas, her query reminds us that to one who voyages in the imagination pressed clothes are as useless as traveler's checks:
"My father didn't believe in Christmas, but still we celebrated it. It was like not believing in God but still you prayed. My mother said it was a shame to cut down a tree, so instead we chose one in the forest and tied a ribbon around it so we could find it again. . . . We opened our presents all at once because it was too cold to take turns. . . . My mother folded and unfolded the iron; then she ran it across the snow. 'How marvelous,' she said. 'What do you suppose its purpose is?' "
The novel is crisply written, economically constructed and so inventive that you read without a clue as to what anyone will say or do next. Offill's fresh voice, endearing and quirky, makes you willingly suspend disbelief. Underlying the surprises is a carefully constructed pattern of motifs -- water, animals, darkness, unsolved mysteries -- that cluster into metaphors for what happens to Grace's mother, which is not described directly. The reader understands it as Grace does, through various clues.
In the last few chapters, Grace takes her first steps toward a life of her own, though scarred by her mother's emotional detachment. The final chapter, filled with lyrical speculation about Anna, has the power of a dream carried not in the head but in the heart.
In an interview with Publishers Weekly, Offill talked about the origins of the novel: "It occurred to me that a child would be a very good companion for a madwoman." This idea is also central to Marilynne Robinson's "Housekeeping," although Robinson's novel, narrated by an adult looking back at childhood, is faithful to memory in what it includes: landscape, characters, personal reflections. In contrast, Offill's is faithful to the child's point of view in what it leaves out -- a circumscribed telling indeed. But if "last things" means things that will last, then Offill's novel is one of them. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Drug Switching Saves Money, but There Is a Cost

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WITH a brother who died of a heart attack and two parents who had strokes, it came as no surprise to Joanne Best that, at age 60, she had developed heart disease. The surprise came at the drugstore counter, when Ms. Best, of Concord, Calif., tried to refill her prescription for Norvasc, the medication that kept her blood pressure under control.
"They said the insurance doesn't pay," she said. "It wasn't on the formulary." Her doctor switched her to nifedipine, a different drug in the class known as calcium channel blockers. But the new medicine isn't working, and last week the doctor doubled the dose. "It's very scary," Ms. Best said. "This could be a matter of life and death with me." 
 Managed care executives call what happened to Ms. Best "formulary management," or "therapeutic substitution." Consumer advocates use a less flattering term: "drug switching."
With more drugs on pharmacy shelves than ever before, and with more prescriptions being written each year, officials at the Food and Drug Administration are growing increasingly concerned about deaths and injuries caused by medications. Much attention is being paid to medication mix-ups and other pharmaceutical errors. But many people don't realize that pharmacists, at the behest of insurance companies, intentionally switch medications all the time, with potentially harmful consequences.
These switches do not involve replacing brand name drugs with generics, which pharmacists are allowed to do unless the doctor writes "dispense as written" or "D.A.W" on the prescription. Rather, one chemical entity is substituted for another; the drugs may treat the same disorder but have entirely different side effects. The practice is particularly common with some of the most often-prescribed medications: anti-depressants, high blood-pressure medication and cholesterol-lowering drugs.
Often, the switching, which is done to save money, is harmless. But for some people, particularly those who have been on an established therapy for a long time, the changes can cause problems.
"It can be very dangerous and it is rampant," said Dr. Raymond Woosley, chairman of the pharmacology department at the Georgetown University Medical Center. "This counters everything we teach in medicine, which is, 'Know a few drugs, know them well, pick the best medicine for your patient, don't change unless it is medically indicated.' "
The idea that doctors should know a few drugs and know them well was the original concept behind formularies, or restricted lists of medications. "It's an old concept," said Susan Winckler, director of policy and legislation at the American Pharmaceutical Association, a pharmacists' trade group, "and in a hospital setting it allowed physicians and other prescribers to get used to a limited number of drugs. Managed care has taken that concept from the hospital to the community environment, and we are not quite sure that the translation has worked as well as it could."
Consumer advocates say it is not working at all. Howard Metzenbaum, the former Democratic senator from Ohio who is now chairman of the Consumer Federation of America, a nonprofit organization in Washington, described drug switching as "an evil practice." He would like to see Congress ban it, but said, "My guess is we'd have a hell of an uphill battle."
In a 1997 report entitled "Pharmaceutical Payola," Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, cited a string of complaints about drug switching that had been sent to the F.D.A. A 63-year-old woman developed a joint condition after switching cholesterol-lowering drugs; a 29-year-old schizophrenic "began exhibiting bruises and swelling" after changing medications, and an 86-year-old woman who traded one high blood-pressure pill for another suffered "nausea, weakness and shakiness."
And even when there is no harm, pharmacists and doctors say, the switching is a nuisance. "That's where the nightmare in pharmacy comes in," said Bruce Roberts, the owner of Leesburg Pharmacy in Leesburg, Va. "First we have to determine what they will cover. Then we have to call the physician and get authorization. Most physicians are so beat down by managed care that they say, 'O.K.' " But when the doctor refuses, he said, "You have to get back on the phone."
Pharmacy benefits managers, who serve as middlemen between drug companies and health plans, say the wrangling is worth it. Drug costs are spiraling upward; the pharmaceutical industry's revenues are estimated at $91.8 billion this year, up from $38.5 billion in 1990. Medications play such a big role in modern medicine, health economists say, that some health plans are now paying more for pharmaceuticals than hospital visits. Switching is so essential to keeping costs down that benefits managers pay pharmacists a premium for dispensing drugs that are on a company's formulary.
"We estimate that we save our clients over $1 billion a year in prescription drug costs," said Kevin Colgan, a spokesman for Merck-Medco Managed Care, which administers prescription drug benefits for more than 51 million people. He said no one is pressured to switch; doctors are simply "presented with an opportunity to help the health plan to save money."
Forty-six percent of the time, he said, they agree. Patients who don't like it, Mr. Colgan said, have another option: "They can always pay for it themselves, out of pocket."
That kind of thinking enrages Ms. Best, who said she already pays a $200 monthly premium for health insurance. Paying for Norvasc would cost her an additional $80 a month.
And what happens when the insurance company and the drug company are one and the same? When Merck, the pharmaceutical giant, purchased Medco in 1993, critics complained that the parent company would steer its own drugs to the benefits management firm, a wholly owned subsidiary. Last year, the Federal Trade Commission agreed; an investigation found that Medco had given favorable treatment to Merck products. Without admitting wrongdoing, Merck-Medco signed a consent agreement that required it to maintain an "open formulary," a practice Mr. Colgan said the company already had in place.
IN the end, some wonder how much money is really being saved by all this switching, and at what cost. Mr. Green, the New York City Public Advocate, concluded that drug switching is "likely to mean that a patient does not get well as fast," which drives up health care costs from additional doctors' visits.
Dr. Kathryn Bennett, who treats Ms. Best, has reached the same conclusion. "Now she is taking this medication twice a day," the doctor said, "which may well be more expensive than what she was taking before."
