HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 6-13-99: Word & Image;
The Information Tyranny

BYLINE: By Max Frankel

 BODY:
The Web nuts of America career around the Internet celebrating a new freedom to shout and spout anything into the ether: no more restraints on speech, they insist; no more hierarchy of thought. I hope they were watching old-time public television for just an hour last week, as Bill Moyers documented our society's slide into a new information tyranny, how corporate wealth is monopolizing debate, corrupting politicians and dictating policy. (The program will be rebroadcast tonight on WNET in the New York area.)
Moyers's thesis, oxymoronically titled "Free Speech for Sale," began with a modest morality tale about how special interests can easily mislead the public. It featured Cindy Watson, the first Republican in a century to represent her rural district in the North Carolina Legislature. Responding to her constituency, she helped pass a moratorium to limit the growth of hog farming until something was done to control the hog waste that spewed nauseating ammonia fumes across the landscape. 
 What the hog corporations did instead was lay waste to Cindy Watson, using their wealth to, essentially, buy the franchise. They spent $2.6 million on TV ads to smear her reputation and to conduct fake polls designed not to sample public sentiment but to ask suggestive questions about her "flip-flops" and "loss of the voters' trust." Unable to afford rebuttal ads, Watson drowned in the muck and lost her seat in 1996.
When corporate interests are unable to mislead the public, Moyers showed, they concentrate their wealth to intimidate Congress. The obvious example: last year's $40 million television ad campaign to redefine an anti-smoking bill as a "tax and spend" public burden. Even after victory, the triumphant industry kept buying commercials to assist the campaigns of loyal senators. No one bankrolled an opposing interest.
Finally, as if monopolizing media time were not enough, some corporate behemoths have bought favor and protection simply by buying the media. Vast conglomerates like Disney, Fox and General Electric have acquired control over entertainment hardware and software -- both the wires into every home and the images they carry. Not incidentally, that also gives them control over all the television news concerning their own conduct. That is why the giveaway of perhaps $70 billion worth of spectrum space -- reserved channels in which broadcasters will greatly improve and multiply their transmissions -- was passed last year with hardly any public discussion. The television networks allowed no serious on-air debate of the possibility of auctioning off such a valuable public resource.
In this distortion of democratic values, the obvious culprit is a legal mythology that grants every corporation -- already enjoying immortality and limited economic liability -- the same First Amendment rights of free speech as those guaranteed to individual citizens. That relatively recent reading of the Constitution produces a false equality between a corporate shout and every ordinary citizen's whisper.
As Bert Neuborne, the legal director of the Brennan Center for Justice at New York University's Law School, told Moyers: "The First Amendment is aspirational. It's romantic. It says that the purpose is to create a world in which people can speak freely and equally to one another. And therefore there's an obligation to step in at some point and even the playing field so that individuals can actually have real discussions and real debates. . . . What we've now got is not a real democracy with real debate but . . . a plutocracy in which money talks."
And on television, money talks out of proportion to all other speech. So it is the field of political talk on television that needs leveling. The great effect and high cost of television commercials corrupt all politics and most politicians. If the commercials cannot be banned altogether, they should at least be offset with free and fair time for opposing views. As Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, has said to the broadcast industry: "If you're getting that kind of income out of this advertising process, don't you have some obligation to provide some alternative access to the alternative points of view?"
The disingenuous opponents of such reform contend that "full disclosure" of who is paying for a propaganda blitz should suffice to keep politics honest. But the discovery that the "Farmers for Fairness" who knocked off Cindy Watson are really corporate hogs who stood to profit enormously did not come nearly in time to do her much good. After the 1996 election, even a paper with the resources of The Wall Street Journal needed more than a year to track the contributions -- including 165,000 individual checks for $5,000 -- that the hedge-fund industry made to Republicans to induce them to pass an amendment yielding huge profits to their industry.
As for legislated "limits" on corporate giving, they have been rendered farcical. Even corporations that bother to observe the limits now give to a wild variety of committees, party units, "issue" campaigns and far-flung state and local do-good organizations, all of whom invariably mock the law by directing the money to the campaign chests of specific candidates.
As has become painfully obvious, the winners of elections by these means are in no mood to change the rules. Can reform be accomplished without them? Can a victimized public somehow circumvent the cynical maneuvers by which both major parties protect their corrupting quest of funds and the influence of wealth? Under pressure from Congress, the Federal Communications Commission has refused to revive the fairness doctrine that once required broadcasters to give equal time to opposing views. But Dennis Morrisseau, now of Oak Island, N.C., once had an idea whose time may have come.
When I last addressed the issue, Morrisseau recalled that as a hugely "underfunded" candidate for Congress in Vermont 25 years ago, he sued the local TV station and the F.C.C. in Federal Court, demanding that they halt the overpowering commercials of his opponents. He said the great effect of television commercials and their high cost meant, in combination, that broadcasters were using the public air to establish an unconstitutional "means test" for achieving Federal office.
His case was thrown out, but "I still like the point," Morrisseau writes.
So do I, and so would most folks if they were told enough about how our information democracy has been hijacked by a corporate tyranny.

HEADLINE: The Promised Land

BYLINE: By Max Rodenbeck; Max Rodenbeck, who writes on the Middle East for The Economist, is the author of "Cairo: The City Victorious."

 BODY:

Between Memory
 and Desire
 The Middle East in a Troubled Age.
 By R. Stephen Humphreys.
 297 pp. Berkeley:
 University of California Press. $29.95. 
 Iran's Minister of Culture and Islamic Guidance narrowly escaped impeachment last month. Religious conservatives were out for his blood, accusing him of allowing "perversion and filth" to spread in the Islamic Republic. The Minister's winning defense was simple. Although Iran's 1979 constitution forbids the undermining of Islamic principles, he said, legislators have never defined what exactly those principles are.
This would surprise the many Americans who tend to regard Islam as a monolithic faith with inflexible rules. It would not surprise R. Stephen Humphreys. The clash between ideals of Islamic governance and the practical difficulty of applying them is exactly the sort of Middle Eastern conundrum he neatly exposes in this refreshingly forthright collection of essays.
A professor of Islamic history at the University of California, Santa Barbara, Humphreys brings a historian's deep and dispassionate perspective to the modern Middle East. In "Between Memory and Desire," he poses incisive questions, elaborates convincing arguments and does not shy from tackling the prickliest of topics. All this is achieved with an eye for telling detail and a concise style that is rare in academic writing.
Students of the region will find little that is really new here. What they will find is an admirably succinct exposition of key issues. These range from the failure of Arab state building to the failure of Arabs and Israelis really to come to terms to the failure of modern Islamists to forge a practical social and political program.
That is a lot of failure, and indeed the picture that emerges is a somber one. "Life is full of surprises," Humphreys writes, "but a betting man would wager that the Middle East will be living with the current legacy of rapid population growth and economic frustration for decades to come."
Few who know the region would seriously dispute this judgment. Levels of unemployment are dangerously high, even in relatively successful economies like Israel's. Such vital resources as arable land and water are scarce. A lack of popular legitimacy makes most governments shaky and intolerant of dissent. Middle Eastern states are only just beginning to adopt policies likely to stimulate rapid economic growth, which is ultimately the only way they will manage to accommodate the thousands of youths entering the job market every year.
What Humphreys might have added is that the Middle East's frightening population growth rates have plummeted in the past decade. In fact, the region is experiencing a profound demographic transition. Recent research has shown that similar transitions helped fuel economic booms in both 19th-century Europe and east Asia during the 1970's. Not only will fewer students be entering the Middle East's overburdened educational systems, but the proportion of working-age people to dependents will rise, creating a far more productive balance. The countries where these trends are most pronounced -- Morocco, Egypt and Tunisia -- are already attractive emerging markets.
But if demographic pressures are easing, there is still plenty of room for pessimism. The region's most serious challenges lie less in economics than in perceptions, habits and attitudes. This is the realm "between memory and desire," the apt phrase Humphreys has borrowed from Eliot's "Wasteland." It is on this intangible plane that the author is at his best.
"Memory in the Middle East," Humphreys says, "tends to be embodied in myth rather than history." Excepting the very new school of Israeli revisionist historians, the region as a whole has made only feeble efforts to scrutinize its own past objectively. The absence of a solid understanding opens history to manipulation and distortion -- a very serious thing considering that memory, according to Humphreys, is what identifies goals and purposes for the future.
Arab memories, for example, are often consumed by a sense of having fallen from grace, of having declined ever since Islam's spectacular efflorescence in the seventh and eighth centuries. The politicization of Islam in recent years has exaggerated this feeling, since fundamentalists hold the early years of Islam to be a perfect model for society in all ages. Scholars who seek to probe and challenge this construct are now exposed to charges of betraying their faith. Without free investigation of Islam's history, Humphreys suggests, there can be little hope of either renewal or reform.
Similarly, the historical memory of both Israelis and Palestinians is so clouded by their own national tragedies that the two peoples rarely pause to consider how to accommodate each other. As Humphreys observes of the Israelis, much of their "memory" of injustice is simply misdirected toward their neighbors. Zionism is strictly a product of European conditions, he says. Far from being grounded in age-old hatreds, the Arab-Israeli struggle "is decisively a 20th-century conflict, and biblical or Koranic texts are relevant only insofar as they are used to sanctify ideas and standpoints whose roots lie in modern times."
Humphreys is equally dismissive of many Western myths regarding the Middle East. The idea of mad dictators driven by irrational rage is one such shibboleth. In a persuasive series of analyses, he shows how seemingly self-destructive policies are nearly always founded in perfectly rational choices. For example, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's support for the students who held hostages at the United States Embassy for 444 days may have isolated Iran in the world, but it also enabled Khomeini to clinch his grip on power at a critical juncture in the Islamic revolution. While admiring of such tactics, Humphreys is hardly sentimental. Khomeini, he says, was "militant, vindictive, sure of Islam's enemies but not of what he hoped to build."
Humphreys concludes his demolition of the mad dictator myth in typically pithy fashion. "The problem for us is not that the goals of Middle Eastern leaders are impenetrable; most of the time they are quite transparent. The problem is simply that these goals are not the ones that we want them to have." A wealth of observations like this place Humphreys's work in the best tradition of writing on foreign cultures. Objective yet sympathetic, scholarly yet accessible, his book ends up revealing as much about our own society as about those it describes. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Fell 10% in April

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Domestic orders for machine tools declined in April as demand in the South and Midwest weakened, an industry survey found.
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools fell 10 percent in April, to an estimated $391 million from a revised $433 million in March, according to a report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association. 
 The April decrease was the third monthly drop in machine tool orders this year. "The softness in our market reflects the overall weakness in the manufacturing sector," said Don Carlson, president of the manufacturers' group, adding that he expected a stronger market by August.
The report showed that tool orders are down 44 percent, to an estimated $1.5 billion so far this year, compared with the 1998 period. March orders dropped 41 percent from the estimated $667 million total the previous March.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1277 words

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Sweepstakes Losing Charm For Magazines

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
For years, America's sweepstakes companies, like American Family Publishers and Publishers Clearing House, have filled mailboxes with letters promising consumers millions of dollars and offering magazine subscriptions. And for years, the magazine industry has flourished with the help of those grand, empty promises, depending on them in the first half of the 1990's to generate a third of its new subscriptions.
But now, the stampsheet houses, as the sweepstakes companies are called, are under a cloud of bad publicity and Government scrutiny, first set in motion by an investigation into their practices introduced by 32 states early in 1998. As a result, the ever-growing lack of consumer trust and the poor performance by sweepstakes companies are threatening to drive the magazine industry into what some publishers are calling its own recession. 
 Because Americans are responding with less enthusiasm, the sweepstakes houses have delivered far fewer subscriptions to the magazine publishers. To counter that, the magazine publishers are finding new ways to attract subscribers.
Next month, E. Daniel Capell, a magazine circulation analyst, will publish a report in his newsletter, Capell's Circulation Report, that shows for the first time the sharp downturn in subscription rates for magazines that sell subscriptions through the two main sweepstakes houses, American Family Publishers, jointly owned by a unit of Time Warner's Time Inc. and an investment group associated with the Pritzker family of Chicago, and Publishers Clearing House, a limited partnership. Mr. Capell announced his survey of the circulation directors of 136 consumer magazines last week at a meeting of those executives sponsored in part by the Magazine Publishers of America, and the results are already sending a chill through the industry.
The stampsheet houses typically rely on their year-end mailings to generate the bulk of their annual responses. Mr. Capell's survey found that subscription response rates, from the 1997-98 year-end mailings to the 1998-99 year-end mailings, were down an average of 37.4 percent for magazines sold through American Family Publishers; for magazines carried by Publishers Clearing House, subscription rates were down 29.2 percent. For many magazines, these figures represent a huge downturn.
"You're going to see serious subscription problems for large-circulation titles that rely heavily on the stampsheets," Mr. Capell said. "The women's services magazines will take the biggest hit: Family Circle, Woman's Day, Redbook, and Ladies' Home Journal. The newsweeklies are the next tier."
Mr. Capell's report comes after American Family Publishers agreed last month to make changes in its practices and settled a civil complaint by four states contending that it had deceived consumers. On Friday, however, a Federal judge in North Carolina found American Family in contempt for violating a 1993 settlement in which it agreed to tone down its promotions. Last week, United States senators received nervous executives from the sweepstakes and magazine industries pressing for last-minute changes to a bill, the Deceptive Mail Prevention and Enforcement Act, that the Senate is expected to pass, perhaps before the July 4 recess. The bill would severely limit the kind of solicitations that have so beguiled consumers in the past.
Industry response to the subscription downturn is uniformly dour. Lindsay Valk, the director of circulation marketing for Hearst Magazines, publisher of Redbook and Esquire, two magazines that are heavily reliant on the stampsheets, said that some Hearst titles "have seen a big hit to their volume."
Gregory B. Zorthian, the vice president of business development at Forbes magazine, which sells subscriptions through both American Family Publishers and Publishers Clearing House, refers to the steep decline as "a circulation recession."
"It's got people scared," he added.
Jim Woods, the circulation director for Prevention magazine, which is published by Rodale, said he had expected to generate at least 100,000 subscriptions from the stampsheets from the year-end mailings, but got less than half that number.
Chip Block, a founder of American Family Publishers and a former consultant to Publishers Clearing House, estimates that for some magazines, the subscription rate will be off by as much as 70 percent.
The Reader's Digest Association founded the first magazine sweepstakes in 1962. Business boomed in the 1980's and early 1990's, then slowed a bit, partly because of consumer fatigue, before dropping precipitously last year.
The pitch is simple: consumers get letters exhorting them to enter a sweepstakes. Accompanying the letters is an offer of cut-rate magazine subscriptions. In the past, many consumers subscribed, either because they thought it would increase their chances of winning, or simply to take advantage of an inexpensive magazine offer. Under the bill before the Senate, the sweepstakes mailing would have to display a statement that no purchase of a subscription is necessary to win a prize.
Deborah Holland, a senior vice president at Publishers Clearing House, would not confirm the percentage drop in subscription rates, but conceded that they were down.
Susan Caughman, the chairman of American Family Enterprises, said that "the mass-market titles sell best with the stampsheets, so they are therefore more vulnerable in the downturns, without question."
"They are more reliant on the stampsheets," she said. "If you're 'Fly Fishing on the Housatonic,' this is not going to affect you."
She would not confirm the percentage of decline but said, "We're not down to zero."
Both executives defended the seductive nature of their company's mailings. Ms. Holland said: "The whole purpose of the sweepstakes is merely to call attention to the offers inside. After all, we do guarantee the lowest magazine prices."
With subscription rates dropping, Mr. Capell predicts that in 2000 many magazines will have to lower their rate bases, the circulation levels that magazines guarantee to advertisers.
Michael Pashby, executive vice president of the Magazine Publishers of American, said: "I assume that would be a logical progression from what has happened. However, I think that publishers have been quick to go out and look for new ways of reaching the consumer."
Indeed, magazines are scrambling to flee American Family Publishers and Publishers Clearing House faster than Ed McMahon can say "You're a winner."
Mr. Woods of Prevention said that the magazine's circulation staff was studying other ways to get subscriptions. The Internet, he said, shows some hope; Prevention now picks up 5,000 subscriptions a month from Women.com, a Web site with which it is affiliated, he said.
Other publishers are relying increasingly on new kinds of marketers, like News Subscription Services, a company in Greenwich, Conn., that provides, for example, a method by which consumers are offered magazine subscriptions every time they order something out of a catalogue; consumers who order from Lands' End, for example, may get a surprise solicitation for a cut-rate subscription to Martha Stewart Living.
And the sweepstakes companies, which can keep up to 90 percent in commissions on the subscriptions, are also trying to reverse their losses. American Family Publishers started an advertising campaign last week that shows the happy, smiling, winners of prizes that start at $1,000. "We're focusing on showing consumers that 19,000 consumers will win prizes from A.F.P. in 1999," Ms. Caughman said. She added: "I believe consumers love us."

HEADLINE: Data 'Brokers' Battle Critics of DeceptivePractices

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
When he entered the private investigation business nearly 20 years ago, James J. Rapp opened a company to do surveillance and other things that he did not want to talk about, particularly because its name, Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap, aptly described its operations.
Now Mr. Rapp, a 39-year-old investigator who used to promise on his Web page that he could quickly get anyone's private telephone records or bank account balances for as little as $100, is in the middle of legislative, regulatory and criminal battles over how much privacy millions of Americans should enjoy when they go to the bank or make a phone call. 
 Mr. Rapp has made a career of posing as the person whose records he is trying to uncover, to trick banks, telephone companies and other institutions into revealing confidential information sought by his clients. The practice is known in the trade as pretexting, and it has drawn a lawsuit from the Federal Trade Commission that names Mr. Rapp, his wife, Regana, and their company, Touch Tone Information Inc. A trial date has not been set, although Touch Tone has agreed to honor a preliminary injunction barring the investigative practices that are at issue in the suit.
The lawsuit is billed by both sides as a landmark case, and Mr. Rapp is receiving significant support from a coalition of information brokers and debt collectors who see the Government's action as a potential threat to their livelihood. But even some of his allies are uneasy about using Mr. Rapp as the vehicle to avoid new and tougher Government privacy rules, because he has a criminal record and served a four-year prison sentence for theft.
The case against Mr. Rapp has also been discussed in Congress as lawmakers in both the House and Senate, with the support of the Clinton Administration, are trying to make such investigative techniques a Federal crime and impose new civil liabilities on those who deceive banks. And he is being investigated by a grand jury in Colorado under a new state law that makes it a crime to use deception to obtain private information.
In a separate lawsuit filed in 1996, he was accused of having helped a client, the International Beverage Corporation, get telephone records of a competitor, Saybrex International, from AT&T as part of an effort by International Beverage to learn who Saybrex's customers were. Saybrex, a family-run liquor exporter in Beverly Hills, Calif., ultimately successfully sued the competitor -- though not Mr. Rapp, who was not named as a defendant in the suit. Saybrex, however, was unable to force AT&T to tighten its procedures on customer records.
In a recent series of interviews, Mr. Rapp and his lawyers said there was nothing inherently wrong with using trickery to get confidential information, particularly since that information is often not otherwise obtainable. They also said that Mr. Rapp had cracked many cases in which deception was the only way to find money for victims of crimes and neglect, like abandoned spouses and children, and for plaintiffs in lawsuits who were unable to collect judgments, and for insurance companies and banks that had been defrauded.
"The message that the Government is sending in its case is that if you're a deadbeat dad, you don't have to worry anymore," Mr. Rapp said. "After all, how else are you going to get at this information?"
Mr. Rapp has his defenders, and is even cited as an exemplar by an industry group of investigators and debt collectors who so far have been moderately successful in watering down proposed legislation and obtaining significant loopholes for certain kinds of cases, such as tracking down assets for child support payments. The group, the Coalition to Amend the Financial Information Privacy Act, is paying for Mr. Rapp's legal defense in the F.T.C. case -- and using him to help raise money for its lobbying efforts.
The coalition's members maintain that the practice of pretexting is no different from what police officers or some journalists do when they go undercover or assume false identities in the course of doing their jobs.
Critics of the information brokers say that publicly available data bases and computer services offer a variety of information about people and their finances, including their Social Security numbers, the prices they paid for their homes and any existing liens. And they note thatother information, like bank deposits, can be obtained when necessary through a court subpoena.
But Mr. Rapp and his supporters say that information like bank and telephone records is generally not publicly available, that it can change quickly during the time it takes to get a judge's order, and that the only way money can be recovered in many instances is by duping a financial institution.
"What our clients are trying to do is even the odds," said Stephen C. Leckar, a lawyer at the Washington firm Butera & Andrews, which represents the coalition and Mr. Rapp. "If some people don't pay their bills, investigators like Mr. Rapp are just leveling the playing field."
But the F.T.C. sees it as a privacy issue. "Touch Tone's pretexting is a particularly pernicious invasion of consumers' privacy -- using deception to gain access to sensitive, private financial information," Robert Pitofsky, the F.T.C.'s chairman, said. "This case should send a strong message to information brokers that the F.T.C. will pursue firms that use false pretenses at the expense of consumers' privacy and also create opportunities for economic injury to consumers."
The banking industry is caught in the middle. On the one hand, it has publicly denounced the deceptive techniques and called for new legislation, although it has also tried to make sure that any new laws do not create liabilities for the banks that might be too quick about turning over confidential information. On the other hand, many of the clients of investigators like Mr. Rapp have been banks seeking to collect delinquent loans.
"There's little question that some banks will hire information brokers," said John Byrne, a senior counsel at the American Bankers Association and an expert on privacy issues. "We have tried to emphasize that banks should ask questions about how they are getting information and that there are legitimate means of getting at the same stuff."
Court papers in both the Saybrex and F.T.C. lawsuits describe Mr. Rapp and his employees as using fake telephone numbers and phony corporations to deceive banks or telephone companies into turning over confidential information.
In the F.T.C. case, transcripts of calls to banks that were recorded as part of the Government's surveillance show Touch Tone employees pretending to be doddering customers in order to obtain Social Security numbers and other information, like the maiden name of an account holder's mother. In some cases, bank representatives declined to help. But in others, they guided the Touch Tone employee to the correct answer and even supplied information like account balances.
Private investigators familiar with the practices of information brokers say another common technique is the "Trojan check." The broker sets up a dummy corporation and sends a check for a small amount of money to the target of the investigation either as a supposed rebate or award. When the target deposits or cashes the check, information about the target's bank account is imprinted on the canceled check. The broker can then use that information to approach the bank.
The legislation and legal fights come as Washington has become captivated by privacy issues.
Late last week, the House Commerce Committee inserted a variety of consumer privacy protections into the latest version of legislation to overhaul the banking system. Those proposals, which were endorsed by consumer groups and include a new right to sue companies that violate their customers' privacy rights, threatens to undermine broad industry support for the legislation.
Experts say it is not clear whether the broadly worded existing Federal fraud laws would permit the criminal prosecution of a person who deceives an institution to gain access to private information, which is why Congress may act this year to make the law more explicit.
On the Web pages and court papers of the coalition supporting Mr. Rapp, he is portrayed as a victim of an overzealous Federal agency, an agency that if it prevails will make it more difficult for abandoned wives and their children to find desperately needed assets of their deadbeat dads.
But even as Mr. Rapp has quickly become the industry's poster boy for what the coalition has called a "witch hunt" by regulators, it turns out that he has had his own more serious difficulties with the law.
Mr. Rapp served four years in prison in the 1970's and 80's in Colorado for theft, which was a violation of his probation on an earlier conviction for auto theft. State records in Denver show that in 1992 he pleaded guilty to impersonating a peace officer. He and his wife have had more than $38,000 in tax liens imposed by the Federal Government for failing to pay taxes.
The industry's using him as their symbol "is like bankers embracing Jesse James," said Marshall B. Grossman, a Los Angeles lawyer who represents Saybrex.
Because he is a man who has made a career out of deception, it can be difficult to sort through the substance of many of Mr. Rapp's claims.
He said in an interview that the investigations and the poor health of his parents had driven him out of business in recent weeks, a business that he said had annual revenue of about $1 million in recent years.
He said that there was nothing wrong with using deception to get at private information and that his clients over the years had included banks, tabloid newspapers and television programs. He asserted that he had trained half of the nation's information brokers, had solved "over 100 cases a day" and that he had worked for private investigators seeking information for news organizations about the families of the victims of the Columbine High School shootings in Littleton, Colo.
He also said he had done work for agents at two offices of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but he refused to provide any references or say anything more about the work.
Indeed, many of his assertions could not be verified.
He also asserted that he had received an "associate's degree" in criminal justice from Metropolitan State College in Denver. But Carrie Schafer, the communications director for the college, said school records showed that Mr. Rapp had attended the school but did not complete a degree.
While Mr. Rapp has had no qualms about using trickery to obtain confidential information on behalf of his clients, he so values his own privacy that he was hesitant to be photographed for this article.
"We live way out in the county and no mail comes here," he said. "Everything is quiet. That's the way I like it. Nice and quiet and easy."

HEADLINE: T.W.A. and Union Reach Pact

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Trans World Airlines and the union representing its flight attendants and machinists said yesterday that they had reached a tentative agreement on a new contract.
The union said it would recommend that its members approve it. 
 Late last month, T.W.A. presented what it said was its best and final offer to the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers union, which represents about 16,000 flight attendants, ground workers and machinists at the St. Louis-based airline. The union had recommended its members reject the pact.
Terms of the contract, which is expected to be presented to union members in the next few days, were not released yesterday. But William O'Driscoll, president and directing general chairman of the machinists' District Lodge 142, said the deal was a significant improvement over previous contract offers.
The airline had said its earlier offer would bring the employees -- who made financial concessions to help T.W.A, the nation's eighth-largest airline, during two bankruptcy reorganizations this decade -- to 90 percent of industry standard wages by the summer of 2001.
The union said it would cancel ratification votes in progress on T.W.A.'s previous contract offers and urge acceptance of the latest deal. The two sides pledged no work stoppages or disruptions during the expected one-month ratification period.
"We are pleased to have reached tentative agreement on new contract proposals that the I.A.M. feels will better serve the interests of its members and that T.W.A. regards as achievable and financially realistic," said William Compton, T.W.A.'s president and chief executive.
T.W.A.'s stock closed Friday unchanged at $4.4375 a share.

HEADLINE: Metropolitan Diary

BYLINE: By Enid Nemy

 BODY:

DEAR DIARY:
My son was scheduled to land at Newark Airport at 11:05 P.M. Our arrangement was that I would pick him up unless the flight was significantly delayed, in which case he would take a cab. When I pulled to the curb at the arrivals level, I learned he would be delayed about 25 minutes. Concerned that he might automatically take a cab, I opened and sat on the back of my Jeep so that I would be visible if he passed by in a cab. I had brought a book and started reading.
Within five minutes, the inevitable police car pulled up to move people from the curb. The window rolled down and the officer driving called out to me, "What are you reading?" 
 " 'The Magic Mountain' by Thomas Mann."
"Thomas Mahn," he said, correcting my pronunciation. "Why are you reading that?"
"I'm not sure. It just caught my attention in the library."
"O.K.," he said. "I respect people who read good books. You can stay."
There were three more sweeps to clear the stopped cars but the officers let me continue reading. CRAIG CAREY
Attending the current revival of "Death of a Salesman" reminded Kenneth Seeman Giniger of a remark overheard when he and his late wife were leaving the theater after the original production in 1949. At that time, the man behind them informed his companion, "That New England territory never was any damn good."
 Natasha Brenner doesn't feel shortchanged even though her 15 minutes of fame lasted only about three seconds. Late last month, she was preparing dinner and listening to the 7 o'clock news on Channel 7. There was a feature on the New York 1939 World's Fair, and as she chopped and minced she heard various buildings and highlights described. When the music of a swing band permeated the kitchen she raised her head just in time to see a close-up of herself jitterbugging.
"Sixty years came back in a wink," she said. "It may have been only three seconds, but it was coast to coast and border to border!"
A doctor at Jacobi Medical Center recently noticed the following information, after the name, on the badge of an elevator operator:
Occupation: Elevator Operator
Dept: Vertical Transportation.
A friend of Mildred Cohen's does volunteer work, and took a group of first graders to a nursing home for a visit. One little girl approached a woman in a wheelchair and asked, "How old are you?" "Oh, I'm very old; I'm 89," the woman said.
"That's really old," the youngster replied. "Did you start with one?"
 
SHAMELESS SPRING
I walk in Central Park
Mother Nature introduces her many daughters
across a pond.
One tosses cherry blossoms in her hair.
A willowy willow sinuously waves her pale green tresses
tendril ends caress the water.
A genteel breeze kisses my cheek
and spreads a moving mantilla of lace
across the sparkling bosom of the lake.
I am pleasured by the perfume wafted
by these spring maidens
as they seduce me shamelessly
out in the open
in sight of everyone.
 DAVID GOLDBERG
(member of the Writers Workshop at the Council Senior Center on the Upper West Side)
Dear Diary:
My friend and I were in a swank East Village bar for a book reading/perfume introduction. The author is tres fabulous, her friends are tres fabulous and I was there because I happen to work for her publisher.
About 10 minutes into the reading, I noticed a woman with long, thick gray-blond hair -- and watched as it went up in flames. Not singed, mind you: it was on fire, lighted from a too-close candle behind her head. I shouted, "Oh my God, ma'am -- your hair!" and the crowd swiveled to look at me. She bent her head, shook it and patted out the flames. The reading had stopped, and most of the bar was staring at her.
"Oh, I'm sorry," she said. "Keep going, please. Continue." She straightened her clothes, smoothed her burnt hair and moved the offending candle a few feet. She didn't even run to the bathroom to check the damage. Everyone turned to the front of the room, where the author picked up in the middle of her sentence and continued. No one, including the woman, batted an eyelash -- except my friend and I who moved here two years ago from the Ohio Valley. We eventually ran out of the room and exploded into laughter at the absurdity of it: in my hometown people would have stopped, dropped and rolled, as one is instructed to do in a fire. In New York they paused, assessed and moved on.
The fire woman? She mingled bit after the reading, then left, I hope to find a 24-hour hair salon.
I love this town. JODY HANDLEY
 
DADS ARE GREAT
Dads are everything
He is the blanket that comforts you
He is the clothes that warm you
He is the teacher that teaches you
He is the friend that plays with you
But most of all he is Dad and he is yours.
 ALLISON GUGGENHEIMER (age 8)
As a window cleaner in Manhattan, Ivor Hanson travels from job to job with a bucket of tools. He was on the 72d Street crosstown bus recently, sitting next to a boy of about 5 and his mother. The boy asked about the equipment, and Mr. Hanson explained how the mop wet the window, the squeegee wiped the water and dirt away, the chamois cloth soaked up any remaining drips and the pole allowed him to clean windows beyond the reach of his arm. The youngster considered for a moment and then piped up: "Sounds fun. Call my mom. Make a play date."
Dear Diary:
Those of us who walk from the Port Authority to and from our offices on the East Side are rewarded daily. First there's the cardiovascular reward of the brisk half-hour of exercise each way; then the economic reward of not paying the additional $3 a day in carfare. But there are many others as well.
Unpredictable but fun to receive and much appreciated are the little gifts promoting new products, entertainment and stores. Within the last month, on different days, I received a staple remover, shampoo, mousse and conditioner, chunks of muffins, coffee, gum, bottled juice, a plastic cup with a refrigerator magnet and store coupon inside, two Knicks posters and a mini-cup of Frappuccino. Plus there are all the tchotchke vendors along the route if I need to indulge in impulse buying.
Take the bus or subway across town? Never! Well, maybe in a blizzard. GLORIA YOSHIDA

HEADLINE: The Big City;
With Guns, A Safer World For Women?

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
WITH Congress primed to pass gun-control legislation, New Yorkers may be tempted to feel smug. The rest of the country is finally starting to share the prevailing distaste in the city for guns. Urbanites seem to be triumphing over the plaid-shirted guys driving the back roads in pickup trucks with N.R.A. decals.
But it's hard to remain smug if you talk to Dr. John R. Lott. He believes that thousands of New Yorkers, particularly women in poor neighborhoods, are victims of violent crimes each year because of the city's strict controls on guns. And he is not one of those guys in the pickup trucks. 
 Dr. Lott is an economist who teaches at the University of Chicago Law School. He grew up in a home without guns and never wanted to hunt. He did not object to the domestic gun controls imposed by his wife, who would not let their four sons have even toy pistols.
But then he did a study that persuaded him to buy a real gun -- with his wife's blessing. As a fellow economist, she too was converted by the data in the study, which tracked crime rates in every county in America for 18 years. The results were summarized in the title of his book, published by the University of Chicago Press last year: "More Guns, Less Crime."
Dr. Lott found that crime drops after a state enacts a right-to-carry law, which guarantees citizens a gun permit as long as they have no criminal records and meet a few specific requirements.
"With more citizens carrying guns, it becomes riskier for criminals to operate," Dr. Lott said. "Some of them switch to safer crimes -- you see an increase in larceny as they switch from robbing people to stealing cars. Some will shift to other jurisdictions, so there'll be an increase in violent crime in the counties just across the border of the adjacent state."
What if New York City, which now gives permits only to citizens who demonstrate a compelling need for a gun, was to adopt a right-to-carry law? Extrapolating from his research, Dr. Lott estimated that after the law had been in effect for five years, there would be about 100 fewer murders a year, 300 fewer rapes, 5,000 fewer aggravated assaults and 9,000 fewer robberies.
"The greatest beneficiaries of right-to-carry laws are residents of high-crime urban neighborhoods, especially women," Dr. Lott said. "A woman who behaves passively when confronted by a criminal is 2.5 times more likely to be seriously injured than a woman who has a gun. It's rare that she has to use the gun -- just brandishing it is usually enough to protect herself."
DR. LOTT argues that right-to-carry laws are particularly effective at discouraging shooting sprees in public areas. Noting that the restrictive policy on gun permits in the Denver area did not avert the killings at Columbine High School, he cited examples of armed citizens stopping students in shootings at schools in Pearl, Miss., and Edinboro, Pa.
"Once a state passes a right-to-carry law," he said, "there's an 84 percent drop in the rate at which multiple-victim shootings occur, and there are fewer fatalities when they do occur. If someone tries to start shooting in a crowded public place, there's a good chance that someone there will also be armed."
Dr. Lott does not advocate arming high school students, but he thinks that Congress made a mistake in 1995 by banning adults from having guns within 1,000 feet of a school. "We're trying to create safe cover for our children," he said, "but my concern is that we're creating safe zones for those interested in harming our children."
In academia, debate has been lively over the meaning of Dr. Lott's research. Gary Kleck, an eminent criminologist at the University of Florida, terms it "mandatory reading for anyone who is open-minded and serious about the gun-control issue," but he cautions that the reductions in crime may be largely because of unknown factors other than right-to-carry laws.
Outside academia, Dr. Lott's work has driven gun-control advocates to desperate measures. Many have spread false accusations that he is financially beholden to the gun industry. The most surprising development, Dr. Lott said, has been dozens of death threats from gun-control advocates.
"I never expected this much attention," he said, "although I can understand why people instinctively want to get rid of guns. Bad things can happen with guns. But guns can also be used to stop bad things from happening, and the net effect is that they save lives." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Illness as a Metaphor for Computer Bugs

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, June 13

 BODY:
The implications of the malicious software program that wove its way around the globe last week struck home for Bernardo Huberman, a physicist at Xerox, in the form of a terse voice mail he received at work on Thursday.
"Our computer system administrators sent me a message saying, 'The worm has hit Xerox, but we've hunted it down and killed it,' " he recalled. 
 To Mr. Huberman, who has studied computer networks for more than a decade, the biological allusions were an apt reminder that the explosive growth of the Internet has numerous parallels to natural systems -- and many are not reassuring.
"I believe that we are indeed living in a computational ecosystem which is more and more globally cross-linked," he said. Or to put it more simply, "It's an amazing system, and it's very vulnerable."
In a world where computers, once isolated work tools, are increasingly the very engine driving modern business life, computer researchers say they are detecting an ominous trend toward programs that mimic viruses and pestilence in the physical world.
The latest focus of concern is a program known among computer researchers as a worm. The one last week was apparently conceived in Israel and quickly spread to Europe and the United States, mailing itself from computer to computer and destroying its victims' files along the way. Called Explore.exe -- for the name of the file it contained that set off the damage -- the worm has affected thousands of computers worldwide and forced a number of corporations to abruptly shut their E-mail systems, in a frantic effort to control the spread of the infection.
 Like biological diseases, which exploit the most basic mechanism of life -- the power of DNA to replicate itself -- a subculture of modern virus-writing now manipulates that same power of replication within the world of interconnected computers.
And while the dominance of a single environment -- the one powered by Microsoft software and Intel chips -- offers the benefits of compatibility among machines, some say it may share the vulnerabilities of fields planted with just one crop.
"The analogies are extremely close," said Richard Dawkins, a biologist at Oxford University. "When you make machines that are capable of obeying instructions slavishly, and among those instructions are 'duplicate me' instructions, then of course the system is wide open to exploitation by parasites."
Indeed, some computer scientists believe that in the rise of the Internet and the World Wide Web, society has struck a Faustian bargain -- gaining the potential of robotic software agents, which can flit from computer to computer to do their masters' bidding almost intelligently, but accepting as well the darker prospect of software infections that can spur cybernetic plagues.
"This may simply be the price you will have to pay for having the flexibility, adaptability, autonomy of this new networked world," said Kevin Kelly, author of "Out of Control: The New Biology of Machines, Social Systems and the Economic World" (Addison Wesley, 1994).
To be sure, biological metaphors used to describe the hostile software are only that, and the analogies do break down because the so-called computer viruses are manmade, not natural, and are frequently designed to be destructive.
But some researchers assert that such diseases are a direct outgrowth of the remarkable complexity emerging in the realm of networked computers. Increasingly, they say, Internet viral issues will come to resemble the modern world's perpetual public health crisis.
"You need to look at this the way the Centers for Disease Control approach things," said Vernor Vinge, a computer scientist at San Diego State University. "There are always new problems on their threat board."
In fact, computer scientists have known about these risks since the first worm programs were written by researchers at the Xerox Corporation's Palo Alto Research Center in the early 1970's.
Experimenting with the power of networked computers, scientists fashioned a wide variety of helpful programs, ranging from "vampire" worms that kept the network's computers laboring late at night to "diagnostic" worms that spread software repairs around the research center.
But a software error in one of the lab's early worms caused the program to run amok, crashing computers everywhere in the building.
Today computer researchers debate what distinguishes worms from viruses, both metaphors drawn from science fiction. The term "worm" first appeared in John Brunner's 1975 novel "Shockwave Rider" (Del Rey Books) while "virus" first appeared in a computer context in David Gerrold's "When Harley Was One" (Ballantine, 1972).
Traditionally, the term "virus" has been used to describe software codes that infect computers by attaching themselves to documents or programs that are passed along. A "worm," by contrast, has been self-propelling, that is, a program sent within the attachment that can then send itself along without any action by the person who receives it.
But the most recent generation of malicious programs -- like the Melissa virus, which spread rapidly around the world in late March, and Explore.exe, the worm that emerged in Israel last Monday -- blend aspects of both types.
The world of computer networks has not yet produced the most telling biological analogy -- evolution. But a particular class of hostile programs known as polymorphic viruses has been designed since 1993, with the ability to mutate to evade the pattern detection capabilities of modern antivirus scanning programs.
And antivirus researchers are also turning to "biological" solutions to face down hostile software codes. For example, last month the Intel Corporation, I.B.M. and the Symantec Corporation jointly released new antivirus software they call a "Digital Immune System."
Just as a biological immune system offers a systemic approach to illness, the new software shifts the antivirus response from the PC to an entire corporation's network, automatically relaying suspect programs for inspection and directly immunizing individual computers.
There have been other attempts to build systems that are immune from security threats. For example, the original intent of the Java programming language was to prohibit the kind of file havoc wreaked last week by creating a "sandbox" that limits a program's destructive capabilities.
Strikingly, the rapid spread of last week's outbreak was made possible because most of the world's users of personal computers now run Microsoft software. The worm was written to destroy documents written in Microsoft applications like Word, Excel and Power Point and certain programming files.
"This is the classic result of a computer monoculture," said W. Daniel Hillis, a computer scientist at Walt Disney's Imagineering unit. Like agricultural ecologies that become unstable relying on only one or a few crops, so the computer world is vulnerable to the degree it relies on Microsoft software.
Noting that the worm had attacked large American military contractors, including Boeing and General Electric, Art Amolsch, editor of FTC Watch, a Washington policy newsletter, suggested that the Government should insure software diversity among its agencies and contractors.
"I propose that no Government agency be allowed to run more than 34 percent of its personal computers on one proprietary operating system by a date certain," he said.
To Mr. Hillis, who in the 1980's experimented with advances in software programs using "evolutionary" techniques in which the programs adapt to their environment, a transition is under way in which computers will be viewed less like mechanical devices and more like organisms, which better accommodate imprecision and failure.
"Today we have the fragility of an engineered system where every part works" but the system itself can fail, he said. "But in the future we're going to engineer systems with the expectation that everything is broken all the time. That's how we treat biological systems today."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Digital Dangers"
As with diseases in the physical world, programs created to wreak havoc with computers have varied characteristics. Here are five types of infections and some prominent examples of each. Many have characteristics of more than one type.
 
MACRO -- Preys on documents like spreadsheets and data bases.
 
Concept (1995) -- Proved more than programs could be infected. Contained code that read And that's enough to prove my point.
 
Melissa (1999) -- Tried to send itself to first 50 e-mail addresses found in victim's files; turned Word documents into templates.
 
TROJAN HORSE -- Initially seems benign; may act as any type of infection thereafter.
 
Happy99.exe (1999) -- Displayed a window titled Happy New Year 1999!! while showing fireworks to disguise the fact that it was copying itself over the Internet.
 
Explore.exe (1999) -- Arrives attached to an e-mail, seemingly sent by an acquaintance. It is also a worm that, when launched, seeks to e-mail itself to other PC's and to destroy certain Microsoft Office and programmer file types.
 
BOOT SECTOR -- Affects startup sector of floppy or hard disks.
 
Stoned (1989) -- Every eighth time a PC was started from an infected 5.25 inch floppy, Your PC is now Stoned! appeared on screen.
 
Michelangelo (1992) -- If a PC was started on March 6, the artist's birthday, it destroyed the hard disk.
 
EXECUTABLE FILE -- Affects program files, not the files created by them.
 
Friday the 13th (1987) -- Deleted any program launched on a Friday that fell on the 13th of the month.
 
Chernobyl (1999) -- Erased hard drive and ROM BIOS (basic input/output system).
 
WORM -- Self-propelled; can move and replicate through a network.
 
Internet (1988) -- Exploited flawed network security to rapidly copy itself onto computers linked to the Internet, overloading thousands of computers with copies of itself. (Source: ICSA Inc.)

HEADLINE: Washington's Mayor Faces a Campaign-Finance Inquiry

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 13

 BODY:
So far Anthony A. Williams, Mayor of the District of Columbia, has committed few of the ethical and managerial blunders that characterized the previous administration, but now campaign-finance charges are threatening his squeaky-clean image.
Six months ago, Mr. Williams took over a city plagued by financial crises and began making changes. But now the city's office of campaign finance is asserting that Mr. Williams violated city law by waiting about eight months before disclosing two consulting arrangements made in July and August 1998, when he was running for office. A hearing is set for this week. 
 Campaign law requires candidates to report changes in their incomes or other information in their financial disclosure filings within 30 days.
Mr. Williams served as the city's chief financial officer for three years before resigning to run for Mayor in last November's election.
Congress has shown confidence in Mr. Williams, passing bills that would shift authority for the day-to-day operation of Washington's government back to its elected officials from the control board that Congress created to oversee its finances in 1995.
In a speech this spring at the National Press Club in Washington, Mr. Williams said that "restoring faith and confidence in the government" was a major focus of his administration.
Marion S. Barry, who did not seek re-election last year, preceded Mr. Williams as mayor, serving three terms from 1978 to 1990 and returning to office in 1994 after a six-month prison term on drug charges. Mr. Barry's personality and politics shaped Washington for almost two decades.
Mr. Williams filed a financial statement on July 17, 1998, about a month after resigning as the city's chief financial officer and announcing his candidacy for mayor. The statement indicated no outside income. But two weeks later, on July 31, Mr. Williams accepted a consulting fee of $30,000 from the Arthur Andersen accounting company. And on Aug. 6, he signed a contract with Nationsbank Corporation for $10,000.
It was not until April 1999, in financial statements that all Washington officials must file annually, that Mr. Williams disclosed information on his outside employment. After that filing, the office of campaign finance asked for more information, and on May 28, Mr. Williams complied.
Mr. Williams issued a statement saying that "nothing improper occurred" in the work he conducted for the two companies.
"I should have disclosed the fact of my outside employment earlier and inadvertently failed to do so," Mr. Williams said. "For this oversight, I am sorry."
The Mayor has been ordered to appear at a hearing before the director of the campaign finance office and Washington's board of elections and ethics on Wednesday.
The campaign finance office could impose a $1,000 fine, $500 for each violation.
Mr. Williams contends that his work was not a conflict of interest, and that the work with the two companies did not "involve their relationship with the District of Columbia."
Peggy Armstrong, the Mayor's spokeswoman, said Mr. Williams would provide any information that would be helpful. The finance office has asked for Mr. Williams's financial records, including canceled checks and statements showing the dates and amounts of his contracts with Arthur Andersen and Nationsbank.

HEADLINE: Group Says New Drugstores Are a Menace to Main Street;
As National Chains Move Into Downtown, Preservationists Fear for Historic Buildings

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
The men (and woman) at the Oswego Elks Lodge are pretty tight-lipped these days.
"We read in the paper all this stuff about Rite Aid, but I can't tell you anything," said Allen Todd, who is on the lodge's board of trustees. "We're doing a study." The woman who answered the phone at the lodge was terse: "The Exalted Ruler is away, and even if he was here, he wouldn't tell you anything." 
 The Elks are deciding whether to sell their historic 1859 Second Empire-style brick house with mansard roof and tower -- a sort of gentle version of an Addams Family house -- to a buyer that everyone, including the local newspaper, thinks represents the Rite Aid drugstore chain. The mystery buyer has reportedly offered a hefty $1 million.
Mr. Todd, despite his wariness, admitted one more thing: the buyer, whoever it is, wants to knock down the old lodge at West Bridge and West Fifth Streets, a major crossroads in town.
"I suppose I wouldn't want to see it torn down," Mr. Todd conceded, "but it's old and sure needs a lot of repair."
The Elks lodge is only one of dozens of old and arguably historic buildings in New York State that are threatened with demolition because they happen to be standing in an ideal spot for a drugstore: a site where the four corners meet in a small town, or at an important intersection in a larger city. Nationally, there are hundreds more such buildings.
As the chain drugstores -- giants like Rite Aid, Walgreen and CVS -- continue their march into small and big towns across the country, building boxy cinder-block stores with drive-up windows and plenty of parking, the National Trust for Historic Preservation has decided to do what it can to stop the drugstores' demolition of historic structures.
And so, when the Trust holds a news conference this morning to announce its annual list of the 11 most endangered historic sites, No. 1 will be "the corner of Main and Main" -- the heart of town, often the site of a prominent old bank, department store or theater, or a cluster of houses facing the town green. Often, preservationists concede, these prominent buildings are vacant -- and not official landmarks.
If the owners are determined to sell, all sides agree, there is not much the preservationists can do, other than whipping up public opinion and lobbying lawmakers to list the buildings on a register of historic places.
The whole drugstore issue really got its start in New York State.
"This is a phenomenon that came to us through the New York experience," Richard Moe, president of the National Trust, said on Friday. "There seems to be an awful lot of activity there." Mr. Moe said he applauded the chain stores' move back into the cities' centers, away from far-flung malls -- "it's what we've been working for," he said. But he certainly does not approve of their decision to knock down antique buildings to do it.
Right now, 37 drugstores are planned for major intersections in New York, said Tania Werbizky, the director of technical services for the Preservation League of New York State and the woman leading this particular preservation crusade.
"We've seen the number of drugstore expansions double in the last two years," she said, "and most aim for the key corner downtown."
The communities, she said, "mainly are caught unawares by the magnitude of change construction creates. In mid-size communities, you typically find the post office, the hardware store, maybe the former hotel, often a park or church -- and now this church overlooks an 11,000-square-foot concrete box."
Among the sites at peril are the massive red-brick School 10 in Albany, threatened by Eckerd drugstores; an imposing 1915 Classical Revival bank in Olean (a few blocks from the 1917 Palace Theater, which was demolished last year with four other buildings to build an Eckerd), and some large Colonial Revival houses on Elmwood Avenue in Buffalo. In Buffalo, a developer who has been identified with Rite Aid is suing the city to allow the demolition.
Yet preservationists said there have been victories: in Ballston Spa, near Saratoga, village officials denied a request for a zoning variance and kept Rite Aid from ripping out several buildings in a Victorian neighborhood. In Hornell, in Steuben County, Ms. Werbizky said, another Rite Aid project was thwarted when residents sued to save six buildings proposed for a National Register historic district. The salvation of the 1928 Monroe Theater in Rochester was announced on June 2.
The drugstore chains say they rarely go after genuine landmarks.
"Overall, we don't target historic buildings," said Michael Polzin, a spokesman for Walgreen, which has its headquarters in Deerfield, Ill. "But it's also very important to distinguish between buildings that are truly historic and those that are just old."
"Is this a pre-eminent example of Frank Lloyd Wright," he continued, "or just some 100-year-old falling-down wreck?"
Occasionally, the chain drugstores do reuse old buildings. The problem with rehabilitation, Mr. Polzin explained, is that Walgreen and the other chains have strict design guidelines for their stores.
"First, it must be either the right size building or one we can make into the right size -- it must make economic sense," he said, echoing the comments of the spokeswoman for Rite Aid. "It has to be a free-standing building, about 11,000 square feet, and there must be ample space for the drive-through pharmacy window. There should be ample parking in the front and on the side, for around 60 or so cars."
Mr. Polzin said the Walgreen chain has several times recycled a large chain grocery store, which are generally 15,000-square-feet cinder-block buildings with open floor space. The problem with buildings over 50 years old, he said, is that they "aren't built so they can be converted."
When the drugstores do resuscitate an old bank or theater, preservationists applaud them.
On Myrtle Avenue in Ridgewood, Queens, an enormous limestone Beaux-Arts bank building with an arched entry and Corinthian columns has been recycled by Rite Aid.
And in Corning, N.Y., Eckerd has taken over two adjacent main street buildings that were used by -- guess what? -- a drugstore.
"It's one of the rare successes," Ms. Werbizky said, "and we want to do everything we can to encourage them."
Is being declared Public Enemy No. 1 the way to do it?
Mr. Polzin, the spokesman for Walgreen, laughed when the question was posed.
"Just keep this in mind," he replied. "It's the decision of the property owner. Maybe the reason a building is not designated a landmark is because the owner didn't want it.
"And now," he said, "we want that corner!"

HEADLINE: Voters Dismiss Political Fervor For Tax Breaks

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: ANSONIA, Conn., June 11

 BODY:
A $50 gift from the State Capitol for every adult might seem a welcome bonus on the steep streets of this blue-collar town, which has been the victim of a depressing parade of fires, strikes and bankruptcies in the century since its now ghostly riverfront factories churned out anything molten, from bayonets to thimbles.
The average annual per capita income here, about $23,000, ranks 157th out of Connecticut's 169 towns. Even Ansonia's leading conversation piece, a plaque marking the high-water mark from the still lamented flood of 1955, corroded away and is now just a memory. 
 But the sales-tax rebate that Connecticut lawmakers approved with much self-congratulation before adjourning on Thursday is seen by many here as wasteful and even insulting, considering what they say the state could buy if the whole $110 million were used in one place.
"People take $50 and think, 'Whoop-de-do,' " said David Ings, 31, a construction laborer. "They're just paying us off."
Mr. Ings's feelings reflect what some pollsters are calling a waning appetite for tax cuts in the New York metropolitan area, eight years after fury over Connecticut's new income tax produced a stream of death threats to lawmakers.
With a booming economy producing a happy electorate, many voters are telling pollsters they want government to use this time of plenty to rebuild schools and roads, instead of returning the bounty a few dollars at a time.
Legislatures in 36 states cut taxes last year, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures, and with revenue in most states running ahead of projections, at least that many are expected to do so again this year. Among them is New Jersey, where Gov. Christine Todd Whitman described a property-tax rebate as "from the State House to your house" when she signed it in April.
In New York, lawmakers continue to wrangle over a budget that was due on April 1, but significant tax cuts remain part of all three competing proposals.
As irresistible as tax cuts may seem to politicians, polls have found that voters are increasingly skeptical. In one of the starkest findings, 78 percent of respondents to a University of Connecticut poll said they would rather have the state use its surplus on services for citizens; just 18 percent said they would prefer a rebate.
The poll, taken from April 6 to 13, surveyed 500 adults and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points.
"When we do tax questions, we don't find much hostility to the tax levels that exist in the tristate area," said Maurice Carroll, the director of the polling institute at Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn. "People are saying: 'The state has a lot of stuff to do. They have the money, and they should spend it on that stuff instead of sending it to me.' "
Nationally, Joel Slemrod, the director of the Office of Tax Policy Research at the University of Michigan Business School, surveyed a dozen polls about taxes early this month and said he was surprised to find that tax cuts came in low or even last on most voters' priority lists.
The bull market, these surveys find, has largely dissipated the Reagan era's anti-tax fervor, which followed the Proposition 13 tax revolt in California in 1978, when two-thirds of voters approved a freeze on property taxes after a campaign featuring bumper stickers crying, "Save the American Dream."
Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican who proposed the Connecticut rebate, was elected in 1994 in part on his 26-page plan to eliminate the state income tax over five years.
But with the tax-cut fever broken, he has retained high approval ratings despite having abandoned that promise long ago, and it was not even an issue during his re-election campaign last year.
Frederick S. Yang, a partner in a Democratic polling firm, Garin-Hart-Yang Research Group, said that even today, few voters would turn down a tax cut.
"But people are not as interested in that as they have been in the past," Mr. Yang said. "In good economic times, people feel they can look beyond their own pocketbooks."
A leading Republican pollster, Frank Luntz, agreed. "In today's economic environment," he said, "the demand for tax cuts is not as great, because money is more plentiful."
Mr. Luntz said that apathy about taxes is most pronounced at the state level, where people are less concerned about wasteful spending than they are when they think about Washington. "The closer you are to home, the more willing people are to pay taxes," he said.
In Connecticut, State Representative Robert M. Ward, the House Republican leader, said he was pursuing tax cuts as a matter of philosophy, not in response to a clamor from constituents. "I call it 'starving the monster,' " he said. "The easiest way to control spending is to control revenues."
But Emanuela Ronzone, 28, who was shooting pool at Snookers Billiards Club here in Ansonia, said she would just spend her rebate on gasoline or cigarettes. "The schools need it more than I do," she said. "They're falling apart."
And Thomas P. Pepe, 51, a groundskeeping manager, said most people do not mind paying taxes if they go toward something worthwhile. "It's part of being an American -- helping people, especially the youth," he said. "We're not as selfish as the politicians think."
The politicians' focus on tax cuts has frustrated groups that had hoped states would use their record surpluses to restore parts of the social safety net that were casualties of the recession of the early 1990's.
"The citizen's voice doesn't seem to be making it into the back room," said Janice M. Gruendel, the executive director of Connecticut Voices for Children, which has sought more spending for programs like day care.
When the legislative session convened this winter, State Representative David B. Pudlin, a Democrat of New Britain, visited business and community groups to urge more spending for children and the working poor. "Let's fix the roof while the sun is shining," he told them.
Now, many of the repairs he had hoped for have been delayed or scaled back to pay for tax cuts. Representative Pudlin, the House majority leader, called the rebate "one of the stupidest things I supported in the budget," but said it was the price of winning Republican votes. He said his consolation was that the guidelines were expanded so that more people would be eligible.
"Some people in Connecticut probably go to the country club and sign the check over to the maitre d' as a tip," he said.
Here on the banks of the Naugatuck River, Mayor Nancy Valentine said that as she makes her rounds, she does not find anyone cheering a rebate. "Roads and schools are what's on everybody's tongue," she said. "It's not like somebody is going to take their $50 rebate and give it to the school. If you aggregate it, though, that's a lot of money, even for Ansonia."

HEADLINE: Conservatives In Europe Gain Ground In Parliament

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 13

 BODY:
Europe's center-left governments suffered a sharp setback today as conservative parties gained votes and won enough seats to become the largest group in elections to the European Parliament.
The defeat was particularly crushing for Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's governing Social Democrats in Germany, whose share of the vote plunged to 31 percent compared to 40.9 percent in national elections just nine months ago, computer projections showed. 
 The center-right Christian Democrats advanced to 48 percent, a sharp gain from 35.1 percent last September, as voters registered their unhappiness with a stagnant economy and Mr. Schroder's failure to have an effect on high unemployment.
With center-left Governments in office in the four largest European countries -- Germany, France, Britain and Italy -- the results suggested an electorate unmoved by what has been portrayed as NATO's victory in Kosovo and more concerned with a European economy that is scarcely growing while America's booms.
Certainly, there was no evidence of any war euphoria carrying the governing parties to victory. But voter turnout for elections to an assembly whose real power remains limited was extremely low, suggesting that the importance of the swing to the right should not be exaggerated.
Early projections showed that center-right parties -- gathered in a grouping known as the European People's Party -- would gain about 219 seats, 18 more than in 1994, and become the largest political force in the 626-member assembly.
The socialists, who emerged from the last elections in 1994 as the strongest party with 214 seats, appear certain to lose at least 30 seats and might finish with as few as 179 seats, the projections said.
Those center and socialist parties are certain to remain by far the largest groupings, trailed by the pro-market liberals with 48 seats and the environmentalist Greens with about 39. Other seats were split among extreme-right and extreme-left movements and regional parties.
The assembly, which generally meets in the eastern French city of Strasbourg, has limited powers but is able to veto the European budget and also call for the dismissal of the European Executive Commission, a power it exercised for the first time earlier this year when several commissioners were accused of fraud.
This flexing of parliamentary muscle against the officials who propose policy and run the community's affairs day-to-day was widely seen as a boost for greater democracy in the European Union. But voters were apparently unimpressed.
Turnout in Britain was just 23 percent, a mere 27 percent in Finland, 47 percent in France and 56 percent in Germany. This suggested that neither the Parliament's greater prominence nor the arrival of the common currency, the euro, had convinced people that voting in Europe-wide polls is important.
The conservative gains reflected the devastating defeat for Mr. Schroder in Germany and what appeared to be a poor showing by Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor Party in Britain. Voter turnout in traditional Labor areas was very small, while conservative constituencies voted in larger numbers.
The French vote, marked by the highest abstention rate in any nationwide poll, was extremely fragmented. The Green vote surged to more than 10 percent from less than 3 percent in the last European poll in 1994, while pro-European and anti-European conservative parties shared close to 25 percent of the vote. The socialists of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin gained about 20 percent, exit polls showed.
The Green campaign in France was led by Daniel Cohn-Bendit, the leader of the 1968 French student uprising who is now a member of the German Green party. Mr. Cohn-Bendit is a German citizen, but nationals of one European country can campaign in another if they so choose.
In Germany, the result amounted to a stark warning to Mr. Schroder that his military and diplomatic efforts in Kosovo may have won him friends in Washington and other European capitals but have not impressed the people who voted for him because he promised to create jobs.
The German unemployment rate, still more than 10 percent and close to 20 percent in many parts of the former East Germany, has not come down since he took office. "We have understood," Mr. Schroder said today. "The fight for a new center must now resume with lower taxes for companies."
Germany, by far the largest economy in Europe, has failed to resolve a paralyzing debate over what degree of social protection and solidarity -- the hallmarks of the postwar success of the "social market" economic model -- must now be abandoned in favor of lower taxes.
