HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Japan's New Strength May Embolden the Fed

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Japanese economic revival is real, and the chances are good that it is going to last. That is welcome news for the world economy, particularly for other Asian countries. But it also makes it virtually certain that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at the end of this month.
Japan reported last week that its economy grew at a remarkable annual rate of 7.9 percent in the first three months of 1999. That followed declines in five consecutive quarters. 
 There is still widespread skepticism about Japan's recovery, but financial markets now seem persuaded, with the yen strengthening and Japanese stocks rising even though the image of Japan Inc. has gone from invincible to incompetent over the past decade. The aura of invincibility led many observers to overlook or dismiss signs of trouble in Japan in the late 1980's. The new aura of incompetence has caused them to miss signs of revival now.
For example, Fuji Bank, a major Japanese financial institution, has redefined how it operates. Its old role was to take in money from depositors and lend it to the companies in its keiretsu, or group of companies. Fuji did so without a lot of regard for its own profitability, but so long as the economy was growing rapidly, it was a cozy relationship that benefited everybody.
When the Japanese bubble burst almost a decade ago, Fuji and other Japanese banks tried to act as if little had changed. They concealed bad loans and remained the piggy banks for companies in their groups in the belief that growth would surely make everything better again.
But it did not, and late in 1997 Fuji shocked Japan by failing to rescue Yamaichi Securities, a member of its keiretsu. In an interview last week, Toru Hashimoto, Fuji's chairman, said the bank refused to step in because it was worried about hidden losses at the brokerage firm stemming from what he called "dubious transactions."
But that was not how the public saw it. "The fact we didn't bail out Yamaichi was perceived as our weakness," Mr. Hashimoto said. Suddenly Fuji was rumored to be in trouble, and its stock price plunged.
In fact, the decision to let Yamaichi fail was a signal that things were changing for the better in Japan. Banks were coming to understand just how much they had been hurt by the old practices. By disclosing more information about bad loans than is customary in Japan, Fuji has since managed to persuade investors that it is in no worse -- and perhaps better -- shape than other Japanese banks. Its stock price has rallied.
Japan's system of lifetime employment also is changing, albeit slowly. Fuji is trying to cut its payroll through attrition, not layoffs, but Mr. Hashimoto said it is changing its pay structure to reward accomplishment rather than seniority. Fuji also has a new system of hiring in place in which some people are hired on terms that pay them more but offer no guarantee of job security. "The old system and the new system will coexist," he said. He seems to hope that some workers who are passed over for raises will choose to quit.
Skeptics about Japan note that there have been false springs before. In the first quarter of 1996, the economy was reported to have risen at a 12.3 percent annualized rate only to quickly stumble. This time is likely to be different because growth now reflects surprisingly strong domestic spending, not the old strategy of boosting exports. This is "a home-grown Japanese recovery," says Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
It is also a recovery based on old-fashioned stimulus. The Government ramped up public spending and cut interest rates as low as they could go. It pumped billions into sick banks and came up with a scheme to provide loan guarantees to small businesses. Japan has not proved it can grow when such stimuli are removed, but restructurings like the one under way at Fuji provide good reason to hope that it can.
Last year the Federal Reserve, fearing that Asia's illness would infect America, cut interest rates three times. Now, with Asia on the mend and some signs of inflation at home, the Fed is all but certain to rescind one of those cuts. It may rightly choose to take back two of them. That would surprise Wall Street, and show that the Fed is determined to resist inflation.

HEADLINE: Practicality Is Biggest Foe Of ID Plan For R Movies

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, June 14

 BODY:
How are theaters going to enforce the plan announced last week at the White House to require teen-age moviegoers to show photo identification at R-rated films?
The conclusion in Hollywood is quite simple: The overwhelming number of them probably won't. 
 William Kartozian, president of the National Association of Theater Owners, which represents proprietors of about two-thirds of the movie screens in the nation, said that each theater would develop its own program to enforce the rating system, which has been largely flouted by teen-agers under 17. But studio distribution executives said that the effort faced two major hurdles.
One, of course, is that teen-agers manage to see R-rated films by asking older friends to buy tickets for them, or by buying tickets for, say, a Disney family film and then sneaking into viewings at multiplexes that show R-rated films.
The other enforcement hurdle lies in the economics of the theater business. Theaters earn most of their profits not from movies, but from concession sales of popcorn, soft drinks and hot dogs. As much as 80 cents of every dollar spent is pure profit to the theaters, and managers reap a percentage of concession sales as income.
Theater owners hardly dissuade teen-agers from hanging out in lobbies all day to play video games, which are proliferating at newer multiplexes; buy food, and glide from theater to theater. In this atmosphere, theater owners quite naturally hire people to work at concessions, not to check on teen-agers at individual screens.
Accordingly, Hollywood executives who deal with theater owners daily said that the White House announcement by the country's largest theaters and President Clinton was probably an ineffective way to curb the availability of violent films to children.
"It's unenforceable," a top studio distribution executive said. Few executives would speak on the record because of the White House role.
Another studio distribution executive, who worked for years at a large theater chain, said simply: "It's unworkable. It's impossible to police unless somebody is standing at the front door and checking tickets stubs and ID's -- and that won't happen."
Marvin Antonowsky, a veteran distribution executive for several studios, said: "It's specious. Kids can get into a multiplex. They'll buy a ticket to 'Tarzan' and see 'The Matrix.' Who'll stop them? You're talking about an honor system. Give me a break."
The ratings were set up by the Motion Picture Association of America in 1968, a time of social and sexual turmoil, to replace the prudish and archaic Hays Production Code, which controlled the sexual content of movies for decades. (Under the code, generally, film husbands and wives did not sleep in the same bed.) With the endorsement of theater owners, the board created the ratings as a guideline for parents.
Over the years the ratings evolved into five categories: G, for general audiences, usually cartoons or films for small children; PG, meaning that parental guidance is suggested and some material may be unsuitable for children; PG-13, meaning that parents are strongly cautioned that some material may be inappropriate for children under 13; R, for which youths under 17 must be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian, and NC-17, a relatively new rating, under which no one under 17 is admitted.
(Last week's announcement by the President did not involve R-rated video rentals, which some stores freely make to youths under 17. Some chains require adult applicants for membership to respond to a question about whether they want their children to be able to rent R-rated movies.)
The plan would require that a ticket taker or someone checking stubs seek ID's from those in line, which would be time-consuming. Even more daunting to owners, especially with the proliferation of multiplexes with 14, 16 or 18 theaters under one roof, theater employees would probably have to stand outside screens showing R-rated movies to insure that no one under 17 slipped in.
Any parent with a teen-ager knows that in terms of drinking, smoking and movies, where there's a will, there's usually a way. Even today, youths under 17 stand in line at a theater and ask an older friend, or a stranger, to buy a ticket to, say, "The Matrix," which is especially popular now among the teen-age crowd. Or a teen-ager may purchase a ticket for a PG-13 film and slip out in the middle to an adjoining theater to see the R-rated movie.
"It's like Prohibition, forbidden fruit," a studio chairman said. "Whenever you set up rules for teen-agers, you're inviting them to find a way around them."
By all accounts, the plan for ratings system enforcement will probably prove more effective in smaller towns than in larger cities like New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. Mike Patrick, chairman of Carmike Cinemas, a Columbus, Ga.-based chain with about 2,700 screens in smaller cities, or what he called "Hometown, U.S.A.," said that it would be extremely difficult, but not impossible, to enforce restrictions on teen- agers.
"The problem is when you have an 18-year-old who buys four tickets, and three of them go to his 16-year-old friend," Mr. Patrick said. "You have to police the auditorium as well as the selling of tickets. Is it realistic? It's extremely hard to do."
But Mr. Patrick said he would impose some unusual restrictions on the coming Stanley Kubrick film "Eyes Wide Shut," an R-rated movie with Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman that has strong sexual content. The film opens in July.
Mr. Patrick said he would place someone at the door of the theater showing the film to bar anyone under 17 from seeing it unless accompanied by a parent or a guardian adult.
"It's expensive and a lot of trouble and it irritates teen-agers, but it can be done," Mr. Patrick said.
But that plan seems to be an exception. Mr. Kartozian himself said that the rating system was meant to advise parents, and that the monitoring of what movies young people see rests in their hands as well as those of theater owners. "This is a shared responsibility," he said.
One studio distribution chief summed up the mood of many other distribution executives. "The dirty little secret of the distribution business is that with 16, 18, 24 plexes, kids show up and buy tickets for a PG-13 movie and see the one that's R-rated," he said.
"The staff is at the concession stand and the ticket office, not the theater door. Kids will see whatever they want to see."

HEADLINE: Inventories Rose and Sales Dipped in April

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Businesses added moderately to their stocks of goods on hand during April as sales weakened for the first time since January, the Commerce Department said today.
The value of total inventories at retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers rose two-tenths of a percent, to a seasonally adjusted $1.098 trillion in April. That was the weakest monthly performance for inventory-building since a decrease of one-tenth of a percent in January; in March, inventories had shown a rise of half a percent. 
Retailers added to their inventories by seven-tenths of a percent, for a total of $346.03 billion, a much slower rise than the 1.6 percent increase in March.
Analysts said the data implied a slower start for overall second-quarter growth as the economic expansion began its ninth year.
"This report shows that the economy began the second quarter on a softer note," said Gary Thayer, an economist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. "We've been hearing a lot about the economy potentially overheating, but the economic data aren't consistently supporting it.
Another report today, from the Federal Reserve's regional bank in Atlanta, showed some softening in production rates in May in the Southeast, though orders remained strong. Its monthly index of manufacturing activity eased to 9.1 from a revised 12.5 in April.
Concern has been mounting in financial markets that the Federal Reserve might soon increase interest rates to cool growth and so keep inflation pressures muted. Fed policy makers are set to meet on June 29 and 30 to consider interest rate strategy, so any economic reports until then are being closely scrutinized for signs of slowing that might damp price pressures.
Retailers have been building up their inventories steadily for nearly a year. The last time retailers reduced their stocks of goods for sale was in July 1998, when they fell two-tenths of a percent.
Overall sales decreased one-tenth of a percent, to $809.34 billion in April, a sharp reversal from robust consecutive jumps of 1.1 percent in both February and March.
Manufacturers trimmed their inventories during April by one-tenth of a percent, to $462.96 billion, after a reduction of one-tenth of a percent in March. Wholesalers built up their stocks of goods on hand by two-tenths of a percent, to $288.96 billion, after a matching two-tenths of a percent gain in March.
The inventory-to-sales ratio, a measure of how long it would take to deplete inventories at the current sales pace, edged up to 1.36 months in April from 1.35 months in March.
Inventories at auto dealers rose 1.8 percent, to $105.74 billion in April, less than half the 4.7 percent increase in March. Auto makers have reported brisk May sales, however, so producers are likely to build up their stocks of new cars.

HEADLINE: Graduating Into Prosperity

 BODY:
As college graduation season draws to a close, it is evident that the gap between the experiences and expectations of the graduating class and their commencement speakers has never been greater. The speakers for the most part grew up in a world of economic highs and lows. They, or their parents, lived through the Great Depression, or at least a series of recessions, and learned to write on a typewriter. Today's graduates have not seen a recession since they were in junior high school and may never have touched a typewriter.
Who could better capture the economic moment, past and present, than Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board? He addressed the Harvard commencement last week, telling students there, and by extension across the country, that they would shape the future state of the world's "cultural, legal and economic institutions." It seemed fitting that one of the architects of the longest period of peacetime prosperity in American history would address men and women entering the working world at a time of unimaginable opportunities as well as unparalleled challenges. 
 The economy is booming. The labor market is the tightest it has been in 30 years and is unusually strong in all sectors. The unemployment rate for college graduates, ages 20 to 24, registered just 4.2 percent in May. The explosive growth of the computer industry has made the entry-level job market especially exciting and lucrative for this and recent graduating classes. The information-technology industry beckons the young. Growing up with computers and the Internet, they are well equipped to take advantage of the entrepreneurial possibilities such technology offers. Career-services offices at colleges report that increasing numbers of students are starting their own companies or joining newly created firms. Many believe they have nothing to lose and may soon join the expanding roster of young millionaires.
Entrepreneurial programs at colleges across the country are expanding. Columbia University, for example, has more than doubled such course offerings for undergraduates in the last several years. The Columbia Business School administers an entrepreneurial initiative fund, which invests in the companies of budding businessmen, allowing them to get on their feet with minimal debt.
Jobs in the information and technology sector, such as systems analysts, computer engineers and database administrators, are projected to more than double by 2006, and opportunities through the Internet seem limitless. The confidence and optimism are admirable, but the Class of '99 should not naively expect that the current economic expansion will be endless.

HEADLINE: District of Columbia Debt Is Upgraded

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
The bond rating for the District of Columbia was upgraded from junk to investment-grade status by Moody's Investors Service today, the District's first investment-grade rating from the company in four years.
Moody's raised the rating of the District's general obligation bond to Baa3, its lowest investment-grade rating, from Ba1, a high-risk investment rating. Moody's said it had a "positive outlook" on the debt, which means it might be upgraded again. The rating affects $3 billion of debt. 
 Moody's cited the likelihood that the District would finish with a budget surplus for a third consecutive fiscal year as one reason for the upgrade. The control board that now oversees much of the District's financial affairs will be removed after four consecutive years of surpluses.
Moody's follows the lead of Standard & Poor's, which raised its ratings on the District's bonds in April from junk status to investment grade.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Says New-Age Economy Can HaveOld Problems

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 14

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that increases in business efficiency could not counterbalance the strains on the economy forever.
Speaking before a Congressional committee, Mr. Greenspan revisited his favorite theme of the last few years, that huge investments in technology are yielding substantial gains in productivity, or output for every hour worked, a fundamental and far-reaching improvement in the way the economy functions.
But without directly addressing 
 the growing consensus that the central bank will raise interest rates as soon as the end of this month, Mr. Greenspan cautioned against counting on technology as a miracle cure for inflation or a rationale for ever-higher stock prices.
"The rate of growth of productivity cannot increase indefinitely," he told the first of three days of hearings held by the Joint Economic Committee on the role of technology in the economy. "While there appears to be considerable expectation in the business community, and possibly Wall Street, that the productivity acceleration has not yet peaked, experience advises caution."
Mr. Greenspan has been an advocate of the view that technology has helped improve the economy's ability to grow without inflation, but he has been distancing himself in recent months from the notion of a "new economy" in which inflation is no longer a threat. As he did in a speech last month, he noted today that "history is strewn" with miscalculations about technology developments and that policy makers had to be modest about their ability to predict technology's effects.
The tone of his remarks was in line with that of other Fed officials over the last month in making clear that the central bank increasingly sees early signs of problems brewing in an economy that has enjoyed a remarkable run of growth.
But he gave no clear indication of whether the central bank had enough evidence of resurgent inflation to nudge interest rates higher at its next policy meeting, on June 29 and 30. As a result, his comments had little effect in the financial markets.
Economists and investors expect Mr. Greenspan to provide a relatively unambiguous signal about his intentions when he testifies about monetary policy before the committee on Thursday, a day after the Government releases figures on consumer price inflation in May.
Mr. Greenspan was the first witness at the hearings, which the Joint Economic Committee is conducting in part to discuss such issues as tax breaks for research and development and the liability of technology companies for problems involving the Year 2000 software problem. The witnesses include William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, who will appear on Tuesday.
But the hearings also seem intended to give the Republican majority in Congress an opportunity to give a sympathetic ear to the technology industry, one of the most important battlegrounds in the fight between the parties for campaign donations, and one that Vice President Al Gore has worked hard to sew up for his Presidential race.
In highlighting the Year 2000 liability issue, the Republicans are putting on display the uncomfortable situation of the Democrats, who are trapped between their desire to court technology companies that want protection from lawsuits and the Democrats' traditional alliance with trial lawyers, who want to protect the right of computer users to sue.
Mr. Greenspan steered clear of both politics and specific references to monetary policy. He reiterated his belief that technology has been perhaps the dominant force in the economy in recent years, fostering widespread changes in the way businesses operate and contributing tremendously to the vibrancy and durability of the expansion, which is now in its ninth year. But with investors and economists looking for any clues about future rate increases, it was his warning about the limits of technology that was most provocative.
Many economists and investors expect the central bank to push its benchmark Federal funds target rate up by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, at the end of the month. Evidence that the economy continues to roar along, including a surge last month in retail sales, has already pushed up the long-term interest rates set by the market in recent weeks, in effect doing some of the Fed's job for it by squeezing sectors of the economy sensitive to interest rates, like housing.
Although a Fed tightening is not certain -- there are still scant signs that inflation has taken root -- the markets are increasingly asking not whether the Fed will move this month but whether the move will be a one-time action or the start of a series of rate increases that would take back all of last fall's easings.
The Fed cut rates three times last fall, in quarter-point increments, to keep the markets stable and the economy humming despite the global financial crisis.
But the financial crisis, which originated in Asia, now seems to be receding. A surprising rebound in economic growth in Japan during the first quarter -- provided it does not turn out to be a statistical fluke -- could prove to be an important turning point. And the fear that gripped the credit markets last fall is all but gone, replaced by more concrete concern that inflation could stage a comeback.
Moreover, as Jack Guynn, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, put it today, the "lucky streak" that the United States has enjoyed on inflation "has finally run out," at least to the degree that price increases have been held down by economic weakness in the rest of the world.
"Energy prices are up substantially from their year-ago levels, and other commodity prices have risen, too," Mr. Guynn said in a speech to a business group in Atlanta. "What's happened, of course, is that as the economies of Asia and elsewhere have turned the corner to recovery, global demand has picked up, and so have prices."
Mr. Guynn, who is a nonvoting member of the policy-making Federal Open Market Committee, said higher inflation was not inevitable. But he offered a list of issues that worry him, including "the residual stimulus" from last fall's rate cuts; signals that the bond market is increasingly concerned about inflation; rapid growth in the money supply, and the very low unemployment rate, which is 4.2 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Rises, but Nasdaq Is Pulled Down by Internet Sector

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed and activity remained subdued yesterday as traders and investors delayed putting money to work before an important inflation report that is scheduled for release tomorrow.
Long-term interest rates, which have risen sharply in recent weeks and put pressure on stocks, eased a bit yesterday. 
 Still, the drop in rates did little to alter the consensus that the Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to dampen growth when its policy makers meet later this month.
Stocks that are sensitive to the business cycle, which do well in an expanding economy, helped to push the Dow Jones industrial average higher. But Internet stocks were crushed, pushed lower by negative developments affecting three of the group's most important companies -- America Online, Charles Schwab and Ebay -- as well as concerns about higher interest rates.
"The big, high-cap stocks are the allure, and money is coming out of technology and Internet stocks and even some small stocks" to move into those companies, said Bill Allyn, head of listed trading at Jefferies & Company.
For the most part, however, money was not going anywhere.
For the sixth time in the last eight sessions, fewer than 700 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. At 832.2 million shares, volume on the Nasdaq market was a bit better but still well short of the one-billion-share trading sessions seen recently.
Led by DuPont, General Electric and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, the Dow rose 72.82 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 10,563.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was flat, rising 0.36 point, to 1,294.00.
But the Nasdaq composite index, dragged down by the Internet sector, fell sharply. At the close, the Nasdaq was off 49.57 points, or 2.03 percent, to 2,398.31.
Some traders and analysts said the market's tone might change after tomorrow's release of May consumer price data.
The April numbers showed the biggest monthly increase in more than nine years. That report rattled financial markets and led to an ever-rising chorus that the Fed would move soon to raise interest rates.
A report showing the April figures to be an aberration would be helpful but hardly conclusive, said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers.
"The stock market has priced itself for at least one Fed tightening, and if the Fed does go, it will have to position itself for another," Mr. Applegate said.
"If the consumer price numbers look pretty benign, then the market might take comfort from that," he added. "But I suspect this is not something that will be sorted out with the next one or two data points. I don't think we are out of the woods yet. There are just too many crosscurrents."
Analysts who follow Internet stocks have been saying for some time that the sector was particularly vulnerable. Still, yesterday's downdraft was particularly drastic.
Concern about slowing subscription rates led to big declines in America Online. At the close, the stock was down 9, to 90 1/2. Ebay continued to suffer from a computer system failure last week, falling 29 7/8, or 18 percent, to 136. And Schwab was punished after it reported that its daily on-line trading volume fell 28 percent in May, compared with April activity. The stock closed at 83 15/16 a share, down 10 5/16.
"Given the price-earnings ratios for companies like America Online and Schwab, there is not much room for error," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney. "These were material, fundamental events."
Weakness in these issues also helped to drag down other Internet shares. Cisco Systems, a component of the S.& P. 500, fell 2 7/8 a share, to 107 13/16. Amazon.com shed 13 13/16, to 92. And Yahoo lost 16, to 119 1/4.
For the Dow, DuPont gained 2 7/8, to 70 3/16. General Electric closed at 103 3/4, up 2 13/32. And Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing gained 3 5/16, to 89 1/4.
Elsewhere, drug and medical service company shares slumped.
Becton Dickinson, the nation's largest manufacturer of medical syringes, declined 8 3/4, to 30 5/16, after notifying Wall Street that earnings for the third quarter and the full year would fall short of expectations because of slower sales in Europe.
Pfizer continued to drop, falling 2 3/8, to 95 1/8. And Warner-Lambert slipped 1/2, to 62 1/4.

Treasury Prices Rise
 By The Associated Press
 Bond prices rose yesterday, recovering from a plunge on Friday with some help from a rise in the dollar.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 25/32, to 88 15/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.09 percent, from 6.16 percent on Friday.
Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in yesterday's auction to the highest level in nearly 10 months. The Treasury Department sold $7.5 billion in three-month bills at a discount rate of 4.62 percent, up from 4.51 percent last week. An added $7.51 billion was sold in six-month bills at a rate of 4.855 percent, up from 4.76 percent.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: HOMECOMING;
Serbian Returnees Revel in Just Being Alive

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: INIS, Serbia, June 14

 BODY:
Yugoslav soldiers leaned out of a civilian bus, waving and whooping noisily, as it swept down the main street bringing them back to this Serbian town today. People out strolling in the warm evening on the main square looked up and waved back.
This town, home to the Third Army, which has done the bulk of the fighting in Kosovo over the last year, has been welcoming its troops home for several days now. Soldiers in camouflage fatigues are everywhere, downing beers in the outdoor cafes and strolling around town, overwhelmingly relieved to be back. 
 After dark tonight the streets resounded with car horns blaring and people whistling and shouting. "I am very happy it's over," said one bearded reservist walking along the street. "I got back yesterday and now I've been told I can go home. It was difficult, but we survived."
Relief is still the main feeling. Both soldiers and civilians are just grateful the bombing has stopped, said Zoran Zivkovic, Mayor of Nis and an opposition party leader.
"But it will be a matter of minutes and hours for most people to remember all the problems they had before the war and which have been multiplied by the war," he said in an interview in his office. "Problems of basic living needs, economic survival and how to support their families."
President Slobodan Milosevic, apparently in an effort to scotch brewing public dissatisfaction, made a rare appearance today, his first since the start of the NATO bombing. He went to the northern city of Novi Sad to inaugurate the reconstruction of one of its destroyed bridges.
In a speech by the ruined bridge, he urged people to rally to the task of rebuilding Serbia.
"The hardest 11 weeks since World War II are behind us," he said. "Now that we have peace again, new tasks await us. These are to rebuild our country."
"I wish our country and our people a fast recovery," he added, vowing to rebuild the bridge in 40 days.
In Nis, Mr. Zivkovic was dismissive of Mr Milosevic's speech. The President has finally decided to emerge from his bunker, he said. The bridge is only one of 39 that will have to be rebuilt, he added, and the country has no money. He estimated that in Nis alone, it would cost $100 million to $200 million to rebuild.
The President has until the end of the summer, while the weather is good, to sort out the country's most pressing problems, Mr. Zivkovic said. And he will not be able to do that without foreign aid and investment, Mr. Zivkovic asserted, adding that he hoped other nations would not isolate Serbia further and create "another Cuba."
The country experienced great tension and trauma during the bombing, he said, and like the survivor of a car accident, is now living in the euphoria of just being alive.
"You have a high chance of being killed and you survive," Mr. Zivkovic said. "After that, for a time, you feel lucky. But that feeling dissipates and you start to realize that you have worse problems than before."
The people of Nis, who had been among the most fervent supporters of democratic change and Western policies, have buried 34 civilians, he said -- casualties of NATO. Among them were 11 killed when cluster bombs hit a market on May 7.
Certainly for the moment, the soldiers in Nis are still feeling lucky.
"We are happy we survived, that we are alive," said a 20-year-old conscript who would give his name only as Nikola, sitting in a cafe with two fellow soldiers. They arrived back from Kosovo three days ago from their antiaircraft unit and have spent much of the last two months hunkered down in trenches in the woods in western Kosovo, he said.
"It is good to see civilization after three months," said another soldier, Dragos, also 20, taking a long pull on his beer. The two said they were counting the days until their year of military service was up. "We are in double digits now," said Dragos, meaning fewer than 100 days.
The first thing they did was to call their families and girlfriends, they said. "They were happy," Dragos said. "They had not heard from us for three months, they didn't know if we were alive or not." Afterward the soldiers hit the town.
"We did not want this," said Nikola, gesturing to encompass the war, the NATO bombing and the whole issue of Kosovo. "We enjoy sitting in cafes and chatting. But it was the bad policy of our side -- they failed to solve it in a peaceful way. So NATO bombed us."
Dragos said that as a child, he had wanted to be a soldier, "but now, no way." Nikola, who said he had trained to be a mechanic, insisted that he would never choose a military career, despite the army's attempts to persuade conscripts to become professional soldiers.
The two were initially reticent when asked if friends had been killed in Kosovo. Fighting their emotions, they revealed that they had lost several,, both in the NATO strikes and in Kosovo Liberation Army attacks.
They changed their tone then, saying they were proud to have defended their country against the most powerful alliance in the world. And thinking about their friends who had died, they said it had been worth fighting to keep Kosovo part of Serbia.
As conscripts, they saw the streams of Albanians being expelled, but said they had played no part in the purging. As to fighting the rebels, they said that although they had not taken part in any offensive, their positions had often been attacked.
Yet they seemed to doubt whether the peace deal struck last week was better than that offered in March, before the bombing began.
"I am happy it has ended," Dragos said, "but it could have ended this way three months ago."

LENGTH: 1810 words

HEADLINE: The Unbuttoning of Al Gore: Act 1

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H.

 BODY:
Al Gore is walking up the path to a home here where 40 people have gathered to listen to his pitch. He has shed his blue suit (as per President Clinton's instructions) for a green polo shirt, khakis and cowboy boots. Spotting his host, who is wearing a tie and sports jacket, Mr. Gore calls out, "I hope I'm not too informal!"
That may be wishful thinking. Even in his casual, earth-tone clothes, Al Gore seems pressed and starched. His language has that same formal quality. "I want to engage in a dialogue with you," he begins, then jumps straight to what he alerts his audience is "my punch line: I want to be President and I need your support." 
 As he sets the stage for the official announcement of his candidacy on Wednesday in Tennessee, Vice President Gore still seems to be painting by numbers, following the chalk while he is learning to dance, telling his audience as much as reminding himself exactly what he is doing and why.
For all of his years of practice for the 2000 election -- he was groomed in a political family in Washington, has already run for President once and has understudied with a political master for the last seven years -- Mr. Gore seems oddly unprepared for it.
To be sure, Mr. Gore probably has a more extensive record on issues than anyone else running for President. From his votes in 16 years in Congress, his authorship of a book on global warming and more than six years as Mr. Clinton's Vice President, Mr. Gore has had to take specific stands on hundreds of topics -- abortion rights, ethanol subsidies, trade with China (he favors them all) -- in a way that few other candidates have.
Still, voters do not know who Mr. Gore is and what he is about -- his pollster Mark Penn calls him "famous but unknown."
His campaign hopes to change that on Wednesday.
The Gore camp views the announcement speech as an opportunity for Mr. Gore to emerge from Mr. Clinton's shadow and begin to define himself. The speech also gives him the chance to try to close the book on a period in which most of the information seeping out about Mr. Gore has been negative: his exaggerated claims about creating the Internet, his questionable money-gathering at a Buddhist temple, his steadfastness toward Mr. Clinton during the impeachment proceedings.
Perhaps most important, it gives him a chance to present himself in human terms -- he will talk a lot about himself and his family -- and to try to overcome the perception that he is a wooden technocrat, or, in the word that most people said in a Pew poll was the one that immediately came to mind when asked about Mr. Gore, "boring."
"With our announcement, we are now in the next phase of our campaign," Tony Coelho, the former California Congressman now in the saddle at Gore headquarters, said in an interview. "The Vice President will be dealing directly with the American people on specific issues."
It is highly unusual for a Presidential candidate to get as specific as Mr. Gore intends to this early in a campaign. But Gore aides believe this will help the Vice President separate himself from Mr. Clinton and show up the weaknesses in the two rivals he is most worried about, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey on the Democratic side and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas among the Republicans.
While he has adhered to President Clinton's policies, Mr. Gore is starting to put his own stamp on certain issues. He has given a speech on education and called for universal preschool. He wants to increase the Federal Government's reliance on religious institutions to help with social programs, like drug treatment. He wants to revive the fight for health-care coverage for people without insurance. He wants to limit suburban sprawl and traffic jams as part of what he calls his "livability agenda." And he will be giving policy speeches regularly from here on out.
"The most important thing," Mr. Coelho said, "is for Al Gore to say who he is before the Republicans say who he is and before Bradley says who he is, and to have the American people relate to him."
The strategy is also intended to smoke out Mr. Bush, whose inaugural speeches this week have been broadly thematic. By being specific on issues like gun control and abortion, the theory goes, Mr. Gore will force Mr. Bush to take positions that might reveal him to be more conservative than swing voters are willing to tolerate. If Mr. Bush avoids being specific, the Gore camp says, he will appear inexperienced and unprepared to lead the country.
Specificity also helps Mr. Gore distinguish himself from President Clinton, which is a tricky task. He wants to bask in Mr. Clinton's successes but distance himself from the President's failures.
The glaring Clinton success is the economy. Mr. Gore is running as the man who can continue the prosperity of the Clinton years. "We know what works," he assures audiences.
The glaring Clinton failure is the character issue, including the extramarital activities that led to his impeachment. Pollsters say that "Clinton fatigue," a weariness with the scandals, has been sapping energy from the Gore candidacy.
To counteract that, Gore advisers said the Vice President would emphasize his family-man credentials -- married 29 years, father of four, expectant grandfather. To reinforce the message, Mr. Coelho said, Mr. Gore is to appear on the ABC News program "20/20" on Wednesday, the day of his announcement speech, and make it clear that he disapproved of Mr. Clinton's personal behavior.
Mr. Gore was once hesitant to criticize his boss in public. Forced by reporters to confront the issue of the President's behavior in September, Mr. Gore would use only Mr. Clinton's own words, "I agree with him that it's indefensible."
Mr. Gore is perhaps best remembered for declaring Mr. Clinton a great President on the December day that the House voted to impeach him. The Gore campaign would like to erase that image and make it clear that Mr. Gore condemns the behavior that led to it.
Marla Romash, the deputy campaign manager, said that most people do not know much about Mr. Gore and that at the top of her list of qualities was this: "He's a loving father."
Mr. Gore is mentioning his wife, Tipper, at every turn. This helps him solidify the family image, puts some personality on his blank slate and is intended to help him connect with women. As Mr. Gore told his audience here, he had to cancel their anniversary dinner last month because he needed to break a tie vote in the Senate on a gun-control measure -- which, he added, was fine with his wife. "She is, if anything, more anti-gun than I am," he said.
In its increasingly extensive use of Mrs. Gore, the campaign is also presenting her, subliminally, as the anti-Hillary. She has said she would not be the same kind of First Lady as Hillary Rodham Clinton. She has acknowledged a bout of depression, giving her an air of vulnerability and casting the Gore family as close-knit and caring. The Gores have let it be known that in the impeachment ordeal, while Mr. Gore was backing the President, Mrs. Gore was unforgiving.
Mr. Clinton may be a drag on the character issue, but oddly, his widely acknowledged political skills have also taken a toll on his Vice President. The concern goes beyond Vice Presidentialitis, an infectious disease usually caught by standing in the draft of a Commander in Chief. Most people appear clumsy next to Mr. Clinton, and Mr. Gore is no exception. A recent joint engagement in Texas proved such a disaster for Mr. Gore that the campaign is now on high alert to keep him and his mentor from sharing a stage.
Mr. Gore's advisers say that his difficulty in establishing a persona has been aggravated by his running in a vacuum, against himself rather than an identifiable opponent with vulnerabilities to be exploited.
"Not only has Gore been running in a vacuum, but you have the reflection of Bill Clinton," one Gore adviser lamented. "We're being compared to the absolute best."
Doug Sosnick, a senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, put it a little differently. "Gore has been running so far against two perfect people -- Clinton, whose skills as a candidate are taking on mythic proportions, and Greta Garbo," he said, referring to Governor Bush's ability to appeal to voters without saying much.
The campaign has been reluctant so far to acknowledge Mr. Bradley, Mr. Gore's only rival for the Democratic nomination. But this is proving harder as Mr. Gore finds he still needs to court certain audiences, including union workers and Iowa Democrats, who are pleased to have an alternative.
"They're struggling with whether to engage Bradley," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic consultant based in Los Angeles. "Do you raise his stature, or ignore him and hope he doesn't get traction? That causes some indecisiveness."
Gore aides take solace in his strong showing in early polls testing him against Mr. Bradley. But the picture turns darker when Mr. Gore is matched against Mr. Bush. Voters know little about Mr. Bush, but he leads Mr. Gore in public opinion polls. A recent Newsweek survey found that Mr. Bush was favored by 54 percent of voters, compared with 36 percent for Mr. Gore.
By large margins, voters say Mr. Bush is more of a leader than Mr. Gore, more inspiring, has a better moral character and is more able to get things done. The Governor polls ahead of the Vice President across every category of voter, most alarmingly among the elderly and women, two bedrock Democratic constituencies without whom the Democrats cannot win.
Some Democrats worry that Mr. Bush's talk of "compassionate conservativism" will blur the ideological lines and magnify Mr. Gore's weaknesses.
"The biggest problem facing Al Gore is the fact that people see him as a politician, through and through," one Democratic consultant said. "It's not that he's not smart or doesn't understand where America is at," the consultant said.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said he had told Mr. Gore he was putting too much emphasis on things like endorsements from elected officials. "People see him as more of a politician than he really is," Mr. Schumer said. "But he's a substantive, policy-oriented guy, and I think that's going to come through." Mr. Coelho also dismisses the personality factor, saying the public is not looking for "a drinking buddy" but someone with experience. Still, he said he was considering enlisting Michael Sheehan, a debate coach for numerous Democratic politicians, including Mr. Clinton. "I'm trying to bring Michael back in," Mr. Coelho said. "He's good at identifying certain situations. But I want Al Gore to be Al Gore. If you start to let the computer in your head dictate what you should do, then you lose your heart."
It is Al Gore's heart, his campaign says, that will be on display this week.

Wal-Mart Agrees to Buy British Supermarket Chain
In its first foray into Britain, Wal-Mart Stores agreed to pay $10.8 billion in cash for Asda Group, Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, thwarting a rival suitor at the last moment and threatening other British retailers with a potentially devastating price war.
The takeover agreement is part of Wal-Mart's aggressive buying spree in Europe, where tight zoning regulations make it almost impossible to build big, new stores, leaving entrants into the businesses of supermarkets and large convenience stores no option but to acquire existing chains. Page C4. 

Greenspan Sounds Note of Caution
In Congressional testimony, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned that increases in business efficiency could not counterbalance the strains on the economy forever. But he did not directly address the prospect of an increase in short-term interest rates later this month. C2.
 
Stocks Mixed as Nasdaq Tumbles
Stock prices were mixed and activity remained subdued as traders and investors delayed putting money to work before an important inflation report scheduled for release tomorrow. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 72.82 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 10,563.33. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was flat, rising 0.36 point, to 1,294.00. But the Nasdaq composite index, fell 49.57 points, or 2.03 percent, to 2,398.31. Internet stocks like Ebay and Yahoo declined. C14.
 
Energy East to Acquire CMP Group
Energy East, the parent company of New York State Electric and Gas, will acquire the CMP Group, the parent of Central Maine Power, in a $957 million deal. C6.

U.S. Bows Out of Internet Venture
The Commerce Department has pulled out of a partnership with a private company, Northern Light Technology, to facilitate finding Government information on the Internet. C2.
 
Natural-Food Giant Switches Focus
Over the last two years, Irwin D. Simon, the chief executive of the Hain Food Group, has spent millions of dollars assembling an empire of natural-food products. The company, which now has 27 brands and more than 1,000 products, has been successful in getting its products on the shelves of supermarket chains. Now it is switching its advertising focus from retailers to consumers. Advertising. C12.
 
Boeing Promotes a Smaller Plane
Boeing's centerpiece at the Paris Air Show is not one of its wide-body jets but the newest and smallest member of its fleet, a twin-engine, 100-seat passenger jet called the 717. C6.
 
Britain to Seek Rebuilding Deals
British Government officials plan to meet with business leaders in London to devise a strategy for securing reconstruction contracts in Kosovo, moving to offset a widespread view that British companies lost out in the race to rebuild Kuwait after the Persian Gulf war eight years earlier. C4.
 
Nortel President Plans to Resign
David L. House, president of Nortel Networks of Canada, the communications equipment giant, will resign as soon as this summer, the company said. C27.
 
Microsoft Calls Hostile Witness
Seeking to prove that America Online had deceived the judge in the Government's antitrust trial against Microsoft about its plans to compete with the software giant, Microsoft put its most important rebuttal witness on the stand, David M. SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 3; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 883 words

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
At Cablevision, a Game Is Always On

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
During the Knicks' celebration Friday night after winning the Eastern Conference finals, a beaming man named Marc Lustgarten bear-hugged ecstatic players. Lustgarten was not a mere suit leaping from a prime courtside seat, but the chairman of Madison Square Garden and vice chairman of Cablevision Systems, the ubiquitous company that is the Garden's principal owner.
Lustgarten's joyful reaction is an apt symbol for Cablevision's encompassing embrace of local sports for business's sake. The Long Island company -- and the Dolan family behind it -- appears omnipresent. At nearly every sports corner stands Cablevision, which once preferred the prosaic life of cable systems to the spotlight of team ownership. It owns 45 percent of the Garden, which includes the arena, the Knicks, Rangers and the MSG Network. 
 MSG carries all Knicks, Rangers and Yankees cable telecasts, and its Fox Sports New York corporate sibling controls the Mets, Nets, Devils and Islanders games. MSG also bought then resold the Yankees and Mets' local broadcast rights to Channel 5 and Channel 11.
These relationships place Cablevision in the position of doing business with sports-field enemies, an increasingly common situation when news-media companies own teams and television outlets. The FSNY deal is fundamental to the economic survival of the Islanders, a troubled franchise; for the foreseesable future the contract (which will pay $14.8 million next season and rise to $36 million in 2030) is the team's chief source of revenue until a new arena is built. The league's biggest cable deal is not enough to stop the ownership from trading its single star, Ziggy Palffy, to the Rangers.
One possible holdup to completing the rare trade between local rivals speaks to the power of Cablevision. The Islanders may seek better treatment from FSNY, which blacked out several of its games last season.
Cablevision is also doing non-hockey business with the Devils' owner, John McMullen, who has scorned the Garden's profligate payment of Ranger salaries. Last month, McMullen announced a joint venture with Cablevision to build an arena in Hoboken, N.J. If it is built, it would extend Cablevision's sports influence to the other side of the Hudson.
"I'm still critical of them," said McMullen, who excoriated the $2.5 million the Rangers have proposed as part of the Palffy trade as "an outrage." "They should be forced to put up another player."
But he said his rash view of the Rangers' riches is unconnected to his arena deal. "They're my archenemy, but I'm not compromising anything," he said. "My sole purpose is to get more money to support the team. This is a deal with a company that knows how to run an arena."
Cablevision's consuming interest in protecting its powerful dominion of cable sports rights led to its unsuccessful attempt to buy the Yankees and a still possible purchase of the Mets. Buying the teams would mean owning their television rights in perpetuity, and in Cablevision's world, teams are programming content, and content is a wellspring of ratings, advertising and sponsorships.
It has significant non-sports forays, too: buying the Nobody Beats the Wiz electronics chain of 40 stores; acquiring 63 movie theaters, purchasing the lease to Radio City Music Hall, producing "The Scarlet Pimpernel" on Broadway.
The strategy is more about the glory of programming than the glory of sport. Every move supports the coming digital overhaul of Cablevision's metropolitan cable systems, which will be the launching pad for its telephone, video-on-demand, E-commerce and Internet services, and channels to let viewers choose camera angles during games (and presumably other channels devoted to single teams or crucial games on pay-per-view). The Wiz sells high-definition televisions, modems and phone service plus tickets to the Garden and Radio City.
Even as they dominate the country's largest news-media market, the Dolans are little known publicly. The executive face most associated with the Garden belongs to Dave Checketts, the president, not to a Dolan.
Charles Dolan, Cablevision's chairman, is a reserved but ferocious corporate builder who attends Garden events occasionally. James Dolan, the Cablevision president, is a more rabid fan who attends almost all Knick and Ranger games. But the Dolans are as anonymous as George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' turtlenecked principal owner, is familiar.
Charles Dolan's personal fascination with football led to his failed attempt last year to acquire the Cleveland Browns with his brother. He then bid unsuccessfully with McMullen for the Washington Redskins.
"John took the lead on the Redskins," James Dolan said.
The elder Dolan, 72, would expand his realm further with the Jets, and may do it again with McMullen in front. But their decision will await the issuance of an offering document by Goldman, Sachs.
"My dad didn't ask me about buying a football team," James Dolan said. "If he'd asked, I'd have said, 'Is it a good investment?' "
He said his father's potential Jets purchase would be a personal one that would fit Cablevision's strategy "minimally." Giants Stadium could be an outpost to market Cablevision's toys and services for the digital world -- which is Cablevision's reason for everything.

LENGTH: 164 words

HEADLINE: Debtor Countries Must Pay Up

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Francis Fukuyama (Op-Ed, June 9) argues that the introduction of the birth control pill in Japan will disrupt the country's social stability. However, even before the arrival of the pill, a decadelong recession had been doing the job quite well. 
 Instead, the pill will help Japanese women and their families cope with the already half-broken promise of lifetime employment and the traditional sexual division of labor.
Few women in Japan today feel secure enough to rely solely on a husband's income. Many women with school-age children have gone back to work, where they face blatant age and sex discrimination. The younger generation of women who came of age under the economic crises are well aware of the plight of our mothers' generation.
The introduction of the pill in itself will not change Japanese family values, but it will help women to function better in a rapidly changing labor market.
 
MITSUE SUZUKI
Rye, N.Y., June 10, 1999

Kosovo Rebels Take Over Sites Vacated by Serbs
The Kosovo Liberation Army is emerging to stake its claim to power as Serbian troops withdraw under NATO tanks and guns. The guerrillas pose a delicate problem for NATO, particularly because of the growing political support they command from Albanians. A1
 
NATO slowly expanded its control over a central swath of Kosovo, pouring thousands more soldiers into major towns and villages but effectively ceding the airport in the capital to about 200 Russian soldiers. President Clinton and other senior American leaders spoke with their counterparts in Russia but were unable to resolve the impasse. A15
 
A British financier, acting with the knowledge of Germany and Finland, held secret talks with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that appear to have helped him reconcile himself to the peace agreement, German and Swedish officials said. A15

NATIONAL A20-24
 
Court Voids Broadcast Ban On Casino Gambling Ads
The Supreme Court unanimously struck down a 65-year-old ban on broadcast advertising of casino gambling, ruling on First Amendment grounds that the Federal law "sacrifices an intolerable amount of truthful speech about lawful conduct." The Court focused on the irrationality of making distinctions among advertisers: gambling at Indian-owned casinos could be advertised, but not at Atlantic City casinos. The Court suggested that a more uniform and "coherent" policy of advertising restrictions might be upheld. That left the door open for the Court to uphold restrictions on the advertising of other lawful products, like tobacco. A1
 
The Court agreed to decide if public schools can provide computers and other "instructional equipment" for use in religious schools. A22
 
Gun Issues Spilt From Crime Bill
House Republican leaders separated gun-control proposals from broader juvenile-crime legislation and put the gun measures in their own, distinct bill. Republicans said they were trying to make sure that new restrictions on firearms had a fair chance of passing the House. Democrats said it was really a tactic to try to insure the failure of gun control. A24
 
New Tack on Clean-Air Rules
The E.P.A., stymied by two court rulings setting aside clean-air standards, said it had a new way to force power plants in 12 states to cut pollutants that contribute to smog in the Northeast. The approach relies on petitions brought by four states saying that no matter what they did within their borders they could not meet older smog standards, because too much pollution blew in from other states. The utility and coal industries, which won the last round in court, said they would file legal challenges to the new E.P.A. tactic. A24
 
Cloning Effort Denied
The Geron Corporation, which has sponsored the leading research on primordial human cells, said it was conducting research on discarded human embryos in the hope of learning how to convert the ordinary cells of a patient into stem cells, which can be used for self-repair. The company denied a published report that it was trying to create cloned human embryos and said it had no intention of doing so. A21

NOW and abortion rights groups gathered at the New Jersey State House for their first demonstration against a measure that would require teen-age girls to notify their parents before getting an abortion. A City Council rift widened over a bill that would clarify and strengthen a law to protect children from poisoning caused by lead paint. B5

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1069 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE CONTINENT;
Europe's Aim: Arms Parity

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 14

 BODY:
The Kosovo war has brought radical changes to the European continent, thrusting Germany into a leading military role not seen since 1945, galvanizing attempts to forge a common European defense policy and altering Europe's relationship with the United States.
Of course, with Russian stability still deeply uncertain, and the abrupt movements of Russian troops in Kosovo suggesting that Moscow's military may be restive, Europeans remain wary of any "decoupling" from Washington. But the desire to maintain trans-Atlantic ties is now accompanied by a push to balance them in a new way. 
 Gerhard Schroder, now often called the Kriegskanzler, or War Chancellor, has found himself steering a coalition made up largely of former pacifists toward involvement in a war that has ended with the planned deployment of 8,000 German troops in Kosovo, the largest contingent after Britain.
"Germany has become a normal country in military terms, and that is a critical change for Europe," said Jonathan Eyal, a British defense analyst. "The change is timely because the war has shown how much Europe needs to do to catch up with the United States in defense terms."
Until the Kosovo war began, the European Union remained obsessed with the creation of a common currency, the euro. Efforts to develop shared European defense and security policies were largely stalled.
But an 11-week NATO bombardment of Kosovo that was dominated by the United States appears to have changed things. Europe's need for new military technologies like laser-guided bombs was clear, as were its dependence on the United States for strategic reconnaissance and its lack of aircraft.
As a result, a debate that had been confined to a few foreign policy and military experts about Europe's growing dependence on the United States and its failure to keep up with new technologies has become a subject of wide public discussion. The decisions Europeans will make are not yet clear, but they know they have to make some.
"Kosovo has been a watershed in so many ways," said Karl Kaiser, a German foreign policy expert. "For Germany, it has represented a coming of age. For Europe, it has brought a crushing realization of the asymmetry of military power between it and the United States, and the need to do something about that."
Already, Europeans have shown that they intend to be in the fore of the Kosovo deployment. Troops from the four major European Union countries -- Britain, France, Germany and Italy -- will total about 33,000, outnumbering the planned American unit of 7,000 troops by almost 5 to 1.
The British commitment of 13,000 troops reflects Prime Minister Tony Blair's determination to give his countrya leading role in the development of European defense. This makes him critically different from former leaders, who saw such a policy as a betrayal of the Atlantic alliance.
The Germans have clearly moved from a peripheral role in Bosnia -- where far fewer troops were deployed, and those only after a heated national debate -- to a central one in Kosovo that was quickly approved last week by Parliament. The ghosts of Nazi horrors in the Balkans, so present at the time of the Bosnian discussions, have faded.
But on Sunday there was evidence of tensions surrounding the German deployment. A German military spokesman said German NATO troops in Prizren shot and killed two Serbs. In another episode about 25 miles south of Pristina, two German journalists from the weekly newsmagazine Stern were shot and killed by unidentified men.
The large European deployment reflects both the Pentagon's enduring hesitations about ground troops and Europe's emerging desire to prove itself after its failure in Bosnia and the American domination of the air campaign over Kosovo.
"Our vision of a multipolar world is being reinforced," Jacques Chirac, the French President, said of the Kosovo deployment, picking up an old French theme stressing the need to counter American "hegemony."
Europe can point to a real role in ending the Kosovo war: its envoy, President Martti Ahtisaari of Finland, brought home the peace agreement from Belgrade. At the same time, Europe at last merged its redundant defense body, the Western European Union, with the European Union itself and appointed the NATO Secretary General, Javier Solana, as its first high representative for foreign and defense policy.
But, as Mr. Eyal, the British defense analyst, remarked, "These changes, for the moment, are largely symbolic ones, and all the difficult decisions lie ahead for a continent still massively dependent on the United States for the military power that was decisive in Kosovo."
Those difficult decisions include increasing defense spending. The United States spends about 3.2 percent of its total output of goods and services on defense, compared with an average of about 2.1 percent in Europe.
Such increases are sure to meet strong domestic resistance in many European states, where important bodies of left-of-center opinion suspect NATO's reinvention of itself as an agent of humanism. They see it as merely a way to reinforce defense industries and spread American capitalism behind a mask of benevolent concern for human rights.
Constraints on European budget deficits imposed when the euro was created will also hamper increased defense spending.
"Kosovo has made it clear that a complete restructuring of European armed forces is needed," said Mr. Kaiser, the German analyst. "The notion that everyone does and repeats the same thing has become absurd. There has to be a new division of labor, new synergies, new European thinking, but politically it will not be easy."
Still, for perhaps the first time since the end of World War II, Europeans seem aware that they cannot eternally remain the security orphans of 1945 or depend overwhelmingly on the United States, which is deeply reluctant to deploy ground troops in conflicts.
Europeans have also realized, more fully even than over Bosnia, that conflict on the continent did not end with the cold war's conclusion, but merely shifted to the Balkans.
"There is no military exit strategy from the region," said Carl Bildt, the United Nations Kosovo mediator. "An international military presence to guarantee peace in the Balkans must be seen in the coming decades as something as natural as it was to have troops in divided Germany during the cold war years."

HEADLINE: Big vs. Local in Harlem Supermarket Proposals

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
As boys, Mauricio and Matthew Fernandez were schooled in the grocery business by their father, Mateo, a hard-driving Dominican immigrant who began life in this country as a waiter and wound up operating seven medium-size supermarkets in Harlem. Three years ago, Mateo Fernandez was fatally injured while driving to work, and his sons took over the business he had built.
Now, the young entrepreneurs -- Mauricio is 26, Matthew, 30 -- say they are ready to move up to the next level and open the first full-size supermarket in central Harlem, on city-owned land near five of their stores. They have asked the city for the chance to build a supermarket on a long-vacant lot on 145th Street and Bradhurst Avenue amid a growing residential neighborhood. 
 For many years, the absence of full-size supermarkets in places like Harlem has forced residents to travel long distances to shop or to make do with a more limited selection and -- in many cases -- higher prices. But these days, such neighborhoods are considered a promising source of buying power, and the Fernandez brothers have found themselves competing for the Bradhurst site with the Pathmark Stores chain and four other bidders.
It is not often that a site large enough for a full-size supermarket becomes available, so the two most talked-about proposals could place city officials in a tough bind: should the city choose Pathmark, which has two decades of experience running inner-city supermarkets and has just opened a gleaming $15 million store in East Harlem? Or should it award the opportunity to local businessmen who have earned the respect of Chase Manhattan Bank, but have never operated anything larger than their flagship store, a 12,000-square-foot Pioneer market on 145th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard? The 35,000-square-foot supermarket that they propose would be nearly three times that size.
Officials of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development are so closed-mouthed about the selection process that they will not even confirm the identities of the applicants for the site or discuss the decision-making criteria in any but the most general terms.
The other applicants include two community development corporations based in Harlem -- the Consortium for Central Harlem Development and Harlem Congregations for Community Development -- and White Rose, a food and dairy wholesaler.
Bidders were also asked to come up with plans for more than 100 units of affordable housing and other retail space. The city plans to make a decision sometime this summer, said Richard T. Roberts, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development.
Supporters of Pathmark, which operates 133 supermarkets on the East Coast, including about two dozen in urban locations, say the chain is better equipped than its competitors to bring the community the type of store it sorely needs.
"Pathmark can provide services that don't exist there," said Paul Travis, the managing partner at Washington Square Partners, a company that is advising the Mattone Group, a developer involved in the proposal to build a 47,000-square-foot Pathmark store. "There is no store of that size with all the features of a modern supermarket."
A Pathmark on Bradhurst would spur further commercial development in the area, just as a Pathmark has on 125th Street, where a developer has proposed building a 10-screen multiplex, said Harvey Gutman, a senior vice president of the supermarket chain.
But some Harlem residents consider the Bradhurst area unsuitable for commercial development. Community Board 10, which represents the neighborhood, opposed the construction of a full-size supermarket, saying it would bring too much traffic to a residential neighborhood, said Stanley N. Gleaton, the chairman.
Harlan Levine, the division counsel for White Rose, said the store that his company proposed would be smaller than both the Pathmark and the Fernandezes' store, but would use the Internet to offer home delivery directly from the store.
Most Harlem residents have not taken a position on who should run the market, said Millicent E. Redick, a consultant to the Consortium for Central Harlem Development, one of the applicants.
Gregory O. Watson, the senior vice president of Harlem Congregations, said that under his proposal, the development team would find a market and negotiate the terms. "There's strong community sentiment for fresh vegetables, for variety in terms of food products -- all the things that Pathmark offers," Mr. Watson said. "If a smaller store can compete, I think the community would be very supportive."
The contest over Bradhurst echoes the battle over the Pathmark on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, which opened in April. In 1995, the owners of several local independent markets, many of them also Dominican immigrants, nearly managed to block the Pathmark by arguing that a large store would have a devastating impact on their businesses. They accused the city of turning its back on business people who were willing to invest in Harlem when no one else would.
But Pathmark supporters said the new supermarket would force the independent grocers to do a better job. Even before the East Harlem market opened, there were signs that some of the independent grocers nearby were improving the appearances of their stores.
Like the market owners in the earlier conflict, the Fernandez brothers say they will suffer badly if Pathmark comes to the Bradhurst site. "If Pathmark wins," Mauricio Fernandez said during an interview in his office above the 145th Street store, "it will be a terrible blow to us." To drum up support for their application, they have called upon the same lobbyist, Richard Lipsky, who unleashed a storm of protest over the East Harlem Pathmark.
But, as Mr. Lipsky points out, some of the independent markets have made great strides in recent years. As evidence that the playing field is becoming more level, Chase, which played a major role in getting the 125th Street Pathmark built and also does business with the Fernandezes, is not taking sides on the Bradhurst project. "The city will decide who the winner is," said Ruth M. Salzman, a senior vice president at the bank, "and if it's a bankable transaction, we would like to be a part of it."
Ms. Salzman said that the success of the Fernandez brothers represents a generational shift in the grocery business. "The owners of today are more sophisticated business people, who also have aspirations to grow their businesses," she said. Compared with their predecessors, these entrepreneurs keep better records and use more formal accounting methods and more sophisticated management and information systems, she said.
Ronald Moelis, one of the developers from Larchmont, N.Y., who teamed up with the Fernandezes, described them as "very strong financially."
Some food service experts wonder if the Fernandez brothers are overreaching. Pamela J. Fairclough, the director of the supermarket project for the Community Food Resource Center Inc., an advocacy group for the poor, praised them for running cleaner stores and caring for them better than many other owners do. But she said that the smaller stores could not match what Pathmark offers. "All of these stores suffer from the way that they handle perishable stuff," she said.
The Fernandez brothers said that because they own several stores, they have already learned how to operate a large-scale business. Mr. Lipsky added that the stores they run total 75,000 square feet. Mauricio Fernandez said, "A lot of people stereotype the smaller stores, but it's not fair when it comes to us."
David Grotenstein, a consultant to the retail food industry who is not advising any of the applicants, said the Fernandezes should not prevail over Pathmark unless they can pinpoint how they would handle the various challenges that such a leap would entail. "The idea of going with a local merchant is very appealing," he said, but "the goal should be to serve the neighborhood. As the decision is made, that should be the major consideration."
