HEADLINE: A Jail Waiting to Explode?;
In Suffolk, Warnings From Guards and Guarded

BYLINE: By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.

 BODY:
There are two ways to tell when dawn is coming if you are an inmate at the Suffolk County jail. First there are the lights -- they are turned up so the guards can serve breakfast. The other clue is the rattle of steel plates.
Breakfast is served precisely at 5:30 A.M. It is usually cold and it is never enough. On a morning early in June it was three undercooked sticks of French toast and tomato juice. The 44 men on the fifth tier declared a hunger strike. "I might be behind bars, but that don't make me no animal," said S Berry, a 23-year-old drug offender who violated his parole. 
 "This place is a hell-hole, and nobody on the outside knows it," said Kevin Duffy, 40, also a parole violator. "You got guys in here actually praying to go to prison, 'cause nothing's worse than the county jail."
Among penal centers with more than 650 inmates, the Suffolk County Correctional Facility has quietly become the most overcrowded in New York, according to the State Commission of Correction, the agency in charge of monitoring jails.
Built in 1969, the jail now holds nearly 1,800 men and women, or 144 percent of its capacity. In contrast, Rikers Island in New York City, with 17,500 prisoners, is at 80 percent of its capacity, and the Nassau County jail, with 1,600 inmates, is at 73 percent.
The Correction Commission notified Suffolk County last year that it would sue unless the county did something to ease the overcrowding. The county has responded by ordering a $150,000 study of the jail. Nassau County, on the other hand, began building more cells in the early 80's in response to a threat of a Federal lawsuit, and New York City began an expansion after a judge ordered the release in 1983 of nearly 600 detainees because of overcrowding.
Conditions at the Suffolk jail are deplorable, says Sheriff Patrick A. Mahoney, the county official in charge of the jail. "I keep saying if you want to lock all these people up, then you better make more bed space or we are going to have a very major crisis here."
The Correction Commission oversees 57 county jails, 70 state prisons, 14 New York City jails and all its precinct lockups, but is unable to monitor everything thoroughly, say lawyers, independent penal observers and clergy members. Without such oversight, they add, it cannot be known exactly how the Suffolk jail compares with others in the state.
The inmates call it the Plantation. The faces behind the bars are overwhelmingly black, while the men with the gold stars who watch over them are mostly white. The walls are stained, and paint falls from the ceilings in chunks. Some of the toilets do not flush.
In the five-story maximum security wing, each tier -- a row of 30 cells built for 30 men -- is overcrowded. Even the walkways outside the cells are now used for housing. Fourteen men sleep on steel cots in each one, increasing the heat, congestion and frustration in the already pulsing atmosphere.
County jails rarely attract the attention or oversight that state prisons do, in part because they hold such a transient population: those who are waiting for trial or bail, who have been sentenced to less than a year, or who have been convicted and are waiting to be transferred to state prison. Yet that very population -- in which violent criminals mingle with the mentally ill, the homeless and those held on relatively minor charges -- can make a county jail a volatile place.
"Most of us in here are by far no angels," said Austin Offen, who pleaded guilty to assault for beating a man outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub and has been waiting in the Suffolk jail since February for a slot in prison. "But if it continues like this, packing dudes on top of each other and bookending them," there could be a riot, he said.
Inmate attacks on officers at the Suffolk jail have nearly doubled, to 80, over the last year, jail officials say. Some inmates are still gang members, and disputes from the street are sometimes battled out in the jail's exercise yard and chapel. About 500 inmates receive psychiatric medication, and many arrive with some sort of drug dependency.
The jail has not made headlines like its counterpart in Nassau County, where four guards have been charged with violating the civil rights of an inmate who was fatally beaten in January.
But Sheriff Mahoney, who is calling for a new jail wing, has complained repeatedly about crowding, and about pressure to reduce expenses that he says he gets from the County Executive, Robert J. Gaffney. Peter A. Scully, a spokesman for Mr. Gaffney, said the County Executive would not comment on the sheriff or the jail.
The Sheriff, who is challenging Mr. Gaffney for county executive in the fall, gave a reporter full access to the jail on several visits within a week.
Inmates showed off washcloths stained orange with rust. Two men revealed rashes on their backs that they attributed to the drinking water. Forty-four men shower in a stall that is caked with mildew; officials say there is not enough money for cleaning supplies. On some floors there is no air-conditioning and the ventilation is poor. The cell block reeks of urine and stale sweat.
The men are locked in their area for 23 hours a day, regardless of whether they were convicted of murder or marijuana possession. A guard slides meals into each cell through a slot. Because the day areas are so crowded, many prisoners prefer to sit all day in their 8-by-10-foot cells, 14 bars wide by 11 bars high, saying they fear being stabbed with a sharpened toothbrush.
At 11 A.M. lunch is served. This day it is chop suey, and it is cold. An inmate on the fifth tier throws it against the wall.
"When the hell are they gonna send me downstate, so at least I'll be treated like a dog?" he bellows.
A man whose bed is in the walkway screams, "You got it all over my damn blankets!"
In the world outside, serious crime may be falling but judges are getting tougher on those still committing crimes, ordering longer sentences and creating a backlog of convicts waiting for a cell in already overcrowded state prisons, experts say. In the meantime, people are sent to the Suffolk jail, a village behind razor wire and cinderblock along the Peconic River.
The average daily population at the jail has increased nearly 40 percent in five years, but no new cells have been built. A few hundred bunk beds have been added, doubling up inmates in cells in the medium security area, in addition to the steel cots in the maximum security walkways.
Over the same period, the operating budget for the county jail has increased 24 percent. Officials say that inflation and the need for more jail workers means low-quality food, few cleaning supplies, worn bedding and peeling paint.
Robert Gangi, executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, an independent watchdog group, said that, judging by the numbers, the jail is swelling like a water balloon. "For all intents and purposes, no one is really monitoring the jails, so abuses and deficiencies are inevitable," he said.
The State Commissioner of Correction, Alan J. Croce, a former Suffolk County undersheriff, was not available for an interview, his assistant said. But last year, Mr. Croce said Suffolk County would have to expand its jail because overcrowding threatened the well-being of both prisoners and guards.
Correction officers, working in some situations where they are outnumbered 60 to 1, are concerned.
"They say the place is overcrowded, but it seems like there is always room for one more bed," said John Simchick, 54, a correction officer who has been on the job 20 years and points out that he has just 5 more before retirement. "The attitudes flare up, and it's your safety on the line, and you start wondering who's the one in prison."
In the late afternoon, the sun is burning. There is no shade, no place to hide in the exercise yard, where one small group at a time can spend an hour lifting weights or playing basketball in the patch of blacktop surrounded by razor wire.
Two dozen men mill about in prison greens. Hand signs flash. A fight breaks out between two gangs. The one guard in the yard calls for backup. When it is over, one man needs stitches in his face, another has a lump on his head, a third has an injured hand and a fourth wears a tight, bitter smile. They go back to their cells, and the guards fill out paperwork, willing to bet that the beef is not over.
Inside Tier Block 1 East, a maximum security row holding high-profile inmates and the extremely mentally disturbed, a dinner of sausage and fries is about to be served. One man, who is required to wear a paper suit so he cannot use his clothes to hang himself, has smeared himself with feces.
Because most of the county's psychiatric hospitals have been closed or scaled back over the last two decades, the jail has become a primary psychiatric and detoxification center, says Charlie Pendlebury, a psychiatric social worker in the jail's mental health unit.
Mr. Pendlebury is a tall, calm man with the demeanor of a painless dentist. He works in a windowless office and is often overwhelmed, he says. Medical records are kept in cardboard boxes and there is only one full-time psychiatrist on staff.
"I've been here 15 years, and what it comes down to is trying to keep the lid from blowing off," he says. "Just keep it cool until they get out of here. Then they are society's problem."
Dinner goes smoothly. The men on the fifth tier have ended the hunger strike they began in the morning. A television bolted to the wall plays until the lights go down at midnight. The guard makes his tour and all is quiet. Then someone starts baying like a dog.

HEADLINE: Albany Budget Stalls, but Discord Stays in High Gear

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 14

 BODY:
When Gov. George E. Pataki and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver had a rare meeting the other day, there was no shortage of unfinished business between the two foes. The discord they had bred in the Capitol had delayed the state budget and along with it decisions on many issues, from health care to drug policy to school violence.
Yet less than 15 cheerless minutes after the meeting began, it abruptly broke up with a familiar result: Each man was blaming the other for freezing the gears of state government. 
 Albany would never be a shoo-in for a civics hall of fame, but this year's proceedings have so far been particularly fruitless.
Since the current six-month session began in January, the Governor and the New York Legislature have enacted only about 60 laws, the fewest at this point for any year in the 90's and less than half the annual average of 125 for that period, according to state records. Most of this year's new laws have been relatively minor, like the ones giving honorary names to roads.
"I have always had trouble with the way Albany functions, and this year confirms my troubles," said Assemblyman Martin A. Luster, a Democrat from central New York.
At the heart of the paralysis is the collapse of the relationship between the Republican Governor and the Democratic Speaker, which has soured beyond the usual mistrust, stalling negotiations on the $73 billion state budget and numerous other matters. At the same time, the system has conferred so many advantages on sitting lawmakers -- last year, not one was defeated for re-election -- that they can be confident there will be little retribution from voters over what happens, or does not happen.
The Capitol's rhythms are usually dictated by the adoption of the budget, because unrelated policy matters are included in the haggling over spending. But the budget negotiators have been particularly wary of one another this year.
In 1998, Mr. Pataki, seeking more control over the budget-making, astonished the Assembly Democrats by vetoing more than $1 billion in programs that they had proposed.
This year, Mr. Pataki is again threatening to use his veto scalpel, saying that the Democrats are spendthrifts, and the Democrats are responding by balking at a new budget until Mr. Pataki promises to leave their programs alone.
As a result, there has been something of a work stoppage in the Capitol. The Governor and lawmakers have agreed on important matters only when faced with a deadline that could not be skirted. One of Albany's few notable accomplishments this year was its repeal of a tax on commuters who work in New York City, which occurred mostly because lawmakers wanted to appeal to voters in an impending special election in a suburban area.
The Legislature convened in January with an ambitious agenda. With the state's finances robust, and the Governor and legislative leaders experienced at piloting the government, they set their sights on a wide range of issues, from initiatives to modify the state's drug laws to new rules for polluted industrial sites. But no laws in these areas have been enacted.
Both houses of the Legislature have passed bills in recent weeks. Hundreds of them, in fact. But they remain merely proposals, since neither the Governor nor the legislative leaders have stepped in to negotiate compromises.
"There is a great deal of resentment and anger and frustration at the process," said State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Westchester County Republican.
The Legislature historically has composed the majority of its laws in the final days of the session, and when this one closes -- the end is scheduled for Wednesday but most likely will be postponed while the budget talks lurch on -- state leaders will probably have some achievements to point to. Still, having fallen so far behind, the Governor and the Legislature will have to jettison many issues in order to focus on a few they have time to resolve.
This has happened before, but it appears that this year the impasses are more difficult to surmount.
To many Democrats, and even to some Republicans, Mr. Pataki's leadership style has contributed to the stagnation. Never known for his noisy advocacy, the Governor has largely chosen to wait out his foes rather than twist their arms. But with the Legislature divided -- Democrats control the Assembly and Republicans control the Senate -- it often takes strong pressure from the executive branch to get the two houses to agree.
"New York has a great tradition of strong Governors who have been able to either work with or coerce the Legislature," said John R. Dunne, a former Republican State Senator from Long Island. "I think that we are lacking that element at this point. I think what Governor Pataki has to do is really utilize the full powers of his office, including that of persuasion, in some really hard face-to-face bargaining with the legislative leaders. Dewey, Rockefeller, F.D.R., Al Smith -- they were masters at it."
Mr. Silver has sought to portray Mr. Pataki as more interested in his national political ambitions than in tending to his current job. "I think it's clear the Governor was running for President," Mr. Silver said.
But Mr. Pataki said that Mr. Silver and the Assembly Democrats were to blame for the state of the legislative session because they "have decided to act based on their political interests, as opposed to the public's interests."
The hostility between the two leaders has reached a point at which they hardly ever speak in person, and while they talk to each other on the phone occasionally, as they did today, it is rarely helpful. In the middle is the leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, who has a rocky relationship with Mr. Silver but who, except except for a few points, gets along with the Governor.
To old hands, the antagonism between state leaders seems more pronounced now.
"We didn't always agree, but we could get along," said Warren M. Anderson, a Republican from Binghamton who was leader of the State Senate in the 1970's and 1980's. "There was more of a spirit of trying to get a job done, which would require compromises. I don't think that it's indigenous to Albany. I think that it's probably the current times."
Usually, the parties put aside their differences after an election, but the attacks of last year's races seem to have exacerbated tensions. Hoping to loosen the Democrats' hold on the Assembly, the Republicans aired television commercials that portrayed Mr. Silver and the Assembly Democrats as sharks eager to gobble up -- that is, tax -- the money of upstate residents.
The Democrats ultimately gained a seat, but the ads offended Mr. Silver. His aides said Mr. Silver, an Orthodox Jew, believed that the ads were subtly anti-Semitic, which the Republicans vehemently denied.
If last year's election caused animosity in Albany, it also gave lawmakers confidence that they had the public's approval, even though the budgets passed in 1996 and 1997 were the state's latest.
Lawmakers say they think that voters care much more about the final shape of the budget than about the messiness of making it, and they think they can forestall any backlash by approving emergency bills to keep the government running. Still, many groups, from school districts to nonprofit agencies, have trouble planning because the delays prevent them from determining how much money they will receive from the state.
Albany's insularity is illustrated by the debate over measures to combat school violence. In the wake of the school killings in Colorado, Congress and state legislatures around the country hurried to pass gun control legislation and other proposals. In Albany, the Assembly Democrats and the Senate Republicans, allied with Mr. Pataki, advanced plans that had much in common, including provisions that raised penalties for violence on school property.
But a stalemate arose when Mr. Silver insisted that any negotiations include his proposal to ban assault weapons in the state. That infuriated Mr. Bruno, who accused Mr. Silver of adding the assault weapons measure, which many Republicans oppose, in an effort to damage the Republicans politically.
Mr. Bruno cut off talks. Instead of reaching a deal on areas over which there was little dispute, like rules governing when principals and teachers could remove disruptive students from classrooms, the two sides have done nothing for weeks.
Despite the lack of progress on that and other issues, lawmakers say there is little evidence that anyone is concerned. Mr. Luster, the Assemblyman from central New York, said he had received only two letters from constituents upset about the late budget, as opposed to hundreds that he had gotten in previous years.
State Senator Kemp Hannon, a Nassau County Republican, said that with the economy strong, people were not looking as much to the state for help. When he is home on weekends, constituents do not complain to him about Albany, he said.
"They think that the Legislature is very productive," he said. "They are thinking that we have done a great job."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Another Company Takes the 'Hong Kong' Out of Its Name

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, June 15

 BODY:
Score another one for globalism over localism. Hong Kong's local telephone company, Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd., said today that it would change its name to Cable and Wireless HKT to tighten ties with its London-based parent company, Cable and Wireless P.L.C.
Hong Kong Telecom said the new name was intended to convey the company's broader ambitions as a supplier of Internet connections and electronic commerce, as well as traditional telephone services, throughout Asia. 
 "We are rooted in Hong Kong and will continue to focus on Hong Kong with investment," said Linus Cheung, the chief executive of Hong Kong Telecom, at a news conference. But he added, "For the future performance of our company, we will have to move out of Hong Kong."
To some people here, the move is more discouraging evidence that Hong Kong is losing its brand-name prestige as a commercial center. Last November, HSBC Holdings, the parent of the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, announced plans to drop the "Hongkong" from the English name of its flagship bank in favor of the HSBC abbreviation.
"Every time the Hong Kong name is removed from a major company, you reduce the publicity for Hong Kong," said Ian K. Perkin, the chief economist of the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "It downgrades the world's perception of Hong Kong, which is disappointing."
Mr. Perkin also questioned Hong Kong Telecom's decision to tie its image to Cable and Wireless, a 127-year-old British company that cobbled together its global network by constructing telephone operations in onetime British colonies, from the Caribbean to India to Hong Kong.
"Cable and Wireless is a company that followed the British Empire around the world," he said, "The name seems to be a throwback."
To Hong Kong Telecom, however, the Cable and Wireless name symbolizes a thoroughly modern company no longer wholly dependent on either its home market or traditional voice communications. Its ventures outside Hong Kong include building the first fiber optic cable linking Chinese cities.
Hong Kong Telecom's nonvoice services range from fax and data transmission to Internet access and interactive television. Voice communications generate only 40 percent of the company's profits, Mr. Cheung said, and that figure could fall to 25 percent in three years.
"Our vision is to make Hong Kong the Internet hub and E-commerce center of Asia," Mr. Cheung said, noting that the company had spent $20 billion (Hong Kong), or $2.58 billion (United States), to upgrade its networks here.
Some analysts said the name change might have been dictated more by corporate imperatives in London. Although Cable and Wireless had one of the first genuinely global telecommunications networks, investors have not rewarded the company with a commensurate valuation in the stock market.
"They weren't getting credit for it because most of the assets weren't named for Cable and Wireless," said Lloyd Fischer, a telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in Hong Kong.
Mr. Fischer predicted that the name change would have little effect in the home market because the company would not be changing its Chinese name, which translates as "Hong Kong Telecom." More than 95 percent of Hong Kong's residents are Chinese. HSBC also kept the Chinese name of the Hong Kong bank.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
If you're going where the tracks go, the train can be a realistic, pleasant alternative to air travel.

BYLINE: By Joe Sharkey

 BODY:
OF course, the train doesn't have anywhere near the reach of the plane. But for business travelers who happen to be headed where the train tracks go, the railroad offers a realistic alternative to the dread airport departure lounge.
Here's a report on one recent business trip on Amtrak's Metroliner, which travels between New York City and Washington, D.C.: 
 The train departed precisely on time. Seats were large (comparable to business-class seats on an airplane), with big pull-down trays and 120-volt outlets for electronic gear. Throughout the trip, computers and cellular phones were widely in use (though, in the case of cell phones, not ostentatiously).
In the first-class car, the seats were the same as coach, but attendants served free drinks and a hot meal or sandwich and snacks. Arrival was exactly on time three hours later at Washington's bustling Union Station. The ride was smooth and pleasant.
According to Amtrak, more business travelers are opting to go by rail, at least on the well-trod Metroliner route between New York and Washington. Last year, 2.1 million passengers took the Metroliner; so far this year, ridership is up more than 6 percent, according to an Amtrak spokesman.
Largely because of its growing popularity with business travelers, the Metroliner makes a profit of about $10 million a year for Amtrak, which recently announced an ambitious revamping of the service. Starting late this year, the Metroliner will be called Acela, with routes expanded to cover the whole Boston-New York-Washington corridor.
Metroliner fares are competitive with those for air travel, an important consideration for many business travelers and employers, who cringe at the huge disparity between air fares for unrestricted business travel and discounted leisure travel. On the airlines, for example, typical business fares now are nearly four times higher than the lowest discounted leisure fares (whereas threeyears ago, they were only about two and a half times higher), according to the American Express Business Airfare Index.
The weekday round-trip Metroliner fare from New York to Washington is $230 ($376 for the first-class accommodations, which means that the meal, drinks and extra service cost a very pricey $146). Unrestricted round-trip fares on both the Delta Air Lines and US Airways shuttles from New York to Washington are $404.
Incidentally, the train-plane fare difference is far more pronounced in California, which generously subsidizes some Amtrak routes. The round-trip fares on the Amtrak San Diegan trains between San Diego and Los Angeles, for example, are $50 ($72 for business class). By air, UAL's United Express and Skywest round-trip fares from Los Angeles to San Diego are $226.
 
Side Trips
Summer travel season is here, with mounting stresses on air-traffic control. Late Monday afternoon, flight controllers contending with thunderstorms in the Midwest ordered 50-mile intervals between all flights converging on New York City, with delays of an hour or more as flights piled up all across the country.
Usually, this is a recipe for more tension between long-suffering air travelers and haughty airlines, especially when a flight has left the gate only to idle interminably on the tarmac while captive passengers fume at the lack of information and the sit-down-and-shut-up attitude of the flight crew.
Not so, however, on AMR's American Airlines Flight 1968 from Chicago to Newark Monday afternoon. The cockpit crew and flight attendants provided a textbook example of how to handle a long delay with skill.
Shortly after announcing that the plane had been held indefinitely on the ground in Chicago, the captain came back on and said, earnestly, "Folks, I didn't know about this when we left the gate or, believe me, we would not have left that gate."
The captain then invited passengers to use their cell phones. Flight attendants passed out cold drinks and magazines, while making an inventory of passengers' connecting flights. Every 10 minutes, the pilot came back on to describe what he did and did not know about the delay. And more than an hour later, after the plane finally took off, a flight attendant announced that the captain had persuaded both American and Continental Airlines in Newark to hold connecting flights to Britain in order to accommodate several dozen passengers on the delayed flight from Chicago.
The upshot: Because of heads-up customer service, grumbles turned to approval in the air. Most of the passengers actually thanked the pilot as they filed out, well over an hour late.
 
Twofers to Britain
British Airways said yesterday that it would offer a free round-trip ticket to London with each seven-day advance-purchase round-trip economy ticket bought before June 30 for summer travel. (Sample round-trip fares for such British Airway tickets are: $598 from New York, $778 from Dallas and $798 from Los Angeles.) But there's a hitch: The free ticket is only good for travel from Nov. 1, 1999, through March 31, 2000 (except Dec. 15 through Jan. 15). This means the two tickets cannot be used together. However, it's a good deal for a business traveler who has to make a summer and winter trip to London.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
N.A.S.D., in a joint venture in Japan, moves to create an around-the-clock, global stock market.

BYLINE: By Edward Wyatt

 BODY:
THE National Association of Securities Dealers took a big step yesterday toward the creation of an around-the-clock, global stock market with the announcement that it would team up with the Softbank Corporation to develop a version of its electronic Nasdaq Stock Market in Japan to trade United States and Japanese stocks.
The new market, to be known as Nasdaq-Japan, will offer trading of the 100 or so largest stocks from the United States Nasdaq market and will recruit new Japanese companies that are seeking to raise capital from Japanese and American investors. In addition, it will seek to jointly list companies whose shares are currently listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. 
 The new market, which is expected to open in the fourth quarter of 2000, will seek to accommodate investors' desires to trade both while the Nasdaq market is open in the United States -- while most of Japan is asleep -- and during the normal Japanese trading day, which lasts until about 1 A.M., Eastern standard time, or 2 A.M. during daylight time.
Eventually, the two markets could together provide investors with the ability to trade for up to 21 hours a day, closing only for a short period either before or after the standard hours of trading in the United States, said Frank G. Zarb, chairman and chief executive of the N.A.S.D., the parent of the Nasdaq market.
Coming less than three weeks after Nasdaq said it would begin preparing to extend its trading hours in the United States, yesterday's announcement demonstrates how rapidly markets around the globe are being transformed by technology and a global economic boom.
"To the extent we are successful here, it could have implications beyond Japan," Mr. Zarb said in a reference to his organization's attempts to cooperate with other financial markets around the world.
In a possible signal of its intentions, the N.A.S.D. recently registered potential names for Internet sites that combine the Nasdaq market's name with Hong Kong, China, Brazil, India and Germany, according to a report yesterday by Newsbytes, an Internet news service.
In Japan, Masayoshi Son, the chairman and chief executive of Softbank, heralded the new venture as nothing less than "a historic moment for the whole Japanese economy and society."
"This is a great opportunity for young, entrepreneurial companies that would like to have access to the equity markets in a different fashion than they currently do," Mr. Son said.
But he also made clear that much of the interest in Japan would come from Japanese investors who wanted to explore what many of them view as a potential gold mine: initial public offerings, particularly of United States Internet companies.
Relatively few Americans have wanted to invest recently in Japanese stocks, which have been in a brutal bear market for most of the decade. But some investment managers say the new market could make it easier for Japanese companies to raise money from investors, thereby stimulating the Japanese market and the economy.
"The obvious benefit is that this will be another venue for companies to raise money in Japan," said David Herro, portfolio manager of two Oakmark International mutual funds. "If the market has good standards, it might give Japanese companies an incentive to be more shareholder-oriented," a characteristic whose absence has often frustrated United States portfolio managers who invest in Japan.
In addition, Mr. Herro said, Nasdaq's entry into the Japanese financial markets is one more blow against the monopolistic forces that have kept foreign competitors out of Japan for so long.
"The most difficult thing about doing business in Japan is the closed nature of the economy," he said. "Anything that eats away at the strength of Japan Inc. is for the better."
The Nasdaq-Japan venture will initially receive an investment of $4.9 million, half of which will come from the N.A.S.D. and half from Softbank, the Japanese venture-capital concern that has backed successful Internet ventures such as Yahoo, E*Trade, Ziff-Davis and Geocities.
But the success of the market is dependent on winning the approval of regulators in both countries, as well as its ability to cobble together the complex systems needed to support on-line trading. The Nasdaq-Japan market will rely heavily on the Internet to connect its American and Japanese constituents rather than on a dedicated electronic system.
Mr. Zarb cautioned that joint ventures were tricky by nature, and they become more complicated when they involve partners from different countries who speak different languages. Approvals for the new market must be gained not only from Japanese regulators, including the Ministry of Finance, but also from the United States Securities and Exchange Commission. Both Mr. Zarb and Mr. Son acknowledged that two sets of regulations could make the hurdles the venture faces twice as tall.
The Nasdaq-Softbank venture is clearly aimed at expanding the popularity of electronic trading. With Nasdaq-Japan, the N.A.S.D. hopes to establish an important beachhead in a country where electronic trading is, so far, insignificant.
Only 36,000 on-line trading accounts exist in the Japan. In the United States, where on-line transactions account for 16 percent of all stock trades, Charles Schwab alone has 2.5 million active on-line accounts. In Japan, however, E*Trade, the electronic broker that is 27 percent-owned by Softbank, is planning a rapid rollout of its services in Japan.
In addition, the Nasdaq-Japan market hopes to offer Japanese investors the opportunity to buy and trade futures contracts, options and index products, investment vehicles that are still oddities in Japan.
Not everyone is enthusiastic about the planned venture. Alan L. Davidson, president of Zeus Securities, a small broker-dealer based in Jericho, N.Y., who is also a director of the N.A.S.D., said that the venture raised the same problems for small securities firms as the recently approved proposal to extend Nasdaq's trading hours -- that is, how to afford to remain open all that time if customers want to trade.
Mr. Zarb said yesterday that the N.A.S.D. would work to limit the inconveniences posed by extended trading hours on small securities firms.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Planned Korean Share Issue Angers a Big U.S. Hedge Fund

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 15

 BODY:
A leading American hedge fund that has prominently invested in South Korea's rebounding economy is protesting a plan by the nation's biggest mobile phone operator to issue more shares.
The objection from Tiger Management L.L.C., operated by the well-known fund manager Julian H. Robertson, calls the plan by SK Telecom unfair because the larger SK group may benefit disproportionately. Tiger's complaint is regarded as another in a series of signs that the momentum of South Korea's economic modernization is slowing as the country regains financial strength. 
 Tiger said today that it was calling for a special shareholders meeting on the matter and threatened to take its case to court if SK Telecom's board did not cancel the plan to issue shares.
Lee Jung Dong, a spokesman for SK Telecom, said today that the company's board had approved the plan. He expressed surprise at Tiger's reaction.
The fact that such a complaint has been made against SK Telecom -- which has been regarded as an example of how foreign investors can impose Western-style corporate governance and disclosure on Asian companies -- is one measure of how unhappy those investors are becoming. SK Telecom's minority investors, in addition to winning the right to recommend outside directors, had succeeded in appointing an outside auditor.
Perhaps feeding such unhappiness, the Government has delayed selling two big banks it nationalized in the financial crisis, which took hold in December 1997 and required a $58 billion aid package from the International Monetary Fund.
Today, the Government said it was dissatisfied with the offers made in its second attempt at selling Korea Life Insurance and announced a third round of bidding. The first attempt failed when the Government's terms scared away big foreign insurers like Metropolitan Life and AXA of France.
On Monday, officials said they might reopen bidding for a 25 percent stake in Korea Gas, a state-owned monopoly, because bidders including the Osaka Gas Company of Japan and BG P.L.C. of Britain had not met its price demands or reached an agreement on management participation.
There is concern among foreign investors that the rights offering is an attempt to prevent them from increasing their stake in the company when the Government lifts the restrictions on foreign ownership of telecommunications companies to 49 percent from the current 33 percent.
They say the SK group is worried that if foreigners own such a substantial part of SK Telecom, the company may slip from its control.

HEADLINE: Abu Ghosh Journal;
His Pot of Gold Gives a Sparkle to the Whole Town

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG

DATELINE: ABU GHOSH, Israel, June 14

 BODY:
Driving his gleaming black Cadillac through the rutted roads of this village outside Jerusalem, Jawdat Ibrahim talked about his miserable childhood. It was miserable even by the relatively abject standards of an Israeli Arab born 34 years ago in a country that considered him second class.
When he was 4, he sat beside his father on a bed as the man, for reasons never known, took his life -- drinking poison, then fading away. His mother, bereft, raised her six children in a cellar with a dirt floor, the only finished part of the house his father had intended to build. There was rarely enough to eat, and what Mr. Ibrahim remembers most is feeling lonely in a village that was technically one big family. 
 Today, in a melancholy mood, Mr. Ibrahim still seems somewhat lonely, although he has literally gone from the cellar to the penthouse. He narrated his story on the expansive terrace of one of his marbled, Jacuzzi-filled townhouses here, a few blocks from his fancy restaurant in the center of town. Then, in butter-soft leather loafers, he glided down the polished stairs.
The terrible circumstances of his youth, he said, created a philosophy in his home. Determined to treat others with the respect she was often denied, Mr. Ibrahim's mother raised her children not only to consider themselves the equal of everyone, Jew or Arab, but also to consider everyone their neighbor. It was a mindset that planted itself deep inside Mr. Ibrahim as a bud of self-confidence.
It stayed with him even as he fled to Chicago, where his uncle lived, and as he drove a tow truck through frigid Midwest winters, bailing out luxury vehicles trapped in snowbanks.
Mr. Ibrahim had no grand design for the future when he bought his first and last lottery ticket in 1990.
But when he won a $17.5 million jackpot in the Illinois State Lottery, he took it as destiny. He was forced to sue to get the prize, denied him on a technicality; the lawsuit increased his earnings to $22.7 million. He embarked first on an extended shopping spree. Then, in 1992, with the option of moving anywhere in the world, he chose to return with his millions to this pocket-sized traditional town -- to his home, his clan.
Mr. Ibrahim has parlayed the money into a peculiar role for himself -- not only inside the town, which he helped remake, but in Israel as a whole, where he used new-found access to designate himself an emissary of peace, brotherhood and protexia (the Hebrew word for pull, or connections).
"Jawdat is an open guy after all those years in the States," said Sallah Tarif, an Israeli Arab member of Parliament with the Labor Party. "This is the kind of type we need here in order to do something with ourselves, to advance."
Shortly after he returned from the United States, Mr. Ibrahim opened the elegant Abu Ghosh restaurant, starting a trend that has considerably helped the economy of the town. Abu Ghosh, whose working people used to solely commute to factories every day, now has a full row of locally owned restaurants.
On Saturdays, the town is jammed with secular Israeli Jewish tourists. For most of the tourists, it is their only contact with Arabs at all, inside or outside Israel. But most do not come for political reasons; almost every restaurant in nearby Jerusalem is closed for the Sabbath.
Still, Mr. Ibrahim, who shmoozes in Hebrew with his customers, thinks of it as a kind of peace industry. And he points to the Israeli-American-Palestinian negotiations that have taken place at his restaurant as evidence that he has created a kind of halfway house between worlds.
"I like to think that I have put Abu Ghosh on the map as a symbol of peace," he said.
"We Israeli Arabs should be the bridge of peace. Israelis have to have peace with us first, then they can think about Lebanon and Syria."
Abu Ghosh has always had a strange standing in the Israeli Arab world. It was seen as a "collaborator's village," because the mukhtar, or leader, of the clan who lived there made a decision 50 years ago not to fight the Israelis in order to preserve the town.
Superficially it looks better off than most Israeli Arab towns, but Mr. Ibrahim said that four or five families are squeezed into almost every house. The town, half the size it used to be, is hemmed in by a highway and Jewish developments. Now, when someone is tempted to sell land to an outsider, Mr. Ibrahim rushes to buy it first.
"I love buying land, especially in Israeli Arab villages," he said.
Part of Mr. Ibrahim's goal has been to reconnect Abu Ghosh with the Israeli Arab world, to make it clear that their problems are shared, that "we are brothers." His Abu Ghosh Foundation finances projects for Israeli Arabs throughout the country, from youth leadership programs and technology training to prenatal care and direct cash grants to cover the medical costs of the very poor.
The foundation also awards about 40 scholarships a year, to both Arab and Jewish students -- "so that maybe some Jewish foundation will do the same in reverse," he said.
He himself barely made it through high school, mostly because he was working nearly full time after class, tending the backyard gardens of Israeli Jews. Possessed of considerable chutzpah, he later tried his hand at running a small ceramics factory in the heart of Jerusalem -- after talking the aging Jewish owner into leasing it to him for a pittance.
But he was not a businessman, and when he ran to the United States, he was fleeing a mountain of debts. He persuaded a travel agent to sell him a plane ticket on credit, and flew off to Chicago to find his uncle.
Personally, his return was triumphant but difficult, reconciling the pain of his past with the power that the lottery money has brought him.
"When people come and ask me for things now," he said, "I can't help but ask myself where were those people when I was a child."
His first marriage, to an American he fell madly in love with, started in Las Vegas and ended in divorce.
Three years ago, his second wedding was a grand affair, a Muslim wedding held at the Notre Dame Church in the heart of town and attended by a who's who of Israeli, Palestinian and Jordanian political figures. His mother and his 100-year-old grandmother beamed with pride. They had persuaded him to consent to an arranged marriage to a young woman from his extended family.
He was told that love would grow, he said, but it didn't work. He and his wife are separated, he said sadly, standing in front of a birthday card framed and displayed on the bar of his restaurant. It's from President Clinton.
The break-up was not his only recent disappointment.
For the last five years, the Interior Ministry, which was controlled by the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party, has run the town. The Mayor and the entire council were religious Jews, appointed by Shas. Finally, the town held its first elections for Mayor early this year. Mr. Ibrahim ran -- and lost.
"He's young, and he was away for a long time," said Dr. Subhi Abu Ghosh. "And we behaved no differently from those in any other democratic race, we didn't necessarily elect the best."
Pensive about his ups and downs, Mr. Ibrahim has tired of the assumption that his lottery earnings have fueled his successes and fed his failures.
"I make myself myself," he said. "It's not the money. It's me."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
An Epidemic of Grins Hits the Granite State

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS

 BODY:
George W. Bush is literally golden, with a ruddy glow that gives him the look of having been perfectly toasted. "I know what matters is that a candidate have a positive, hopeful, upbeat, optimistic message," he said at a rally in New Hampshire this week, going on to assure the crowd that he himself was positive, hopeful, upbeat and optimistic as all get-out.
At this point, the Governor of Texas had been campaigning for President for approximately 40 hours, and appeared to have pretty much wrapped up the Republican nomination. The average voter, who could not identify Mr. Bush in a lineup, nevertheless seems to like him much better than Al Gore, rating him higher in almost every possible category of achievement. The way things are going we will probably soon hear that polls show most Americans think Mr. Bush would do a better job as Tipper's husband. It would be enough to make even Bob Dole giddy. 
 The cheer absolutely pulsates through his campaign. Mr. Bush has a Clintonian determination to win over every single individual in a crowded ballroom, and if one stray voter seems oblivious to his presence he will go after that lost little sheep, grabbing an arm or clapping a back until contact is made. He can work a room for hours, till no hand is left unshaken. This is a good day to be alive! Later he will make his formal speech, which is always about being a compassionate conservative, and he will perhaps tell a little story about his mother, the former First Lady, or his dad, the ex-President, or remind them of all the successes he achieved governing Texas during one of the greatest economic booms in the nation's history.
"I love being in New Hampshire!" Mr. Bush says over and over.
And New Hampshire loves Mr. Bush. Its famously dour inhabitants are making money hand over fist these days, and they are positive, hopeful, upbeat and optimistic too. Frankly, the Republicans there do not seem nearly as interested in the principles of compassionate conservatism as they are bonded to Mr. Bush's euphoria. They like all the candidates! Larry Emerton, an uncommitted state legislator, has hardly had time to decide whom to support this time around, what with the way his real estate business has been going like gangbusters. He thinks Mr. Bush would be a terrific nominee even though he has been a longtime backer of Lamar Alexander ("He's a nice guy") and admires just about everybody else as well. "I even like Bill Bradley," says Mr. Emerton, as he watches Mr. Bush spreading cheer at the Republican Women's Lilac Luncheon.
Mr. Bush is supposed to be on a mission to recapture the Republican Party from extremism, just as Bill Clinton took back the Democrats for the moderate middle in 1992. At this moment, his job seems beyond easy. The forces of right-wing righteousness whose howling scared away voters over the last two elections are already in retreat. When Mr. Bush implicitly declares war against Pat Buchanan in the free-trade section of his stump speech ("The fearful build walls, the confident tear them down!") he is really paying Mr. Buchanan the compliment of pretending he's on the radar screen.
However, the old, angry Republican Party is still alive and yelping in Washington, where it is currently engaged in a war against gun control and a fratricidal feud over the budget. Mr. Bush actually shares many of its positions on matters like guns and abortion and tax cuts. (When asked to name the first two things he would do as President, Mr. Bush, who didn't appear to have thought quite that specifically about the future, basically said he would build more antiballistic-missile systems and cut taxes for the wealthy.) But the mean-spiritedness of the capital is anathema to his message of cooperation and inclusion -- there's plenty to go around and nobody should be left out.
It would be interesting to see Mr. Bush and the House Republicans trying to inhabit the same ticket. At the candidate's first stop in New Hampshire, someone asked him what he had to say about Congress's accomplishments.
"I thought the welfare package was great," he said, reverting to Bill Clinton's first term. Asked for something more recent he laughed, and called 1996 "recent memory."
It was the only time all week that George W. Bush looked backward.

HEADLINE: Mexican Chief Seeks to Insure A Nightmare Doesn't Recur

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, June 15

 BODY:
The former Mexican President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari, was a political hero when he ended his term in 1994. But just a few weeks later, the peso dived, jobs and savings were annihilated, and Mr. Salinas was soon forced into disgrace and exile.
Now his successor, President Ernesto Zedillo, is trying to insure that an end-of-term economic nightmare does not recur when he leaves office next year. 
 Today Mexico announced that it has pulled together financing and credits worth $23.7 billion to "armor" the economy, as President Zedillo put it, through December 2000. That is when he will turn over his office after six years to a new President chosen in the most democratic -- and therefore the most unpredictable -- elections in Mexican history.
To add to the reassurance top finance officials are offering ahead of time to international markets, they also pledged to maintain the disciplined economic policies that have allowed Mexico to ride relatively smoothly while other Latin American countries, especially Brazil, were buffeted by global turbulence during the last year.
Finance Minister Jose Angel Gurria said Mexico would stick to a modest Government deficit of 1.25 percent of the nation's gross domestic product this year, and plans to lower it further, to 1 percent, next year. Guillermo Ortiz, the head of Banco de Mexico, the central bank, said the battle against inflation would remain a priority.
Mr. Gurria said the finance package, including a $4.2 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund, would "allow us all to sleep easier."
The I.M.F. is providing the funds under a 17-month Standby Arrangement, one of the agency's regular, non-emergency programs. Mexican officials said the monetary fund is showing confidence in Mexico, which is continuing to pay down $5.9 billion it owes from a 1995 bailout.
The package includes $5.2 billion from the World Bank, mainly for investments in social programs and government reforms, and $4 billion from the Export-Import Bank of the United States to help underwrite some of the $200 billion in trade each year between the two countries.
In addition, the Inter-American Development Bank announced that it would provide $3.5 billion in loans through the year 2001 for big construction projects and reforms to strengthen local governments.
Enrique V. Iglesias, the president of the bank, joined the chorus of praise for Mexico today, saying that by negotiating the I.M.F. loan Mexico "provides additional comfort" to international markets about the coming elections.
Like a patient struggling with mood swings, Mexico went far toward controlling its habitual end-of-term depressions by just acknowledging that they existed. Throughout his presidency, Mr. Zedillo has built up foreign reserves so that the country would not be caught short in case political events during the next year make investors want to pull back. Now reserves stand at $30 billion, a record high.
"None of the imbalances that existed in 1994, and that led to the crisis of 1995, are present today," Mr. Ortiz, the central banker, announced triumphantly this morning.
Mexico is expecting at least $9 billion in long-term foreign investment this year, Mr. Gurria said. Overall foreign debt, by one measure, is about half what it was in 1994, the Finance Minister said.
"It's almost overkill," said Walter Molano, the head of research at BCP Securities in Greenwich, Conn. "They are so heavily armored, they seem to be expecting something much worse than even what the markets expect."
Steep downturns also came in 1982, when President Jose Lopez Portillo nationalized the banks just before leaving office, and to a milder degree in 1988 when Mr. Salinas took over.
Economic collapse did not come until weeks after the end of Mr. Salinas's term in 1994, but a series of unsettling events during his final year in office undermined confidence in the economy. The Zapatista Indian uprising in the southern state of Chiapas and the assassination of the governing party's first presidential candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, made investors nervous. They bolted en masse when Mexico disclosed that its debts were far outrunning its foreign reserves.
Mr. Zedillo spent his first years in office picking up the pieces of the economy and started it growing again. He also promoted reforms that made it much more difficult for him to control the outcome of the presidential elections in July 2000.
He has said he is anxious to spare Mexicans the losses they have routinely suffered at the end of presidential terms. He is also anxious to be spared the ostracism that fell to Mr. Salinas.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Advances by 31.66; Inflation Data Are Awaited

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Stocks inched higher yesterday in thin, convictionless trading in advance of an important inflation report scheduled to be released this morning.
Concern about what the May Consumer Price Index might show caused bond traders to pare positions late yesterday. And the sight of rising long-term interest rates brought stock prices down from their highs. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.66 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 10,594.99. Blue chips that have been punished recently -- a list that includes Procter & Gamble, Citigroup and Merck -- led the advance yesterday.
Among broader indexes, a rise in large technology stocks helped to lift the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by 7.16 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 1,301.16. The Nasdaq market, hit hard on Monday, recovered a bit yesterday as prices of some Internet stocks came off their lows. The Nasdaq composite index rose 16.36 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 2,414.67. And the Russell 2000 index of smaller- company stocks gained 2.48 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 434.01.
"All in all, the market gave a great account of itself a day before an important number" like the consumer price report, said Ned Collins, head of stock trading at Daiwa Securities America.
"But there is no conviction about anything. Until we get some definitive statement from the Fed about interest rates and start to see some second-quarter earnings reports, the market will lack a catalyst to take off."
Trading activity reflected the lack of enthusiasm many seem to have for stocks just now.
On the New York Stock Exchange, 696 million shares changed hands. Volume on Nasdaq was 837 million shares.
As Mr. Collins suggested, uncertainty is likely to remain mired in the market for the rest of the week at least even if the consumer price report shows that inflationary pressures are subdued. That is because Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is scheduled to testify before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress on monetary policy and the economy. And Friday is a "triple witching" session, when options, futures contracts and options on futures all expire. Trading on those days is often volatile.
"I would not be surprised to see the market trade in this directionless fashion until the Fed holds its meeting at the end of the month," said Hug Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
The Fed's policy-making Open Market Committee is scheduled to hold two days of meetings beginning June 29. Most financial market participants expect the central bank to raise short-term interest rates by a quarter-point at the meeting.
Yesterday was a good one for semiconductor stocks, which rallied after a Merrill Lynch analyst raised his estimate for the growth rate in semiconductor revenue.
Texas Instruments gained 5 1/8, to 134 3/8. Broadcom jumped 9 5/8, to 110 5/8. And Intel , the industry leader, rose 1 5/16 , to 55 11/16 .
Oil companies also did well on expectations that demand for gasoline is rising as the summer driving season gets under way.
Exxon, a Dow component, rose 1, to 82 1/8. BP Amoco gained 2 5/16 , to 113 3/16 . And Royal Dutch Petroleum was up 7/8, to 60 1/8.
Other market movers included Coca-Cola, which fell 1 1/16 , to 63 3/4, after a health scare in parts of Europe led the company's drinks to be pulled from shelves in Luxembourg and parts of France and the Netherlands.
CMP Group, which owns Maine's largest electric utility, saw its shares jump 5 11/16 , to 25 3/4, on news that Energy East, which owns a New York utility, had offered to buy it for $1.2 billion.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices were little changed yesterday as investors were reluctant to buy Treasuries ahead of today's consumer price report, which may convince the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates later this month. "People are cutting back on any unnecessary positions" before the May price report, which follows the biggest monthly price gain in almost nine years in April, said Alan Day, who helps oversee about $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. "When in doubt, sell."
Yields have risen more than a quarter-point in the last three weeks, and many investors said they were already being compensated for a possible half-point increase in the Fed's overnight lending rate, now at 4.75 percent, when policy makers meet June 29-30. The price of the 30-year issue fell 6/32 , to 88 9/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.11 percent, from 6.09 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Dancing to a New Health Care Beat;
Latin America Becomes Ripe For U.S. Companies' Picking

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

 BODY:
Millions of people across Latin America are, for better or worse, getting a taste of American-style health insurance. Pushed by the rising expectations of a growing middle class, countries in the region are opening their government-dominated health systems to private companies, both domestic and foreign.
Some of the biggest United States insurers, seeing Latin America as a prime growth market, are actively testing the waters from Mexico to Argentina, Brazil and Chile. Latin Americans already spend $120 billion annually on health care, or about $412 per capita, adjusted to reflect local health costs. While this is only about one-ninth of the total health spending in the United States, the big Latin American countries are spending a much bigger share of their economies on health than all the Asia-Pacific economies except Japan. 
 Aetna International has already put together health plans with 3.3 million members in seven Latin American countries. The Cigna International health care unit has 1.5 million members in five countries. American International Group has more than 300,000 health insurance customers in the region.
Of course, government officials, physicians and health care workers there are all too aware of the problems of managed care in the United States, which include disputes over the decision-making authority of doctors and growing numbers of people without health coverage. But they hope to avoid similar pitfalls. Doctors' groups in Brazil and Ecuador and the powerful Government-allied unions in Argentina, in fact, have resisted moves to privatize health care.
"The negative part of the picture," said William C. Hsiao, director of health systems studies at the Harvard School of Public Health, "is that the private health plans in these countries compete by selecting the best risks" -- recruiting predominantly young and healthy members and avoiding people who would be likely to need costly treatments.
"The insurance companies take the cream off the top: employees of banks, high-tech companies, large multinationals," Professor Hsiao said. They do not operate in the countryside, where health services have always been sparse. Governments have tried to provide at least rudimentary care, typically by government doctors and public hospitals. However, exploding populations and the rising cost of care have swamped the public system as life expectancy in Latin America has risen to 71 years, about five years less than it is in the United States.
Wealthy Latin Americans still go to prestigious medical centers in the United States and Europe, as they always have, or to Rio de Janeiro, a world capital of cosmetic surgery. But middle-class working people, who often must wait in line for hours at overtaxed clinics, have lost patience with the public system.
With encouragement from the World Bank and other Washington lending agencies that promote privatization, Chile, Colombia and Brazil have lowered the bars that had kept out foreign-owned health companies. Argentina and Mexico have taken the first such steps and may go further after their coming presidential elections.
 
Seeking Payoffs Down the Road
 Managed care is an often contentious concept both north and south of the Rio Grande, and American companies are avoiding the term. But they are preparing the ground for managed care techniques, setting up computerized information systems that can monitor the practice patterns of physicians and hospitals, and help supervise patients with expensive problems.
"We have not used the term 'managed care' in Argentina," said Mark Tabak, chief executive of International Managed Care Advisers, a New York-based fund that invested $50 million in a joint start-up venture with Banco de la Provincia de Buenos Aires. The plan, Provincia Salud, calls its business "coordinated care," he said.
Revenues of private health care companies are growing much faster in Latin America than in the United States, where managed care has matured into a slow-growth field with slim profits. American International Group says its revenues in the region are growing 20 percent annually on average.
Chris James, a senior vice president of Cigna International health care, said the number of health insurance customers and the amounts they would be able to spend were growing significantly.
"These markets are already larger than most countries in the Asia-Pacific region, except Japan," he said. "More significantly, they are changing faster."
Aetna International has invested $510 million in health care ventures in Latin America over the last five years. Cigna has invested $475 million overseas since 1997, most of it in health care in Brazil.
Both Aetna and Cigna had $800 million or more in Latin American health care revenues last year. Profits have been modest so far, but the companies project substantial payoffs down the road.
One reason for that forecast is that relatively easy savings -- what health care consultants call the low-hanging fruit -- are still there to pick. For example, there are the big initial savings like those that managed care concerns reaped in the United States by paying hospitals a fixed amount for each patient or a low negotiated rate. As hospitals sent patients home sooner, charges dropped for employers and insurance companies.
Also, unlike the United States market, the private insurance market in many Latin American countries is not closely regulated.
"Each country is on a different time frame," said Howard Kahn, vice president for global health business at Aetna International. "You have to be sensitive to the medical culture, the social culture, the stage of economic development."
 
Greater Access, And Room to Grow
 Some middle-class Latin Americans with good jobs say they are glad to have private coverage, which so far has included few restrictions on care.
"Obviously, I'm happy," said Alejandra Couto, 34. Her son Tomas, a premature baby who weighed less than 2 pounds at birth, was treated for 10 weeks in a well-equipped Buenos Aires hospital that is part of a big health care company that Aetna bought in January for $120 million. Tomas, now 3 months old, has thrived, Ms. Couto said.
"In public hospitals you can have one nurse for eight infants," she said. "Here, it's one nurse for every two babies."
Ms. Couto said she paid $28 each month for coverage that her American-owned employer, Foxboro Argentina, arranged with the Aetna unit, Asistencia Medica Social Argentina. Her employer picked up the charges not covered by the insurer.
The good news, Professor Hsiao of Harvard said, is that public and private hospital officials and physicians "all begin to think a new way" -- they become alert to making the system more cost-effective and efficient, which may someday lead to better care. "These countries are spending a significant amount of money for health care," he said.
According to the World Bank's latest figures, Brazil spends 6.8 percent of its gross domestic product on health care, Chile 7.9 percent and Argentina 9.7 percent. The United States spent 13.5 percent of its gross domestic product on health care in 1997, the most recent data available.
Poor, elderly working people who were fully covered by Government social security programs now must come up with co-payments in Chile and Argentina. This presents "enormous barriers to access," said Dr. Howard Waitzkin of the University of New Mexico, one of the authors of a survey of the growth of managed care in Latin America published in The New England Journal of Medicine on April 8.
In Chile, the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, taking advice from advocates of a free market who had been trained at the University of Chicago, began to privatize in the early 1980's. But private insurers still cover fewer than 5 percent of those over 60 and typically charge higher premiums to women of childbearing age, said Cristian Baeza, a former head of the national insurance fund in Chile who is joining the department of health policy and management at Johns Hopkins University.
Alejandro Ferreiro, a Government official who supervises health insurance in Chile, said, "The current system of risk selection is based on economic logic, but this does not make political or social logic."
Employers, especially American companies, yearn for anything to hold costs down. But some expensive local practices may be hard to change. Employees at one multinational in Brazil had a choice of three health plans and could go to doctors belonging to any of them at any time, said Helen Darling, a managed care expert at the employee-benefits consulting firm Watson Wyatt.
Companies that provide paid coverage often find that an employee has "lent" his health plan identification card to a "cousin."
"We run into that a lot," Mr. Kahn of Aetna said. But insurance companies have to proceed carefully. "We try to stay a step ahead of the competition," he added, but if a company gets "too far out in front, it may lose customers.
"What we consider clear fraud in the United States may not be considered fraud in some places," Mr. Kahn continued.
 
A Tempting Niche . . . And Politics
 In Brazil, the colossus of the region, 40 million people are covered by hundreds of private health plans, from traditional fee-for-service plans to varying degrees of managed care. Many plans are cooperatives owned by physicians, but American insurers and venture capital funds hope to scoop them up and install their own management methods.
One giant federation of co-ops there, Unimed, which has 11 million members and 87,000 doctors, seems too big to swallow.
"Brazil is the fastest-growing opportunity," Mr. James of Cigna said. "The public system doesn't work. Per capita spending on health is less than $300," compared with more than $3,900 in the United States in 1997.
More than 60 percent of Argentina's 37 million people have some coverage, mainly through labor union plans called obras sociales.
"No private company would do what we do to prevent disease and improve the life style of our members," said Alberto Antoniotti, the administrator of the Primero de Mayo clinic in La Matanza, an industrial city near Buenos Aires. The clinic is operated by a union that represents education workers.
But members of small, weak unions typically get lower-quality care in poorly equipped clinics, and at least 11 million people in Argentina have no coverage at all.
In his office, surrounded by photographs of Eva Peron -- who is still revered as the patron saint of the obras sociales -- Jose Luis Lingeri, the superintendent of the system, said people who now fall through the cracks would have better access to coverage as the weaker union plans merge into stronger plans.
Meanwhile, critics say funds earmarked for health often vanish into political slush funds and the pockets of union officials. "The problem is, we have a political system that corrupts," said Hector Carrica, a health care official of Argentine Workers Central, a 750,000-member federation that competes with the much larger unions allied with the big Peronist party.
Two million people, most of them middle class, are covered by prepaid plans like the Aetna-owned company, which has 240,000 members. Each provides access to one or two hospitals and a list of doctors, much like a preferred provider network in the United States.
The World Bank lent Argentina $350 million to revise its system and make it easier for obras sociales to deal with private managed care companies. But the politically powerful Peronist unions blocked President Carlos Saul Menem's deregulation program in Congress.
Blue Cross plans are also looking for Latin American opportunities. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Delaware has a joint venture with local partners in a small prepaid plan in Uruguay and plans to expand in Argentina, where it already offers coverage to people who go to United States medical centers. Blue Shield of California and the Blues plans in Texas and Arizona have a joint venture that intends to open shop in Mexico when it gets the go-ahead from the Government.
"It is natural for the private sector to move into the health system because public resources are so scarce," said Antonio Palocci, a public health doctor in Brazil who is also a Workers Party member of Congress. "But I worry about foreign groups coming in, because they might view health care more as a business than a basic service."

HEADLINE: Gates Testifies, and the Republicans Seek to Forge Closer Links

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
Al Gore may not have invented the Internet, but he and President Clinton have honed their skills of extracting political contributions from Silicon Valley. Now, in a three-day "High Tech Summit" on Capitol Hill, Republicans are trying to show that they have the capacity to be even better friends of William H. Gates and his competitors.
This morning, Mr. Gates -- his once-sharp barbs about Washington lawmakers replaced with such deferential comments as "you've raised an interesting issue, Senator" -- was filled with prognostications about how the Web, wireless networks and electronic commerce would turn "consumers into big winners." 
 And the members of the Joint Economic Committee, led by Republicans, were so filled with praise for the Microsoft Corporation and its entrepreneurial ilk that they only once, and then only obliquely, raised the uncomfortable question of how antitrust laws were applied to the world's most powerful software company. Left unsaid, but understood, was that it is President Clinton's Justice Department that is pursuing Microsoft in court a few blocks away.
Indeed, the subtext of the three days of hearings, which began with the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and continued today with Mr. Gates's appearance, is that Republicans are eager to get the Government off the valley's back. Certainly, many in Silicon Valley would be happy to see Microsoft have its hand slapped by the Government. But that did not stop heads from nodding today when Mr. Gates talked about how keeping "a light hand" on the regulation of technology industries "is working very, very well."
No sooner had he finished talking than the Senate voted to lighten the touch even more: Over the Administration's objections, it approved a bill that would limit the liability of high-technology companies for any damage from the Year 2000 computer bug. President Clinton has pledged to veto the legislation, a version of which has already been passed in the House, providing yet another wedge for Republicans who maintain that the White House is the valley's fair-weather friend.
"There are two things going on here," a Republican member of the committee said after today's hearings, asking not to be further identified. "There are real issues we'll have to deal with," among them hearings on Internet privacy, data encryption and support for basic research. "And there are questions of political funding. Which of those goes first? That will depend on how cynical you are."
Mr. Gates once reveled in an apolitical nature. Until a few years ago, Microsoft maintained only a small presence in Washington, eschewing professional lobbyists and suggesting that the importance of what happens in hearing rooms pales in comparison with what happens in software labs. Meanwhile, the Republican leadership, or at least those leaders without significant high-technology constituencies, largely ceded the territory to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore.
But these days, they see an opportunity. Software makers are still haggling with the Administration, and Mr. Gore in particular, over rules limiting the export of programs that offer high-level encryption of data -- which American intelligence agencies fear will be exploited by potential enemies.
And at today's hearings, William L. Larson, the president of Network Associates Inc., described how the company is about to lose "a seven-figure deal" to provide such software to Chrysler, after its new parent, DaimlerChrysler, insisted on purchasing programs that could be shipped around the world. The business is likely to go to a German competitor, Mr. Larson said.
Others used the moment to lobby for an extension of the research and development tax break. Charles Vest, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, warned against "growing complacency" about American high-technology superiority, and noting that Federal funds for basic research and development were declining. He said that at this point "the United States is living off of historical assets that are not being renewed." The Internet's origins lie in a system developed by the Pentagon and used for years, largely in obscurity, by academics.
But the big draw today was Mr. Gates, who received the gentlest of handling all around. There were no tough questions about charges that have arisen during the antitrust trial. In fact, there were no tough questions at all -- either from the Senators or from students who were asking questions, via an Internet link, from university and high school projects that Microsoft is backing.
While it was never discussed, the Republican-dominated panel was aware that Microsoft greatly increased its giving to political causes in the 1997 and 1998 election cycles, and the expectation is that the amounts could increase significantly for the Presidential election.
The company and its employees gave about $1.3 million in unregulated "soft money" over the last two years, putting them among the top dozen or so in this category.
It was listed as a "table sponsor" for the Republican Congressional Committee dinner last week. While tables sell for $25,000 -- relatively small stuff in the world of big contributors -- the move was viewed as a sign of things to come as Republicans seek to exploit Microsoft's unhappiness with its treatment by the Clinton Administration.
Microsoft has increased its permanent lobbying staff in Washington and has also reached out to some of the capital's longtime consultants. Among the lobbyists under contract is the former chairman of the Republican National Committee, Haley Barbour.
Roughly two-thirds of Microsoft's political spending already goes to Republicans, a figure that a senior employee at the company's Redmond, Wash., headquarters said "would probably come as a surprise to most Microsoft employees."
Mr. Gates did everything he could today to steer clear of controversy. He talked about forthcoming inventions that would help members of Congress in their work, including new types of portable digital devices that would help them "access your own 'digital dashboard' " even when they are out of Washington.
He banished from his vocabulary almost all his usual tech-speak, talking as if he was giving a speech to an interested but somewhat unsophisticated chamber of commerce.
Invited to give his views on the state of American antitrust laws, he said that "the laws as they are currently written are fine." The implication he left is that they are being wrongly interpreted in Microsoft's case. But he dodged specific mention of the litigation, other than to say "things like integration of new features are one of the freedoms companies have" under those laws.
Part of the Microsoft case hinges on the matter of whether the company is integrating its Internet browser into the Windows operating system in a way that undercuts the ability of competing browsers to operate.
