HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

With Silicon Valley Bounty Comes Unease About Boom
In Silicon Valley, the nation's high-technology heartland, the good times have arrived in abundance and have stayed longer than ever before. Wage rates are about 60 percent above the national average and are growing far more quickly than average, and the trappings of wealth can be seen everywhere. 
 But the indicators of affluence have in turn led to a growing sense of unease among many valley longtimers who oscillate between a faith in what has been called the "long boom" and the knowledge that each of the valley's booms in the last half-century has inevitably been followed by a bust. Page A1.
 
G.O.P. Seeks Closer Ties to Valley
The Joint Economic Committee is conducting a three-day "High Tech Summit" on Capitol Hill in which the Republicans are trying to show that, compared with the Democrats, they have the capacity to be even better friends of William H. Gates and his competitors. C6.
 
Global Trading Takes Step Forward
The National Association of Securities Dealers took a big step toward the creation of an around-the-clock, global stock market with the announcement that it would join with Softbank to develop a version of its electronic Nasdaq Stock Market in Japan. Eventually, the two markets could together provide investors with the ability to trade for up to 21 hours a day, said Frank G. Zarb, chief executive of the N.A.S.D. C11.
 
Stocks Edge Up in Weak Trading
Stocks inched higher in thin trading in advance of the Consumer Price Index report, which will be released this morning. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 31.66 points, to 10,594.99. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 7.16 points, to 1,301.16, while the Nasdaq composite index rose 16.36 points, to 2,414.67. C14.
 
Politician Accused of Extortion
Foreign investors in the Far Eastern Shipping Company of Russia have accused a top politician of using extortion to try to wrest away their stakes in the concern, causing a shareholder rights scandal. C3.
 
Hong Kong Company Changes Name
Hong Kong's local telephone company, Hong Kong Telecommunications, said that it would change its name to Cable and Wireless HKT to tighten ties with its London-based parent company, Cable and Wireless. Linus Cheung, the chief executive of Hong Kong Telecom, said the new name was intended to convey the company's broader ambitions in Asia. C3.
 
Oracle Results Beat Expectations
Oracle reported fourth-quarter revenue and earnings that surpassed analysts' estimates and announced that it was laying off 325 employees to trim costs. C10.
 
Tensions Escalate Over Internet
In the latest sign of escalating tension between the Internet's new oversight board and Network Solutions, the company that controls the distribution and registration of Internet addresses, the board's interim chairwoman, Esther Dyson, said that the company was fostering unfounded criticism of her group. C11.

HEADLINE: Treatment Rooted in Culture;
Tying Drug and Alcohol Programs to Immigrants' Backgrounds

BYLINE: By SUSAN SACHS

 BODY:
For years, Mohammed Arif denied he had a drinking problem. He saw himself as an immigrant success story: he had mastered a new language, earned enough to support relatives back in his native Pakistan and fit right in when his fellow construction workers hit the bars at the end of the day.
"The thing about drinking was this false pride," Mr. Arif said, recalling the dark years when he failed to see how alcohol was corroding his new life. "There was all this finger-pointing in my family, and it would get me so mad. Why is everyone telling me I've got a drinking problem when it's me who's taking care of everybody?" 
 He eventually sought help, ricocheting from one detoxification program to another. It was not until he landed at Nav Nirmaan, the only New York City substance abuse treatment program run by and for immigrants from southern Asia, that he pulled himself and his family together.
"It made a big difference," said Mr. Arif, who now tells his story as a means of counseling other immigrants at the center, which is in Elmhurst, Queens. "When you're with people from your own background, your own culture, it's like there's no more curtain in front of your eyes."
Nav Nirmaan, which means "new beginning" in the Gujrathi language of western India, is at the vanguard of a growing trend in drug and alcohol treatment programs that not only provide counseling in the native language of immigrants, but also consider their particular cultural background and the traumas of the immigrant experience itself.
Immigrants arrive with specific cultural attitudes and family dynamics that influence how they respond to treatment. In a Russian family, for example, a teen-ager on drugs often listens more to a grandparent's guidance than a parent's. An Asian man arrested for drunken driving is more likely to let down his defenses and talk with a female therapist. And the therapy offered in mainstream drug abuse and alcoholism programs, counselors say, does not work for immigrants who fear or distrust authority figures, feel deep shame at revealing family problems to strangers and do not relate to their self-help jargon.
"Immigration and acculturation stress are very pronounced in immigrants," said Luis H. Zayas, a psychologist and professor of social work at Fordham University who has studied drinking patterns in Latin American immigrants. "But it's only recently that we have culturally adjusted treatment, as more clinicians become attuned to the impact of immigration."
Spanish-language social service groups proliferated in the mid-1980's, and there are now many substance-abuse centers with Spanish-speaking professional staff members. But there have been far fewer services adapted to the non-Hispanic immigrants who have poured into the New York City area in the last decade, bringing with them their own cultural idiosyncrasies and assumptions.
"Do we take treatments that exist and modify them, or do we have to create services that mirror the cultural aspects of the population we're treating?" Dr. Zayas said. "These are the questions we're asking. Not all of them are being answered, but they are being raised and addressed more and more."
Drug abuse prevention programs are getting similar attention. The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy has now recognized that an antidrug message aimed at American-born parents and their children may not make sense to immigrant families who do not even recognize drug slang.
Beginning next month, its new $185 million youth campaign will feature material in 11 languages tailored to Hispanic, Vietnamese, Korean and other cultures.
"The issue is not that they have greater drug use -- many of these groups have drug rates that are lower than whites," said Alan M. Levitt, the manager of the White House antidrug campaign. "It's just that for some of these audiences -- first generation immigrants, for example -- there is a whole different kind of information you have to supply."
That immigration is stressful, now and in the past, is obvious. For people who do not speak English, it means first and foremost the inability to communicate. Often, especially for those from the former Soviet Union and some Asians, it means a substantial loss of economic and social standing.
Female immigrants usually find work faster than the men, straining traditional family roles, because they are more willing to take low-status jobs. Children adjust to the new culture and learn English before their parents, giving them more independence and more adult-like responsibilities.
In short, psychologists say, what many people experience when they come to the United States is a tremendous sense of loss. Some immigrants try to cope by turning to drugs or alcohol.
"Usually, we hear the phrase 'I'm nobody here,' " said Helen V. Kagen, a social worker who created and runs a substance abuse program for Russian-speaking immigrants at the Educational Alliance in Manhattan. "People find themselves in a situation where they are not capable of doing anything."
She said the pressures are particularly debilitating to immigrants from the former Soviet Union, who are products of a culture that embraced drinking and a totalitarian system that undermined any sense of individuality.
Counselors who deal with Russian-speaking immigrants said they were also seeing serious drug use in youngsters, who experience both the exhilarating freedom and the burdens typical of immigrant children.
"The kids are under stress, even more than the adults," said Anna Snol, who counsels teen-agers in Brooklyn with her husband, Arkadiy, a former doctor in a Soviet prison camp for drug users. "They come here and everything is possible: sex freedom, work freedom, school freedom.
"They learn English and they know more than their parents. They begin to feel themselves heroes. They say to themselves, I see everybody smoking marijuana. Why not me?"
Problems arise when old habits combine with immigration stress, boredom and lack of knowledge about local laws.
"Drinking is so deeply rooted in the culture, especially with male identity," said Mina Chang, the director of the Asian American Mental Health Institute in Queens, who has created an alcohol treatment program for Korean immigrants. "The more you drink, the more you show you can control yourself and the more you are male."
She sees clients who are often working several jobs, who never drove a car back in Korea and do not understand what happens when they drive drunk, either in terms of the effect on their abilities or the risk of being arrested.
"I ask them, 'Why do you drink?' " Ms. Chang said, "and they say it's because they are bored."
For immigrants, as for anyone else, one family member's drinking problem can spawn other problems, like spouse and child abuse, and that is the behavior that often brings them forcibly into treatment.
"In our cultural makeup, the cry for help is the last stage," said Roy V. Tellis, the Indian-born executive director of Nav Nirmaan. "There's a lot of shame involved, and there's the isolation."
The typical Nav Nirmaan client, he said, is a man who lives in a cultural cocoon. He drinks as a form of socializing with other men from his home region, reads newspapers and watches television shows in his native language, and feels confusion and rage when his wife and Americanized children try to venture outside the tight circle of southern Asian culture.
"It is a male-dominated patriarchal society," Mr. Tellis said. "And the father says: I work hard, I put food on the table. So what if I take a few drinks?"
Understanding an immigrant's cultural background can also make a difference in finding the right treatment and the right tone.
"In Southeast Asian thinking, there is a respect for educated authority," Mr. Tellis said. "For them, there's no difference between a counselor, a therapist or a doctor. So if the therapist says, 'I want to see your wife,' they accept that."
Ms. Chang, who counsels Korean men with alcohol problems, said her clients open up and relax more when talking to a woman. "In their imagination, they are so much roughed up by the system and by the world that someone who appears to be soft helps them," she said.
An approach like that used in Alcoholics Anonymous, counselors said, rarely works with immigrants. People from the former Soviet Union, for example, often distrust not only their peers, but also people with authority.
"We are talking about an enormous level of resistance to outside persuasion, because all the messages, all the lies, in the totalitarian society were delivered by authority figures," said Dr. Kagen of the Educational Alliance.
And it is particularly difficult for those who lived in the Soviet system to admit they are alcoholics, a term that was reserved for those in the physically incapacitated late stages of the disease.
"In Russia, there is a difference between a drinker and an alcoholic," said Michael, one of Dr. Kagen's clients who spoke only on the condition that his last name not be published. "The drinker can stop. The alcoholic can't. So if you ask for help, it is admitting you're an alcoholic."
A 63-year-old former professor in Moscow, Michael started drinking heavily after he lost his first job in New York City and became homeless.
"When you sleep on a bench," he said, "it's not so bad when you drink, but it's impossible when you're sober."
Michael was sent to shelters, to hospitals and to detoxification programs. "They were nice and very professional," he recalled, "but all their experiences connect with American realities. Here, I don't have to explain a lot of things. They understand already."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DEPLOYMENT;
U.S. Offering Compromises On the Role of the Russians

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 15

 BODY:
In an effort to break an impasse over how Russian troops will operate in Kosovo, Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen is to suggest to his Russian counterpart that the troops be allotted an "area of responsibility" within one of the five established NATO sectors, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Cohen also plans to propose a command structure that he hopes will satisfy the Russians' demand that their troops not report directly to an allied commander, but will not violate NATO's insistence on a unified command for the entire security force, the officials said. 
 Mr. Cohen and his counterpart, Igor D. Sergeyev, are to meet in Helsinki on Wednesday.
Mr. Cohen is bringing two possible compromises on the sensitive issue.
The first is that the Russians report to a commander from a neutral, non-NATO country, like Sweden or Finland, an Administration official said. This commander would report to a more senior NATO officer.
The other possibility is that the Russians duplicate the pattern used in Bosnia, where Russian troops operate in the American sector and report to an American commander. He in turn reports to a Russian liaison officer at NATO headquarters.
The idea of involving Mr. Cohen and Mr. Sergeyev in the talks -- and moving the dispute away from diplomats -- came from the Russians, an Administration official said, after Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and the Russian Foreign Minister, Igor S. Ivanov, failed to come to a solution over the weekend.
But on the eve of the defense secretaries' talks, senior NATO military commanders are concerned that the political need to keep good relations with Russia will interfere with the allies' military need to insure control over the peacekeeping troops.
The alliance will not be represented during the talks. Instead the Secretary General, Javier Solana, and the alliance's top military commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, will be kept informed by telephone.
"Remember, this is an Administration that prides itself on constructive engagement with Russia," a senior NATO official said today. "These Administration officials do not wish to acknowledge that Russian high officials have been stringing them along all week."
But Kenneth H. Bacon, the Pentagon spokesman, said: "It doesn't seem to me we're sweeping this under the rug -- quite the contrary. We are spending a lot of time and high-level energy and so are the Russians on this issue. That's a sign we want a solution that's good for the Russians and for NATO."
The standoff has touched a raw nerve in the Administration, not only because the surprise arrival of Russian troops at the airport in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo, robbed NATO of a grand entry into Kosovo.
The underlying concern, Administration officials assert, is that while Russian involvement is welcome, it is welcome on grounds that do not subvert two Administration goals: that there be no partition of Kosovo and that the allies maintain a unified command of all security forces.
In arguing that the Russians take an "area of responsibility" and the proposed command structure, Mr. Cohen will not cross the "red lines" of partition and unified command, Administration officials said.
The "area of responsibility" for Russia -- most likely in the north and thus most likely in the French zone, where there is the largest concentration of Serbian civilians -- would have a concentration of Russian troops but allied forces would be able to come and go, an official said.
The session in Helsinki comes as President Clinton arrives here for the start of a six-day European trip, including a meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia on Sunday in Cologne, Germany. The two Presidents have spoken on the phone three times in three days, a rare number of back-to-back calls and a measure of the volatility of the issue.
The Administration would like to have the Russian role settled by Sunday so the men can publicly embrace a deal at a summit meeting of the seven major industrial nations and Russia.
The Russians showed no signs today of leaving the Pristina airport; indeed, a convoy of 11 vehicles is en route from Bosnia to re-supply the approximately 200 Russians in Pristina with fuel and food.
But NATO officials said they were encouraged that this time the Russians requested permission from the NATO commanders in Bosnia to leave their posts and take the supplies. Last week, when the convoy of Russians left Bosnia for Kosovo, they did so without informing the commanders in Bosnia.
The unexpected fuss over the Russian troops was in part a price to be paid for the help that Moscow provided Washington in getting President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia to accept a withdrawal from Kosovo, allied officials said.
It is still unclear how high the price will be, or which faction in the Russian political elite will be decisive in reacting to Secretary Cohen's proposals.
But the Russians have always made it clear that their main objective in Kosovo is to protect the Serbs, an Administration official said.
The largest concentration of Serbs is in the north, the area monitored by the French. The British military control a sector centered on Pristina, and the Americans are operating a zone in the southeast. Germany and Italy are moving into two other sectors, in the south and west.
Another interest for the Russians, according to officials, is to protect what is left of the the economic interests of the Serbs in Kosovo. The Trepca smelting complex, which includes the Stari Trg lead and zinc mines, is in northern Kosovo.
By giving the Russians an area of responsibility inside a NATO-led zone, Administration officials argue, their presence should not deter the return of Albanian refugees. Many have told officials of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees that they would not go back to their homes if Russian troops were patrolling where they lived.
But in any area where a lot of Serbs are still living, the return of Albanians is unlikely anyway, one Administration official said.
It is also not clear how big the "area" for Russia would be. A realistic number of Russian soldiers for Kosovo is in the vicinity of "several thousand," so the area would have to be "decent sized," the official said.

HEADLINE: Senate Passes Bill to Curb Lawsuits From Year 2000 Bug

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
After months of partisan squabbling, the Senate approved legislation today that would limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures.
But the 62-to-37 vote fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to override President Clinton's promised veto, as did the vote in the House on a similar measure passed earlier. That means further negotiations with the White House will be needed for the measure to become law, as is considered likely. 
 The bill would place a ceiling of $250,000 on the punitive damages that could be assessed against companies with fewer than 50 employees and give all companies 90 days to solve Year 2000 computer problems before they could be held liable.
Most important for the large and wealthy computer companies, the legislation specifies that all the companies responsible for a computer failure would share the legal liability and that no company could be assessed damages greater than its proportional responsibility for a breakdown. This would prevent a wealthy company like Microsoft that was marginally at fault from bearing all the damages when smaller companies with fewer resources were mostly responsible for a breakdown.
What is called the Y2K problem results from the reliance of some computers on programs that use only the last two digits of years. Those that are not properly updated could misinterpret the year 2000 as 1900, causing the computers and electronically controlled machinery to fail.
While the specific legislation involves computers and the year 2000, the underlying politics reflects the longstanding division between business interests, which are the largest financial supporters of Republicans in Congress, and trial lawyers, who are among the biggest Democratic donors.
Both parties are also fishing for political support from the ocean of money in high-technology companies. Democrats, torn by the conflicting claims of trial lawyers and cyberspace magnates, insisted today that legislation would soon be enacted to protect the computer companies from unnecessary litigation.
Business lobbies like the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers have spent millions lobbying and advertising for the legislation. The Chamber of Commerce made the issue the organization's biggest legislative priority of the year.
In addition, big technology companies like Intel and Compaq Computer, as well as small ones from Silicon Valley, are working for the measure. "I cannot tell you the depth of passion that the high-tech industry feels for the bill in California," said Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, one of 12 Democrats who joined 50 Republicans in voting for the bill. Voting against it were 4 Republicans and 33 Democrats.
Opposing it, along with the trial lawyers, were many organizations that advocate consumer rights like the Consumer Federation of America and Public Citizen.
In the final debate, both sides painted horrific pictures of what would happen if they did not get their way.
Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, the chief sponsor of the bill, reading from a prepared statement, said its purpose was to prevent "an avalanche of frivolous lawsuits" that could "stymie the economy."
"Litigation has become big business for a segment of the trial bar," he said. "That small group is eagerly anticipating the bonanza that Y2K problems present in litigation."
Without restraints, Senator McCain said, "the legal costs associated with Y2K will exceed that of asbestos, breast implants, tobacco and Superfund combined."
Leading the opponents was Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat of South Carolina who was a trial lawyer before going into politics and has long been the lawyers' champion in the Senate. "We're now going to legalize fraud," he asserted.
"This town loves lawyers -- office lawyers," said Senator Hollings, 77, one of the few remaining senators who always speaks extemporaneously, as old-timers did, rather than reading his floor speeches. But Republicans, he added, have made a political sport out of demonizing "working lawyers -- trial lawyers."
In fact, he said, in the United States business sets the standard for safe products, and the reason is fear of lawsuits over faulty products.
The House approved a similar bill last month, 236 to 190, also well shy of a two-thirds majority.
Now, representatives of the White House are likely to join negotiators from the Senate and House in the conference committee to work out the differences between the Senate and House versions of the legislation. A bill is likely to emerge before long, lawmakers said, that will satisfy most of President Clinton's objections.
These are among the President's objections:
*Hurdles intended to prevent frivolous lawsuits by companies would also apply to individuals, making it more difficult, for instance, for a person to collect legitimate damages if his house were burglarized after a computer problem caused his alarm system to fail.
*Class-action suits would be forced into Federal courts, where the rules are generally more favorable to defendants than in state courts.
*The proportional liability requirement could be burdensome to plaintiffs who could not afford multiple lawsuits.
After the vote, Senator McCain seemed prepared to make concessions. "We will do what we can to avoid a Presidential veto of this important legislation," he said.

HEADLINE: House Votes to Keep Limits on Number of Flights Into Kennedy and La Guardia

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 15

 BODY:
The House voted today to preserve limits on how many large commercial jets can fly into Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports every day, although, under the bill, small jets from small airports would fly in without restrictions beginning next March.
The bill would also begin phasing out the system of limits, called the "slot rule," at the only other airports that have them, O'Hare in Chicago and Reagan National in Washington. 
 But the significance of the provisions is uncertain, because immediately after the bill was passed, the Transportation Secretary, Rodney E. Slater, said that it should be vetoed because it authorizes too much spending and goes outside the normal budget process. And the Senate is working on a bill that would remove some slot rules faster, as a spur to airline competition.
The provisions for Kennedy and La Guardia were a compromise between legislators with districts near the airports who say they want to delay extra noise and congestion, and those from upstate New York and elsewhere who say they face monopoly ticket pricing so severe that it stunts their economic growth.
The chairman of the House Transportation Committee, Bud Shuster, Republican of Pennsylvania, helped arrange the compromise to round up extra votes for the bill, an authorization measure he is backing because it allows higher transportation spending. It calls for spending $57.4 billion over five years, or $14 billion more than in the Congressional budget resolution, which is Congress's overall spending plan.
Some House Republicans opposed the bill because it would authorize more money for transportation than they agreed to when they outlined the entire budget, and could reduce the amount available for a tax cut.
But Mr. Shuster is trying to spend extra money by reducing the accumulation of funds in dedicated trust funds, like ticket taxes in the aviation trust fund.
"It is morally wrong to say we're going to take that $14.3 billion that's in the Aviation Trust Fund, and use it, give it away, as part of a general tax cut," he said.
The bill would also allow airports to double the Passenger Facility Charge, now $3 per flight, to pay for airport improvements.
The slot-rule amendment passed on a voice vote. The underlying bill passed by a 316-to-110 vote.
While the significance of the vote on slot rules in New York was uncertain, members of the New York delegation were quick to claim it as a major victory.
"We buy some time here for our communities," said Gary L. Ackerman, a Queens Democrat, in an interview. "That's a critical thing, a quality of life issue." By 2007, he said, the Federal Aviation Administration may have a requirement on the books for quieter planes.
But members of Congress from upstate said that when all the slots are assigned to major airlines, they can prevent competitors from entering, thus strangling competition. Louise M. Slaughter, a Democrat of Rochester, said in debate that round-trip fare from there to Chicago was $1,267. "If you live in an area where air fares are reasonable, the people of Rochester, New York, are helping to subsidize that," she said.
Under an amendment backed by Mr. Shuster, jets of 70 seats and under could fly in without restrictions as of March 1 if they were coming from "a small hub or nonhub airport," which backers said would include Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and Albany. Bigger planes or planes from bigger airports would be limited until Jan. 1, 2007.
It was not clear, however, how many planes were in each category. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs the airports, said it could not predict.
Joseph Crowley, Democrat of Queens, another backer of the compromise, said that under the small-jet rule, La Guardia might get another dozen flights a day, and Kennedy somewhat fewer.
The Transportation Department said in a 1995 study that Kennedy would get 29 additional landings or takeoffs between 3 P.M. and midnight if slot rules were lifted, which would represent a 5 percent increase, and that La Guardia would get 70 additional landings or takeoffs between 7 A.M. and midnight, an increase of 6.9 percent.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
Jobless Rate Up to 4.7% In May;11-Month High

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The unemployment rate in New Jersey rose to 4.7 percent in May, the highest level in almost a year, state labor officials said yesterday.
The figures for May, the most recent available, show an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent over the rates for both March and April and mark the highest level of unemployment since last June, according to a study by the Labor Department. The state figures are also higher than the 4.5 percent national unemployment rate for May, the study found. 
 Although the unemployment rate rose, New Jersey employers continued to produce more jobs, adding 5,300 to payrolls in May, according to the study. If job growth continues at the same rate, 64,500 jobs will be created by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Year of the Donation

BYLINE: By MICHAEL POLLAK

 BODY:
Buoyed by the stock market and sustained economic growth, private donors gave a record $18.4 billion to American colleges and universities in the 1998 academic year, according to the Council for Aid to Education.
The annual increase of 13 percent, adjusted for inflation, far outstripped the 2.2 percent rise in spending, reports the council, a nonprofit subsidiary of the Rand Corporation. 
 Another factor elevating donors' generosity is their aging, David R. Morgan, the council's vice president for research and director of the study, said last week. As the elderly population grows, deferred giving as part of estate planning can become more attractive, he explained.
Not all institutions shared equally; Mr. Morgan noted that one-third of private liberal-arts colleges saw their gift income fall in 1998, although in some cases that was coming off a banner year in 1997. And private contributions to public colleges surveyed in the report fell last year, although Mr. Morgan added that the economy had allowed public higher education budgets to rise.
During good times, he said, colleges can become lulled into feeling that the record gifts will continue. "Of course, they never do," he said. MICHAEL POLLAK

HEADLINE: To Dine, Not Just Eat, for $10

BYLINE: By ERIC ASIMOV

 BODY:
TO visit El Fogon on a Saturday afternoon is to see East Harlem pass before your eyes. Politicians, musicians, writers and athletes descend on this tiny Puerto Rican restaurant just west of Third Avenue, exchanging jokes and gossip with Felipe Colon, the dapper co-owner, whose sole concession to the June heat is to shed his beret and ascot.
But it's not just the good talk that draws the crowd. It's the wonderful food, the fried yellow plantains stuffed with beef and green beans, or the tangy codfish stew with eggplant. For a huge serving of either dish, which come with plump red beans, rice and perhaps fried sweet plantains, El Fogon charges the absurdly low price of $6. 
 In these days of $5 coffees, $12 hamburgers and $35 bowls of soup, extraordinary yet inexpensive places like El Fogon can still be found in Manhattan, providing welcome relief from the outrageous prices that even many mediocre restaurants routinely charge. At this small core of restaurants, great food and a generous spirit take precedence over the bottom line. For no more than $10, these places will serve a great main course and often a side dish or two, usually in such quantity that you'll never wish for dessert. And unlike restaurants that are primarily concerned with getting you in and out, most of these places welcome you as if you were in their homes.
The people who run them are passionately serious about their food, as much as any four-star chef. Ask Habib Belkadi, the owner of Habib's Place in the East Village, how he makes what is possibly the best couscous in the city, and he'll offer a sermon worthy of a revival tent on the proper Moroccan way of steaming the grain.
Charles Gabriel, of Charles's Southern-Style Kitchen in Harlem, is perhaps not as eager to talk about his methods for making sensational fried chicken. But one look at the huge blackened iron skillets he uses, and one taste of his cooking, and you know you're in the presence of an artist.
How do they keep prices so low?
Real estate, for one thing. Most of these restaurants are in less prosperous neighborhoods, far off the expense account trail. You're not likely to see limos idling outside these places in Harlem, Clinton and the East Village, unless somebody outside the neighborhood has found out about the place and rushed in for a bite to remember.
Creature comforts are low (lawn furniture, rather than leather club chairs, plastic tablecloths, not linen), and staffing is minimal. Yet an overwhelming aura of pride and warmth makes these places enjoyable. You don't mind placing your own order at the counter of Krik Krak, a Haitian restaurant on the Upper West Side, for example, because the food will be great and plentiful. A wine list would be a surprise, and while you can bring your own bottle to most of them, you may have to bring your own corkscrew.
The cost of food is not high, because these are not luxury ingredients. At Los Dos Rancheros Mexicanos on Ninth Avenue, turning rough cuts of pork into savory tacos wrapped in soft corn tortillas requires a different sort of artistry than matching foie gras with Sauternes. Markups are low, which means these restaurants rely on a high volume of business, and since they are mostly neighborhood restaurants, many have become hangouts integral to the life of the community.
Mr. Belkadi is more than just the owner and chef of Habib's Place. He knows almost everybody who comes in, he accepts packages for neighbors and serves meals on credit if customers are short of money. He is a particular favorite of musicians and is a jazz lover himself. Habib's may be the only Middle Eastern restaurant in New York decorated with photographs of Louis Armstrong and Miles Davis, Thelonious Monk and Charlie Parker.
"You have to give the neighborhood something worthwhile," Mr. Colon of El Fogon said. "Sometimes, we like to give a little extra snack, offer some pickled green bananas or some baked sweet potatoes."
These 10 restaurants are not the only inexpensive gems in Manhattan. Far from it. You could have a meal of sublime roast pork at 69 Mott Street in Chinatown or a fabulous lunch from the curried chicken vendor who parks daily on 43d Street, east of Avenue of the Americas.
Even at some more expensive restaurants, you can find great deals for under $10, like the juicy Yucatan-style rotisserie chicken at Gabriela's on the Upper West Side, or the red-cooked pork with chestnuts at Grand Sichuan International in Chelsea. But these are my 10 favorites for under $10, all the time.
CHARLES'S SOUTHERN-STYLE KITCHEN , 2841 Frederick Douglass Boulevard (151st Street), (212) 926-4313.
Charles Gabriel produces amazing fried chicken with crisp, nutty crusts. But that is by no means the limit to his artistry. His salmon cakes are light, crisp and flavorful, his oxtails come in a wonderful oniony brown gravy and his pork ribs are sweet, tender and meaty. In typical Southern style, main courses each come with two sides, like smoky collard greens, yams as sweet as honey and crisp-edged macaroni and cheese. Mr. Gabriel's operation has two sections: a takeout counter and a dining room, where the all-you-can-eat buffet is a mere $8.69 nightly. If you hanker for a particular dish, it's best to call in advance; Mr. Gabriel does not make everything all the time.
CHEZ GNAGNA KOTY'S , 530 Ninth Avenue (39th Street), (212) 279-1755.
Gnagna Diene, the chef and owner of this friendly West African storefront, serves hearty, rich Senegalese stews in portions that are almost impossible to finish in one sitting. Chicken yassa ($8) is a terrific dish of grilled chicken in a piquant sauce of lemon, mustard and onions that is great spooned over the side of fluffy white rice. I also like the thiebu djen ($7.95), the Senegalese national dish better known as cheb, made with a firm white-fleshed fish stuffed with green onions and herbs and served over rice stained red by earthy palm oil, a West African staple. The rice and fish are then topped with cabbage, manioc, tomato and carrots. Ms. Diene and her assistants are warm and eager to answer questions.
EL FOGON , 83 East 111th Street, (212) 426-4844.
The Puerto Rican specialties are fabulous at this friendly neighborhood hangout. Felipe Colon, the co-owner, will hold you in an extended handshake as he gives you a guided tour of the photographs lining the walls: salsa greats, heroes of the Puerto Rican independence movement and compadres from Mr. Colon's beloved stickball games. His partner, Maria Elena Velez, who does the cooking, generally offers two main courses each day, and they are always interesting. Her corned beef is ground fine and served in a rich sauce with olives, squash, peppers and onions, enhancing its briny, smoky flavor, while her roasted pork is moist and garlicky and her chicken fricassee is a beautifully flavored stew. Each dish ($6) comes with white rice and plump red beans, and if for some reason you don't want the specials, she can always offer pork chops or steak. For an extra $1, try a remarkably light, flaky and crisp pastelillo, the Puerto Rican version of empanadas, stuffed with beef, pork or whatever inspired Ms. Velez that day.
FLOR'S KITCHEN , 149 First Avenue (Ninth Street), (212) 387-8949. Flor Villazan, the owner and chef of this little Venezuelan storefront in the East Village, traces many of her recipes back to her grandmother in Caracas, and the restaurant itself has an almost maternal glow to it. In the rear, you can sometimes see a woman shaping dough to make the smooth, crisp empanadas ($1.50 to $2.75), with stuffings like savory shredded beef or pureed chicken. Or you can see her scraping corn off a cob to make arepas ($2 to $3.25), corncakes with excellent stuffings like chicken and avocado salad, or cachapas ($4 to $4.50), loosely knit corn pancakes. Soups like chupe ($4), chicken broth with potatoes, hominy and herbs, are wonderful, as is grilled kingfish ($8.50) with rice and plantains. Almost everything tastes better with a liberal dose of guasacaca, a lively sauce of avocado, lemon juice and olive oil.
HABIB'S PLACE , 438 East Ninth Street, (212) 979-2243.
Sometimes, it seems, Habib Belkadi knows everybody who comes into his small restaurant in the East Village. But it's not what they do that is interesting, it's what Mr. Belkadi does. His couscous ($8.50) is twice-steamed, and has a rich, almost buttery flavor. Though each grain retains its integrity, it melds successfully into a whole. The generous servings come with plenty of steamed carrots, potatoes, onions and squash, and a few pieces of thoroughly tender, delicious lamb. For some spice, Mr. Belkadi offers a cup of his own fiery harissa. You can quench the flame with mint tea served in glasses. If Mr. Belkadi's sister is in town, he will feature her own Western desserts, like intensely rich chocolate walnut pie.
JOHN'S PIZZERIA , 278 Bleecker Street (Jones Street), (212) 243-1680.
What would a list of inexpensive New York restaurants be worth if it did not include a classic New York-style pizzeria? In Manhattan, John's Pizzeria is synonymous with great thin-crust pizza, which is generally cooked in intensely hot coal ovens, allowing it to achieve the signature smoky, charred crispness of the crust. With its famous warning -- "No Slices!" -- and its contentious waiters who fling the pies to the worn wood tables, John's is a notoriously grumpy place. Newer branches of John's are scattered around Manhattan and have sunnier dispositions, but their pizzas never quite achieve the flavor of the original, which is run by Pete Castellotti and Bob Vittoria, grand-nephews of the founder, John Sasso.
John's is not necessarily the best pizza in town, but it is the most consistently good and a marvel of economy. There is no excess sauce, just the right amount of mellow mozzarella and the whole is a perfect combination of flavor, texture and regard for tradition. A large pie costs $11 and feeds at least two.
KRIK KRAK , 844 Amsterdam Avenue (101st Street), (212) 222-3100.
This bright little storefront adorned with colorful Haitian art specializes in Haitian cuisine. Some dishes are served daily, like griot limbe ($7), small chunks of mellow pork marinated in garlic, lemon and spices, boiled and then fried until crisp. Other dishes are served occasionally, like poulet maison ($8), small pieces of chicken on the bone served in a fiercely hot sauce. Portions are stupendously large and come with equally large servings of hauntingly good rice and beans. I've always been teased by a listing for Haitian cake on the menu, but Nadine Arche, the owner, says it's always sold out. "Keep trying," she says.
LOS DOS RANCHEROS MEXICANOS , 507 Ninth Avenue (38th Street), (212) 868-7780.
The improvement of Mexican food in New York over the last 10 years is striking, and from the wonderful tacos to the deeply flavored main courses, the welcome difference is on display at this bright, airy restaurant in Clinton. Pipian con pollo ($7), tender pieces of chicken in a spicy green sauce made with tomatillos, chilies and toasted pumpkin seeds, is notable for the vivid flavors that seem to ricochet from one end of the mouth to the other, while pollo con mole poblano ($7) offers this more familiar sauce at its chocolatey, smoky best.
MAMA'S FOOD SHOP , 200 East Third Street (Avenue B), (212) 777-4425.
This little self-serve restaurant with just a few tables, offers homey American dishes that are the equivalent of white picket fences and shady elm trees. Savory meatloaf, roast chicken and fried chicken ($6 each) are all fine, but the vegetables (available with main courses at $5 a pint) are unbelievably good. Brussels sprouts are flavored with garlic and charred, while carrots and beets are sliced thin and roasted until they are bursting with sweetness. Sweet potatoes are caramelized and mashed potatoes are simply wonderful. Mama won't have to tell you twice to eat your vegetables. Desserts like fruit cobbler and banana cream pie are predictably gooey, gloppy and delicious.
PEPE VERDE TO GO , 559 Hudson Street (Perry Street), (212) 255-2221.
Though it's mostly a takeout operation, Pepe Verde to Go has a warm little dining room with brick walls, a wood floor and a worn old green couch. If you order by phone, you'll miss the aroma of fresh bread, olive oil and ripe tomatoes that permeates the little room, and the alluring sight of loaves stacked on shelves and peppers soaking in oil. Pastas are terrific and never oversauced, like fusilli with broccoli rape and crumbled fennel sausage, or ravioli with butter and herbs. Boneless sauteed chicken breasts that have been bathed in herbs and marinated in lemon come with a mammoth serving of rice mixed with roasted peppers, broccoli, mushrooms and tomato ($6.95). And Pepe's sandwiches, especially air-cured beef on focaccia with arugula and Parmesan ($5.95), are exceptional.

HEADLINE: Bush Draws Donations, And Conservatives' Fire

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., June 15

 BODY:
George W. Bush, the man in the monogrammed cowboy boots, reconnected tonight with the Yankee roots he so often plays down, at the end of a day on which his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination gave him his harshest taste yet of the political perils that lie along the campaign trail.
On the final stop of his first campaign swing, Mr. Bush was showered with $1.3 million at a dinner crowning him the adopted favorite son of Greenwich, which considers itself ground zero for Bushes although the candidate himself has never lived here. 
 The instant embrace by a crowd of more than 1,000, few of whom had ever met the Texas Governor but almost all of whom revere his parents, seemed fitting for a campaign so mysteriously turbocharged that even Mr. Bush himself claims not to understand the engine driving it.
But on Day 4 of his road show, conservative opponents rose up to criticize him for a comment he made in New Hampshire on Monday about prospective judicial appointees in a Bush administration. Mr. Bush said then that he would nominate judicial conservatives to the Federal courts but would not require them to share his views on specific issues, including abortion.
"There will be no litmus test," he said, "except for whether or not the judges will strictly interpret the Constitution."
In the past, Mr. Bush has voiced a general opposition to abortion while acknowledging the constitutional right to it found by the Supreme Court. He has also expressed a preference for changing people's minds on the issue rather than changing the law. The distinction appears to be an important part of Mr. Bush's strategy of projecting conservative values while trying not to alienate his party's moderate wing, including voters who support abortion rights.
In any event, his latest remarks on the matter brought fire from his closest challenger, Elizabeth Dole, who said through her spokesman, Ari Fleischer, that any Federal judge she appointed would have to share her "general philosophy" of opposition to abortion except in the cases of rape, incest or pregnancy that endangered a woman's life.
Two other rivals, Patrick J. Buchanan and Senator Robert C. Smith of New Hampshire, were much blunter.
"Governor Bush's response is grossly inadequate," Mr. Buchanan said from Manchester, N.H. "After 40 years of liberal judicial activism, we must have Supreme Court nominees dedicated to overturning the abomination called Roe v. Wade."
And Mr. Smith said Mr. Bush was trying to "have it both ways," posing as an abortion foe while allowing the possibility that his judicial nominees would hold a different view.
All this, along with similar criticism from other challengers, was a preview of the whiplash Mr. Bush can expect as he greets huge and largely unskeptical crowds at the same time that his rivals are firing at the same target -- him.
Here at the Hyatt Regency for the dinner tonight, some eager but tardy supporters turned blue bloods into scalpers, beseeching dinner organizers for the right to pay for the seats of people who had bought tickets but could not attend. "People were desperate," said a longtime family friend, Betsy Heminway
As much as Greenwich is money country, it is Bush country. Mr. Bush's grandfather, Prescott S. Bush, was Moderator of the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting before becoming a United States Senator from Connecticut. The Greenwich establishment has also fancied this the "favorite hometown" of the Governor's father, former President George Bush, even though he was born in Massachusetts, summered in Maine and kept his official address at a hotel in Houston.
From the time he campaigned for Governor in 1994, one of Mr. Bush's stock lines has been that the fundamental difference between the two George Bushes is that his father went to Country Day School in Greenwich, where people want to know who your parents are, and he went to Sam Houston Elementary School in Midland, Tex., where the children wanted to know if he could hit a ball.
In other tellings, he mentions San Jacinto Junior High in Midland. Either way, the tale does not take into account his later stops at Phillips Academy, Yale University and Harvard Business School. Although his campaign Web site finds space for the names of his dog and his three cats, it omits mention of his birthplace: New Haven, where his father was studying economics at Yale.
Tonight organizers acknowledged Mr. Bush's new life with a "Star of Texas" theme that added fruit salsa and lemon-sage sauce to the roast breast of chicken, and pink grapefruit to the green salad. Larger donors were listed on tonight's program as "Longhorns," while the next category down was "Lonestars."
People here professed not to be worried about what they, and the country, did not know of Mr. Bush and his positions on issues.
Asked about his foreign policy experience, Natalie T. Pray, a former diplomatic officer who has known the family for 30 years, gave him credit for "living in an area bordering Mexico."

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Gov. George W. The article also referred incorrectly to Mrs. Dole's attitude toward Mr. Bush's stance. Her spokesman said Mrs. Dole did not criticize Mr. Bush's position, but agreed with it.

HEADLINE: Boom Mind-Set Deeply Etched in Chip Capital

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., June 14

 BODY:
In Silicon Valley these are the days of miracles and wonder.
In the midst of the longest sustained boom in the nation's high-technology heartland, there is a palpable air of unreality that has come to color the outlook of the computer engineers, venture capitalists and software hackers who make up the valley's rank and file. 
 Wage rates in the region are about 60 percent above the national average and are growing far more quickly than average. Driven by the vast new wealth created by a wave of Internet-related start-up companies and the increasingly vast inflows of venture capital, good times have arrived in abundance and have stayed longer than ever before.
The good times have led so many valley workers to sports car showrooms that Raymond Lane, the president of Oracle, the giant data base company, complained recently that he could not find the new Porsche he wanted in Northern California; one local dealership had a six-month waiting list. (He ordered one from a Southern California dealer through the Internet.)
And in meetings at power breakfast spots here like Il Fornaio or Bucks in Woodside, executives shake their heads over stories such as the one about the home in a comfortable Palo Alto neighborhood that sold in April for $1 million more than the $2.4 million asking price.
But indicators like those have in turn led to a growing sense of unease among many valley longtimers who oscillate between a faith in what has been called the "long boom" and the knowledge that each of the valley's booms in the last half-century has inevitably been followed by a bust.
"The valley is now divided into two camps," said John Shoch, a partner at Alloy Ventures, a venture capital firm based in Palo Alto. "There are those people who are firmly inside a reality-distortion field and there are the rest of us who realize that this is going to end but who can't help going along for the ride."
The talk at the restaurants and sports clubs is frequently of the power of "Yahoo dollars" or "Weimar currencies," the fruits of a stock market that seems to have a bottomless appetite for Internet start-ups.
In fact, stock certificates have in many ways become the currency of the valley -- to such an extent that the Menlo Park Presbyterian Church receives more than 10 percent of its contributions in stock instead of money. And St. Joseph's, a Roman Catholic school in Atherton, devotes part of its endowment to its own venture capital fund.
While the surging stock values have allowed companies to attract the best and brightest employees and acquire other companies, there is also a growing perception that the excesses of the boom may have permanently undermined the valley's traditional no-nonsense, engineering-driven culture.
At the Palo Alto office of R. R. Donnelley, the printing company that publishes the documents known as red herrings that are a key part of the rite of going public, the valet parking, the pool table and the cigars in a thermidor occasion more than one raised eyebrow.
And such is the cash rattling around that an editor at the high-speed Internet service At Home recently purchased a new $625,000 home on his debit card.
Indeed, one consensus is that this unrivaled wealth creation has led to a stock market bubble that will certainly end, but nobody knows when or how. "There are some people who are making the case that the Internet has changed the law of physics," said Fred Hoar, a longtime Silicon Valley publicist. "But this is still a Newtonian world, and when you throw something up in this world, it's going to come down."
One thing that has made this boom so unusual is that it has gone on for so long. It has been more than six years since the valley has seen tough times, a fact that has caused memories here to grow hazy and has led some longtimers here to look for ways to cling to a past that seems increasingly distant.
Roger McNamee, a fund manager at Interval Partners in Menlo Park, has followed the valley's ups and downs since the beginning of the PC era. Now he points across a parking lot at his Toyota Camry, a modest car contrasting with the more typical turbo-charged luxury cars. He says he hangs onto the car as a touchstone to a world he is in danger of losing contact with.
Economists and researchers who are trying to understand the apparent disappearance of the valley's decades-old boom-and-bust cycle point to the convergence of two separate trends that set the economy into a sustained period of overdrive.
The semiconductor industry, long the bedrock of Silicon Valley, was just beginning to recover in 1993 when the demand for Internet communications gear started its rapid acceleration. Then in 1995 the Web economy kicked in, creating a remarkable business spiral.
Yet, although there have been booms before, this one has altered the valley in ways that many of the region's longtimers regret. And not without reason: only 38.2 percent of the valley's homes, for example, are affordable to those making the median income, compared with 65 percent nationally, according to the National Association of Home Builders.
"People who are inclined to make money fast are flocking here," said Garth Hardwood, an environmental researcher who grew up in Menlo Park but has moved to the coastal village of Pescadero to escape the valley scene. "It's hard to grasp what's going on -- it's so big and fast, and people are so aggressive."
Even within the industries that gave Silicon Valley its name, some lament what the boom mind-set has done to the valley's entrepreneurial culture. "It is a corrosive effect on the valley parallel to Wall Street in the mid-1980's," said Eric Schmidt, who was the chief technology officer at Sun Microsystems before decamping to Utah two years ago as president and chief executive of Novell.
"The level of expectation is well beyond the norm, even in Silicon Valley," he added. "People have very short attention spans when it comes to their careers. It is a youth phenomenon, a new generation of entrepreneurs who have not had to concentrate on building institutions that endure. Moreover, the venture industry has no longer had to build a long-term business. The corrosive effect is in creating a short-term versus long-term way of thinking."
And the wild successes of Stanford students like Jerry Yang of Yahoo or Joe Kraus of Excite have now made it common for graduates to choose Silicon Valley start-ups first.
"Today 75 percent of my students are joining emerging companies," said John Hennessey, the dean of the school of engineering at Stanford University.
That is a sharp turn from the days when the normal career meant joining an established high-technology company like Hewlett-Packard.
"You've got this funny psychology in which the reality and the unreality coexist," said Michael Borrus, a managing director at Petkovich & Partners, a San Francisco investment firm. "These kids really believe they're going to get wealthy and this youthful optimism is overriding the fact that maybe 9 out of 10 of them won't have an I.P.O. in their lifetime."
It is, however, an economy in which several waves of new workers have never known anything but explosive growth.
"In the semiconductor industry, we've known historically that every four years we get hit cross the lip," said Mr. Hoar, the publicist, who was an early employee at Fairchild Semiconductor, a pioneering chip maker. "There is one group that has seen it all and they have the scars. On the other hand you have this group that says, 'Every breath I take is golden.' " That latter view rankles some valley pioneers like Andrew Grove, a founder of Intel, and Steven P. Jobs, Apple Computer's co-founder.
Mr. Grove said that only recently had he begun to hear the phrase "exit strategy" -- do we want to be acquired or aim to go public? -- which is now routinely part of the planning for start-up ventures that have yet to sell their first product.
"This is not reality," Mr. Jobs said. When Apple started, he said, his role models were William Hewlett and David Packard, who set out to build an institution rather than an overnight gold mine.
And ignoring that reality will ultimately bring its own reckoning, Mr. Hoar said. "There is one chapter that keeps repeating itself in this valley, and that's Chapter 11," he said.

HEADLINE: Optimism About Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your June 13 Week in Review article on the reduction of unemployment rates among the various categories of the jobless neglects the impact of a rising imprisonment rate, which has more than doubled since 1985. Imprisonment for young minority-group males, who make up the bulk of the underclass, has increased nearly sixfold since the economic boom of the 1960's. If the 1.8 million people in American prisons and jails were counted, male unemployment would increase by two percentage points. 
 While you conclude with the sanguine view that young black men and single mothers respond well to tight labor markets, we must consider the other side of the business cycle: the psychological and material impact the next recession will have in dashed expectations and diminished welfare supports.
 
ROBERT P. WEISS
Plattsburgh, N.Y., June 14, 1999
The writer is a professor of sociology and criminal justice, State University of New York at Plattsburgh.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
A Sexy Economic Feud of No Interest to the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 16

 BODY:
In the northwest of Tokyo is an area of a dozen square blocks that wakes up at noon and parties till dawn, where gamblers and gangsters run rings around the police, where prostitutes and strippers undress for success, where curses and quarrels are in Chinese.
The area is Kabukicho, Japan's largest "entertainment zone," as it is politely called, and these days it is a reflection of Japan's troubles in competing with China and other Asian countries. 
 For the same reasons that Nissan and Hitachi are in trouble -- high labor costs and inflexible management -- the bars and brothels of Kabukicho are passing into Chinese hands. Even the yakuza, the Japanese gangsters who see themselves as the toughest businessmen, are being driven out by shrewder and more ruthless Chinese gangs.
"Our biggest problem is the rise of the Chinese mafia," one yakuza lamented. "The Chinese gangs are taking business from us in every area -- in prostitution, in gambling, in fencing stolen goods."
"The difference between us is that Japanese yakuza think of long-term business relationships, but the Chinese mafia thinks just of the short term," he added, in a remark strangely reminiscent of what Japanese industrialists often say. "Their only goal is money, money, money."
Still bickering and distrustful because of the legacy of World War II, Japan and China compete for markets and influence around Asia. In the last half-dozen years, Japanese have become increasingly nervous about the possibility of being sidelined by the behemoth next door. Many Chinese and Japanese alike believe that Japan's dikes are crumbling and that in another decade there will be several times as many Chinese in Japan as today -- for this is where the money is to be made.
"None of us like Japanese men," said a 25-year-old woman from Shanghai who has worked as a prostitute for a year. "They're so different from Chinese people. They're cold, and we're warm. I wouldn't choose them for pleasure."
"But this is business," she added.
She has overcome the language barrier and prospered because, like many of the immigrants, she is well educated and fiercely ambitious. She takes classes in Japanese and English during the day, then goes to work in the hostess bar and nearby "love hotels" from 9 P.M. to 5 A.M.
"It's tough, but I'm making a lot more money than I did in China," she said. "With the money, I hope I can go to the United States. I have some relatives in Florida, in a city called Miami."
Despite extremely strict immigration rules for Chinese, their numbers in Japan are surging. The official figure for Chinese in Japan has risen to 252,000, from 95,000 a decade ago, and this does not include the tens of thousands who are here illegally.
Many of the Chinese are engineers, software designers and investment bankers, but those immigrants tend to live scattered around Tokyo and attract little attention. It is the thousands of gangsters and prostitutes clustered in Kabukicho who have become notorious, inflaming anxieties and hostility toward Chinese.
Despite Kabukicho's image as a Chinese enclave where gangsters hack each other with cleavers, it seems by American standards a surprisingly tame and safe area. It is the kind of red-light district that would have emerged from the paintbrush of Norman Rockwell. The streets are well lighted and spotless, pimps sometimes wear neckties and clean-cut barkers ask men to step inside, "Please."
"In spite of everything, Kabukicho is still a Japanese place," said Mark Schreiber, an American in Tokyo who has taken an interest in Kabukicho for more than 30 years and is researching a book on the area. "In Southeast Asia, you might get knocked on the head, but you know it's not going to happen here -- because this is Japan."
Only one killing in Kabukicho has occurred so far this year -- one Chinese man stabbed another in a karaoke parlor -- and graffiti and muggings are almost unknown.
"If you're honest, nobody bothers you in Kabukicho," said a Shanghai restaurateur who was lured to Japan by the money and says she has no troubles with the gangs. "The hoods just feed off the hoods."
Japan has had red-light districts since ancient times, long before there were red lights. Prostitution was made illegal only in the 1950's, and even now it is regarded by many as less felonious than jaywalking.
Originally Kabukicho was a purely Japanese-run area, but in the 1980's, Taiwanese steadily took over the bars and clubs in the area and began to bring in young women from China as "hostesses." The Chinese invasion picked up speed in the 1990's, and Taiwanese or Chinese establishments replaced Japanese.
Now the grocery stores offer Shanghai newspapers and Chinese specialties like live eels. Some of Japan's best (and cheapest) Chinese restaurants are in Kabukicho, and families regularly stroll past the strip parlors for Cantonese noodles or Shanghai dumplings.
The collapse of the "bubble economy" hurt Japan's huge sex industry, and Government statistics say the number of sex-related businesses has fallen to 12,200, from 14,200 in 1989. But Chinese bars and brothels pay employees less and are able to thrive despite the recession.
"Here, if you work hard, you can make money and get ahead," said a 27-year-old doctor from Harbin, in northeastern China, a tall woman who has worked as a prostitute for only a few months. "The Japanese complain about unemployment, but there's good money to be made here. You just have to be willing to work hard and take the tough jobs."
"This is my way to get ahead in life," she added. "I'll live the rest of my life here. Or maybe I'll go to the States."
She and others said immigration restrictions are simply a minor inconvenience. Some of the women enter Japan as university students or after "marrying" a Japanese man in exchange for a few thousand dollars, while others sneak in by boat or use fake or stolen passports arranged by Chinese gangs.
Chinese in Kabukicho have also prospered by making a science of indulging their drunken Japanese customers.
"If a guest complains, immediately refund him his money," states Rule 29 on a four-page list that one Taiwan bar owner circulates among her prostitutes. "If any girl gets three complaints, she must immediately resign."
The list of rules, which is supposed to be confidential, stipulates that the women must smile and wear makeup at all times. Any woman caught chewing gum gets an $80 fine. Asking a customer for a tip is a firing offense, and a system of bonuses and penalties creates incentives for the prostitutes to fawn over the customers in the bar and in bed.
"When a customer sings karaoke, please, everyone clap," states Rule 37. "This is compulsory."
Chinese gangs prospered partly because they have been quicker than Japanese crooks to adopt high technology, like equipment to forge passports and make fake magnetic-strip cards that fool pachinko-game arcades and allow the user to play and win prizes. Chinese mobsters also won business by charging low prices --offering contract killings, for example, starting at just $2,700.
"The Chinese mafia is very, very good at business," the Japanese yakuza said. "Whether in fake magnetic cards or fencing stolen goods, they go about things with a real system. They are very serious about making money."
The yakuza complained that Chinese gangsters -- whom he referred to using a derogatory Japanese expression equivalent to "dogs" -- are multiplying wildly and are so brazen that they have taken to robbing Japanese mobsters at knifepoint or gunpoint.
"For Japanese yakuza, the most important thing is staying alive, and making money is second," the yakuza said. "But for the Chinese gangsters, the first thing is money. The second thing is money. And the third thing is money."
In December the police formed a special 101-member force to crack down on foreign crimes, especially in Kabukicho, but it seems to have made little headway.
"We know how the Japanese gangs work, because they've always been in Kabukicho," Taiichi Kawasaki, the head of the force, said in an interview in police headquarters. (The location of the Kabukicho office is a secret.) "But it's difficult to figure out how the foreign gangs work."
Few Chinese think that the crackdown on Kabukicho will succeed or will stem the tide of Chinese migrants, but even some of those engaged in shady businesses seem to welcome a greater police presence.
"The gangs are out of control," a Chinese pimp fretted as he stood on the street late one evening. "They kidnap anybody who's Chinese and hold them until they get money, and sometimes they hurt them. If it's a girl, they rape her and take her bank card and force her to tell the PIN number. She's usually not legal, so she can't go to the cops.
"The Chinese community is living in fear."

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Lessons of the Balkan War

 BODY:
As NATO peacekeepers move into Kosovo, they are finding grisly evidence of Serbian brutality in nearly every town. The signs of mass killing and wanton destruction in places like Djakovica, Vlastica and Cikatova ought to give pause to those who fault NATO for confronting Slobodan Milosevic. Though definitive judgments on the war await further developments in the Balkans and the work of future historians, it is not too soon to conclude that the air offensive was just, and more effective than its many critics expected. As an exercise in military and political coercion, the campaign achieved most of its aims with limited civilian casualties. Perhaps most important, it demonstrated that the United States and its allies can act decisively in defense of democratic principles and against ethnic violence in Europe. 
 This was the first military conflict since the end of the cold war fought primarily for humanitarian purposes. It probably will not be the last. Washington went to war in the Persian Gulf eight years ago because Iraqi aggression threatened America's economic welfare. The threat in Kosovo was different. Certainly, maintaining stability in Europe is essential to American security. But the immediate hazard in Kosovo was a demonic assault on the principles of a civilized society. NATO bombed Serbia for 78 days to combat lethal ethnic cleansing, to reverse the expulsion of more than a million ethnic Albanians from their homes and to prevent Slobodan Milosevic from terrorizing the Balkans.
That Washington and its European allies were willing to confront Mr. Milosevic is a powerful signal to other tyrants that the instigation of ethnic violence, even within their own borders, can reach a point that the world will not tolerate.
That does not mean the West can or should intervene whenever ethnic conflict erupts. As a practical matter, intervention should be confined to cases where violence is extreme and threatens to engulf neighboring nations and where democratic nations have the means, as in Kosovo, to respond. The combination will be rare outside Europe. When possible, such military actions should be conducted with the approval of the United Nations Security Council. They should not be initiated without the support of the American people and Congress.
Air power is not a panacea, but the war in Yugoslavia demonstrated that sustained aerial attack with precision munitions can erode resistance and bring retreat. Civilian casualties are inevitable, but NATO worked hard to avoid them. It is a tribute to American military technology and the skill of NATO pilots that in almost 10,000 bombing runs no allied airmen were lost and only two planes were downed. Americans should not count on such success in every conflict, but the bombardment of Serbia and Iraq suggests that most air defenses can be defeated by American weapons systems.
NATO, in its first war, showed surprising cohesion and determination. Much was made of Germany's opposition to a possible ground war, and Italy's and Greece's preference to end the bombing, but in the end the alliance did not crack as the air war was extended and intensified. This was due in considerable part to the steady leadership of President Clinton, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Jacques Chirac of France. Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, raised in the turmoil of earlier European conflicts, brought great conviction and passion to the fight against a new kind of chaos.
The mass graves, gutted buildings and torched farmhouses of Kosovo are not the inevitable product of military conflict. They are the result of a premeditated assault by Mr. Milosevic against ethnic Albanians. Enforcing the peace in Kosovo will be difficult, as the events of the last week have shown. Reconstruction will take months, and reconciliation may be impossible after so much bloodshed. But to have done nothing in the face of Mr. Milosevic's campaign of terror would have been unconscionable.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A case for forgivingthe world's biggest debtors their debts.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
TANZANIA, half of whose population is illiterate, spends a third of its budget on debt payments and spends four times more on debt than it does primary education. Niger, where life expectancy is only 47 years, spends more on debt payments than it does on health and education combined.
Lydia Williams of Oxfam America, a nonprofit organization, presented these and other chilling facts to the House Banking Committee on behalf of legislation that would have the United States unilaterally write off most of its loans to some of the world's poorest countries. 
 The bill, sponsored by the chairman, James A. Leach, Republican of Iowa, and John LaFalce, Democrat of New York, would also urge international financial institutions to offer the world's poorest countries more debt relief than now provided under a 1996 initiative of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. Additionally, the Leach-LaFalce plan would provide more relief than the proposal that President Clinton will promote when he meets this weekend in Cologne, Germany, with the heads of state from six industrialized powers and Russia.
But does the Leach-LaFalce bill, let alone the President's plan, go far enough? Not so, says Jeffrey Sachs, director of the Harvard Institute for International Development. He applauds Mr. Leach for pressing the Administration to seek more debt relief. But, he says, proposals that only partly wipe out the debt of the worst-off countries are inadequate. Many heavily indebted countries cannot afford to repay their loans, and, he said, "nobody with good sense would want them to."
Consider the 700 million people living in the 41 poorest, most indebted countries. They live on an average of about $4 a day; many survive on less than $1 a day. Yet these countries are expected to repay about $130 billion in loans from the I.M.F., World Bank and Western countries.
The fund and the bank began a program in 1996 to solve the problem, focusing on about two dozen countries for relief. Under the program, countries that undertake economic reforms overseen by the I.M.F. would -- after six years -- qualify for enough relief to reduce the ratio of their remaining debt to their export revenues to between 200 and 250 percent. Three years later, only three nations have qualified. Many economists say the program leaves crushing levels of debt in place.
The Leach-LaFalce plan would focus on more than 40 countries and reduce their debt payments to 10 percent of government revenues, probably about half the level of the President's proposal. Under the Leach-LaFalce plan, the United States would forgive almost all its $6 billion in loans to those nations and require them to spend the savings on education, health and other social needs.
President Clinton's plan would cut the debt of those countries by at least $70 billion beyond the current I.M.F.-World Bank program. It sets some of the same targets as the Leach-LaFalce bill does, and would also require the countries to use debt relief to strengthen health and education programs. The Administration does not think it can convince leaders from the other Western powers to do more than it has already proposed.
But Mr. Sachs argues that much more -- complete debt forgiveness -- is desperately needed for perhaps 25 of the 40 countries. And he provided Mr. Leach's committee with data to show that forgiveness is affordable.
He starts with the I.M.F. The 40 countries owe it about $8 billion. He notes that the fund owns gold worth, at market prices, more than $30 billion, but it carries the gold on its books at only about $5 billion. By recognizing the truth value of its gold reserves and selling modest amounts over time, Mr. Sachs suggests, the fund could write off loans to poor countries yet leave its balance sheet looking better than under current accounting rules.
He also shows that the World Bank could easily afford to write off unsubsidized loans. He concedes it would need extra money from rich nations to continue issuing as many subsidized loans. Yet, even if it is forced to curtail such lending, the most heavily indebted countries might not be worse off. For many, the combination of less debt and fewer loans would be better than the situation now, in which they wind up repaying the bank with one hand the money they borrow with the other.
Mr. Sachs estimates the cost to the United States of writing off loans would also be small. The $6 billion in loans to the worst-off countries is truly worth only about $600 million, he said, the most that the United States could expect to recover.
Beyond the numbers hovers the issue of justice. "Any attempt to collect debt payments from these countries," Representative Tom Campbell, Republican of California, said, "starts from the false premise that they owe the money. But why should a fisherman off the coast of Ghana set aside two extra fish to pay for lavish spending by former tyrants?"
In many cases, he said, "these loans were not loans at all," adding, "They were grants for political purposes like winning the cold war."
