HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Sector Spurs Nasdaq; Dow Rises by 189.96

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Paced by the technology sector, which propelled the Nasdaq market to its biggest-point gain on record, stock prices soared yesterday after the Government reported that consumer inflation nearly disappeared in May.
Investors had grown increasingly fearful that continued rapid economic growth might start to generate inflation, a concern shared by Federal Reserve policy makers who in May announced a bias toward raising short-term interest rates, if needed to keep prices in check. 
 Coming in contrast to expectations that the Consumer Price Index would rise by two-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department's report of no change was greeted with great relief. Some analysts who had feared Fed policy makers, at their meeting at the end of this month, would make the first of perhaps multiple rate increases suddenly expressed doubts that there will be any rises.
"That the C.P.I. was positive on all fronts got things going in earnest," said Joseph Battipaglia, investment policy chairman at Gruntal & Company, adding that a second factor in yesterday's market surge was the Oracle Corporation's surprisingly strong sales and profit report after the market closed on Tuesday.
Shares of Oracle, the biggest database software maker, jumped 71 3/16, to 32 15/16, as brokerage and bank issues joined computer-related stocks as the day's biggest gainers.
The Nasdaq composite index soared 103.16 points, or 4.27 percent, to 2,517.83, surpassing its 96.05-point jump on Feb. 11 to claim the record as the most points ever. The percentage rise was the biggest this year and the seventh biggest on record.
Other major gauges also posted substantial gains -- in contrast to their frequent tendency recently to move in opposite directions from the Nasdaq. The Dow Jones industrial average, with many blue-chip components sensitive to the business cycle, rose 189.96 points, or 1.79 percent, to close at 10,784.95. This put it ahead 17.46 percent for the year, but it was still 2.9 percent shy of its record of 11,107.19 reached May 13.
The Standard & Poor's 500 stock index, a benchmark for many professional money managers, climbed 29.25 points, or 2.25 percent, to finish at 1,330.41, putting it up 8.23 percent so far in 1999. The index had an unprecedented string of gains of more than 20 percent a year from 1995 through 1998.
Perhaps inspired by the United States performance, Mexico's chief stock index leaped 6.2 percent, while Brazil's Bovespa was 4.12 percent higher. European markets, which had less time to react to the C.P.I. and other Government reports here, finished with moderate gains.
The bond market advanced, driving interest rates down by as much as one-tenth of a point. Most analysts said they still expected the Federal Reserve to lift the overnight lending rate by one-quarter point, to 5 percent, on June 30.
"Everyone kind of expects that's still to come," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management. But, he said, the C.P.I. report at least "raises some doubt" about this. He noted, for example, that since early October bond yields have already risen 50 percent relative to commodity prices, which have actually retreated. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is to discuss monetary policy today before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
J. P. Morgan posted the biggest advance among the Dow 30, surging 6 points, to 134. American Express, up 4 15/16, to 124, was the third-biggest contributor. Financial stocks are particularly sensitive to interest-rate changes, which affect lending volume, spreads between borrowing and lending costs, holdings of derivatives and, in the case of brokers, trading activity that tends to shrink in weak markets.
Chase Manhattan climbed 5 1/4, to 80 3/8; Citigroup 2 5/16, to 46 1/16; Merrill Lynch 5 3/8, to 72 15/16; Charles Schwab 7 3/4, to 89 1/8, and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter 5 3/16, to 93 1/16.
In technology, I.B.M. climbed 4 13/16 to 120 11/16; Hewlett-Packard 4 5/16, to 90 3/4; America Online 11 3/4, to 106 1/2; Microsoft 3 5/16 to 81; Ebay 13 1/4, to 148 3/4, and Amazon.com 15 3/16, to 111 11/16. Despite downbeat comments by some analysts, Pfizer advanced 1 9/16, to 99 1/8, its second straight rise following six declines. Merck rose 1, to 68 5/8, in an otherwise restrained drug group.
Oil stocks and those of oil service companies were prominently weak, with Exxon, Mobil, Texaco, Phillips each down more than a point and Halliburton down 2 1/4 after hitting a 52-week high and Schlumberger down 2. Coca-Cola, which has identified production problems related to a health scare in Europe, steadied yesterday, closing at 63 7/8, up 1/8.

SECTION: Section A; Page 31; Column 2; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 603 words

HEADLINE: Stocks Till We Drop

BYLINE: By David Handelman; David Handelman is a contributing editor at TV Guide.

 BODY:
As I heard the final boarding call announced for my flight to Los Angeles, I saw a fellow passenger lingering at a free Internet-access computer, pecking feverishly at the keyboard. I peered over his shoulder: he was checking stock quotes.
"I manage a fund," he explained. "I usually hold stuff long term, but I still want to see how we're doing." 
 Seeing how you're doing on the stock market has become the overriding obsession of this decade. When I was a child, stocks were stored deep in safe-deposit boxes, to be removed for college tuition or distributed to heirs when the stockholder died. Today, I get a daily E-mail bulletin after the market closes that gives me ulcer-inducing news about my stocks rising and falling 5, 10, even 22 percent, huge changes that used to take a year or more.
If the recent push to keep the market open longer becomes reality, such bulletins will be rendered obsolete. But even if I stopped getting the bulletins, it would be impossible for me to avoid market reports. In this era of rapid buying and selling and wildly vacillating prices, every available space has been turned into a stock ticker, providing a continuous EKG to the nation's economic -- and, ultimately, mental -- health.
Now even when I'm getting my hair cut I am faced with scrolling prices. The television in my barbershop is set to CNN with the sound turned off, and the bottom of the screen -- formerly devoted to those old-fashioned national obsessions, sports and weather -- now often lists stock declines and gains.
When I try to get away from it all at Shea Stadium, my eyes drift to a sign above the left field bullpen that alternates between the type and speed of the last pitch thrown, and, yes, a stock ticker. (If you notice more botched fly balls than usual, it might be because a millionaire outfielder is peeking over his shoulder too often.)
In the Times Square area, already home to a Dow Jones zipper and a Morgan Stanley wraparound triple zipper, pedestrians will soon be treated to a Nasdaq ticker and a Reuters video sign featuring stock information.
When the fund manager and I boarded our plane, the in-flight telephone nestled in the seatback in front of me had a small LCD screen that included the day's Dow Jones Industrial Average. I had to stare at it the entire flight. Now the latest Palm Pilot gives Internet access, so people walking down the street talking on cell phones will be bumping into people walking down the street hunched over their E*Trade screens.
As the baby boom generation tries to rejigger the boundaries between work and family, extending the hours of the stock market might seem like a convenient solution. Like the 24-hour drugstore, restaurant, grocery or Internet shopping site, the full-time stock market, in theory, would allow people to deal with their investments at their leisure instead of forcing them to cut into their workday or quality time with their children.
But actually it promises the reverse: a life in which there isn't any down time, in which the tickers screaming across the sky, the computer screen, the television, the Palm Pilot, the stadium keep us all in a constant state of panic.
These ubiquitous tickers convey a false sense of security, as if we are all as up-to-the-minute as traders on the floor, a phone call away from striking it rich. But the truth is, if another crash comes, all these tickers will be as useless as the old men with signs saying "The End Is Near." And when the dust settles, maybe they can be used for something truly important -- like sports scores or weather forecasts.

HEADLINE: U.S. Backs a British-Dutch Plan To Partly Lift Sanctions on Iraq

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 16

 BODY:
The United States has decided to support a British and Dutch proposal that would partly lift oil sanctions on Iraq if Baghdad answers outstanding questions about its unconventional weapons programs and cooperates fully with a new group of United Nations arms inspectors.
The proposal is the latest effort by the 15-member Security Council to end the diplomatic deadlock that has prevailed since American and British planes struck Iraq last December to punish Baghdad for its lack of cooperation with arms inspectors. 
 The United Nations inspectors have not been permitted to return since then, leaving Council members increasingly concerned that Iraq may again be trying to acquire unconventional weapons.
The new proposal would create a new inspection agency for Iraq to insure that Baghdad is complying with its commitment to forswear unconventional weapons and that it answers outstanding questions about its past nuclear, biological and chemical weapons programs.
Only if Iraq cooperates would the oil embargo imposed after it invaded Kuwait in 1990 be partially suspended, the proposal states. Specifically, it would suspend sanctions on exports, but not imports. Russia, China, and France, by contrast, favor a total lifting of sanctions.
Moreover, the British-Dutch proposal would maintain "effective financial controls" on Iraqi revenues to insure that Iraq does not use the revenue to buy or make unconventional weapons. This means that the United Nations would still maintain an escrow account into which oil companies would pay for Iraqi oil.
Finally, the suspension would require Security Council approval every four months, which means that the United States could always veto the suspension if it concludes that Baghdad is cheating on its disarmament and other commitments.
Since the Council already permits Iraq to sell $5.26 billion in oil every six months -- currently more oil than it produces -- several diplomats dismissed the importance of the new proposal. But that revenue can only buy food and medicine under Council restrictions.
Yet some diplomats called it significant that the United States and Britain had for the first time endorsed a proposal partially suspending oil sanctions. A. Peter Burleigh, the American representative here, said that though Washington still had "some problems with some parts" of the proposal, "it is something the U.S. can support." The British draft, he said, would permit foreign companies to invest in expanding Iraq's oil infrastructure and permit unlimited exports if Iraq disarms and cooperates with inspectors.
The British and Dutch draft presents what one British diplomat called a "stepping stone" approach by which Baghdad, if it disarms, can eventually escape the sanctions regime. "It's a road map for the future," an American diplomat agreed.

HEADLINE: Embracing Clinton at Arm's Length, Gore Formally Begins Run for President

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: CARTHAGE, Tenn., June 16

 BODY:
Against a backdrop of small-town America, Vice President Al Gore took his first formal step out of President Clinton's shadow today, announcing his quest for the Presidency and pledging to "bring a new wave of fundamental change to this nation."
Part of that wave of change, he made clear both in his speech and in earlier remarks about Mr. Clinton's impeachment, would be a fresh moral start in the Oval Office. 
 "If you entrust me with the Presidency, I will marshal its authority, its resources and its moral leadership to fight for America's family," Mr. Gore said, with his own family, including his 87-year-old mother and his pregnant 25-year-old daughter, creating a tableau behind him. "I will take my own values of faith and family to the Presidency."
While trying to distance himself, however, Mr. Gore at the same time embraced all the issues that form the bedrock of Mr. Clinton's domestic agenda. He said he wanted to move more people off welfare, put more police on the streets, expand the Family and Medical Leave Act, make college more affordable, provide universal preschool, protect Social Security, help the elderly pay for prescription drugs and raise the minimum wage.
"We have to have schools that instill the values and character we need in the next generation," the Vice President said, saying that every school in America should be drug-free and gun-free.
"Families deserve refuge from a culture of violence and mayhem," he said in a speech marred for several minutes by protesters concerned that Mr. Gore was not doing enough to get AIDS drugs to Africa. "I will work to give parents the ability to protect their children from the marketing of cruelty and degradation."
Mr. Gore, 51, who spent his boyhood summers on a family farm near here, spoke before a crowd of about 5,000 in front of the bunting-draped, red brick Smith County courthouse, where he has declared his candidacy for various offices seven times before, first for Congress in 1976, then the Senate, and in 1987, for President.
In that announcement speech 12 years ago, he said he was restless, and he said so again today -- restless to enact legislation that at once expands Mr. Clinton's agenda but departs from his Presidency in being guided by moral constancy.
"It is our own lives we must master if we are to have the moral authority to guide our children," Mr. Gore said. "No policy proposal can change a culture that does not place family life at the top of our hierarchy of values, where it belongs."
If he was distancing himself from Mr. Clinton on the character issue, Mr. Gore also signaled to reporters earlier that he could begin to distance himself on policy matters as well. In fact he said he had had many such disagreements with Mr. Clinton in the past but preferred to debate them in private.
"There have been many of them," Mr. Gore told reporters on Tuesday in Tennessee.
He declined to reveal what they were, but he said: "Everything changes when I become a candidate because I'll be describing my own vision of the future. If that happens to be different in some respects from what the Administration wants, then I think that is understandable."
Picking up on a theme espoused by his wife, Tipper, he said he wanted health care plans to cover mental illness just as they cover physical illness. He said he wanted to make it easier for the elderly to receive health care in their own homes.
The thrust of Mr. Gore's speech was that by virtue of his experience, he was the candidate most prepared to lead the country and to maintain the record-breaking economic expansion of the last several years.
"I want to keep our prosperity going, and I know how to do it," he asserted, without elaboration but with one of several digs at Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican front-runner, and Mr. Bush's platform of "compassionate conservatism."
"I want to do it the right way," Mr. Gore said, "not by letting people fend for themselves, or hoping for crumbs of compassion, but by giving people the skills and knowledge to succeed in their own right."
Mr. Gore emphasized his experience in foreign policy in a world he called "complex and volatile," and said, "You deserve a leader who has been tested in it." He also spoke a few sentences in Spanish, directly competing with Mr. Bush, who is fluent in Spanish, in his appeal to Hispanic voters, who make up an important swing constituency.
And Mr. Gore made a straightforward declaration of support for abortion rights, with a veiled reference to Mr. Bush's more ambiguous comments. "Some try to duck the issue of choice," he said. "Not me."
He also set up a contrast with Mr. Bush over the issue of access to guns. "While some want to pass new protections for gun manufacturers, to shield them from lawsuits," Mr. Gore said, "I will work to get guns off the streets, out of the schools and away from children and criminals."
His speech, 25 minutes long, was notable for its specificity and its scant mention of Mr. Clinton. Mr. Gore said on Tuesday that his announcement speech was his chance to step out on his own, and he made that evident in his repeated emphasis on moral leadership today.
But he was most explicit when speaking to reporters the night before, when he landed in Tennessee. He talked about "that awful year we went through," referring to the yearlong impeachment ordeal.
"What was most upsetting about it," Mr. Gore told reporters, was "the wasted time."
"I'm even more anxious to move forward swiftly to make up for that waste of time," he went on. "We shouldn't have had to go through it."
While Mr. Gore has said -- and repeated tonight in a taped interview on the ABC News program "20/20" -- that Mr. Clinton's behavior was inexcusable, he had not said publicly before that he was upset over the time that was squandered. During the impeachment scandal, Mr. Gore stood loyally behind the President and declined to criticize him.
Mr. Clinton, who left today for a weeklong trip to Europe, called Mr. Gore this morning to wish him luck before the speech and called him again after he saw it on television. Mr. Gore was out shaking hands and Mr. Clinton left a message, saying "Great job, Al."
After his announcement here, Mr. Gore went on to Iowa and New Hampshire. He plans to visit Wall Street on Thursday and hold a fund-raising reception before continuing his announcement tour in Los Angeles, Seattle and Philadelphia.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: PRISTINA;
With Armed Serbs Still on the Scene, Albanians in Kosovo's Capital Are Wary but Hopeful

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: PRISTINA, Kosovo, June 16

 BODY:
The arrival of NATO-led peacekeeping forces has brought Kosovo's Albanians to city streets and rural lanes to celebrate, shouting "NATO!" and tossing flowers and giving victory signs.
But not in Pristina, the Kosovo capital. Here the mood is tentative, wary and restrained. 
 While NATO forces are patrolling the streets in jeeps and armored personnel carriers and now, sometimes, on foot, some Serbian police and military personnel remain in Pristina.
"There are a lot of Serbs still in Pristina," said Gzim Gercari, 33. "And there are many armed and angry Serbs, who have been drinking a lot."
Mr. Gercari was one of many Albanians who remained in Pristina throughout the war. But the last three days, he said, have been as bad as anything he experienced.
He lives near a headquarters for the Serbian militarized police. As they have prepared to leave Pristina, under the terms of the peace agreement signed by President Slobodan Milosevic, some of the Serbs have been looting and smashing houses, and NATO has not intervened.
"They ordered people out of houses and smashed windows and demolished doors and stole what they wanted," he said. "They started to burn my apartment in Suncani Breg," a neighborhood of Pristina, but a cousin put out the fire.
This morning, the police were finally gone, Mr. Gercari said. But he worries still about anxious and armed Serbian civilians, some of whom have been kidnapped by the rebel Kosovo Liberation Army.
On Tuesday, two Albanians were shot after getting into an argument with some armed Serbian civilians. Early this morning, at the downtown Brooklyn Bar, some very sentimental and very drunk Serbian soldiers, in their fatigues, staggered into the street firing their weapons into the air, as a goodbye to Kosovo. As they swayed and dropped the barrels of their Kalashnikovs, passers-by hit the ground.
But after months of a heavy military presence and incessant NATO bombing, when many Albanians were pushed out of Pristina or fled, there is a new lightness nonetheless.
The streets are getting jammed again in Pristina, with the Corzo cafe downtown now so crowded it is hard to find a seat, even though there has been no water for the last two days. With espresso not an option, people drink juice or mineral water or iced instant coffee with some ice cream.
Albanians are returning home, from the camps in Macedonia and Albania, but also from the mountains. In a poor Albanian section of Pristina, near a new headquarters of the Kosovo Liberation Army and an aid distribution center, Halil Dirbranaj, 41, pulled up today in his tractor and a trailer stuffed with seven members of his family.
"The Yugoslav Army threw me out of my house," he said, "so we went to the mountains." That was near a village called Kriljevo, some 15 miles east of Pristina. They spent most of the time in the open, "with no protection from anyone," he said. "We were just hiding behind the rocks, open to the rain." But even with his elderly mother lying pale in the trailer, as one of his daughters held an umbrella to shield her from the sun, Mr. Dirbranaj said he was afraid to go into his house, fearing Serbian booby traps.
Fatos, an Albanian of 24, arrived from Macedonia two days ago to find the lock on his building had been changed, so he could not get to his apartment. Hydajet, another Albanian, came home to a burned and looted apartment. But others were luckier, finding everything as they had left it, sometimes because of the intervention of Serbian neighbors.
People are poor and hurting, but there are the beginnings of what will be a hot economy designed to service the foreigners pouring into Kosovo. "It's going to be like Bosnia or Cambodia," an experienced United Nations official said, a little sadly. "There will be almost as many foreigners trying to help as those who need it. And they will need restaurants and bars and brothels, and this place will never be the same."
While there is no running water, making the atmosphere rather ripe in the summer heat, there is electricity. And just a few days ago, the main Yugoslav cell-phone company, Mobtel, turned its transmitters on again in Pristina. There had been no telephone service during the war. With travel restricted to Kosovo, the province was almost entirely isolated.
While most people assumed NATO had bombed the transmitters, it is now understood that Belgrade did not want Kosovo reached by telephone. It is also suggested by knowledgeable officials that given the electricity problems, Mobtel also feared that it would be unable to keep its computers going to charge customers for their calls.
At the misnamed Grand Hotel, stuffed now with journalists and the first influx of aid workers, Albanians offer their services as translators, drivers, money changers and landlords.
There is a desperate need for restaurants for all these foreigners and their money, but many of the restaurants that existed before the war were owned by Albanians, and most have been burned or looted. Many of their owners also remain abroad, as refugees.
The owners of the Corzo, Muslims from the Gora region between Albania and Macedonia, are contemplating opening a new restaurant, as are their waiters. But it is still too dangerous, they say, wanting another week or so to see how the peacekeepers function and how the Serbs react to the withdrawal of their military and police forces.
Of course, many Serbs are leaving Pristina, too, terrified that the insurgents of the Kosovo Liberation Army will show up at their houses to exact a generalized revenge. On many streets, one sees Serbs packing their cars and trucks. Some say they are going for good; others say they hope to be back. But their hope seems to lack conviction.
Rumors sweep the Serbian population of atrocities against them, of kidnappings and killings. Some of the rumors, unfortunately, turn out to be true. A missing poster has gone up for Ivan Celic, a 40-year-old mechanical engineer, missing since June 14, believed kidnapped as he was driving his Volkswagen Golf in the mostly Albanian area of Suncani Breg. He has four children. "Any information," the poster says, referring to the peacekeeping mission, "pass to the civilian authorities and the KFOR mission."
Today in Kosovo Polje, a British officer met several hundred local Serbs to urge them to remain. "If you are threatened, tell us about it, and we will do our best to protect you," he said from the steps of a Serbian Orthodox Church. "You have to consider the future of your country. If you want it to have a future, be brave."
But Kosovo Polje is heavily Serbian, and many always intended to stay. Dejan Jovanovic, 24, said many of the men would remain, "but the women and children will go," at least as a temporary precaution.
In Pristina, the Kosovo Liberation Army has proudly opened two new offices. One is in a school, where young women in white T-shirts and black overalls guard the gates.
The other, the headquarters, was opened a few days ago in a large house offered by an Albanian businessman. Uniformed, armed soldiers stand guard and pose for photographs, while another soldier mans a sniper position looking down the road.
A British liaison officer from the Irish Guards entered to discuss security, he said. "It's really about getting them to behave," he said crisply. Asked what it meant to "demilitarize" the Kosovo Liberation Army, as called for under the peace agreement, he shrugged. "Just now, it's important that they behave," he said. "They're a little confused, too, looking for instructions. We'll get around to the rest in time."
Inside, Salih Mustafa, a 28-year-old history student who was the commander of the guerrilla operations inside Pristina during the war, talked coolly of having "liquidated" Serbian paramilitaries and secret policemen and sabotaging buildings in what he called Operation Hawk.
He refused to say how many men were under his command, but he had a presence that lent credence to his account, even if the actions of his men hardly turned the tide of the war.
But such operations were all he could do, given the shortage of weapons, especially heavy weapons, he said.
The army is grateful to NATO but remains entirely committed to independence, Mr. Mustafa said. "This war is a step forward, but we still have work to do before independence. This NATO plan doesn't solve the Albanian question, and it just restores the status quo in this fake peace."
NATO and the West have different interests, he said, adding: "That's why I call it a fake peace. Real peace will be when Kosovo gets its independence."
NATO's effort to demilitarize the insurgents is a form of insult to the soldiers "who fought to defend their homes, honor and country, while the criminals of the paramilitary Serb forces burned and looted houses, killed and raped, and they are put in an equal position," he said. "They can just take off their uniform and weapon and go wherever they want in Pristina."
The NATO efforts will just be "an interlude in the struggle," Mr. Mustafa said. "Until we get the liberation of all Albanian lands, there will be fighting in the Balkans."

HEADLINE: Korean Clash May Ruin U.S. Reconciliation Bid

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Two weeks before North Korean and South Korean gunboats opened fire on each other in disputed waters, former Defense Secretary William J. Perry spent three days in the North trying to get a government known for its paranoia to build a relationship with Washington.
During 15 hours of talks, Mr. Perry laid out a plan in which President Clinton would lift economic sanctions gradually in return for commitments from North Korea to stop testing missiles and selling missile technology, and to expand a freeze on nuclear-weapons development. 
 The North Koreans were suspicious, a member of Mr. Perry's party said, suspecting a trap.
But they were also intrigued, and ended the visit with a banquet and floor show in which performers entertained Mr. Perry with a mix of Korean revolutionary songs and American tunes, including "Oh! Susanna."
Now, only two weeks later, Mr. Perry's detailed proposals for reconciliation are already in deep trouble -- perhaps a casualty of the outbreak of shooting this week that resulted in the deaths of at least 20 North Koreans.
"It's very damaging," said Donald Gregg, a former American Ambassador to South Korea who heads the Korea Society in New York. "And like everything the North Koreans do, no one is entirely sure why they did it."
Republicans in Congress were suspicious of Mr. Perry's initiative even before the confrontation, and several emerged from a classified briefing last week noting that the North had indicated no willingness to give up its ballistic missile program.
Some hardliners, led by Representative Benjamin A. Gilman of New York, had already introduced legislation that would tie Mr. Clinton's hands, preventing him from lifting sanctions and blocking further aid to the North until it makes major concessions.
"This latest incident fit the standard model for North Korean negotiations," Mr. Gilman said today in an interview. "They create a crisis. Then they demand concessions in return for backing down. The Perry report, if and when we get it, should take into account this kind of brinksmanship."
It is unclear when Mr. Perry will formally issue a report, or in what form. While President Clinton and the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, have reportedly approved the strategy, the White House played down Mr. Perry's mission and, so far, has offered no public support for his proposals. In fact, Administration officials have refused to discuss his overtures to the North in public, saying they fear that would undercut delicate diplomacy with a volatile regime.
Even within the Clinton Administration, there is growing skepticism that the North Koreans will take the deal, or that Congress would go along.
"Every time the North Koreans do something defiant or something stupid, all it does is harden the view that they could never be trusted to execute whatever deal we strike," a senior Administration official involved in Korea policy said this week. "If you think 'engagement' is a hard sell with China, try it with North Korea."
This week's gun battle on the seas off the Korean Peninsula was particularly unsettling to the Administration because it clearly was more than a confrontation among hot-headed captains. It was preceded by a standoff that lasted several days, as South Korean ships tried to push the North's vessels, chiefly fishing craft seeking crabs, back into Northern territory.
"There was plenty of time for North Korea's military leadership to tell them to back off," said an official familiar with the intelligence gathered from American and South Korean aircraft over the area. "But clearly they wanted to send a message that they were not about to back down."
After the sinking of the North Korean torpedo boat, however, Pyongyang did back off, clearly calculating that they were outgunned.
Equally interesting, the South Koreans backed off as well, and President Kim Dae Jung, who arrives here next month for his second visit to Washington, said he would not retreat from his "sunshine policy" of expanded contacts with the North Koreans.
"It was a sign of a growing maturity on the part of South Korea," said Mr. Gregg, whose long career with Korea included a tour as the Central Intelligence Agency's station chief there during other moments of tension with North Korea. "There is a confidence among the South Koreans we did not used to see."
That confidence, however, is no assurance that Mr. Kim's policy or Mr. Perry's congruent initiative will sell.
The Perry effort hinges on what a State Department official today called "a broad vision of what a new relationship with North Korea could look like."
At its core would be a series of commitments by the North, each verifiable by inspections or American spy satellites, to halt several projects that North Korean leaders have said are important to their national or economic security.
First would be an end to the testing of missiles, including the medium-range missile that was launched over Japan last summer. Pyongyang would also have to end its export of missile technology to the Middle East and Pakistan, one of its few sources of hard currency.
It would also have to expand on the 1994 nuclear accord, allowing broader inspections to dispel fears that it has simply moved its nuclear-weapons projects to sites outside Yongbyon, the frozen nuclear complex where that research was located.
"We didn't go there with the idea that they would say, 'Great idea. Where do we sign up?' " said the State Department official. "But they also listened very intently, asked a lot of questions, took copious notes."
Most of Mr. Perry's interactions were with Kang Sok Ju, the country's First Vice Foreign Minister, who is regarded by American intelligence officials as the civilian official closest to President Kim Jong Il, the son of the North's late founder, Kim Il Sung. President Kim declined to meet with Mr. Perry, though American officials believe that he read a letter from President Clinton that the American delegation carried. The contents have not been made public.
Mr. Perry also met with Lieut. Gen. Li Yong Chol, the director of the national defense commission. Presumably, General Li was in the chain of command as North Korean forces engaged in Tuesday's firefight with the South.

HEADLINE: Bradley Takes On California, One on One

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, June 16

 BODY:
When the tall man talks, people tend to listen. They have to, because he speaks so softly.
So the other day, in a room overlooking San Francisco Bay, maybe three dozen environmentalists listened closely as Bill Bradley led them through a discussion that began with the wind in the sycamore trees in his home town on the Mississippi River in Crystal City, Mo., then threaded its way through the thickets of California's water wars and finally, almost by chance, to the point.
"For me, there's only one reason to run for President of the United States," Mr. Bradley told a listener who asked him why he was doing it. "That's because you think your leadership could improve the quality of life for millions of Americans. I look at my situation and think ability matches the moment."
That understated answer distills the way Mr. Bradley has campaigned up and down California this week: personally, peacefully, almost obliquely. From a storefront black church in South-Central Los Angeles to a mentoring program for minority teen-agers and new immigrants in Sacramento, from an earnest discussion with underpaid home-care workers to a playful pass through the Farmer's Market in Hollywood, where he made like Meadowlark Lemon with a couple of a cantaloupes, his style has been the same: he talks quietly about the issues that drive him, like race relations or the environment, and lets everything else -- including his candidacy -- speak for itself. On this road trip, there is no set stump speech, no repeated slogan, few snappy sound-bites. There is just a tall man talking.
"I wanted in this trip, notwithstanding what the pundits have said, to show that you can campaign in California person-to-person and succeed," Mr. Bradley said of his nine-day swing through the Golden State.
The trip is a bit of creative counter-programming that has kept his underdog presence on the radar screen as Vice President Al Gore, his rival for the Democratic nomination, officially kicks off his candidacy today in Tennessee. "I want to show respect for the voters of California," he said, "just like I show respect for the voters of Iowa or New Hampshire."
Almost no one thinks that retail campaigning is the way to win in California, where politics sometimes seems to exist only in paid television advertising and the disembodied debates of direct mail. But as he finally embraces the quest for the Presidency that he has considered and rejected so many times before, Bill Bradley is not -- ostentatiously not -- a candidate who buys what everyone else thinks. And for better or worse, as he lopes along, trailing Mr. Gore in California by worse than 2 to 1 in the latest Los Angeles Times Poll, Mr. Bradley, more than ever, seems to have a sense of where he is.
There is still the lanky 6-foot-5-inch grace that marked his years as a basketball star for Princeton and the New York Knicks, and the cool, cerebral blend of diffidence and directness that suffused his 18 years in the Senate from New Jersey. But two and a half years after Mr. Bradley left Washington for writing and teaching, there is something else as well: a kind of Zenlike calm and self-acceptance that makes him seem looser, easier, lighter than he did on Capitol Hill, when he tended to come forth periodically with carefully wrought pronouncements on topics like trade, taxes or race but otherwise often stayed above the fray.
"I developed a real peace of mind about what I'm doing now," Mr. Bradley said in an interview between campaign stops on Tuesday. "I have a clear sense of why I want to do it, what I want to do and how I want to do it. I'm just being myself."
Mr. Bradley is not running the anarchic, outsider campaign of a Jerry Brown or Ross Perot. There are plenty of traditional campaign-style events, including a Beverly Hills fund-raiser to be headed by the entertainment mogul Barry Diller on Thursday and the structured sessions of empathetic discussion with diverse constituent groups that President Clinton has made de rigueur in contemporary politics. He acknowledges that television advertising will be important and today made a traditional policy speech on child poverty, reading from a prepared text, at Para Los Ninos, a child-care center on Skid Row downtown.
"After seven years of the first two-term Democratic administration since Franklin Roosevelt, the percentage of American children living in poverty has barely changed," Mr. Bradley said, calling for greater parental involvement and improved day-care standards, but omitting the most specific proposals in the news release circulated by his staff: raising the minimum wage and expanding the Federal earned-income tax credit for working families.
All the same, he is striving to do things differently. He has yet to take a poll, for example, and is "not trying to be some kind of political mannequin," as he told a Los Angeles television reporter. Or, as he told environmentalists in San Francisco, he hopes to construct, "a narrative and some coherence to all these things that are occurring in people's lives."
"I think the way politics are done today, too often you try to be somebody else," Mr. Bradley said in an interview. "And I think that quite frankly the press is bored with this as much as the politician is bored with it. And I think the idea of my relating to the press, meaning standing before some backdrop and saying three or four poll tested phrases in an attempt to manipulate you only makes you angrier and therefore your job is to destroy, or as you would say, unmask, the candidate, and basically on both sides of the equation it's boring. So my view is my job is to make something happen with people out there."
How well that approach will work, and how well Mr. Bradley can execute it, remains to be seen. He says his top priorities will be to "be a good steward of a good economy," protect the environment, insure that "every child in America has a chance to realize his or her potential," and to overhaul campaign finance laws, but those are not vastly different from Mr. Gore's. And although Mr. Bradley has criticized Mr. Gore as relying on small-bore ideas, some of his own proposals are not exactly giant, like the notion of creating "15-month houses" where unwed teen-age mothers could live under supervision in the final months of pregnancy and the first months of their child's life to learn parenting skills.
For his part, as he joked with political reporters in Sacramento on Monday, Mr. Bradley took heart from the underdog performance of his old team. "I think," he said dryly, "the Knicks are proving that speed and quickness are more important than bulk."

HEADLINE: North Korea Suspends Contact With South

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, June 16

 BODY:
North Korea said today that it was suspending contacts with the South, a day after South Korean vessels sank one of its warships in the Yellow Sea.
The suspension appeared to be retaliation for the sinking of the ship and the deaths of all 17 crew members. 
 More than 20 North Korean sailors may have died in a high-seas gun battle that lasted less than 30 minutes early Tuesday morning.
The North Korean suspension immediately endangered talks between North and South Korea set for Monday in Beijing, although North Korea did not specifically mention the meeting. It also deals a blow to President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, who has singled out closer ties with the North as a major pillar of his presidency. An aide to Mr. Kim declined to comment today.
But the suspension appeared to be a careful calculation not to destroy relations between the countries. In particular, North Korea is receiving lucrative benefits from recent business deals that it has struck with the South.
So the North seems to be walking a delicate line, trying to preserve the advantages of economic ties as it tries to retaliate for military losses and negotiate for political advantage. That may explain why it seems to be restricting visits to only Pyongyang, the capital. It appears that other regions of North Korea are not affected. But the declaration today was vague on that point.
A statement carried by the official North Korean news agency criticized the South for "bringing the situation of the country to the brink of war."
"We solemnly declare that we will restrict or suspend Pyongyang visits of South Koreans and their contacts with us for the time being in view of the serious situation created by the South Korean authorities," the statement said.
Patrol boats from the two sides circled today near the disputed waters in the Yellow Sea. North Korean boats did not try to cross the line, and there was no exchange of fire.
The United States said that it was dispatching additional forces to South Korea, and in particular it said that an Aegis-class cruiser, the Vincennes, would arrive soon, as well as electronic warfare aircraft and antisubmarine aircraft.
The confrontation began on June 7, when North Korean naval vessels escorted fishing boats south of the "northern limit line," the customary demarcation line that separates the seas of the two Koreas. The North does not recognize the line, but it had never challenged it so openly.
The North had periodically sent ships south of the line, but they ordinarily retreated when ordered back by the South. This time, however, the North Korean vessels refused to back off, and on Friday, South Korean vessels began to ram the North Korean boats.
On Tuesday, tensions exploded in gunfire. South Korean patrol boats sank a North Korean torpedo ship, killing all 17 aboard, and damaged at least five other North Korean vessels.
Two South Korean patrol boats were damaged, and seven South Korean sailors were slightly injured. South Korea put its entire armed forces on the combat level of alert, which is a state of emergency.
Although the United States Command in South Korea is closely watching the developments, it has not put its 37,000 troops on alert.
The disputed waters are rich in crabs. North Korea, suffering widespread famine, particularly values crabs, because it can export them for hard currency.
The two Koreas are still technically at war -- the Korean War ended in 1953 without a peace treaty -- and there are few visits between the sides. Still, several thousand South Koreans are in North Korea at any one time, many in various regions. One increasingly popular site is Mount Kumgang, a scenic spot where tours for South Koreans are run by the Hyundai Corporation, the largest chaebol in South Korea.
The tourism deal that the North struck with Hyundai is extremely attractive to North Korea, particularly because it has been receiving millions of dollars each month.

HEADLINE: Zero Inflation In May Sends Stocks Soaring

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
After haunting investors for weeks, the specter of inflation suddenly retreated -- at least for now.
The Consumer Price Index, which jumped a scary seven-tenths of 1 percent in April, did not rise at all in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday. And the closely watched "core" inflation rate -- which excludes volatile food and energy prices -- edged up a mere one-tenth of 1 percent versus a four-tenths of 1 percent increase in April. 
 While the Federal Reserve is still expected to raise short-term interest rates at its meeting later this month, the absence of any signs of inflation last month eased worries that the Fed was about to embark on a sustained series of rate increases.
A wave of relief swept the stock and bond markets, which both rallied yesterday.
The Dow Jones industrial average advanced nearly 190 points, to 10,784.95, and the Nasdaq composite, encouraged as well by a surprisingly robust earnings report from the software maker Oracle, jumped more than 103 points, to 2,517.83, surpassing its previous record one-day point gain of 96.05, set Feb. 11. Yields on 30-year Treasury bonds fell as soon as the report was released, ending the day at 6.06 percent versus 6.11 late Tuesday.
"The market was expecting several tightening moves by the Fed," said Paul Kasriel, chief economist at Northern Trust. "Today's data lower the probability."
Indeed, a sustained campaign to raise interest rates such as the one conducted by the Fed from early 1994 to early 1995 seems much less likely now.
But most analysts say the Fed will probably engineer a modest rate increase of one-quarter of a percentage point at the end of its June 29-30 meeting. Not only have several voting members of the Fed's Open Market Committee been making hawkish noises in public lately, but all indications are that the economy is still growing too fast for the Fed's comfort.
"People are still very confused and very cautious," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "Everyone knows Greenspan is talking tomorrow and everybody expects him to give us the word."
Mr. Greenspan is scheduled to testify on the economy today to a Congressional committee.
To most Americans basking in the lowest unemployment and inflation rates since the 1960's, the notion that the Fed is fretting about a revival of inflation may seem puzzling, if not outlandish. But if the central bank waits for actual inflation to take off, analysts warn, it has probably waited too long. Fed actions may affect stock and bond prices instantly, but they take a lot longer -- a year or more -- to work their way through the economy.
"The Fed is worrying about what the C.P.I. will do six to 12 months down the road," said Nicholas Perna, chief economist at the Fleet Bank in Hartford.
In fact, when Fed officials issued a list of their concerns on April 18 in disclosing that their next move was more likely to be up than down, there was no mention of current inflation at all. Instead the Fed focused on factors affecting the speed of the eight-year-old expansion: strong domestic demand, tight labor markets and economic recoveries abroad.
Since then, the Government has released more data suggesting that the economy is not slowing down as much as expected. Yesterday only added more fuel to that fire. Housing starts rose 6.3 percent in May after a sharp drop in April, the Census Department reported. And the Fed said that factory output climbed for the fourth consecutive month in May as manufacturers churned out more cars and computers. Last week, there was fresh evidence that Germany and Japan were on the road to recovery.
Meanwhile, several forces that have helped restrain inflation are fading. Oil prices, which plummeted during the Asian crisis, have climbed recently. The increases have leveled off in the last six weeks or so, but as the rest of the world begins growing again further increases are likely. The same is true for the prices of commodities like copper and aluminum, which are still depressed but have been rising recently at the fastest pace in more than two years.
Still, there are few signs of the usual precursors of a sustained pick-up in inflation.
Productivity gains, which usually peter out as economic expansions get older, have sped up. Last quarter, productivity was up 2.7 percent from a year earlier, and over the last four years productivity growth has averaged 2 percent, twice the rate of the previous two decades.
As a result, labor costs per unit of output have been rising more slowly during this expansion than during any since the 1940's. They were up just 1.4 percent in the first quarter. Moreover, American industry, in the wake of a huge investment boom, has a lot of excess capacity. Even though production has been rising, the utilization rate is still around 80 percent.
"Producers would like to raise prices, but I'm not sure they can on a steady basis," said Katherine Kobe, an economist at Joel Popkin Associates, a forecasting firm based in Washington.
Today's low inflation is giving consumers plenty to celebrate. In May, the price of moving around fell. Gasoline prices, which accounted for half of April's surge in consumer prices, fell 1.3 percent after soaring 15 percent in April.
Air fares dropped, too, partly because fuel prices were flat. And despite near-record car sales, the prices of new and used models also declined.
Clothing also got cheaper, as it had been doing for some time until April. That's partly because so much of it is imported and partly because a lot of the fabrics are, too.
The price of shelter fell as well.
Computers continued to get cheaper, down nearly 2 percent last month. So far this year, computer prices have been falling at an annual rate of more than 30 percent.
Perhaps more important, given the graying of America, is that increases in the price of medical care, which had been rising briskly of late, slowed in May.
Some things that have been bargains did get more expensive last month, however. Food prices jumped six-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Will the Fed chief bare his chest when he discusses interest rates with Congress?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
IAN SHEPHERDSON, the chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics, is hoping for full disclosure today when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, testifies before Congress.
For Mr. Greenspan to bare all his thoughts on the economic outlook would be startling. Still, that is what the bond and stock markets want after yesterday's report that a primary gauge of inflation, the Consumer Price Index, was unchanged in May, while the core rate, excluding food and energy, inched up just one-tenth of 1 percent. The news scrambled investor expectations. 
 Since mid-April bond investors had been doing interest rate fire drills in preparation for the Federal Reserve's meeting of policy makers at the end of the month. And after all that practice, they had braced for a quarter-point jump in the short-term interest rate target.
Then came the incredibly mild May inflation report. It made April's jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent -- the surge that started all the fire drills -- look like a fluke, not a trend toward troublesome inflation.
And with that the mood shifted yesterday in the bond market, which can change its mind every hour, much less every day, and which routinely overreacts. A rate increase by the Fed is still expected this month, but no longer considered "guaranteed." More importantly, the attitude about a possible second rate increase in August to further slow economic growth and ward off inflation has gone from very likely to wait and see. Mr. Greenspan, of course, could force a quick revision of that view today in his testimony about monetary policy before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
Mr. Shepherdson said the benign report on inflation shifted the odds of a Fed rate increase on June 30 to 50/ 50 from 80/20. "I don't like the uncertainty," he said. "I just want to know, either way," if the Fed is going to sit tight or raise interest rates.
"It would have been easier for the markets," he said, "if the C.P.I. number had been a big plus or a big minus" and investors could have been all but certain that the Fed would raise rates -- in the case of a plus -- or leave them unchanged -- in the case of a decline.
Right after the inflation report was released by the Labor Department at 8:30 A.M., the price of the 30-year bond jumped more than a full point, while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.02 percent, from 6.11 the previous day and an 18-month high of 6.16 percent last Friday.
But the 30-year bond gave up half of its early gains later in the day, with the price rising just 20/32 . The yield finished at 6.06 percent. Stocks had a stronger rally.
There is little chance for relief in the bond market until the Fed chairman speaks. In his three most recent appearances, Mr. Greenspan has done nothing to indicate that the bond market was wrong to expect a rate increase this month. His silence was followed by remarks from other members of the Fed, several considered hawks on inflation and supportive of a rate increase, who seemed to suggest a Fed move was a sure thing.
Mr. Shepherdson, who forecast an unchanged C.P.I. for May and saw no need for a rate increase now, said this silence was an indication that Mr. Greenspan would join with the hawks. "It's a great number," he said of the inflation report, "but I am not sure it's good enough" to keep the Fed on hold.
James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, also expects the Fed to raise interest rates this month. But his argument is based on the rapid pace of economic growth, rather than on the pace of inflation.
When Fed policy makers announced they were leaning toward a rate increase in May, they emphasized the "ongoing strength in demand" in the United States and the improved foreign economic prospects, he said. At the same time, they noted that "trend increases in costs and core prices have generally remained quite subdued."
So even though the core rate of inflation has risen just 1.8 percent this year, the fact that the economy is not showing signs of slowing significantly still gives the Fed a reason to raise rates, in Mr. Glassman's view.
Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, also argues that inflation is not what will make the Fed raise rates. He said that the Fed, as officials have signaled recently, needs to take back some of the three, quarter-point rate cuts it made last fall, when it moved to calm global financial markets and to insure that the world's economy would not head into a downturn.
Now both Asia and Latin America show signs of a turnaround, and global markets have stabilized. And overall consumer inflation is rising toward 2.5 percent from the 1.6 percent increase recorded last year. Given that environment, he said the Fed's short-term interest rate target, which is now 4.75 percent, is just too low for the present mix of inflation and economic growth.
All three agree that the inflation report -- if it is backed up in the months ahead -- means that a second rate increase may not be necessary. The recent jump in certain market barometers showed that many investors were beginning to bet on two one-quarter rate increases at least.
"The market may move quickly to a view that the Fed won't have to move any further," Mr. Glassman said.
But Mr. Shepherdson, as he thought of the Fed chairman's testimony today, said, "It's completely in Greenspan's court."

HEADLINE: Clinton Presses Treaty to Ban the Worst Child Labor Practices

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 16

 BODY:
Appealing for a "human face" on the global economy, President Clinton urged the International Labor Organization today to adopt a treaty that would ban the most abusive child labor practices, including the use of children in pornography and prostitution.
The speech to the 174-member organization, Mr. Clinton's first appearance of his six-day European trip, underlined the Administration's insistence that free trade does not have to mean increased abuse of poor workers in developing countries. 
 "As we press for more open trade, we must do more to insure that all our people are lifted by the global economy," Mr. Clinton told e delegates of the labor organization gathered for their annual conference at the United Nations building here.
Among the conditions that the new treaty would outlaw are work dealing with toxic substances, and labor that is deemed harmful to children's health, safety or morals.
Mr. Clinton declared his support for the treaty after a compromise was reached on the recruitment of people under 18 year old into the military. The United States and Britain recruit 17-year-old volunteers. The treaty's final draft would now prohibit forced recruitment of children for use in armed conflict" but allow voluntary enlistment.
In another compromise, the treaty omits from its list of "worst forms" of child labor, work depriving children of education, a goal that some developing countries said was unrealistic. But Mr. Clinton used as a success story a program in Pakistan where the labor organization and the United Nations International Children's Education Fund joined forces to remove children under 14 from soccer ball production and replaced them with women needing the work. The children then were given a chance to attend school, he said.
As a worst case, Mr. Clinton singled out Myanmar, formerly Burma, where, he said, the labor organization just reported that "flagrant violation of human rights persists, and I urge the I.L.O. governing body to take definite steps."
In a recent report, the labor organization said 250 million children between the ages of 5 and 14 worked, mostly in Asia and Africa.
To reinforce the treaty that is expected to be adopted here and which the White House is urging the Senate to approve, Mr. Clinton issued an executive order last weekend directing Government agencies not to buy products made by forced child labor. The order mandates preparation of a list of countries and products that may involve forced labor. All Government agencies must then consult the list before purchasing and contractors must certify child labor is not involved in their products.
The child labor treaty does not include sanctions against countries that do not enforce the provisions. Instead, the labor organization makes persistent abuses known.

HEADLINE: Labor Market Remains Tight Across U.S.

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 16

 BODY:
Widespread strength in the nation's economic activity in April and May fostered growing shortages of workers and put mounting pressure on wages, the Federal Reserve said today.
"Labor markets remained very tight in almost all districts, with increased reports of upward pressure on wages in many parts of the country," the Fed's latest beige book summary of national economic conditions said. 
 The survey will be used by Fed policy makers meeting on June 29 and 30 to consider interest-rate strategy. There are widespread expectations that the central bank may raise interest rates to cool the economy and thus avert inflation. Today's report was more emphatic than the last beige book, issued on May 5, about the vigor of the expansion.
"The U.S. economy remains strong, with gains in activity widespread," said the summary, prepared by the Kansas City regional Fed bank and based on data collected before June 7.
Consumer spending was up nearly everywhere during April and May and consumers "remained upbeat about the economy," the report said. Auto sales were up, construction and real estate markets were booming and loan applications were strong.
Spending by optimistic consumers was the driving force behind the 4.1 percent annual rate of growth in gross domestic product, or G.D.P., in the first quarter. The beige book said spending "showed almost no signs of easing in April and May," with demand up for everything from new furniture to airline and cruise ship tickets.
The indication that the economy continued to roar ahead chilled some of the enthusiasm set off in financial markets by the Government's earlier release of data showing consumer prices were flat during May.
Treasury bond prices remained well into positive territory, but shed some gains after the beige book release lent weight to the notion that policy makers might fear growth was so strong that it could fan inflation.
The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, is scheduled to offer his views to Congress on Thursday morning on the economy's prospects; his testimony has been intensely awaited by financial markets for clues about future Fed action.
A Reuters survey of Wall Street analysts today showed most expected Fed policy makers to announce an increase in interest rates on June 30 in a pre-emptive move to keep a damper on prices by making it more expensive to borrow.
Although the beige book cited pressure on wages, it said prices for most products "remain well behaved" except for some key construction materials like Sheetrock used in home building. It said, "The shortages have created rising construction costs."
Because of "extremely tight" labor markets, some manufacturers said they were having so much trouble finding employees that they could not meet demand for their products.
The Fed said the manufacturing sector continued to shake off a year and a half of sluggishness and was churning out electronics, machinery, trucks and construction equipment at an especially strong rate. Many producers reported healthy productivity gains stemming from increased capital spending on new plants and equipment.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE APOLOGY;
In Beijing, Envoy Struggles to Persuade Chinese That Bombing Was a Mistake

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Thursday, June 17

 BODY:
Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering spent Wednesday trying to convince determinedly skeptical Chinese officials that the bombing of China's embassy in Belgrade on the night of May 7 was a mistake. But after listening attentively, the Chinese made clear that they were not persuaded, American diplomats said today.
Mr. Pickering, supported by officials from the Defense Department and intelligence agencies, gave a detailed account of "a long series of errors over time" that led to the bombing, members of the delegation said. 
 The Chinese side, represented by Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan and Deputy Foreign Minister Yang Jiechi, "listened with respect and appreciation of the seriousness with which we spoke," an American diplomat said.
"They're digesting what we said," the diplomat said. "They have to think it through."
Mr. Pickering arrived with a letter of introduction from President Clinton that included an offer to pay compensation to the families of the victims. Three Chinese died in the embassy attack, which Chinese officials condemned as a deliberate act of aggression and which created severe strains in Chinese-American relations.
The officials refused today to give details of the oral and written explanations given to the Chinese, saying that the same information will soon be released to the American public.
But they said the previously offered theory involving a faulty map was far too simple to explain how NATO planners identified the Chinese Embassy as a military site and pummeled it with multiple bombs. "It was a more complicated series of mistakes than that," a diplomat said. "It wasn't just one faulty map."
Mr. Pickering spent more than four hours meeting with Mr. Yang and with other officials from the Foreign Ministry and the Chinese military. In the afternoon, he met with Foreign Minister Tang for about one hour. Wednesday evening, during a two-hour dinner with Mr. Yang and others, the two sides turned to discussion of bilateral and strategic issues, diplomats said.
China has demanded not only a full and public explanation of the bombing but also the punishment of those responsible, a condition the Americans may have difficulty meeting. On Wednesday the Americans promised that at the end of the investigation into the bombing "the issue of accountability will be addressed," the diplomat said, and the Chinese did not press the issue.
In a sign of the visit's sensitivity, not even the fact that the American delegation had arrived in Beijing was reported in the press here on Wednesday or this morning.
In the angry aftermath of the embassy bombing, China suspended talks with the United States on its proposed entry into the World Trade Organization as well as on human rights and arms control, and put off planned military meetings.
The two Governments are now feeling their way toward a new, perhaps more realistic, relationship than in the past, when both spoke of building a "constructive strategic partnership." Members of the American delegation said that no timetable for resuming economic or political negotiations had been set, but that it was now up to the Chinese to decide when to start.
Even before the bombing, China's leaders were angry over the NATO campaign in Yugoslavia, which they called an illegal intervention. Officials here described the embassy bombing as a crime, and encouraged the state-controlled press to run wild with accusations that it was an intentional act to keep China down.
In place of last year's friendly talk of partnership, top officials including President Jiang Zemin began warning about American plans for global domination, although they always maintained that business ties should continue.
Latent public resentment of American power erupted into days of rock-throwing demonstrations at the American Embassy in China, mainly by students. Their fury was genuine, but they also received support from the Government, which seemed to view the outpouring of nationalism as a useful way to divert attention from economic and political issues at home.
Few Chinese openly accept the proposal that the United States, with its technological wizardry, could have hit their embassy by mistake. And in the meetings on Wednesday, Chinese officials said they had a hard time believing that so many mistakes could have occurred at the same time. "But they also seemed to have a sense of confidence that this won't be swept under the rug," a diplomat said.
In the last two weeks, the vitriolic attacks on the United States have eased. Communist Party leaders have tried to channel the nationalistic energy into hard work and support for the party in its drive to build a stronger China that can better stand up to any attempts at foreign domination in the future.
Wednesday's newspapers reported the statement of the Foreign Trade Minister that the right atmosphere for negotiations over China's entry into the World Trade Organization will not be restored until "U.S.-led NATO" gives a satisfactory explanation for the bombing.
As they decide how to portray Mr. Pickering's visit, Chinese leaders face another delicate task: how to escape from a month of anti-American rhetoric and declare the resumption of, in Mr. Shi's words, a "good and friendly atmosphere."
An American diplomat said: "We don't have any illusions that they are going to turn on a dime and say, 'Oh, Chinese people, we got it wrong.' They may never buy our version of the facts."
But President Jiang and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji are both pragmatists who see American trade and investments as crucial to China's modernization.

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Yankee Trash May Preserve Rebel Shrine

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

DATELINE: CHARLES CITY, Va.

 BODY:
"ROBERT E. LEE played as a child under this tree," Charles H. Carter 3d said on Tuesday, speaking of his first cousin five times removed. Mr. Carter was standing by the enormous willow oak on the front lawn of his home, Shirley Plantation, on a bluff above the James River.
Mr. Carter is the 10th generation of his family to live on this land, which was settled in 1613, just six years after the founding of the Jamestown colony down the river. Today it is still a working plantation that grows wheat, corn, cotton and soybeans, although most of the family's income comes from the tourists who file through the landmark mansion and stroll around the elegant lawns and gardens. 
 It is Mr. Carter's ambition to carry on the family tradition and preserve these bucolic 700 acres, 20 miles southeast of Richmond. To do that, he wants New York City trash by the bargeload, and he has gone to court to get it.
"People may struggle to understand how solid waste fits into the picture here," he said. "Reporters love to write about bringing New York garbage into the home of Robert E. Lee's mother. But I'd never do anything to hurt my own backyard, and I'd never jeopardize our tourist business." He pointed a half-mile away to a stand of trees hiding a cove with a new port ready to receive sealed containers of trash.
"You won't see it, smell it or hear it," he said. "The only impact of the trash will be to help us keep this plantation the way it is. We need the income to preserve the buildings and the paintings and the the grounds, and to pay the inheritance taxes so it stays in the family."
Mr. Carter's $15 million container port, named Port Tobacco, was paid for by Waste Management Inc., the operator of the nearby landfill, where the trash would be taken by truck. But the cranes are sitting idle because of a new state law. The Virginia legislature, responding to the recent outcry from some politicians and journalists over the importing of Yankee trash, banned the shipping of garbage on the James River.
Seeking to overturn the law, Mr. Carter filed suit earlier this month along with the landfill company, the barge company and the Charles City County government. The prospect of diminished revenues from the landfill has already forced Charles City County to raise taxes and make cutbacks in its schools and police force.
"It makes no sense to ban just trash from the river," Mr. Carter said. "Right now six million tons of commercial cargo go by this house every year, and well over two million tons are classified as hazardous. There are industrial chemicals like carbolic acid and sulfuric acid, plus oil and aviation fuel.
"Trash is not even classified as a hazardous material. There'd be at most one barge every two days, and you wouldn't even be able to tell it from a barge carrying containers of televisions."
MAYBE the problem is the trash's provenance.
"If we were getting the trash from North Carolina," Mr. Carter said, "it'd probably be: 'Y'all come back now and bring some more.' They'd name the barge the Bobby Lee and everybody'd be happy. There's a special hatred for New York."
Mr. Carter was appalled by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's lack of political finesse in January, when the Mayor mentioned the "reciprocal relationship" between Virginians visiting New York's cultural attractions and New Yorkers who need a place to throw their garbage. But Mr. Carter understood the point that Mr. Giuliani had been trying to make about the comparative advantages of a crowded city and a sparsely populated area.
"Two-way trade is in both sides' economic interest," Mr. Carter said. "That's why this plantation was established here. The James River was the nation's first commercial highway. My ancestors had a port here to ship tobacco and lumber and other raw materials to London, and their ships would come back with finished goods. Now the market's New York, and we're essentially trading them the air space in our landfill for their really finished goods."
Such economic subtleties, of course, did not matter to Virginia politicians happy to appeal to voters' chauvinism. But it would be unfair to blame them entirely for the problem facing Mr. Carter and his neighbors. The trash war was also orchestrated by a powerful out-of-state corporation. For more on that, see this space on Monday.

HEADLINE: The Wired Campus

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I read with interest "Coming Era of High-Speed Web Access Is Here and Now on College Campuses" (May 27), about how broadband access has changed the lives of many university students living on wired campuses like Columbia University. At Northwestern University we have a similar phenomenon: upperclassmen are lining up to live on campus, citing the advantage of Northwestern's broadband telecommunications system. 
 But for two years, the city of Evanston has been following a vision to provide every resident the same access our college students enjoy -- and more. Everyone will have the opportunity to be connected both to the Internet and to a sophisticated Intranet that will link everyone in Evanston to the school systems and City Hall and to hundreds of businesses and institutions. This effort is headed by Evanston Inventure, a private economic development entity.
We anticipate that our efforts will become a template for other communities.
 
RON KYSIAK
Evanston, Ill., June 7, 1999
 
The author is executive director of Evanston Inventure.

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
RUSSIA: I.M.F. MEASURE REJECTED -- The lower house of Parliament rejected a proposed gasoline tax, a linchpin of an economic reform package that the International Monetary Fund has sought as a condition for resuming loans to the near-bankrupt Government. The 291-to-101 defeat raised questions about whether any form of a gas tax could be passed this year; however, I.M.F. officials indicated this week that they might approve new loans even if the bulk of the economic overhaul stalls in the legislature. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: 'BLOODY SUNDAY' ANONYMITY -- The High Court ruled that 17 soldiers due to appear before a judicial inquiry into the "Bloody Sunday" killings of 14 unarmed Catholic civil rights demonstrators in Londonderry in 1972 could remain publicly anonymous. The soldiers had protested a decision ordering them to identify themselves, saying it might expose them to retaliation. The inquiry is a review of a speedy and widely disparaged investigation the same year that exonerated the paratroopers and faulted the protesters. Warren Hoge (NYT) 

IRELAND: BODY SEARCH LAGS -- Prime Minister Bertie Ahern said the police are scaling back their search for the remains of eight people executed as traitors and buried in the 1970's and 80's by the I.R.A. Acting on information provided by the I.R.A., the police have been digging in several areas, but have found only one body. The action by the I.R.A., which has refused appeals to provide additional details, was widely seen as a backfired attempt to improve its image and that of its political wing, Sinn Fein. James F. Clarity (NYT)
 
GERMANY: PROGRESS ON SLAVE WORKERS -- Just a week after lawyers for Holocaust victims walked out of talks with German industry over a fund to compensate Nazi-era slave workers, American and German officials said they were again making progress. "We restored the trust that had been somewhat fractured," said Undersecretary of State Stuart Eizenstat. German officials said U.S. lawyers appeared to have agreed on the need to shield companies from further litigation after the fund is under way. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)
 
SPAIN: 36 NEW PINOCHET CHARGES -- Judge Baltasar Garzon added 36 new charges of torture against Gen. Augusto Pinochet, making a total of 108 from the period beginning in 1988. The former Chilean dictator has been under house arrest in London since October on Judge Garzon's warrant, and extradition hearings are set for Sept. 27 in London to determine if he must stand trial in Spain. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
MEXICO: HUMAN RIGHTS FUROR -- Human rights groups criticized Arturo Montiel, the gubernatorial candidate in the state of Mexico from the governing party, known as the PRI, for saying "human rights are for humans, not for rats," in a campaign ad pledging a harsh crackdown on crime. "The rats are in the PRI," responded Jose Luis Duran, the candidate of National Action, a pro-business party. Mr. Montiel holds a modest lead over Mr. Duran three weeks before the July 4 vote. The state, which surrounds the capital, is Mexico's most populous, with 11 million people. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
EAST TIMOR: U.N.'s COSTS -- The U.N. spent $52.5 million on its mission in East Timor between May 5 and Aug. 31, Secretary General Kofi Annan said in a report to the General Assembly. That covers the cost of recruiting 242 international officials, 425 volunteers, 274 civilian police, 50 military liaison officers and some 3,645 local agents involved in an Aug. 8 referendum in which some 400,000 people will be asked to choose between independence and autonomy under Indonesia. What a U.N. official called "concerns about security" could still delay the vote, but Mr. Annan's spokesman said no decision to delay had been made. Judith Miller (NYT)
 
AZERBAIJAN: CEASE-FIRE CRUMBLES -- Fighting has erupted along a cease-fire line between Azerbaijani and ethnic Armenian forces near the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, Azerbaijani officials said. The Defense Ministry said both sides suffered losses, but it did not provide casualty figures. The enclave is recognized as part of Azerbaijan but has been held by its ethnic Armenian residents since 1994 after a six-year war in which about 35,000 people died and hundreds of thousands were forced from their homes. (Agence France-Presse)
 
INDIA, BANGLADESH: NEW BUS SERVICE -- India and Bangladesh signed an agreement to start a direct bus service between Calcutta and Dhaka. Service will start on June 29, with buses running six times a week between the two cities. (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
EGYPT: MILITANTS SENTENCED -- A military court sentenced four Muslim militants to life in prison with hard labor for what prosecutors said was a plot to assassinate President Hosni Mubarak at a presidential palace in Alexandria in 1996. Sixteen defendants were jailed for between 5 and 15 years. (Reuters)
 
AFRICA
 
ANGOLA: U.N. ENVOY RETURNS -- The U.N. envoy to Angola, Issa Diallo, returned to Luanda three months after the U.N. decided to curtail its observer mission following renewed fighting between Government troops and Unita guerrillas. The war began again in November and the two sides continue to fight, mainly in central and northern provinces. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NIGER: GOVERNMENT VOTE -- The junta that seized power in April has ordered political parties to agree on a new system of government within two days so the proposal can be put to a referendum. The order comes after two parties rejected a draft constitution that would have shared power between a president and a prime minister. (Agence France-Presse)
