HEADLINE: A New Course on Iraq

 BODY:
The stalemate over Iraq's illegal biological and chemical weapons programs grows increasingly dangerous. United Nations inspectors have been barred since last December, leaving Baghdad free to rebuild its stocks of deadly toxins, germs and nerve gas in secret. Under these circumstances, the Clinton Administration is right to give provisional endorsement to a new United Nations resolution sponsored by Britain and the Netherlands that may point a way out of the impasse. In doing so, Washington has put aside its counterproductive insistence that sanctions against Iraq must remain in place as long as Saddam Hussein holds power.
The resolution offers Iraq a chance to earn temporary suspension of some economic sanctions. But to do so, it must re-admit U.N. weapons inspectors and fully honor a list of requirements they present. Before signing on to this resolution, Washington must make sure that its provisions will be rigorously interpreted and strictly enforced. 
 The resolution would form a new U.N. inspection commission. If allowed to resume work in Iraq, the new commission would draw up a list of "key tasks," outlining the specific steps Baghdad must take to disclose and destroy its illegal weapons and their ingredients. The list would include things Iraq has refused to do in the past, like providing unrestricted access to suspected weapons production and storage sites and turning over information on what has happened to ingredients Baghdad is known to have possessed. If Baghdad complies, it would be eligible for a four-month suspension of the nine-year-old ban on Iraqi oil exports. Payment for these exports would go to a United Nations account, and Iraq's use of the money would be carefully monitored and supervised. The suspension could be renewed at four-month intervals, depending on continued Iraqi cooperation.
The resolution also provides that the suspensions could eventually give way to a full lifting of sanctions once the inspectors are able to declare Iraq fully free of all illegal weapons -- a constructive change from the previous American insistence that sanctions could not end as long as Saddam Hussein remained in power. While it is extremely unlikely that the Iraqi dictator will ever comply with his disarmament obligations, he should be given every incentive to do so.
The resolution is likely to be submitted to the Security Council in the next few days. Washington should make clear that it expects the new commission to be led by someone as tough as the two previous chief inspectors, Rolf Ekeus and Richard Butler.
Russia or China might veto such a strict resolution. But these countries should recognize that it represents a significant shift in American and British diplomatic strategy on Iraq. To reject it would dangerously prolong the stalemate and needlessly extend the economic misery of the Iraqi people. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Hints of a Mild Fed Action

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, signaled yesterday that the Fed would take only the tiniest of steps to push up interest rates when its Open Market Committee meets at the end of this month. That is likely to have only a mild impact on the economy.
Mr. Greenspan, in Congressional testimony, referred to "modest pre-emptive action" to head off inflation, which probably means that the Fed will raise the Federal funds rate -- the rate at which banks borrow from one another -- by only a quarter of a percentage point. That would reverse just one of the three cuts made last year when the Fed was worried about world recession. 
 The economy appears to be growing at a rate of about 4 percent a year, a rate Mr. Greenspan believes is unsustainable without bringing on unacceptable inflation. He wants to slow that to about 3 percent, which would still be a healthy rate.
As Mr. Greenspan noted, the current expansion, which began in 1991, will be the longest in American history if it extends through next February. Credit for that excellent performance is widely shared. Fiscal and monetary policy have been generally good, but they would not have been enough without the burst of productivity brought on by technological advances or without international events that have helped to make the United States an attractive place for investment while also restraining inflationary forces.
Such a favorable economic environment, as Mr. Greenspan noted, "can induce investors to take on more risk and drive asset prices to unsustainable levels." He is clearly worried that stock prices may be too high, but is not inclined to second-guess "hundreds of thousands of informed investors."
Instead, he is confident that the Fed can limit the economic damage if there is a crash. "While bubbles that burst are scarcely benign, the consequences need not be catastrophic for the economy," he said. That sounds markedly different from the old Greenspan, who 30 months ago warned investors against "irrational exuberance" and urged central bankers not to underestimate "the complexity of the interactions of asset markets and the economy." The new Greenspan is brimming with self-assurance. Let us hope the market does not test his new confidence. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Treasury Nominee Is Closely Questioned

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
During the height of the Mexican peso crisis in 1995 Lawrence H. Summers was the favorite target of the Senate Finance Committee. He was viewed as the scheming architect of an end-run around Congress that resulted in the $12 billion Mexican bailout. Some Republicans called for his resignation.
Today virtually all the members of the same committee said they expected Mr. Summers, the Harvard economist whom President Clinton nominated last month to succeed Robert E. Rubin, to easily win approval as the 71st Treasury Secretary of the United States. 
 But first they wanted him to suffer a little.
In a three-hour confirmation hearing today Mr. Summers twice apologized for saying over lunch with a small group of reporters in 1997 that Republicans wanted to cut estate taxes because of "selfishness." ("What I said there was wrong," Mr. Summers said today. "It is always wrong to impugn motives in these kinds of policy debates.")
He sparred at length with an angry Senator Bob Kerrey, the Nebraska Democrat, about the Administration's plans for financing Social Security. Pressed on the question of whether the Administration would raise payroll taxes, he would say only that Mr. Clinton would not raise "payroll tax rates," leaving open the possibility that the Administration could find other ways to raise revenue, including increasing the ceiling on incomes that are subject to the tax. Currently, it applies to the first $72,000 in income.
And then Mr. Summers and Mr. Kerrey entered a lengthy debate on the question of how the Government would pay to convert into cash Treasury bonds that President Clinton proposes to place in the Social Security trust fund so that it does not run out of money. Mr. Summers ducked and dodged a bit until Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the committee, exclaimed:
"Larry, it's taxes!" Mr. Summers later acknowledged that the general revenue pool of the Government would have to be tapped to liquidate the bonds, leading Mr. Kerrey to conclude that the President's solution to saving Social Security was no solution at all.
"That's the President's answer to the problem," Mr. Kerrey said. "Take the current problem that we have of using more individual and corporate income taxes to pay Social Security beneficiaries and consider it to be a virtue."
"We would see it differently," Mr. Summers said, clearly trying to obey the unwritten mandate that nominees should never engage in lengthy arguments with senators voting on their confirmation.
For all the heat of the exchanges, there was never any real question that Mr. Summers is likely to be confirmed. The last real obstacle was surmounted on Wednesday, when the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, announced that he had negotiated a deal that would lift a freeze on all Senate confirmations. The freeze had been declared, under the rules of senatorial privilege, by Senator James M. Inhofe, a Republican from Oklahoma. Mr. Inhofe said he was outraged that President Clinton had issued a recess appointment for James C. Hormel as Ambassador to Luxembourg. Mr. Hormel is a gay businessman, and the appointment was made when the Senate was out of session to avoid opposition to his confirmation.
Mr. Summers had clearly trained for today's hearing, suppressing his occasional tendency to respond to questions with a quick and sometimes cutting quip, and an attitude that demonstrated he knew far more about a subject than the questioner. It was this approach that contributed to his troubles in 1995. Nonetheless, today one of the senators who was most vocal in opposing the Mexican bailout, Frank H. Murkowski, an Alaska Republican, conceded that he had been wrong. "I think it is fair to say that you and Secretary Rubin proved that you were on a correct path," Mr. Murkowski said today, an acknowledgment that Mexico both recovered and repaid its loans from the United States.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The New Key to Employee Loyalty May Unlock a Leased BMW

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS

DATELINE: HOLMDEL, N.J., June 17

 BODY:
Forget dental benefits and stock options. When Al Galdi was searching for a perk to inspire employee loyalty, he wanted something a bit more, well, dynamic.
Today Mr. Galdi, chief executive of Arcnet, which designs and builds wireless communications systems, handed keys to 28 new BMW's to company workers ranging from administrative assistants to architects. Under a new company policy, every employee on the job at least a year gets a leased BMW, plus fully paid insurance. Turnover has been such that of 57 workers, only half qualified. But the other half can taste it. 
 This dramatic gesture, which some might call extravagant in the extreme, was anything but that to Mr. Galdi, who told of constantly losing trained people to rivals. Weighing the cost of recruiting, retraining and lost business, he estimated that the privately held company, which does $15 million in sales annually, had been spending nearly $1 million a year just to keep up.
"We ran the numbers and this made sense because it gave us something that made us stand out from the crowd," he said. "It is going to be better than a raise, because every time they turn that ignition key, they will think of me and the company."
The new perk turned what was by most measures a happy shop into an ecstatic one, said Lauren Catalano, an administrative assistant for 19 months. She was standing next to her silver BMW, with the other new cars in the company parking lot.
The bestowing of keys took on a carnival atmosphere, with Mr. Galdi, 36, as the chief barker. Family members sat in balloon-festooned bleachers, hot dogs were cooked under a tent and employees drove their BMW's around the parking lot in a horn-honking caravan.
While unusual, Mr. Galdi's gesture is not singular. At least two other small companies, Revenue Systems Inc. of Alpharetta, Ga., and Net2000 Communications of McLean, Va., have provided a range of workers with a luxury BMW. And according to Michael F. Carter, vice president of Hay Group, a human resources consulting firm, it fits in with employers' need for dramatic moves to counter the triple woes of a tight, competitive job market in highly technical fields, decreased loyalty and lingering cynicism in the wake of the mega-layoffs of the early 1990's.
"This is a super-flashy, extreme version of a far less dramatic trend among employers who are trying to do different and unusual things to distinguish themselves," said Mr. Carter, whose firm surveys trends in benefits packages.
More common, less costly moves, Mr. Carter said, included signing bonuses, "work-life benefits" like telecommuting, flexible hours, job-sharing arrangements and "convenience benefits" like on-premises dry cleaning pickup. But none, he said, can dazzle like a free BMW.
Dazzling was precisely what Mr. Galdi had in mind when he appropriated the idea from Revenue Systems. Bill Glover, that company's chief executive, said he too was drowning in headhunter and retraining costs when he hit on the idea of providing each employee with a choice of the 3 series BMW or the Z3 Roadster.
"We had all the benefits that you could expect, from full medical and dental to 401(k), but we still didn't have the visibility we wanted to attract the kind of people we needed," said Mr. Glover, whose 70-employee company provides software for government revenue collection.
Mr. Galdi echoed those sentiments today as he told employees he wanted to give them the "ultimate benefit." In an interview he acknowledged that the publicity was likely to expose his firm to potential employees who are not among that "homogenized group of currently unemployed" job seekers but "the stable, longtime employed" with other firms.
The lease on each $31,000 car runs about $7,000 a year, while insurance is about $2,000. (And employees must pay tax on this added income.) The cost of the first batch, Mr. Galdi said, is about $270,000 a year. This compared "very favorably," he said, with the roughly $900,000 he had spent on recruitment and training over the last 18 months.
George Slocum, a 51-year-old purchase order coordinator who came to the company three years ago after being "downsized" by a large heating oil distributor, said that before the BMW offer he might have entertained other job offers, but not now. He has sold his Mercury Grand Marquis, happily settled into his forest green BMW with the tan interior and plans to stick around.
A new employee, Barton Stabler, 41, who came on as communications and marketing director about a week ago, also plans on staying the "11 months, 27 days, 3 hours" he says it will take to get his car. The car offer was not his reason for applying to the company, he said, but he conceded that it had a lot to do with his decision to take the job after being self-employed for 13 years.
Ms. Catalano said she felt like one of those running, screaming, jumping winners on "The Price Is Right." Perhaps the only downside, she said, came after her photo appeared with a article about the plan in the local paper. After she went into a local BMW dealer to order her car, several men she did not know started persistently calling her at the office asking her out on dates.
"I think maybe they wanted me for my car," she said with mock horror.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Siemens and Fujitsu to Join European Computer Units

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, June 17

 BODY:
Hoping to close the gap with bigger American computer rivals, Siemens of Germany and Fujitsu of Japan said today that they would combine their European computer businesses.
The new entity, with total annual revenue of more than $6 billion, would rank as the world's fifth-largest computer maker after Compaq, Dell Computer, I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard. 
 Fujitsu and Siemens said they hoped to cut expenses, mainly by obtaining more bargaining power with suppliers and by spreading research and development costs over a broader base. The deal also gives Fujitsu access to a better distribution network in Europe, which it has long needed.
For Siemens, of Munich, the move represents the latest step in a corporate overhaul aimed at streamlining the company. Siemens is currently spinning off its semiconductor business, with annual revenue around $3.5 billion, through a public stock offering early next year. It is also pushing deeper into the Internet business, having recently reached agreements to acquire three young American software companies.
Siemens appears to be contributing far more to the deal than Fujitsu. Its computer division has about $4.2 billion in annual sales and 8,000 employees, while Fujitsu Computers Europe has sales of $2.1 billion and 1,600 employees.
Both companies glossed over the apparent imbalance, suggesting that Fujitsu had contributed more valuable assets and has a stronger focus on information technology.
Heinrich von Pierer, chairman of Siemens, had originally hoped to sell the personal computer business to Acer of Taiwan. But that deal fell through last year, when the Asian financial crisis forced Acer to back out.
The new deal could help Siemens achieve enough volume to keep up with bruising price competition. Siemens, though the biggest personal computer manufacturer in Germany, produced only 1.5 million units last year. The combined entity plans to produce more than four million.
Siemens and Fujitsu also sell a fairly broad range of other equipment, from computer networks and servers to big mainframe systems.
Neither has generated meaningful profit from computers, said Frank Alexander Rothauge, head of the technology group at Oppenheimer & Company here.
But analysts said the merger should strengthen their ability to make money even as computer prices come down.
"The advantages are mainly on the cost side," Mr. Rothauge said. "The challenge is really to make use of the scale in order to actually reduce costs of purchasing."
Many analysts had speculated that Siemens might simply sell its entire computer business, and there were some signs that investors were disappointed that such a divestiture had not taken place. Siemens shares, after surging to a record high of 73 euros in midday trading here, settled back to close at 71.61 euros, up 1.43 percent. Reaction was far more positive for Fujitsu shares, which rose 110 yen, or 5 percent, in Tokyo to 2,290 yen.
"This is not an exit strategy for Siemens -- it is quite the opposite," Mr. von Pierer said.
The two companies predicted that the new venture would increase sales to about $8 billion in 2000.

HEADLINE: Greenspan All but Announces That an Interes t Rate Rise Is Ahead

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave the clearest indication yet today that the central bank will raise interest rates by a quarter percentage point later this month.
Speaking to a Congressional committee, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that inflation is currently negligible, as shown by the report on Wednesday that the Consumer Price Index did not rise at all last month. 
 But to applause from many economists -- and in the face of skepticism from politicians of both parties who have grown increasingly convinced of the economy's ability to expand at a robust pace without much risk of accelerating prices -- he laid out a case for why the Federal Reserve sometimes needed to act well before inflation took root.
Sounding more like the Greenspan of old, a hard-line advocate of price stability, than his more recent incarnation as apostle of a new, technology-driven economy, the Fed chairman said that growth was on an "unsustainable trend," and warned somewhat ominously that the excesses of human nature had brought all expansions to an end.
Mr. Greenspan said that continued strong growth -- fueled in part by booms in the stock market and in housing prices -- could soon lead to a shortage of workers, a condition that has historically set off a spiral of rising wages and prices.
Mr. Greenspan did not flatly say he would call for a rate increase when the Federal Reserve next meets to set policy on June 29 and 30. Instead, he coupled his warning about the brewing inflationary pressures with a call for the central bank to act sooner rather than later when it spots strains that could derail the economy further down the line.
"When we can be pre-emptive we should be, because modest pre-emptive actions can obviate the need of more drastic actions at a later date that could destabilize the economy," Mr. Greenspan told the Joint Economic Committee.
Analysts quickly connected the dots and concluded that Mr. Greenspan was all but guaranteeing a quarter-point increase in rates at the end of the month. That would bring the benchmark Federal funds target rate to 5 percent.
Mr. Greenspan gave little guidance, though, about whether the central bank would tighten policy further later in the year. Economists said that he wanted to keep his options open while he waited to see whether growth slowed.
"They want to put some measure of financial restraint in place to moderate demand early enough to head off a significant problem," said Robert V. DiClemente, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney in New York.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony appeared to bring to an end speculation that the Federal Reserve had adopted a "Bunker Hill" strategy of waiting to fire until inflation was staring it in the face, Mr. DiClemente said.
Mr. Greenspan has been a primary proponent of the view that huge investments in computers and telecommunications are revolutionizing American business and making it much more productive. But today he seemed to be signaling that his faith in new technology should not be confused with his willingness to take early and perhaps unpopular action to squelch the Fed's old nemesis, inflation.
He even provided a simple bit of arithmetic to back up his case for an early tightening. The economy, he said, has grown 4 percent a year for the last three years. Of that, improvements in productivity, or output for each hour worked, account for two percentage points. Another percentage point represents the growth in the working-age population.
The remaining percentage point, he said, is accounted for by dipping ever deeper into the pool of available workers, a trend that could not be sustained much longer given the low unemployment rate, now 4.2 percent. The smaller the pool of available workers, the greater the pressure on wages, and ultimately prices.
With growth remaining strong and the global financial crisis having receded, the Federal Reserve signaled last month that it might soon begin reversing the three rate cuts -- each a quarter-point -- it made last fall. Since the May meeting of the Fed's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee -- when members adopted and announced a formal bias toward a tighter monetary policy -- Fed officials have gradually prepared investors for the likelihood of a rate increase this month. Thus, Mr. Greenspan's statements today did not shock anyone on Wall Street.
Apparently interpreting Mr. Greenspan to be suggesting that one rate rise might be enough, the bond market rallied, sending the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond back below 6 percent. Stocks rose modestly, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing 56.68 points higher at 10,841.63.
Clearly sensitive to the need to soothe Wall Street, where higher interest rates tend to be bad news over the long run for both stocks and bonds, Mr. Greenspan reassured investors that the Fed's goal was not to end the bull market.
"Betting against markets is usually precarious at best," Mr. Greenspan said, adding that monetary policy should focus on price stability for goods and services.
The Depression in the United States and the problems of recent years in Japan were not caused by the bursting of asset bubbles, Mr. Greenspan said, but by bad economic policy in the years following the market crashes.
"Should volatile asset prices cause problems, policy is probably best positioned to address the consequences when the economy is working from a base of stable product prices," he said.
Mr. Greenspan has won widespread acclaim for his management of monetary policy for the last 12 years. But his broad hints today about his intention to raise rates drew quick responses from politicians of both parties, who questioned the justification for tightening policy in the absence of inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's argument in favor of an early tightening drew skepticism and in one case pointed criticism from Democrats who heard him testify before the Joint Economic Committee.
Representative Maurice D. Hinchey, a New York Democrat, said that raising rates now would send a signal that the Fed's policy is to put an end to strong growth just as all working Americans are benefiting from plentiful jobs and higher wages.
"I know that's not what you want to do," Mr. Hinchey told Mr. Greenspan, who tried in vain to cut him off. "But that will be the effect if you give in to this notion that interest rates need to be raised now."
Steve Forbes, who is running for the Republican Presidential nomination, also warned Mr. Greenspan against raising rates now. In a statement issued in Iowa, where farmers have been hard hit by falling prices for agricultural products, he said that the real threat was deflation, not inflation, and suggested that Mr. Greenspan could become a political issue if he enacted a series of rate increases as the Presidential campaign proceeds.
"The threat of resurgent inflation exists only in the fevered minds of the Federal Reserve and the Clinton-Gore Treasury Department," Mr. Forbes said. "Jacking up interest rates now would be a pre-emptive strike against American prosperity, not against inflation."
Mr. Greenspan defended the need to attack inflation before it became a problem, with such criticism in mind. The combination of strong growth and low unemployment, he said, had not yet put the expansion at risk.
"But should labor markets continue to tighten, significant increases in wages, in excess of productivity growth, will inevitably emerge, absent the unlikely repeal of the law of supply and demand," Mr. Greenspan said. "Because monetary policy operates with a significant lag, we have to make judgments, not only about the current degree of balance in the economy, but about how the economy is likely to fare a year or more in the future under the current policy stance."

HEADLINE: Ford Raises Productivity At Its Plants

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 17

 BODY:
The big difference in labor productivity between American and Japanese auto makers in the 1980's, then a matter of considerable dismay in the United States, has been sharply reduced by Ford, but General Motors and DaimlerChrysler still lag, according to a comprehensive study released today.
Two decades ago, Japanese car makers enjoyed a labor cost advantage of roughly $1,000 a vehicle, adjusted for inflation, according to Harbour & Associates, a manufacturing-consultant in Troy, Mich., which published its annual productivity report today. The labor cost difference has persisted for G.M. and DaimlerChrysler, which have only improved as quickly as the Japanese makers. 
 But Ford has cut the gap in half, and has nearly eliminated it, if Ford's huge costs for retired workers are excluded. Ford factories are now almost as efficient and in some case more so than Japanese-owned factories in North America, which in turn are almost as efficient as Japanese company factories at home.
Because the majority of Japanese-brand cars sold in North America are now assembled here, Detroit auto makers now compete most directly with North American factories, unlike in the 1980's, when they competed mainly with cars from plants in Japan.
In terms of the number of hours of labor needed to produce each vehicle, the most efficient assembly plant in North America last year was the Toyota Corolla factory in Cambridge, Ontario, which required 17.66 hours for a vehicle. The next two in order of productivity were the Ford Taurus factories in Atlanta and Chicago, at 17.72 and 18.09 hours of labor a vehicle, respectively.
The most efficient light-truck factory in North America last year was the Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle factory in Louisville, Ky., at 19.29 hours. It was the first time that an American-owned factory has led either of Harbour's lists of the most efficient car and light-truck factories.
Ford's overall productivity in North America is now almost the same as that of Nissan, Honda and Toyota, according to the report. By contrast, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler still require nearly 50 percent more labor for a vehicle.
Ronald Harbour, the president of Harbour & Associates, said that G.M. and DaimlerChrysler were still spending billions of dollars annually for unscheduled overtime, mainly because of factory-equipment breakdowns and the need to repair cars that do not come off the assembly line in salable condition. By contrast, he said, Ford has done a much better job maintaining factories and managing production to avoid unscheduled overtime.
G.M. issued a statement today noting that it had two factories on Harbour's list of the 10 most efficient car assembly plants, and two more on the list of the most efficient light- truck factories. The G.M. factories were near the bottom of each list. Ford had four of the most efficient car factories and six of the most efficient light-truck factories.
DaimlerChrysler had no factories on either list. David Barnas, a DaimlerChrysler spokesman, said that the auto maker believes it has an edge in vehicle design. Mr. Harbour said that DaimlerChrysler's profits a vehicle, at $1,470 last year, were the highest in the world, partly because of attractive designs and also because of the company's heavy reliance on sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans, which are all very profitable.
Ford's wage and benefit costs now exceed those in Japanese-owned factories in North America by only $154 a vehicle, according to today's report. The cost of pensions and retiree benefits put Ford at an additional disadvantage of $348 a vehicle because Ford has as many retirees as active workers.The Japanese factories in North America have virtually no retirees.
G.M. and DaimlerChrysler's wage and benefit costs lag behind the Japanese by roughly $500 a vehicle. Their retiree costs are also slightly higher than Ford's.

HEADLINE: News Corp. Agrees to Buy Two PublishersFrom Hearst

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL and GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
Intensifying the consolidation of the nation's top book publishers, the News Corporation announced a deal yesterday to expand HarperCollins with the purchase of the Hearst Corporation's Avon Books and William Morrow & Company.
With the acquisition, estimated at less than $180 million, HarperCollins will remain the nation's second-ranking trade publisher of popular titles, but will expand its share of the $8 billion consumer book market to more than 10 percent. Together, Avon and Morrow are ranked eighth among trade publishers. 
 The new combination will increase the popular commercial presence of HarperCollins, which publishes writers like Barbara Kingsolver and John Gray, and extend its reach into the mass market through Avon Books, the second-oldest paperback publisher in the United States. The potential union will also deepen its children's offerings through Morrow, which was founded in 1926, and publishes best-selling children's authors like Beverly Cleary.
The expansion of HarperCollins, which is second in size to Bertelsmann's Random House, comes in a market for popular books that has been roiled by consolidation within the ranks of the top 10 trade publishing houses.
With this latest deal, few publishing giants remain that are ripe for future sales, but consolidation is quickening in other categories of publishing and reaching the second tier of midlevel publishing companies that have remained independent thus far. The interest comes not just from publishers. Distributors are buying small presses, for instance. Even the nation's largest bookstore chain, Barnes & Noble, has become one of the leading suitors for Friedman/Fairfax Publishers, a New York company specializing in nonfiction and illustrated gardening and home decorating books, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations. A Barnes & Noble spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Keating, declined to comment, saying the company does not discuss "speculation with regard to potential business transactions."
Yesterday, the educational and professional publisher John Wiley & Sons announced that it had closed its $82 million acquisition of the San Francisco publisher Jossey-Bass, a deal that immediately followed its $58 million purchase of a list of 60 college titles from Pearson P.L.C. -- which sold the titles and Jossey-Bass as part of its purchase and breakup of a large part of Simon & Schuster last year.
Several years ago, the News Corporation considered selling HarperCollins, but having kept it, it is now trying to expand, a move that spreads the heavy costs of operating a publishing company over a broader base. HarperCollins, which got $200 million of its total $737 million in sales last year from Britain, is also said to be involved in discussions to increase its clout abroad through a possible merger of its foreign operations in Britain with Penguin/Putnam, which is owned by Pearson, or W. H. Smith, Britain's largest book retailer, which recently bought a large stake in the British publisher Hodder Headline.
HarperCollins's announcement of its planned purchase drew mixed reviews, but it appeared that the expansion was not big enough to prompt any organized effort to challenge it for anticompetitive reasons and executives expect the deal to be completed within about 30 days.
The New York-based Authors Guild, which took its challenge of Bertelsmann's purchase of Random House last year and its union with Bantam Doubleday Dell to Federal regulators, said it would probably not follow the same strategy in this case.
Letty Cottin Pogrebin, an author and the president of the organization, said that HarperCollins was not expanding enough to prompt Federal disapproval for antitrust reasons. She noted, however, that she remained wary about the union of more imprints under Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation because of a 1998 incident in which HarperCollins dropped the publication of a book by Chris Patten, the last British Governor of Hong Kong. In that case, Mr. Murdoch blamed publishing executives who "screwed it up" for the cancellation, although the decision was widely attributed to Mr. Murdoch's desire to avoid antagonizing the leaders of China, where he has large media investments.
At HarperCollins, the company's chief executive, Jane Friedman, said that the planned purchase of Avon and Morrow was the News Corporation's "stamp of approval" of the effort to turn around HarperCollins. HarperCollins struggled through a bleak period in 1997 when it canceled about 100 book contracts and took a $270 million charge.
"I'm thrilled, I'm thankful and this says that we are here to stay," Ms. Friedman said. "And to be here, to stay in this competitive environment one has to do something."
She said that it was too early to answer whether any of HarperCollins's imprints would be merged with the publishing units of Morrow and Avon, which between them have 22 imprints and publish 1,000 books annually. Both Morrow and HarperCollins, for example, each have six children's book imprints.
The appeal of the union, Ms. Friedman said, is that "you've got a bigger market share and you've got economies of scale, which of course we all are looking for." She added, "We are obviously going to be looking at some consolidation, but nothing to speculate on at this point."
William M. Wright, the chief executive of the Hearst Book Group, which is the unit that presides over Avon and William Morrow, will remain a Hearst employee, but will participate in the transition.
Asked about potential job reductions, Ms. Friedman said she could not comment because she first needed to "get to know people."
But some literary agents remained concerned about the potential consolidation, although the sale could benefit some writers. On the one hand, the company's expansion could increase advances for established commercial writers because HarperCollins will have more resources to compete for authors in high demand within the industry, said Robert Gottlieb, a literary agent and executive vice president of the William Morris Agency.
But at the same time, he said: "It makes my job much more difficult. There are fewer places now to grow new writers. Whenever these companies make new acquisitions, the first thing they say is that it's going to be business as usual. But the reality is that they try to create a greater level of production and greater margins, by cutting down on their business."
Behind all this activity is the hard reality that most publishing companies have single-digit profit margins, hovering around 8 percent while educational publishers are much more profitable, with margins of 17 to 22 percent.
Typically, trade publishers are sold for lower multiples than other types of publishers, usually for one to 1.2 times sales revenues. The News Corporation is buying Morrow and Avon for less than $180 million -- a price that is not a premium one because the companies' sales revenues last year totaled about that amount. The price is also less than the $220 million that they were asking for six years ago when MCA's Putnam Berkeley Group considered buying the companies.
By merging, a buyer gets saving on warehousing, distributing, order processing and marketing, all of which can be spread across a broader number of books.
Using that logic, some analysts believe that Time Warner, which owns Warner Books and Little Brown & Company, might well be interested in acquiring Simon & Schuster.
However, a person close to Time Warner said that the company had no intention of expanding its publishing business dramatically. Time Warner gets some leverage on paper costs and fulfillment because it has a large magazine operation, which has been an advantage, but "it's a very tough business," this person said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Compaq Projects a Loss And Plans a Reorganization
In its first comment on its prospects since dismissing its chief executive two months ago, Compaq Computer said that it would lose as much as $237 million in the second quarter and announced a sweeping reorganization, which will include thousands of layoffs, meant to save $2 billion a year. 
 Compaq has been losing money and market share in the face of Dell Computer's more efficient and flexible method of selling directly to customers, and Compaq plans to increase its direct sales to consumers. Page C2.

Stock and Bond Prices Rally
Stock and bond prices moved higher as investors and traders grew increasingly confident that the Federal Reserve will not embark on a series of interest rate increases. The Nasdaq composite index rose 26.32 points, or 1.05 percent, to 2,544.15, and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 56.68 points, to 10,841.63. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 9.49 points, to 1,339.90. The yield on the 30-year Treasury fell below 6 percent, finishing at 5.96 percent. C6.
 
Confirmation Seen for Summers
Virtually all the members of the Senate Finance Committee said they expected Lawrence H. Summers, whom President Clinton nominated last month to succeed Robert E. Rubin, to easily win approval as the 71st Treasury Secretary. C4.
 
Frontier Backs Global Crossing Deal
Frontier said that its board had discussed and took no action regarding a $13 billion unsolicited offer made by Qwest Communications International, reaffirming its commitment to a merger deal already agreed to with Global Crossing. C4.
 
Gillette Expects Weak Quarter
After the market closed, Gillette said that its second-quarter results would be weaker than expected because of disappointing sales of its Braun, stationery and toiletries products and a slow recovery in overseas markets. In after-hours trading, its shares fell 6 percent. C16.
 
Lucent Said to Seek Nexabit
Lucent Technologies, continuing its push into the market for Internet equipment, is near a deal to acquire Nexabit Networks, executives close to the talks said. The two companies declined to comment. C5.
 
Fidelity Gives Look at Finances
Fidelity Investments sold $1 billion in long-term debt after strong demand from institutions, which for the first time got a detailed look at the fund company's finances. Documents suggested its total market value would top $30 billion if it were publicly traded. The bond sale has prompted speculation that Fidelity wants to assess its potential value if its chairman, Edward C. Johnson 3d, ever wants to take the company public or sell a piece. A public offering could make it easier for Mr. Johnson's daughter Abigail to take control of the company. C17.
 
Ford Narrows Productivity Gap
The big difference in labor productivity between American and Japanese auto makers in the 1980's, then a matter of considerable dismay in the United States, has been sharply reduced by Ford, but General Motors and DaimlerChrysler still lag, a study says. C6.
 
Airlines Offer Passengers Reforms
The nation's airlines appeared to slow the momentum in Congress for "passengers rights" laws by announcing modest reforms. A32.
 
Microsoft Changes Ad Agencies
Microsoft abruptly ended its five-year relationship with Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore., shifting its corporate brand account, with billings estimated at $100 million, to McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.

Kellogg, seeking to break out of a prolonged slump, said that it might close a portion of a plant in its hometown of Battle Creek, Mich., and dismiss as many as 700 of the 1,100 workers there. C18.

HEADLINE: Kellogg to Scale Back Hometown Operations

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY

 BODY:
The Kellogg Company, seeking to break out of a prolonged slump, said yesterday that it might close part of a plant in its hometown of Battle Creek, Mich., and dismiss as many as 700 of the 1,100 workers there.
The cuts could come by the first quarter of next year and would produce savings of $35 million to $45 million a year, according to the company, which makes Frosted Flakes and Rice Krispies. Analysts said the company would probably cut most of the 700 positions. 
 The proposed cuts, the analysts said, are a signal from Carlos M. Gutierrez, who became Kellogg's president and chief executive in April, that he intends to make the tough decisions necessary to awaken the sleeping giant of a company.
"The fact that they would actually close capacity in their hometown, which is pretty small, is a statement that Mr. Gutierrez really means business and is really going to cut costs to be a low-cost provider in the cereal business," said William Leach, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc.
The planned cuts would include hourly and salaried workers. The company said it would meet with union representatives before making a final decision.
"An integral part of our strategy is continuing to reduce costs and improve efficiency to enable greater reinvestment for profitable growth," Mr. Gutierrez said. "Streamlining our operations and avoiding future costs would help keep our North American cereal business cost-competitive going into the 21st century."
Kellogg has struggled to expand its business after watching sales tumble and profits shrink as consumers have switched to cheaper cereal brands and more convenient breakfast foods. Largely for those reasons, Kellogg's profits have dropped in each of the last four quarters, including a 15 percent decline over the last three months.
Analysts said, however, that it would take more than cutting costs to reinvigorate the company.
"Ultimately you can't cut your way to growth," said Andrew Lazar, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "Cutting costs must be combined with innovative new product launches and high-quality marketing spending to try and get the consumer to eat more product."

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Narrowed in April, U.S. Says

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 17

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit in goods and services narrowed in April from March's record high as exports rose for the first time in six months.
The deficit totaled $18.939 billion for the month, compared with the record $18.948 billion in March, the Commerce Department said today. The March deficit was revised downward from a previous estimate of $19.7 billion as part of an annual revision of the trade data. 
 The trade deficit with Japan narrowed, but the shortfall with China was the widest since January.
"While it cannot be said that the world markets for U.S. products is booming again, it certainly does look as if the bottom has been reached," said Joel Naroff, a private economist in Philadelphia.
In a recovery from last year's slump, exports of goods and services rose 1.2 percent, to $78.012 billion during April, led by capital goods, consumer goods, industrial hardware and agricultural products.
Imports, benefiting from strong consumer demand, rose 1 percent, to a record $96.952 billion in April, led by higher oil prices and an increased volume of petroleum shipments.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Speaker Threatens To Block 'Smart Gun' Measure

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 17

 BODY:
Efforts to make New Jersey the first state to require so-called smart-gun technology on handguns sold in the state appeared to stall today, when the Speaker of the General Assembly indicated that he was unlikely to allow a vote on the bill.
For more than a year, gun control advocates have been lobbying lawmakers in New Jersey -- which in 1990 enacted the first assault weapons ban -- to mandate smart guns: weapons equipped with computer chips and other features that make them inoperable by anyone other than the owner. 
 Fierce opposition from sportsmen's organizations and the National Rifle Association blocked the measure until this spring. But after the school shootings in Littleton, Colo., the campaign was re-energized, and a State Senate committee approved a bill last month that would mandate that new guns be "smart" by 2004.
In the Assembly, where Speaker Jack Collins, a Republican, has long contended that it would be irresponsible for government to mandate the use of technology that does not yet exist, it was unclear whether the intense public outcry generated by the Littleton shootings would persuade lawmakers to support the smart-gun bill.
In fact, when Mr. Collins unexpectedly scheduled a news conference for this afternoon and promised to make a major announcement about gun policy, some legislators hoped that it might signal a shift in his position.
Instead, Mr. Collins said that he would propose that a $1 million research grant be awarded to the New Jersey Institute of Technology to develop smart-gun technology.
"In our rush to protect children, we should not mandate unproven technology that may one day cost a police officer his or her life because the new high-tech firearm malfunctioned," Mr. Collins said. "Instead of passing a bill and then keeping our fingers crossed, we are taking a much more proactive approach."
Mr. Collins said he would also push for a bill that would set aside money to pay for trigger locks for existing handguns.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who has also voiced concerns that personalized handgun technology is not yet ready, has also advocated mandatory trigger locks.
The statements by Mr. Collins, who described himself as "pro-gun" during a recent newspaper interview, appeared to doom any chance that smart-gun legislation might be voted on before the summer break.
Bryan Miller, executive director of Ceasefire New Jersey, a gun control organization, acknowledged that Mr. Collins's words were far from a ringing endorsement of the smart-gun bill.
"If the Speaker's intention is to basically throw out a red herring and attract attention to this bill instead of the childproof handgun bill," Mr. Miller said, "then we'd be concerned, because he's thwarting the will of the people."
Democrats applauded Mr. Collins's support for the research, but maintained that there was no reason to delay passing the bill. Assemblywoman Loretta Weinberg, a Democrat from Bergen County who sponsored the Assembly's smart-gun bill, said she hoped that Mr. Collins wanted a legitimate study and "not a political stall."
The Senate minority leader, Richard J. Codey, said that smart-gun technology prototypes already exist, and that his bill, which is awaiting a vote by the full Senate, would allow gun manufacturers five years to put the mechanisms into mass production.
"The technology already exists," Mr. Codey said. "Gun makers need the economic incentive of a state law to prod them into applying the existing technology to their products."

HEADLINE: Gore Returns to the Scene of a Flop

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
Al Gore returned to New York as an official candidate for President yesterday, hoping to reverse the fortunes of his last such outing, in 1988, when the state's primary drove him from the race and frayed his relations with his own party.
Mr. Gore spent that New York race in the shadow of Mayor Edward I. Koch, his exuberant booster. The Vice President's campaign organization hopes that if he ends up this time in the shadow of Hillary Rodham Clinton and her likely run for the Senate, it will work to his advantage. 
 "I look forward to the Republicans' beating up on her," Tony Coelho, Mr. Gore's campaign manager, told reporters. "I know she won't be happy to hear me say that, but they will beat up on her so much so that you're going to have a lot of women in New York and a lot of women all over the country who are going to deeply resent what they say and how they say it. And as a result of that, we are going to benefit as a party, and Al and Tipper Gore will benefit because of what the Republicans try to do to Hillary."
Mr. Coelho said Mrs. Clinton "can stand on her own and she can be tough and she will be very effective."
"But," he said, "I encourage the Republicans to take her on."
Mr. Gore was not eager yesterday to discuss the assessment of some political analysts that a candidacy by the First Lady would compete with the Gore campaign for cash in a state that customarily bankrolls Democratic Presidential candidates.
"I've already addressed that issue," he told reporters on a flight to New York from New Hampshire. Of Mrs. Clinton's candidacy, he said, "I'm all for it," and added, without elaborating, that he thought it would help him because it would "generate enthusiasm."
Back in 1988, as a Senator from Tennessee, Mr. Gore demonstrated little appeal outside the South. In a bruising New York primary, he alienated Jews and blacks alike and won only 10 percent of the vote, trailing both Michael S. Dukakis, the eventual nominee, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
Mr. Gore, whose expected take from two fund-raisers at the Pierre Hotel last night was $900,000, appears better situated this time around to capture New York's delegates.
Norman Adler, a Democratic consultant, said that the Vice President had already lined up endorsements from most of the state's leading Democrats and that barring some unforeseen circumstance, those officials would activate their machines for him.
But Lee Miringhoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion, said that while his most recent poll, in March, showed Mr. Gore leading his sole rival for the nomination, former Senator Bill Bradley, by 47 percent to 30 percent in New York, there appeared to be room for growth by the underdog. "I assume, given that Bradley is doing better nationally than he was at that point, that New York is now within striking distance for Bradley," Mr. Miringhoff said.
The latest polls from Quinnipiac College show that New York voters view Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley -- who is from neighboring New Jersey and, perhaps more important, was a star player for the champion New York Knicks -- with equal favor: 43 percent have a favorable opinion of both. But where 24 percent view Mr. Gore unfavorably, only percent 6 view Mr. Bradley unfavorably, although 40 percent say they do not know Mr. Bradley, while only 9 percent do not know Mr. Gore.
"It's a state Bradley will focus on," Mr. Miringhoff said of New York, "because it's a good state for him, potentially."
Mr. Miringhoff also said that it was unclear at this point what effect Mrs. Clinton's likely entry into the Senate race would have on Mr. Gore but that so far it had completely overshadowed the Presidential race among New Yorkers. "Right now," he said, "Gore is not punching through. The fact that these other questions are out there -- if Hillary is running and can't campaign for him, it's sinking Gore's chances -- shows he's not holding down a lot of real estate. He's not defining himself."
Mr. Gore mentioned none of this yesterday, of course, as he held a rally under gray skies on Wall Street, where hundreds of people jammed into the intersection at Nassau Street in front of Federal Hall.
He repeated the official announcement of his candidacy that he made in Tennessee on Wednesday, highlighting his moral authority, his proposals to make preschool available to everyone and his promise to help parents save for college tuition. He also claimed, as he has for months, a special knowledge that he says will enable him to continue the economic expansion of the last eight years. "I know what works," he said.
Since he was on Wall Street, he also gave a nod -- twice -- to the role of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, in building the economic prosperity. And earlier in the day, he promised to keep Internet commerce free of international taxes. In just four years, more than $1.4 trillion has been spent on goods through cyberspace. "I want to keep the Internet a duty-free, global free-trading zone," he said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE PRESIDENTS;
Clinton Sees No Quick Effect Of Indictment on Milosevic

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: COLOGNE, Germany, June 17

 BODY:
Still trying to sort out the untidy aftermath of the Kosovo war, President Clinton suggested today that the indictment of Slobodan Milosevic by the war crimes tribunal would serve to isolate Serbia on the international stage but would not immediately affect Mr. Milosevic's personal position in Belgrade.
As forensic experts prepared to enter Kosovo to examine mass grave sites that could yield evidence for the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, Mr. Clinton urged patience on what the outcome of Mr. Milosevic's indictment would be. 
 "I do not believe that the NATO allies can invade Belgrade to try to deliver the indictment," Mr. Clinton said at a news conference with the French President, Jacques Chirac. "That does not mean that this is not an important thing, or that there won't someday be a trial." Sometimes, he added, "these things take a good while to bear fruit."
In Paris, Mr. Clinton held talks with Mr. Chirac and the French Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, on the future of Kosovo and the Balkans. He strolled in the Tuileries gardens, spent half an hour shopping on Rue St.-Louis en l'Ile, and then flew to Cologne, Germany, for a three-day meeting of the seven leading industrial countries and Russia.
On Sunday, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to meet the Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin. At the top of that agenda will be the Russian military role in Kosovo, which Administration officials said they hoped would be settled by then at talks between American and Russian military officials in Helsinki, Finland.
How to deal with the reconstruction of the Balkan region but at the same time not reward Mr. Milosevic has become one of the trickier problems that the allied leaders are beginning to confront. Mr. Chirac and Mr. Clinton said today that they favored relief aid to Serbia, on the ground that the Serbs had suffered.
Mr. Chirac expressed the justification for the ban on economic assistance to Serbia most strongly: "There can be no economic development aid to a regime which is not democratic and whose present leader, furthermore, has been indicted with crimes against humanity by the international war crimes court."
How long Mr. Milosevic will retain his grip on power and how vulnerable he is now that his troops are withdrawing from Kosovo are being assessed by Balkan specialists in the Clinton Administration as well as in Western Europe.
The question of his survival in power is important because economic experts assert that to try to revive southeastern Europe without including Serbia is a tough proposition. "It is difficult to conceive of the reconstruction of the Balkans without the participation of Serbia, because the land routes go through Serbia," said Vladimir Gligorov, an economist at the Institute for Comparative Economics in Vienna.
For countries like Bulgaria and Macedonia to regain their trade, for instance, bridges through Serbia would have to be repaired, economic experts said. Bulgaria announced today that it had lifted its ban on the export of oil to Serbia.
So far, officials said they believed that Mr. Milosevic would strive to consolidate his power in the police force, his traditional source of strength. It is too early to assess how the Yugoslav Army would react to Mr. Milosevic's decision to order their withdrawal from Kosovo.
But in the short run, they said, Mr. Milosevic will probably prevail. He has already sent signals that he will organize parliamentary elections before the end of the summer. By calling quick elections, Mr. Milosevic is apparently planning to take advantage of the disarray among the democratic opposition forces.
Mr. Milosevic will also try to create an atmosphere of normalcy by lifting the state of war that he imposed at the start of the air strikes.
The call this week by the leaders of the Serbian Orthodox Church for Mr. Milosevic's resignation was important symbolically and represented a dramatic shift in the church's attitude, officials said. But its practical effect on Mr. Milosevic in the short term is hard to predict in a country where the political opposition is barely visible and the church is not the powerful popular force that it is in some other countries.
In the longer run, Western diplomats said their hopes for unseating Mr. Milosevic depend on some influential sector of Yugoslav society's becoming disenchanted enough to put political pressure on a leader who has proved impervious to opposition in the past.
Mr. Milosevic's closest cronies, Western diplomats said, may find it increasingly difficult to maintain their wealth.
It was some of those businessmen, particularly those close to Mr. Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, who appear to have had considerable influence in persuading Mr. Milosevic to agree to the peace settlement, a senior Administration official said.
These cronies are not going to be much better off now, diplomats said. About 300 Serbian officials and businessmen, all close associates of Mr. Milosevic, are unable to get visas to European Union countries. The ban on visas for those people was put in place last year as part sanctions to punish the Milosevic Government.
"The economic pressure will increase, and these people could turn against him," a European Union diplomat said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Agency Adopts Treaty on Child Labor

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, June 17

 BODY:
The International Labor Organization today adopted a treaty meant to abolish the worst forms of child labor, one that includes a contested provision allowing people under 18 to serve in the military.
The pact is intended to end the exploitation of millions of children who are involved in pornography, prostitution, slavery, hazardous work and forced recruitment as child soldiers. Drawing attention to the treaty, President Clinton addressed the delegates, the first American President to do so. 
 Adopted unanimously by delegates from the 174 country members of the I.L.O., the convention aims to protect those under 18 but does not provide an across-the-board ban on child labor. The treaty's text does not prohibit people under 18 from voluntarily enlisting in the military, an omission that nongovernmental groups and some governments believe weakens the document. A compromise was adopted after insistence by the United States that there be no bar to such military service.
A number of countries, including the United States, Britain, Germany and the Netherlands, recruit 17-year-olds into their armies. The United States, among others, requires parental consent.
United States officials estimated that the American military services have fewer than 10,000 enlistees per year under 18. Of these, fewer than 100 are involved in combat units, and those are in the Balkan region, officials said.
The compromise treaty language now bars "forced or compulsory recruitment of children for use in armed conflict."
Trade unions, along with a diverse group of countries, including Canada, Norway, Denmark and France, had urged tougher provisions.
"We believe it's not appropriate for people under age 18 to be involved in the military," said Tim Noonan, of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.
Defending the Clinton Administration's position, the Labor Secretary, Alexis M. Herman, said, "We wanted to make sure the emphasis was on forced, compulsory child labor."
But Martin McPherson, of Amnesty International, disagreed. "In the end, it makes no difference whether the person has gone voluntarily or compulsorily," he said. "Military service is hazardous -- regardless."
Although Mr. Noonan said trade unions wanted a flat ban, the compromise was agreed to because "our primary concern was children in Uganda and Sudan -- the 10- and 12-year-olds with guns."
United States officials said many countries allow 17-year-olds to serve voluntarily. "Our concern is about the use of the younger ones being abducted and coerced by paramilitaries and militias," one official said. Amnesty says there are an estimated 300,000 such child soldiers worldwide. They are among the estimated 250 million children under age 14 who, according to I.L.O. statistics, work in developing countries, mainly in Africa and Asia.

HEADLINE: Resegregation in the Schools Hurts All Students

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Chester E. Finn Jr., a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, derides the report by the Harvard Graduate School of Education's Civil Rights Project about the resegregation of our public schools, saying people ought to be more concerned about "whether kids are going to good schools where they are safe and learning to read" (news article, June 13). 
 But clearly there is a connection between schools that are racially and economically isolated and poor student performance.
School desegregation has brought educational opportunity to many poor black children, resulting in documented improvements in their academic performance. In cities like St. Louis, poor black children who voluntarily enroll in suburban public schools go on to college at a far higher rate than their counterparts in city schools. However, as schools resegregate, the gap in performance across racial lines is growing. Desegregation isn't the only way to provide educational opportunities to minority children, but abandoning it is a mistake.
 
WILLIAM L. TAYLOR
Washington, June 14, 1999

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Russians Land a Big One;
F.A.A. Gives Stamp of Approval to Ilyusian Cargo Plane

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

DATELINE: LE BOURGET, France, June 17

 BODY:
Displayed proudly above the reception desk of the Ilyushin Aviation Complex office at the Paris Air Show here is a newly minted air-worthiness certificate from the United States Federal Aviation Administration. On June 2, the big, four-engine Russian Ilyushin IL-96T parked nearby became the first wide-body jet, other than ones made by Airbus Industrie and the Boeing Company, to meet F.A.A. safety standards.
It was not easy. 
 While Airbus and Boeing have the certification process for new models down to a science, often breezing through it in a year or less, Ilyushin struggled for five years to get approval. And even though it now has the certificate, making it easier for leasing companies and banks to finance sales of the IL-96T, the success of the cargo plane, or of a sister passenger plane that is in the works, is by no means assured.
Ilyushin, founded in 1933 by Sergei Vladimirovich Ilyushin, who won the Order of Lenin three times for designing some of Russia's most famous military and civilian airplanes, has built only one IL-96T so far. The company, which was partly privatized in 1994, has orders for 19 more from Aeroflot International Airlines. But it cannot even deliver the first one because an agreement for loan guarantees from the Export-Import Bank in Washington that would help pay for the planes has lapsed.
But the Ilyushin team, in the best Russian tradition, knows how to live with adversity. "We have overcome so much," Vladimir A. Belyakov, the company's deputy marketing director, said, ticking off the collapse of the Soviet Union, the introduction of a market-based economy that eliminated decades of fat government subsidies, and last summer's financial debacle. "And we continue."
The IL-96T was the inspiration of the late industrialist Armand Hammer, who in 1989 suggested combining the best of the Soviet and American aerospace industries. He convinced wealthy friends, including the publisher Robert Maxwell and the real estate executive Paul Reichmann, to invest in the project.
But after Dr. Hammer and Mr. Maxwell died and Mr. Reichmann's Olympia & York went bankrupt, the deal fell apart. Mr. Belyakov said Ilyushin executives now joked that they should have taken $1 billion from Mr. Reichmann. "What difference would it have made if he were $11 or $12 billion in debt?" he asked.
But the idea of building a Russian-American airplane survived. Eventually Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies, agreed to supply the engines, while Rockwell-Collins, a unit of Rockwell International, furnished the cockpit instruments and controls. Other American suppliers also signed on. The result was the IL-96T.
It was -- and is -- a bet on the future of the aviation market in Russia, a country that spans 10 time zones and desperately needs more airplanes. Arthur Kelly, the Rockwell-Collins executive who oversaw the company's role in the project, was a believer, making his final presentation to Rockwell-Collins's board of directors in the early 1990's, dressed in the uniform of a Russian Air Force colonel.
"Arthur was passionate about getting Rockwell Collins into international markets," Karen C. Tripp, the company's chief spokeswoman, said. "He would do things like that." Mr. Kelly, who died of cancer in 1996, got the board's approval. So far, Rockwell-Collins has invested $50 million in the airplane and Pratt & Whitney $80 million. Mr. Belyakov estimated that Ilyushin had spent $600 million.
Sergei Ilyushin joined the young Soviet military as an aircraft mechanic in 1919 and began building gliders as a student at Russia's Air Force academy in the 1920's. During World War II, he developed the IL-2 attack airplane to support infantry.
For most of its history, Ilyushin was simply a design center, creating airplanes that were built by factories around the Soviet Union as ordered by the central authorities. The system may not have been efficient but it was certainly productive: More than 36,000 of the single-engine prop attack planes were built, making it a mainstay of the war and the most widely produced model in the world.
During the cold war, the Ilyushin Design Bureau, as it was then called, continued to create bombers and fighters but also branched into civil aviation. Hundreds of Ilyushin airplanes were produced each year and "sold" to Soviet allies in the East bloc and elsewhere -- the allies had little choice but to buy them.
The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 ended the cozy relations between the state and the aircraft industry. Government orders dried up. Designers like Ilyushin and the factories that produced its planes were told to make it on their own. While some airplanes, like the mighty Antonov, the world's largest cargo airplane, have found niche markets, most Russian airplane makers have fallen on hard times. The Antonov, for example, moved the Rockefeller Center's 73-foot Norway spruce Christmas tree to New York from Cleveland last year. And, because it was being leased, it did not need F.A.A. certification.
Liberated East European countries dumped their Russian planes, opting for more modern and cost-efficient Airbus and Boeing jets. Even Aeroflot decided to buy Boeing 737's and leases Airbus A310's and two wide-body Boeing 777's.
The Moscow-based Ilyushin teamed up with its factories in Voronezh and Tashkent to form a joint-stock company. (The Tashkent deal was delayed because the Governments of Russia and the former Soviet republic of Uzbekistan first had to work out a two-way agreement.) In addition to the new IL-96, Ilyushin now makes the IL-114, a regional two-engine prop, the four-engine IL-76 cargo jet, and the IL-103, a small, single-engine private plane that in December was actually the first Russian airplane to receive F.A.A. certification.
So far, business has not been good. A decade ago, 60 IL-76's were made each year; last year just 15 were produced. And while China bought three wide-body IL-86 passenger jets and one IL-76 freighter three years ago, most of the new Ilyushins now coming off the assembly line are flown by Russian airlines that lack the money to pay for them.
Mr. Belyakov estimated that around 1,500 Ilyushins, ranging from the four-engine prop IL-18's of the 1950's to the wide-body, 350-passenger IL-86's of the 1970's, remain in service in Russia and places like China, Cuba, India and Vietnam.
The new, Westernized version of the IL-96 is based on the all-Russian IL-96-300, which went into service in 1993. It is currently flown only by Russian airlines and serves as the official plane of President Boris N. Yeltsin. The IL-96M, which is the soon-to-be-introduced passenger version of the new airplane, can carry up to 436 passengers.
The company says the IL-96T, which is the cargo version and the first of the planes to come off the assembly line, can carry as much as 92 tons more than 7,000 miles.
That makes it smaller than the biggest Boeing 747 freighter, which can carry up to 140 tons. But Genrikh V. Novozhilov, Ilyushin's chief airplane designer since 1970, said the IL-96T's 16-foot-wide and nine-and-a-half-foot-high side cargo door, which is bigger than any competitor's, gave it a competitive edge. And at an asking price of $75 million, the plane is less than half the list price of a new 747, even though it has the latest high-tech American cockpit instruments and fuel-efficient American engines. Thus, its backers contend, the IL-96T could find a ready market, even a huge one, from cash-short customers that need cheap hauling capacity.
That may be one reason why Boeing unsuccessfully lobbied the Clinton Administration in 1995 not to let the Export-Import Bank guarantee a $1 billion loan to pay for 85 percent of the Western content of the first 20 planes. Boeing said that it did not mind competing with Ilyushin but not when Russian Government subsidies enabled it to sell its planes at below market prices.
"It's not a bad airplane," said Edwin Laird, the publisher of Cargo Facts, a monthly magazine that focuses on freight airplanes, as he watched the IL-96T lumber along the runway into take-off position for its demonstration flight here. But that is a just a small part of the equation, he explained.
"The airlines are not worried about the engines or the avionics, which are all made in America," he said. "They are worried about everything else. What do you do if it breaks down? Do you go out in the back yard and make a part?" He said he doubted there would be much of a market for the plane outside Russia until it had proved itself.
Mr. Belyakov said Ilyushin was prepared to offer airlines a global support network with the help of Pratt & Whitney and others. The real problem, he said, is that Ilyushin lacks the money to help customers finance the purchase of its planes.
The F.A.A. certification will help with that. Uncertified planes like the IL-96-300 are allowed to fly back and forth between the United States and Russia but it is very difficult to sell airplanes in third countries without a stamp of approval from American or European safety authorities. Few banks and other financial institutions will lend money to finance the sale of an uncertified airplane.
Mr. Belyakov said that Ilyushin was now looking for alternative ways to finance the Aeroflot sale to make up for the absence of the Export-Import Bank loan guarantees. Ilyushin's plan is to deliver the planes to the Russian airline as soon as it can, so it can show the world how well the IL-96 can perform in commercial service. But Ilyushin executives were busy entertaining prospective customers at the air show here and were said to have some interest from airlines in Europe and Asia.
"There is a lot of opportunity for it in the C.I.S.," said Louis Chenevert, the president of Pratt & Whitney, referring to the Commonwealth of Independent States, the successor to the Soviet Union. "But as the airplane builds credibility for itself, it will gain customers all over the world. The airplane will do well over the next couple of years."
Not that Airbus and Boeing should really lose any sleep. Together, they will deliver more than 900 new airplanes this year, while Ilyushin will be lucky to deliver one of its IL-96's.
"The F.A.A. certification will ease access to international capital for us and for our customers," Mr. Belyakov said. "We are rising to the same level of competitiveness with the Western-made aircraft."
