And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE BOY ON THE GREEN BICYCLE: A Memoir, by Margaret Diehl. (Soho, $25.) After the deaths of her brother and father, the author devised a host of inventive, if ultimately destructive, self-intoxications; she enumerates them in a memoir that explores the line between enchantment and insanity.
 
A CLEARING IN THE DISTANCE: Frederick Law Olmsted and America in the Nineteenth Century, by Witold Rybczynski. (Scribner, $28.) How a modest man with no formal training in landscaping became a symphonist of public space, designing Central Park and other scenic masterworks.
 
CLOSE RANGE: Wyoming Stories, by Annie Proulx. (Scribner, $25.) A collection that depicts the New West within the framework of the Wild West, and discovers life hasn't changed all that much.
 
ELEMENTALS: Stories of Fire and Ice, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $21.95.) In stories that home in on the place where esthetics and moralism meet, priggish northerners fettered by incuriosity (the greatest crime in the Byatt universe) are forced to rub up against a warmer-blooded breed -- artists, mostly -- unremittingly interested in the world around them.
 
1185 PARK AVENUE: A Memoir, by Anne Roiphe. (Free Press, $25.) Shunning confessionalism in favor of critical detachment, Roiphe recalls her affluent girlhood, where Scotch flowed daily at 5 and children wanted for nothing but parental affection.
 
HAVANA BAY, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $24.95.) Arkady Renko, taciturn Russian police detective and star of "Gorky Park," fetches up in Cuba bent on suicide; he is revitalized when his plan is rudely thwarted by a would-be assassin.
 
LAST THINGS, by Jenny Offill. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) A quirky first novel follows its 7-year-old protagonist as she observes the descent into madness of her mother, who has built them a private cosmos filled with signs and wonders.
 
LAYOVER, by Lisa Zeidner. (Random House, $24.) This novel's heroine, who has endured maternal loss and marital betrayal, simply fails to come home one day, embarking on a parallel life of free (read illegal) hotel rooms and relentless sexual conquest.
 
MARY PICKFORD REDISCOVERED: Rare Pictures of a Hollywood Legend, by Kevin Brownlow. (Abrams/Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, $39.95.) America's first film star, this reappraisal argues, was more than the sum of her golden ringlets: urchin and princess, she was an adroit shapeshifter worthy of serious attention.
 
TIPPING THE VELVET, by Sarah Waters. (Riverhead, $25.95.) Suffused with eros, this picaresque first novel chronicles a wide-eyed Victorian girl's ardor for a music-hall actress, her life in London's mean streets and her eventual redemption.

HEADLINE: Surfing On the Slippery Skin Of a Bubble

BYLINE: By Po Bronson; Po Bronson is a writer based in San Francisco. His nonfiction book about Silicon Valley, "The Nudist on the Late Shift," is due out this month.

 BODY:
For a homeless shelter's annual charity auction not long ago, Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist, donated a breakfast with himself not long ago at Buck's Restaurant. Buck's is a bustling diner in Woodside, Calif., a single-intersection hamlet nestled into an oak grove at the base of the San Mateo County foothills. The booths at Buck's are upholstered in ocher Naugahyde and the menus have the feel of political-action newsletters and the owners are mighty proud of their coffeecake. Buck's also happens to be the place where Netscape and many other high-tech companies were hatched.
"Breakfast at Buck's" was sold off by way of the Internet site Ebay at the end of February; 78 bids after the auction started, a budding Manhattan entrepreneur named Mark Hernandez offered to pay $4,400 for the privilege of flying out to Silicon Valley two weeks later to present his business idea. That might sound like a lot of money to have breakfast with someone, but Jurvetson is a venture capitalist with a reputation -- young, enthusiastic, open-minded. He can be found at Buck's most mornings. He bounds in like a kangaroo, exuberant, flashing a joyous smile, his youthful face tanned from his noon-hour games of ultimate Frisbee. He is generally more dapper than his colleagues, wearing a charcoal Czechoslovakian hand-made suit over a cobalt shirt with faint royal blue pin-stripes. His tie picks up these colors perfectly; the black wing tips on his large feet shine. In the plastic window of his wallet is the bridal portrait of his wife of eight years, Karla, who is a psychiatrist at Stanford. 
 He has a prototypical resume for a Silicon Valley V.C.: earned B.S. and M.S. degrees from Stanford, designed microchips at Hewlett-Packard, learned management consulting at Bain & Company, returned to Stanford for his M.B.A. and then beat out 250 other applicants for a position at Draper Fisher, the venture firm. Prototypical resume, except for the date column: as an undergrad, he tricked the registration computer -- which blocked signing up for more than 20 units -- by penciling in just two units of credit on what were five-unit classes. In this way, he was able to take eight classes at once and finish in two and a half years with an A plus average. Think that's fast? The conventional wisdom in Silicon Valley is that it takes three years to learn the craft. Steve Jurvetson made partner in six months. He was 28.
Venture capitalists' favorite unit of measurement is the factor X. They live life on multiplication scale, and anything less than X is inconsequential. When they invest, they ignore 12 percent or 15 percent or 18 percent returns. They start to take notice when they see potential for 10X returns. In this lingo, Jurvetson blasted through college at nearly 2X the normal rate, and made partner at 6X speed.
Now he's accelerating -- straight into what could be a precarious stretch of road. Only 32, Jurvetson is in for the summer of his life, with no fewer than 11 of the Internet-related companies he has backed (Wit Capital, Goto.com, Tumbleweed and Netzero among them) at various points along the road to an initial public offering. The brand name he has built for himself with investments in a couple of other successful Internet start-ups -- his firm's specialty and the hottest destination for venture capital -- will be put to the test.
That's because the market's taste for Internet stocks appears to have soured: bellwethers are way off their peaks and new issues are coming out of the box more cautiously. Dave Marquart, a Silicon Valley veteran who was the only venture investor in Microsoft and the co-lead investor of Sun Microsystems, warns: "To be a bona fide venture capitalist, you have to go through a complete cycle. Those who've entered the business since the mid-90's have never seen a down cycle. Everything has been to the right and up -- very up."
To understand why Jurvetson is a folk hero for so many of those looking to convert their dreams and visions into Net wealth, consider what happened in February 1996. Sabeer Bhatia was an immigrant from India with zero experience running a company, zero experience in consumer products and zero experience in software. (He had been a hardware engineer at Apple.) He was Jurvetson's age less two years, or J - 2.
Bhatia had already been turned down by 21 other venture capital firms. He had produced no prototype, not even a graphic printed on a piece of paper. What he did have was what Jurvetson called "hallucinogenic optimism" and one intriguing idea, which he sketched out on a conference room white board. Jurvetson invested $300,000 to buy 15 percent of the project. Less than two years later, the company that emerged from that meeting, Hotmail, was sold to Microsoft for $400 million. Jurvetson became an instant legend, the guy every young entrepreneur wants to meet, even if it means paying 250X the cost of breakfast at Buck's.
Increasingly, successful venture capital firms are sheltering themselves from the hail of unsolicited business plans by invoking the Inverse Rule of Referrals: all good ideas come by referral, so if it didn't come by referral it must not be a good idea. Here's how a typical venture firm might catalogue the incoming slough: administrative staff scans the first paragraph of the cover letter for a referral by a "trusted third party," which is entered in a database. Partners scan the database; they'll look at the plan only if they trust the referral. "It makes being a venture capitalist 90 percent simpler," Jurvetson comments.
Draper, Fisher, Jurvetson has cultivated a reputation for ignoring that rule. The firm is located in Seaport, a sailing harbor in Redwood City -- psychologically far from V.C. ground zero, Sand Hill Road (but close enough to zip there in 10 minutes for a meeting). The problem with referral networks, as D.F.J. sees it, is that as the venture capitalists age, so does their referral network, cutting them off from the original thinkers. They say they read every one of the 5,000 plans sent to them each year. Theirs was the first venture capital firm to run an advertisement.
D.F.J. is a "seed" firm, meaning it gets in on the first round of financing for nascent businesses. "Getting companies started is the hardest part," says Tim Draper, the firm's founder, "and it's the most rewarding -- both financially and personally." To Jurvetson, it's even more rewarding than being an entrepreneur. "I get bits and pieces of several success stories, sort of a highlight reel," he says.
Jurvetson has succeeded so far by making himself accessible to the kind of young people who he figures come up with unusual ideas -- as opposed to what the industry calls "Me, Too" product. One recent month's "Me, Too" was on-line gift registries. He saw 30 business plans on that concept. The month before, it was Web-calendar companies. He saw three Web-calendar plans out of Sun Microsystems' employees alone. Having lunch in San Francisco one day, he bumped into an old friend who said he had left Netscape to found his dream start-up; without much tact, Jurvetson jokingly blurted out, "I hope it's not another Web-calendar company!" His friend's face fell. They always think they're the only ones with the idea.
"Truly original thinkers tend not to be entrepreneurs who've spent 10 years at Cisco and can be trusted to know what they're doing," Jurvetson explains. "They tend to be 26 years old and highflying. They often have a very childlike mind, with some navete. We're impressed by people who don't know what can't be done."
Just as the wild success of venture capital firms has made them magnets for business plans, it has made them extremely popular with fund investors (which tend to be pension plans, university endowments and insurance companies). At a typical V.C. firm, money under active management has gone up 40X; the number of partners to manage that money has gone up only 4X. It's now common to raise $350 million to $500 million every couple of years. When Draper Fisher Jurvetson mailed out prospectuses for its most recent fund, the firm received 3X the pledges it needed. The partners drew the line at $180 million -- but even that is a huge sum to deploy among early-stage firms, and easily the biggest fund D.F.J. had ever raised.
V.C. firms have a fat incentive to raise more and more money, because they get paid in two ways. First, when investors in a specific fund are paid back after a set period of time has elapsed (typically 10 years), the venture firm keeps 20 percent of all the profits. Second is the gravy train: a 2.5 percent annual management fee paid by investors, regardless of performance.
To deal with all the incoming money, most firms are ratcheting up the size of investments, especially on secondary rounds, when a company that has survived the seed stage needs large cash infusions. That means sticking with start-ups that have a high likelihood of growing not just big but gargantuan, with billions of dollars in annual sales. The Amazon of pharmacies, the Amazon of insurance, the Amazon of auto parts -- consumer markets so big that even a small slice of them guarantees a stellar payoff. They're not really start-ups, they're bulk-ups. They put on weight fast and flex their muscles and try to scare competitors off the beach.
But as Jurvetson sees it, something has been forgotten in this process. Sure, it's cool to make so much money. And sure, it's cool to be able to buy hair dye and condoms from the privacy of home. But on-line superstores aren't creating new markets, and though they might evolve the technology of E-commerce, they're not revolutionizing it. They're just big Web sites. Where's the adventure in that kind of venture?
Seed investing requires a special kind of hunger. Jurvetson's parents were immigrants from Estonia, and he was reared in Dallas by the creed that what he was to make of his life was entirely up to him; there were no entitlements. In an undergraduate psychology class, he answered a series of Enneagram questions meant to divine his character type. He so fit the description of a Type 3, the Performer (as in star performer), that he was asked back in following semesters to lecture about the traits of Type 3's: tremendous need for achievement, with an inner drive to do something beyond the ordinary.
That drive is why he belongs dead center in the creation zone of the new economy: where there's constantly a new goal to keep him from getting bored, and where he has all of Silicon Valley as an audience to perform for. He seems very similar in character to the headstrong young entrepreneurs he deals with, and perhaps that is partly why they mind-meld with him so well.
At no time was this more clear than the day he drove across the Dunbarton Bridge to meet Joe Chen, the C.E.O. of a very new start-up, See U There.com. Chen had 12 employees working in the living and dining rooms of his Union City home. Jurvetson admits he's a sucker for this kind of raw fertile atmosphere, and he grooved on it for a while that day, talking to the employees and soaking up their ambitious energy.
The whole point of money is that it's transferable legal tender, that it retains its value no matter who possesses it -- your million dollars is just as valuable as my million dollars. With venture capital, that's not always the case. Chen already had two other venture firms ready to give him the million dollars he needed. "Literally, they are screaming at us, asking when we are going to close the deal," Chen explained as we sat down at his conference table in the garage. But he would rather have Steve Jurvetson's million dollars. His pitch: a plan to build an Internet site to capture the largely untapped $60 billion market for event planning. Jurvetson seemed inclined to invest (and two days later, did).
Chen is J + 1 years old. He wanted Jurvetson's technical fluency, but also a certain kind of cultural chemistry -- the difference between working with someone who is just like your father and working with someone who is just like you. As Chen puts it, "He's not some stiff suit walking in here."
"The hotmail story reached us even in Singapore," says Eng-Siong Tan, the C.E.O. of a start-up called Third Voice. Tan is J + 4 years old. "It resonated and became part of the folklore of the valley that he was willing to invest where 21 other firms had passed. We knew Steve would be someone who gets our idea."
Tan and eight other Singaporean engineers uprooted and came here cold. They crammed into a cement-block storage warehouse in Foster City, their front door an aluminum roll-up gate. In November, Tan pitched Jurvetson. Third Voice would make software that allows users to post comments, viewable only by other users, directly onto the front page of any Web site. It's the Web equivalent of empowering people to spray-paint the State Capital. Jurvetson got it: this could do to on-line chat what Ebay did to classified ads.
Today, Tan has come by to discuss some new hires, of which there will be many in the next month. Internet companies are like Bazooka bubble gum. It takes a lot of chewing and manipulation -- a tremendous amount of effort -- to get the first bubble started. Then, with the slightest additional effort, a mere exhale, it expands 100X. For a while it's customary to double in size every month. That's what Tan is about to go through. He's ready to exhale.
We meet with one candidate for vice president for business development, Leo Jolicoeur, who brings experience from a couple of the more prominent corporations in the valley. He has five other job offers already on the table. As V.P. for business development, he would be responsible for partnering Third Voice with major tech companies. He wants to know how Jurvetson might help.
"O.K.," Jurvetson says, "let's run down the list real fast. Yahoo? I live on the same street as founder Jerry Yang and we walk our dogs in the morning. Excite? The C .E .O., George Bell, is a college buddy of our partner John Fisher. AOL? We sold them two companies last year. Microsoft? We sold them Hotmail. That's just external. Then we have our internal portfolio of 50 Internet companies. I can think of several right off the bat to partner with."
"All right, I get the picture," Jolicoeur says.
Later, Tan wants Jurvetson to help recruit an engineering student from Stanford. "It's going to be very tough," he says. "He already has a job offer from Drugstore.com and he's leaning toward taking it. You'll go up against Doerr." Drugstore.com is financed by the firm of the legendary venture capitalist John Doerr. The day before this meeting, it had been widely reported that Amazon.com had bought 40 percent of Drugstore.com. The company looked to be a grand slam.
"That's no problem," Jurvetson says. "Drugstore.com is a 'Me, Too' product. It's got six or seven competitors, and it's not even first mover -- that was Planet Rx. Besides, what's cool about selling pharmaceutical supplies? We'll see what kind of person this recruit is. I'll just ask him: does he want to sell Preparation H, or does he want to launch a new product category that will alter the balance of power in the world?"
The recruit signed with Third Voice.
The first of Jurvetson's 11 I.P.O.-bound companies -- Wit Capital, an Internet investment bank -- went public earlier this month, right on the heals of a disastrous week for Internet stocks. In late May, Juno Online and Ziplink not only failed to post triple-digit first-day returns, they both dropped below the offering price. Two other I.P.O.'s were postponed.
Suddenly the center of the Internet boom seemed to a lot of people like a scary place to be. But Wit went out and and finished its first day up 85 percent -- a figure that would have been a disappointment just months before, but now looked strong. And Jurvetson sounded as chipper as ever. Yes, some of the insane pops of early 1999 probably won't be back, but Jurvetson says that only means offerings are being priced more fairly and supply and demand are synching up. But the Internet is the economy, he insists; businesses that still think it's just a fad are in denial.
"We've seen I.P.O. windows open and close," he says. "The fact that some I.P.O.'s -- other people's I.P.O.'s -- haven't done well doesn't really matter to us. The businesses that we're backing . . . they're really good businesses, and it's not like they're going to shut down without a huge cash infusion from the public markets. Wit Capital -- they're just closing business left and right.
"It takes a really dramatic sea change for a venture capitalist to revisit whether a sector is a good idea, and we just haven't seen that," he continued. "We're actively investing like crazy. We've done more deals in the last three months than we did in the previous six -- with no eye whatsoever to the public markets, because we're thinking about the public markets two or three years out."
Of his I.P.O.-bound companies, only one is considering putting off its public offering by a quarter, he adds, and there is nothing in his voice to suggest fear or unease about the future. That's what the Type 3 description doesn't capture: This is a guy having time of his life. The default setting on his face is a birthday-boy smile. And why not? "I get to have the Steve Jobses of the next century come to me and make their pitch. I can't define a better recreation activity, let alone a job, that would be better than that."
Mark Hernandez, the winner of the Breakfast at Buck's auction, is J - 3 years old. He shows up at Buck's wearing a navy blazer, khakis, tortoise-shell Clark Kent glasses and his Stanford class ring. He resigned from his position as director of Merrill Lynch's Latin American derivatives desk four days ago to pursue a new life, though it's not clear just yet what that life will entail. Their conversation swells and fades, never coming to a head with the Pitch. Hernandez has a lot to choose from. Since winning the auction, he has been besieged by other Manhattan entrepreneurs offering finder's fees for connecting them with Jurvetson. On top of that, he has invested his own money into four start-ups, and he obligingly runs down the list, getting strategic feedback.
Not until the plates are cleared does he get around to his dream project: he's going to raise $5 million from cash-rich friends on Wall Street and pair it with a special $15 million loan into a highly leveraged kitty called Transformation Capital. It's a seed fund!
He'll be looking for 20 start-ups to invest in.
Mark Hernandez doesn't want to be the Steve Jobs of the next century. He wants to be the Steve Jurvetson of lower Manhattan.
"Ever since I read that Hotmail story," he says, "I wanted to get in touch with you."

HEADLINE: A Perfect Madness of Plants

BYLINE: By Verlyn Klinkenborg; Verlyn Klinkenborg writes editorials for The New York Times. He is the author of "Making Hay" and "The Last Fine Time."

 BODY:
The architecture of Dan Hinkley's garden on the Kitsap Peninsula in Washington State is native, shaped by old Douglas firs and a seeping bog. But in the cultivated understory, he has convened plants from all around the globe, reuniting the tribes of the botanical diaspora. More than 50 kinds of arisaemas -- called jack-in-the-pulpit in North America -- rocket from the soil, and one, Arisaema nepenthoides, stands fully erect, a single cobralike spathe beside a rotting stump crowned with ferns. Thirty-five varieties of Solomon's seals, or polygonatums, from China, Japan, Taiwan, Nepal and Sikkim unspiral from their early growth, and dozens of types of hellebore have just passed their prime. Throughout the garden, hydrangeas and viburnums are beginning to dispense their leaves; Stachyurus and Edgeworthia, winter-flowering shrubs from Asia, are leafing out. On some loops of the garden trail, where a Cardiocrinum giganteum thrusts its antediluvian seedpod six feet into the air, you almost expect to see a dinosaur wander past. Bud-break has stirred among an orderly chaos of growth-forms.
The man behind this collection of plants is Daniel Hinkley, a 45-year-old native of northern Michigan who has come to be regarded as one of the pre-eminent plant explorers in the world. Hinkley is the co-owner and chief plantsman of Heronswood Nursery, started in 1987, which lies within the visual domain of the Olympic Mountains across Puget Sound from Seattle. Heronswood is Hinkley's personal garden, his trial garden and a two-and-a-half-acre commercial nursery rolled in one. It's also Hinkley's home, which he shares with his partner, Robert Jones, an architect who is to the mailing list, the account books and the commercial operations at Heronswood what Hinkley is to the plants. 
 Here are more than 9,500 plants sprung from seed gathered all over the world. Most are numbered and listed in a loose-leaf binder that Hinkley calls the Big Bang, a compilation of plants already for sale and those that someday will be. The binder listing current inventory is called the Grand Mal. To most gardeners, the plants on these lists would be unfamiliar. Instead of the classic Hosta "Frances Williams," for instance, there is Hosta kiyosumiensis, which Hinkley collected from Mount Kiyosume in Japan's Chiba Prefecture in 1995. Instead of hybridized Asiatic and Oriental lilies, there is Lilium nanum, collected by Hinkley during a joint expedition to the Himalayas in 1995. Instead of a Norway maple or a David Austin rose, there is Acer rufinerve, a striped-bark maple he gathered in central Japan in 1997, and a rose of as yet undetermined species collected from an altitude of 10,800 feet in China's Yunnan province in 1996.
From this garden each year also comes the Heronswood catalogue, a major literary artifact in the world of gardening ephemera. Printed solidly in small type, it begins with Hinkley's wry musings on the imperfect art of running a mail-order nursery and ends 300 pages and some 2,500 plants later. The catalogue is a saga of botanical excitement and a chronicle of adjectival fatigue, the fate of a man driven to travel the world searching for remarkable plants and then doomed to write a terse, descriptive paragraph about one $6 or $8 clone after another, beginning with Abies balsamea "Nana" in the "Conifers" section and ending with the New Zealand sedge Uncinia unciniata, the final plant in the section on grasses.
Though it advertises nowhere and admits visitors only by appointment, Heronswood Nursery mailed 35,000 copies of the 1999 catalogue, and subscription requests are currently arriving at the rate of 100 a week. At $8 for a two-year subscription, the catalogue just pays for itself, unless you count the cost of Hinkley's writing time, in which case it is grossly underpriced. Subscribers pleasantly lost among Hinkley's paragraphs can be forgiven for wondering whether the nursery exists to justify the catalogue, or vice versa. Still, appealing to a newly adventurous generation of gardeners, Heronswood was an almost instant success. In 1993, the year after it incorporated, it had a gross income of $220,000. In 1998, it was five times larger, $1,100,000. These days, as Robert Jones says, he and Hinkley are trying to choose their limits, trying to let Hinkley's interests, rather than mere economic growth, continue to shape their offerings.
Plant introduction has traditionally been one of the reasons public agencies, public gardens and university arboretums -- like the United States Department of Agriculture, the New York Botanical Garden and the Arnold Arboretum at Harvard University -- have mounted collecting expeditions. But such institutions, as even they sometimes admit, usually do a far better job of collecting and studying plants than they do releasing them to the public. There is a historic rivalry between the public gardens and commercial nurseries like Heronswood, which dates to well before the days when the legendary plant hunter Ernest Henry Wilson combed turn-of-the-century China first for Veitch's nursery and then for the Arnold Arboretum. It's a rivalry, as the academics would put it, between science and mere trade or, as the tradesmen might put it, between exclusivity and openness. But these days, in fact, many public gardens and arboretums buy directly from Hinkley, sometimes taking a share in his plant-collecting expeditions, which entitles them to a portion of the seeds Hinkley gathers. "They're some of my best customers," he says.
Mid-April is the peak of the spring plant-shipping season at Heronswood, where overworked staff members try to meet the florid expectations of gardeners by selling them plants that are not only garden-worthy but that also carry, for many customers, an echo of the exotic places where Hinkley has collected -- Nepal, Sikkim, China, Japan, Korea, Tasmania, Mexico and Chile. The nursery office, an attractive prairie farmhouse of sorts, is surrounded by open shade-canopies sheltering tables crowded with flats, each marked with a customer's name and shipping date.
Hinkley's Michigan drawl crackles over a walkie-talkie clipped to a plant-packer's belt. Concealed somewhere in the woodland garden, he is the ghost in this botanic machine, enjoying a 10-day respite from a busy spring speaking schedule and preparing for a collecting trip to Japan. A path leads into the benign enveloping shade characteristic of the Northwest woods. The light falling on the mounded garden beds seems detached from its source, and what it illuminates has a freshness that is an attribute of the early season and of the vegetation itself. A hundred yards down the path, Hinkley works in mottled shade helping a new crew member shovel steer manure from a garden cart onto a planting site. No matter how exotic his expeditions may be, this is the end point of every collecting trip -- making a hole in the ground, sprinkling a little 20-20-20 fertilizer in it and grubbing the earth back into place by hand around the stem of a newly propagated plant.
Hinkley speaks quietly, slowly, but there is a sense of haste about him, the result of living in what he calls "a perfect madness of plants," a garden that needs to be brought into peak condition within the next few weeks. "At this point it feels like it's moving day," he says. "But as long as I keep bringing new plants into trial, it's always going to be like this. I get tired of one plant, or it's just not doing for me, so I get rid of it and start over again. But every time you do that you want to rejuvenate the soil, and to do that you've got to move another plant." Hinkley kneels on the ground, chopping at the soil with a border spade and looking up from time to time as he talks. He is direct and delicate at the same time, handling plants with none of the hesitation of the amateur gardener. He overflows with affection for the garden he has made, and yet his criticism of each individual plant-form -- a kind of veiled self-criticism in fact -- is unsparing.
Hinkley is bearded and balding, and he wears wide suspenders over a T-shirt from the J.C. Raulston Arboretum at North Carolina State University. Raulston, who died at 56 in a car accident three years ago, was one of Hinkley's mentors and a widely respected emblem of intellectual and horticultural generosity. Hinkley has dedicated his next book, "The Explorer's Garden," which Timber Press will publish in the fall, to Raulston and to Gerald Straley of the University of British Columbia, another gardening mentor who died in his 50's. "J.C.'s everywhere in this garden," Hinkley said. "Every day, I could take out a plant that he gave me, and I would never run out of plants. He knew, he sensed what a good plant was."
To sense what a good plant is -- to recognize it in the wild and then confirm it in his own garden -- is the essence of Hinkley's work. At Heronswood, there are really three different kinds of garden and, hence, of garden-worthiness. Among the greenhouses, for instance, there is the denatured, rationalized garden, which consists of plants grouped by size and species -- garden-worthy, in Hinkley's judgment, but also able to withstand shipping. In the woodland garden, tested and marketed varieties of plants compete with untested kin. The search here is for better form, greater hardiness, a distinctive virtue -- variegation or a more upright or prostrate habit -- or simply for the illumination, vital to Hinkley's task, that comes from growing many related species in proximity to each other. "For me," Hinkley says, "it makes a more complete, more understandable portrait of plants if I get the opportunity to grow many different relatives together."
And then there is the private garden surrounding the house, which is set at the back of the property. This is a place where Hinkley has tried to set aside at least some of the cultural limitations that frame our sense of what makes a garden. It is a subject he understands very well. "We have all this Lutheran guilt," he says. "We all moved west from the Midwest where we couldn't have winter gardens, and so our gardens in Seattle and Portland and Vancouver are amazingly timid as far as what our climate can actually do." But there is no timidity in this garden. What takes it beyond timidity isn't massed plantings or vibrant color or expansive scale or even mere exoticism. It is Hinkley's subtle reliance on the globally diverse forms of individual plants. Each plant, grown well, reveals itself and reveals something, too, about its neighbor. What creeps grows next to what climbs. The fastigiate and the pendulous conspire. Bark peels, thorns protrude, vines finger their way across an arbor, and what unites it all, what makes these plants garden-worthy, is the interest they bestow upon each other.
There are few explicit canons for deciding what makes a plant garden-worthy, but one of them -- a base line below the realm of the esthetic -- is lack of ecological invasiveness. Most gardeners are familiar with species that tend to be invasive in the garden, like Ajuga reptans, sometimes called carpet bugle. But what haunts Hinkley is the thought of plants that can break loose from cultivation and run rampant across the landscape -- purple loosestrife, kudzu, tamarisk, honeysuckle. "My greatest concern," he says, "is the introduction of a bad plant."
To help prevent that, Hinkley has hired Sarah Reichard as a consultant. Reichard, an ecologist at the University of Washington's Center for Urban Horticulture and a founder of Washington's Native Plant Society, began to wonder while collecting seed in South America as a graduate student whether any of those plants would prove invasive in the Pacific Northwest. She has constructed a model -- a decision tree, based on a plant's observed characteristics, which asks questions about how quickly the species reproduces and whether it belongs to a family or genus already strongly invasive in North America -- that indicates whether a plant is likely to become invasive.
On the burn pile at Heronswood lay one of the results of Reichard's work. There, atop other horticultural debris, was Ligustrum delavayanum, a species of privet named after the French priest and botanist Jean Marie Delavay, who collected plants in China in the late 19th century. This ligustrum bore fruit in Hinkley's garden for the first time in October, and it caught the attention of Roy Lancaster, the English dean of plant explorers, who was visiting Heronswood at the time. "He said he'd never seen a more beautiful form of it," Hinkley told me. "But it's a broad-leafed evergreen, and those do really well in the Northwest. I looked at it all winter long and battled with it in my conscience. You've probably seen what Ligustrum sinense has done in the Southeast. It's everywhere. Finally we had Sarah run it through her model, and she said, Reject."
Invasiveness is a hot issue, and it inspires a botanical xenophobia, a fear that just because a plant is exotic -- i.e., non-native -- it's inevitably invasive or otherwise harmful to the suite of native plants, changing the balance of nitrogen in the soil, for instance, or causing the water table to dip below the roots of native plants. But in horticulture, as in agriculture, the distinction between exotic and native has been blurred by the ancient, extensive exchange of plants for their economic or ornamental value. Because plant material -- seeds, cuttings, fruits -- moves as readily as humans do, human plant collecting, like the invention of agriculture, predates history itself. Gardening may be a way of enclosing a distinctive botanical world -- separating the cultivated from the uncultivated -- but few gardeners have ever restricted themselves to growing only native plants. The literature of gardening is underwritten by the literature of plant trafficking -- Robert Fortune, Joseph Hooker, Joseph Banks, Armand David, Ernest Henry Wilson and a host of predecessors traversed temperate Asia searching for plants of botanical and horticultural interest. Their motto, and Hinkley's as well, might be the words of William Bartram, who explored America in the late 18th century, when it was still the gardening world's China. "Let us advance to the spot in which nature has seated them," Bartram wrote of the plants he sought.
If there's an ecological argument to be made against plant collecting, there are many to be made for it. The term itself is a misnomer. Hinkley does not collect plants. As he notes in the Heronswood catalogue, "Our wild collections are primarily of seed, which we collect in a very conservative manner." This means collecting only when there is abundant seed, adhering to the terms of local permits and customs and making sure the seed is carefully prepared to meet U.S.D.A. restrictions (free of any potentially contaminating soil, insects and so on). The image of ship decks full of Wardian cases -- the enclosed, portable greenhouses that made the 19th-century boom in plant hunting possible -- has been replaced by the image of tired botanists cleaning seeds for U.S.D.A. inspection under less-than-ideal conditions. "It isn't necessarily a fun thing to do," Hinkley says, remembering a trip to Nepal, "especially when you're doing it in a tent at night and it's raining cats and dogs outside and the only light is a headlamp."
Gathering seed from wild plant populations is also a means of preserving genetic diversity in the face of widespread environmental degradation. In Nepal, for instance, a grazing yak-cow hybrid, the dzo, has had a grave impact on alpine plant communities. In China, deforestation is proceeding at a rate that far outstrips the ability of Chinese and foreign botanists to inventory and collect seeds from endangered plants. Even in a gardening culture as traditional as Japan's, there's a tendency to overlook native species in favor of the exotic -- which in the case of Japan means American species. After searching Shikoku Island in 1997 for a wild Japanese hydrangea called Hydrangea sikokiana, Hinkley began scouting Japanese nurseries, hoping to find the plant in cultivation. "We thought we'd see it from a distance in every single nursery, and we'd go up to it and it was our native Hydrangea quercifolia. No one we talked to had even heard of sikokiana. They had no interest in growing it because they had this very exotic, much, much more exciting hydrangea from America." The exotic sikokiana is now growing at Heronswood, not far up the woodland path from the native quercifolia.
But the ultimate rationale for Hinkley's work is the garden itself. He shapes his expeditions by looking for climates similar to that of the Pacific Northwest, traveling to places where plants show similar hardiness because of elevation or latitude, and are accustomed to similar rainfall patterns. Sometimes a collecting trip broadens the gene pool for a plant that has already been collected, like Paris polyphylla, a Nepalese trillium relative Hinkley had grown at Heronswood for a decade but was the only clone in North America. Often a trip leads to a new understanding of how, as Hinkley puts it, a plant "wants" to grow. It can also be a means of expanding the idea of the garden philosophically and esthetically by allowing Hinkley to see cultivated species and their wild near kin in their native habitat. Perhaps, Hinkley says, re-collecting seed "will bring additional hardiness or additional insect or disease resistance, so I never pass up a plant if it's in seed, if indeed I think it's a plant that deserves to be in cultivation."
Hinkley's garden feels like a glimpse of another creation, a place where the monoculture of the mind is disturbed by a willingness to push beyond the familiar botanical forms into a realm of pleasing visual discomfort. Walking along the woodland trails at Heronswood, Hinkley points out some of the plants he admires -- like Podophyllum delavayi, a May apple from Sichuan, which, he says, "deserves to be worshiped" -- and some of the plants he thinks will become important to American gardeners in the years ahead, not only among "plant nerds," as he puts it, but also among gardeners generally. He points out a group called the woodland lilies -- Smilacinas, Polygonatums, Uvularias, Disporums and Disporopsis.
But above all he points out Hepatica -- Hepatica acutiloba, an American native and Hepatica maxima, which grows only on one island in the Japan Sea, Hepatica in a single clone, in many clones, in enough clones one day to sell. To a casual visitor, these are perplexing plants, modest, growing in low mounds with rather formal, old-fashioned leaves and small flowers, not half as striking as the arisaemas and trilliums that are rioting in the woodland. But besides being a "simply good" plant, Hepatica maxima, for one, is also very rare in cultivation, which makes its goodness no longer simple. It goes about its business in a quiet corner of the garden, reaffirming a strange premise of life itself, for being there at all is part of its beauty.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1094 words

HEADLINE: Streetscapes /The Gardiner-Tyler House, West New Brighton, Staten Island;
Where a President's Widow Backed the Confederacy

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
DURING the Civil War, the elegant Greek revival Gardiner-Tyler House, in West New Brighton, Staten Island, sheltered one of New York's most conspicuous rebel sympathizers, Julia Gardiner Tyler, widow of President John Tyler. When she was not involved in pro-Confederate activities, she was busy trying to reunite her family, scattered by the war. Now another family is reuniting in this grand temple-fronted house, as a new addition brings together three generations under one roof.
 Now on a small plot surrounded by modest houses, the Gardiner-Tyler house was built around 1837 as a much larger country estate, apparently by an Eliza Racey, about whom little is known.
The main entrance -- under the temple front -- faces south across a wide valley, and the house is of simple plan, with a front to back center hall. 
 The precisely carved Corinthian capitals on the four double-height columns seem more sophisticated than the heavy scrolled brackets that connect the portico to the house, but it is difficult to tell if they are later alterations -- the earliest good photographs of the house are from the turn of the century.
Early occupancy of the house is sketchy, but Robert Seager's 1963 book, "And Tyler Too," says that, according to Gardiner and Tyler family correspondence, Juliana Gardiner, Julia Gardiner Tyler's mother, bought the house in 1852.
 Juliana Gardiner was the widow of David Gardiner -- a member of the Long Island family that owned Gardiner's Island. Gardiner had died in February 1844 after a cannon exploded during testing on a ship in the Potomac River. President Tyler had also been aboard.
Already friendly with the Gardiner family, Tyler became even more friendly with Julia and married her in New York City in June 1844.
Tyler had been elected Vice President in 1840 under William Henry Harrison and became President in April 1841 when Harrison died after only a month in office. Weakened in a dispute over tariff bills with his own Whig Party, Tyler withdrew from the 1844 presidential election.
 The Tylers lived at their James River estate, Sherwood Forest, in Virginia. After 1852, Juliana Gardiner lived in the Staten Island house, called Castleton Hill. Tyler was generally identified with pro-slavery, pro-Southern policies -- he had about 70 slaves at Sherwood Forest.
In 1853 The New York Herald and other papers carried an article by Julia Tyler defending slavery, which aroused much comment. She said that the Southern slave "lives sumptuously" compared to workers in modern industrial economies. She was also an intimate of Jefferson Davis and his wife, Varina.
 AT least as early as 1857 Julia and John Tyler visited Juliana Gardiner at Staten Island, and when the former President died in 1862, Julia crossed Civil War battle lines to live at the Staten Island estate, despite her own Southern sympathies.
On Staten Island, Julia Tyler worked for the release of Southern prisoners, for the relief of occupied Southern cities and for various peace efforts.
 Julia Tyler went back and forth to her Virginia estate with a regularity that Northern patriots found suspicious. Her Southern sympathies brought conflict to the house, where she often violently quarreled with her uncle, David Lyon Gardiner, who was finally sent away by Juliana Gardiner, his sister.
During this time Julia Tyler was also trying to keep up Sherwood Forest, look after other children in the family, and come up with a way to live in the safety of her mother's house while safeguarding her teen-age sons, David and John, who were in military service -- on the Confederate side.
 In April 1865, just hours after Lincoln's assassination, three Staten Islanders forced their way into the house to retrieve and destroy what one claimed in a letter in The New York Herald was a Confederate flag, describing Julia Tyler as the "widow of the deceased rebel ex-President."
In a letter to The New York Mail, Julia Tyler denounced the "outrage committed at my house" and said the flag was only an ornamental bunting, without political significance.
 A June 1, 1865, census recorded Julia Tyler in the house with five of her children, as well as a tutor, an Irish-born coachman and two English-born servants. Juliana Gardiner died in 1868, and Julia got the Staten Island house after a venomous court fight with David Lyon Gardiner.
 Her lawyer in the litigation, William M. Evarts, was also a family friend and lent her money, taking the house as security. Julia Tyler left New York in 1871 for Washington and then Virginia, and later in the decade Evarts, who was also prominent in politics, took ownership of the house, although it is not clear if he lived there.
 IN the 1880's and 1890's the house was occupied by Douglas M. A. Brown, a wallpaper manufacturer, and in 1898 the land was divided into 157 building lots styled as "Tyler Park" in anticipation of a public auction to be accompanied by music and lunch. Included in the sale was to be the "fine house" occupied "by President Tyler," although it appears he was never more than an intermittent seasonal guest.
 After 1900 the house and most of the lots were purchased by Thaddeus J. Carlin; the 1920 census shows him in occupancy with an English servant and his 15-year-old son, Arthur. Arthur Carlin's granddaughter, Arlene Gillen McGinley, says that when her mother, Arlene Carlin, married Arthur Gillen, "the house was so large they asked the Gillens to move in with them."
The family gradually sold off the surrounding lots, and now the grand house is surrounded by low ranch houses, like Gulliver encircled by Lilliputians.
 Mrs. McGinley moved out herself when she married Terrance McGinley in 1977, but now that Mr. and Mrs. Gillen are aging, she and Mr. McGinley have purchased the Gardiner-Tyler house from them and are adding a side wing in complementary style, designed by the architect Timothy Boyland, working with the preservation consultant Mary Dierickx. Mrs. McGinley, her husband and their three children are planning to move in next month.
 The new wing will be accessible for people with disabilities, to make living there easier for her parents, and will also permit her older brother, Kevin, to visit more frequently -- he has multiple sclerosis and lives in a nursing home.
"When people hear I'm moving into that house they say, 'My gosh, that's a mansion,' " and then I have to tell them I grew up in it," Mrs. McGinley says. "I'm the fourth generation here, and my children, God willing, will live here in the future also."

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 12; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 3895 words

HEADLINE: Hopes and Fears of the Class of '99

 BODY:
In Westchester, the class of '99 has many faces. Here is what some of its members had to say when interviewed by Elsa Brenner.
 
Looking for a Role In Local Politics
 
WHO -- Jeremy Weinberg, 17, New Rochelle High School. 

ACHIEVEMENTS -- President of the school's chapter of the National Honor Society, member of high school's model congress, writer of poetry for the school literary publication Opus.
 
AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to enroll at Cornell University and major in policy analysis and management. I want to study government, economics and sociology with the goal of one day playing an active role in local politics."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was the kinship I developed with my classmates and, perhaps more important, my teachers. Shared interests and a collective desire to excel transformed many of my classrooms into settings that resembled a family home more than a place of learning. It was an amazing experience to learn and grow with a group of others."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was having to see peers of mine who lacked the desire and motivation to care about what they were doing. It was difficult for me to accept that some people cannot be made to take pride in achieving in the classroom. I always hate to see people who have no passion for anything."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "What surprised me the most in my high school experience would probably have to be my school's reaction to the verdict in the O. J. Simpson trial. Many people expected that a school as ethnically diverse as New Rochelle High School would erupt at the climax of a racially charged event like that trial. However, there was a great amount of peace after the verdict was announced. It was quite a pleasant surprise."
 
WHAT IF? -- "If I could change anything about high schools, I would make them more of a partnership between faculty, students and parents. I think that the key to success is a desire to succeed. The only way to create that desire is to establish an environment where all three of these important links feel a sense of community and a shared goal of creating a higher level of education. If parents, teachers and students work together, each can feel as if they can influence the direction that their community's education system is moving. Involvement on the local level makes all the difference. In high schools around the country, I would like to see teachers making more of an effort to establish a relationship with students and their parents outside of school. A little time and a small amount of caring on the part of educators could improve schools across America."
 
GOOD ADVICE -- "The piece of advice that is freshest in my head at the moment is one given to me at my Senior Awards Ceremony by my advanced placement government teacher, Deborah Minchin. She said, 'Never confuse who you are with the awards you have won.' "
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "The thing that excites me the most about the future is the chance I will have to run for public office and put my ideas into practice."

 THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I am scared the most by the prospect of not being able to achieve the level of success of my father's generation. My generation has caught on to the prospect of the American Dream hook, line and sinker. We look at our parents and envy the innocent America in which they were raised. We like to think that our hard work will lead to success, but we fear that the wonderful opportunities our parents had will not be there when we grow older. I think that every generation would have the same fears at this age. However, my generation has seen our parents achieve a much greater level of financial success in America than their parents did. The bar has been raised for the children of the 90's and they fear that at some point the opportunities others had in the past will disappear in front of their faces."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I see my life at 30 being difficult but rewarding. As much as I fear that the American and global economies will not be as friendly to me as they were to my parents, I still believe that if you work hard enough, then opportunity will always come your way. At 30, I see myself working as hard as I am now to insure that opportunities will always be at my disposal."
 
Overcoming the past To Live the Present
 
WHO -- Luis Ortiz, 21, Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services class at Rye Neck High school.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Returned to complete his education after a shooting that left him in a wheelchair; winner of the Overcoming the Odds Award given by the Board of Cooperative Educational Services.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to go to United Cerebral Palsy to train with computers in order to get a paying job. I need training on a computer because that will be the main tool I will use when I start to work."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of the Boces program was the fact that I had teachers who have helped me a lot. They really care about me and have helped me get the things I really needed."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst thing about school was in my old one in the Bronx. Kids would bring guns and other weapons to school. The school was more like a jail because of the metal detectors and guards in the building. They were needed in the school, but that made it feel like a prison."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise I ever had during high school was when I received the Overcoming the Odds Award last month. It was such an honor and I was very surprised when I found out I was one of the winners. One of the prizes is going to be a laptop computer, which I really need."
 
WHAT IF? -- "If I could change one thing in all the high schools, I would bring in more computers for the students to use. Technology is changing the world, and all kids need to know how to use computers. I know it is the main thing I need to know."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice anyone had ever given me is not to do drugs. Unfortunately, I didn't listen to my mother and now I am in a wheelchair. I got involved with a bad crowd and it has left me a quadriplegic."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "Right now I can't really think about the future. I have to concentrate on right now."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "The future scares me because I don't know what it will be like. I don't know how it will be for me. It really does scare me!"
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I don't want to think about when I turn 30. I don't look that far ahead. I only think about right now."
 
A Pursuit of Dance and Choreography
 
WHO -- Elizabeth Anne Gill, 18, Yorktown High School.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Student council member; choreographed and performed in "Fiddler on the the Roof" and "West Side Story," and a member of Students Against Drunk Driving.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I will be attending the Alvin Ailey/Fordham University Bachelor of Fine Arts program in dance at Lincoln Center."

THE BEST AND WORST -- "The best and worst parts of high school have both come from watching me and my fellow students change in our most formative years. Growing as a person and watching my friends develop into people whom I greatly admire has been extremely satisfying. On the other hand, watching some old friends distance themselves and develop into strangers was one of the worst feelings in the world."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "Looking back at high school I was most surprised at how involved I became in the intricate workings of the school. When I first entered high school I was content to remain isolated in my studies and uninvolved in the various organizations. Over the years, I have realized that becoming a part of my high school and knowing that I will leave some bit of myself behind have become surprisingly important to me."

WHAT IF? -- "High schools need to examine the delicate relationships that can be built between teachers and students when there is a mutual sharing of knowledge. Unfortunately, many students are lost in school because they don't feel involved in their education. When students are given the opportunity to influence their teachers, just as teachers hope to influence students, then the students value the education they receive."

GOOD ADVICE -- " Some of the best advice that I have received came from my English teacher, Natalie Farina. She said to our class one day: 'Become observers of the world. Learn to really see what is happening around you and how it relates to the society around it.' I feel that this advice is especially poignant when applied to high school. Because high school students are just beginning to discover who they are, they sometimes try to project an image of how they'd like to be seen. I have found that in high school it is especially important to distinguish between the qualities you see on the surface and those that are true to someone's real self."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am both excited and scared about the responsibility that I will have in the future. Most of the time I can't wait to be in New York City, getting myself around and pursuing dance. However, I am also scared when I realize that only I will be able to push myself. This responsibility means that my successes and failures will be completely my own."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS: -- "When my parents were preparing themselves for college, the Vietnam War was heating up and both feared the escalation of the war as well the possibility of losing their friends who might be sent over to fight. Since the present U.S. conflicts have not produced a draft, I have been lucky enough to live without extreme fear of war. My fears are more personal. I worry about not being a success in my own eyes. I worry about the rejection that comes with pursuing a career in such a competitive field as dance. My parents did not have the same career dreams when they were my age. I dream of being a respected dancer-choreographer."

LIFE AT 30 -- "I hope that when I am 30 years old, I will have already started establishing myself within the artistic community. I would like to have had substantial experience with dance companies by then and opportunities to display my own choreography."
 
The Goal: Opening own Florist Shop
 
WHO -- Danielle Arco, 18, Westlakes High School in Thornwood.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Majored in horticulture through a program offered by the Southern Westchester Board of Cooperative Educational Services, receptionist in a veterinary hospital.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "My plans after high school are to get a job working with a florist and to train in that field so I can open up my own shop someday."

THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was the happy memories, the friendships and my boyfriend, Sal."

THE WORST -- "The worst part was seeing some friends come and go, and losing them."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "Looking back, the biggest surprise for me was how fast it all went by. You don't realize at the time how fast it will all be over."

WHAT IF? -- "If I could change one thing in high schools, it would be to make people set aside their differences and get along, and not belong to cliques where some people are left out because they don't dress a certain way. It didn't bother me personally so much, but I have seen many kids hurt because they weren't included."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my father, who always encouraged me to try new things and not to get down on myself. He helped me realize that I wanted to study horticulture and flowers."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "When I look ahead, the thing that excites me the most is the opportunity I will have to do things for myself, to be responsible for myself."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me is not knowing what to expect. Maybe it won't turn out the way I wish it will. Everyone always says that life is easy only when you're young."

LIFE AT 30 -- "Hopefully at 30, I will be happily married, have two children and own a flower shop."
 
A Lifelong Desire: Becoming a Lawyer
 
WHO -- Louise Kellie Beach, 18, Peekskill High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Member of National Honor Society, student council president, intern in a law office.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "My post high school plans are to attend Hofstra University and major in English, minor in science and go on to law school, ultimately practicing law."

THE BEST -- "I enjoyed being involved in many of the extracurricular activities: National Honor Society, student council, community service, cheerleading, Black Culture Club."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of my high school years was the preparation and taking of the Scholastic Achievement Test."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "I was surprised to find that the work load was not as overwhelming as I had been told."
 
WHAT IF -- "I would change the scheduling process because not all, but many, students take classes just to simply get by and receive a passing grade. I feel that each student should be challenged with a rigorous schedule to prepare them for what college life offers, because after all, high school is a stepping stone leading to college."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I received was from my grandmother, who instilled in me from a very early age that there is nothing too hard for me and that obstacles are meant to be overcome."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "What excites me the most about the future is achieving my lifelong dream. From a young age I knew my desired career goal -- a corporate lawyer. To achieve this goal would be a dream come true not only for me but for my parents also."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I would have to say that what scares me the most are the challenges associated with college life -- being in large classroom settings, getting along with a roommate and navigating my way around campus."

LIFE AT 30 -- "At the age of 30, I will be a successful corporate lawyer, married and raising a family."
 
For the Future, Being Happy is the Goal
 
WHO -- Andrew Goldberg, 18, Hastings-on-Hudson High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Class valedictorian, National Merit scholar, student government participant, guitar player.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to study mathematics and computer science at Amherst College in Amherst, Mass."

THE BEST -- "Coming from a small high school, I'd say the best part of my high school experience was the close interaction between students and teachers. In a small school, there are so many opportunities available for everyone."
 
THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was the occasional stress and worrying that accompanied all of my hard work. It was hard to balance everything all the time, and sometimes my self-imposed pressure was a little too strong."
 
THE UNEXPECTED -- "My biggest surprise looking back would have to be the fact that I was able to maintain my academic performance while being busy with several clubs and activities and many other obligations. I always tried to manage my time well to make sure this was possible."

WHAT IF -- "If I could change any one thing in high schools, I would make it possible for all students to have all the opportunities they desire. Some students attend public schools which lack money and many of the resources that are available to students in other areas of the country. All students should be able to explore and branch out in many directions so that they find their niche."

GOOD ADVICE -- "I can't think of specific advice that anyone has given me, but my parents have always taught me to work toward and try to surpass my potential."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am most excited about going to college this fall. After growing up in such a small village, my classmates and I know each other almost too well, and it will be a great opportunity to begin again in college with an empty canvas."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me the most about the future and college is not being able to form a close-knit group of friends like I have in high school now. I bet my dreams and fears are rather similar to those of my parents when they were my age because they are fairly natural feelings. The future can be intimidating, and to have worries is completely normal."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I don't really know what I'll be like when I'm 30. I could go through college and graduate school and wind up in a computer-related career, while I could also find new direction at college and end up somewhere totally different. Whatever I do, though, I would like to have a family and be happy when I'm 30. As long as you're happy, the rest doesn't really matter."
 
'I've Become a Role Model for Other Kids'
 
WHO -- Jerome Matthews, 18, Port Chester High School.
 
ACHIEVEMENTS -- Co-captain of the basketball team. (Said he "learned in high school to play a sport rather than let it play him.")

AFTER GRADUATION -- "I plan to attend Delhi Junior College in Delhi, N.Y."
 
THE BEST -- "The best part of high school was recovering from my downfalls and being in the wrong crowd. I've become a role model for other kids."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was going through some obstacles. I was cutting classes and bringing myself down. I was failing my courses, and I was left out of sports for a while."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise was turning myself around academically and otherwise and finally being able to graduate with my class. I live in a low-cost housing project in Port Chester, and Earl Johnson, another basketball player who lived in my building and now attends Rutgers, encouraged me to bring up my grades."
 
WHAT IF -- "If there was one thing I could change, it would be to set up a mentor system for kids. It's important for us to have someone to look up to."

GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my grandmother and mother, who sat me down and said: "Jerome, you have to play basketball. Don't let it play you. Don't forget your studies because you have to have something to fall back on."
 
THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "The thing that excites me most about the future is that I am one of the first people in my family who is going to college. A lot of the younger kids are looking up to me."
 
THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me is that I'll be three or four hours away from my family. What if there are problems?"
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "By the time I'm 30, I hope I am well educated and have an associate's degree, a bachelor's degree and a master's degree -- and a nice wife and two kids and a home like I did not have."
 
A Lesson Learned: 'Never Give Up'
 
WHO -- Christopher C. Ellis, 17, Archbishop Stepinac High School.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Member of the track team, Salutatorian of graduating class, winner of the William Plunkett Award given annually to a student who has excelled academically, given exceptional service to the school and served as a role model of values.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "After caddying this summer at a golf club, I will attend Syracuse University to study communications and journalism."

THE BEST -- "The best part of high school and going from a small parochial school in Yonkers to a larger school was meeting a lot of new people, making new friends and learning from new teachers."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was having to travel so far by train and bus from my home in Yonkers to White Plains."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "I was suprised at how different high school was from grammar school and how independent I was able to be."

WHAT IF -- "If I could change something in high schools, it would be to have more teachers get more involved with students. I would like to see students having more of a say in the classroom and more opportunities to interact. Classroom teaching should not be just about straight lectures."
 
GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice I ever received was from my parents who told me never to give up, even when I hit slumps either in sports or with my school work."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "I am most excited about the new independence I will experience living at college, and the chance I'll have to focus in more on a particular subject like journalism."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "I am most uncertain about what the future holds -- both in college and the job market."

LIFE At 30 -- "I want to be successful -- to have a good job, even if I am not the highest paid person -- and to have a wife who is a good person. I want to live an honest, straight life and be happy. Some people see success as making millions of dollars or driving the best car, but I don't know if that necessarily makes someone emotionally happy. I want to be settled by 30 and not stressed out."
 
First Woman To Be President, Perhaps?
 
WHO -- Erika Zauner, 17, Hackley School, Tarrytown.

ACHIEVEMENTS -- Voted most valuable player for the varsity field hockey team, editor of The Vision, the school's literary magazine.

AFTER GRADUATION -- "Before attending Princeton University in the fall, I will work for part of the summer as a volunteer for a cardio-thoracic surgeon at Cornell Medical Center in New York City. I am also working as a waitress for several weeks in Spring Lake, N.J., and will attend field hockey camp for two weeks."

THE BEST -- "The highlight of high school was working with teachers and coaches who love what they are doing and inspire students to excel at and enjoy a subject or activity."

THE WORST -- "The worst part of high school was the cliques. Most kids are so insecure in high school and super-conscious of other people's perceptions of them, which fosters the formation of cliques."

THE UNEXPECTED -- "The biggest surprise for me in my private high school, as a student coming from public school, was the extraordinary commitment of so many teachers to a positive learning experience."
GOOD ADVICE -- "The best advice ever given to me was from my grandmother, who often says, 'If you enjoy the simple pleasures in life, you will always be a happy person.' This advice has helped me to appreciate little things every day, like an intimate conversation with my sister or the sunset on my drive home from school."

THE FUTURE, HOPES -- "What excites me most about the future are the many opportunities created by rapid advancements in the fields of technology and science and genetics. I learned a great deal about genetic disorders in a genetics tutorial I took this year and the thought of helping people overcome a disorder or sickness, such as breast cancer, by manipulating their genes is amazing and very promising."

THE FUTURE, FEARS -- "What scares me the most? Although the thriving field of genetic research has many positives, the work done to manipulate genes to clone people or the possibility of altering the genetic code of fetuses so parents can choose the traits they want their child to possess is very scary. While the field of genetics possesses promising potential in helping people overcome illnesses or disorders, daunting images of a "Brave New World" society come to mind when thinking of the consequences of abusing genetics."
 
LIFE AT 30 -- "I hope by age 30 to be a pediatrician or pediatric surgeon. However, I might go to Princeton and find that I'm intrigued by politics, who knows? Maybe I'll end up being a lawyer or a teacher or even the first woman President."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 14; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 868 words

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
Looking to Put Fatherhood in Its Proper Place

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; E-mail address: liorder@nytimes.com

 BODY:
KING LEAR'S daughters didn't need a Father's Day to remember the old man. He was constantly in their thoughts. But, in 1925, Calvin Coolidge decided that fathers were no longer getting enough attention or respect. He proclaimed the national observance of Father's Day. Too late, of course: when we need a special day to remind us of something, it's already a lost cause.
Fathers need a special day more than most. They are in danger of being forgotten altogether, what with divorce, single motherhood and the fashion for artificial insemination. Despised as deadbeat dads, and ridiculed in endless television sitcoms as incompetent boobies who can't outwit a 5-year-old child, fathers are falling out of sight, and out of style. 
 Today's fathers cry out with Rodney Dangerfield, "I don't get no respect." Archie Bunker could bluster his way through life on the excuse that he earned the wages for the whole family. But women now earn as much as men in half of all American households. In many families, they earn more than their miserable spouses. So father is a junior partner now, and he has been introduced to the pleasures of domestic slavery.
Father is absent without leave from a third of all American families. Who let him get away? The social critic Barbara Ehrenreich points the finger of guilt at Hugh Hefner and his Playboy magazine, which, back in the 1950's, offered men a new deal. The Playboy philosophy divided men into two groups: husbands, who were despised as economic slaves, and "free men," who could spend all their incomes on toys and treats for themselves. It was, said Ms. Ehrenreich, a huge mistake to give men this choice. The weaker members of the sex -- just about all of them -- decided that having a good time was more appealing than the duties of family life.
Fatherhood is the least well-planned of all human activities. Young men dream of being wealthy lawyers or Wall Street brokers. Perhaps some still dream about being astronauts or explorers. But fatherhood is not on their agenda. They just don't see it coming. Attractive young women are one of the few things in America not to carry a large label: Warning, Keep Clear, Danger of Fatherhood. When he reads the personal ads, a young man gets almost no clue as to the risks he is running in this particular marketplace. "Beautiful intelligent female," "Tall, blue-eyed, fun-loving blonde" and "Love bomb," like most advertising, omit some important details. A child, up to the age of 22, now comes with a quarter-million dollar price tag, not including extras like post-graduate education, Camaros and bail bonds. If men really thought about all this ahead of time, the human race would die out in a single generation.
We need ways to make fatherhood more attractive. Just a single day in the year, with a few predictable gifts, is not enough of a reward. A tie is a kind of noose; a pair of socks is an insult. "How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is to have a thankless child," King Lear might have cried, confronted with yet another umbrella or electric screwdriver.
How do we get Dad back into the family picture? Some experts have suggested that we should bring back patriarchy. Men might be more keen on fatherhood if they could have some of the privileges that used to go with it, like not expressing their feelings. But we can't turn the clock back to Archie Bunker's time. Men have simply lost the knack, and the old-fashioned man is an endangered species. The last remnants of the breed -- loud, obnoxious, untidy fellows who can't even iron a skirt -- can be found hanging out in sports bars, dreaming about the days when John Wayne and Clint Eastwood ruled the world.
These last few macho men disturb the more disciplined men of suburbia, the way that outdoor cats upset the tranquility of indoor cats. Sooner or later, for the good of society, they will have to be rounded up, along with their trucks and their Harley Davidsons and taken to a reservation out west. This last refuge of old-fashioned masculinity could become a theme park, Testosterone Valley, a monument to the father we're glad we never had.
This suggests a foolproof scheme for the revival of fatherhood. Fathers who stick with the job should get mileage credits, just like airline travelers. Every day or evening at home would count for so many points, with a bonus for Parent-Teacher Association meetings, school plays and visits to the pediatrician.
The dedicated Dad would soon accumulate enough points to claim some modest prizes: an evening at the sports bar, a ride in a truck, a day out fishing. But the end of the rainbow, for the Dad who really stacked up the points, would be a special kind of sabbatical in the old-fashioned world of masculinity, out there in Testosterone Valley with the banished men of yesteryear. The prize would include a ritual burning of his suit and apron, the company of a meek and adoring wife (an actress) and quiet, obedient children (robots), lots of politically incorrect buddies and a special therapist with death-or-glory tattoos to put the suburban man out of touch with his feelings. But a week in Testosterone Valley would be the maximum. They might begin to enjoy it.
